description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Prince2® 2017 project management and prepare for the Axelos Prince2® 2017 Foundation examination accredited by PeopleCert.

We start with a downloadable introduction to the series.
descriptionMD:
In this series we explore the concepts of Prince2® 2017 project management and prepare for the Axelos Prince2® 2017 Foundation examination accredited by PeopleCert.

We start with a downloadable introduction to the series.
name: Prince2 2017 Foundation
subtitle: Introductory certification to Prince2 2017 project managment

episodes.description:
In this series we explore the concepts of Prince2® 2017 project management and prepare for the Axelos Prince2® 2017 Foundation examination accredited by PeopleCert.

We start with a downloadable introduction to the series.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.067
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:02.067 --> 00:00:09.122
[SOUND] Hi, I'm Joe Peacock with ITPRO TV.

3
00:00:09.122 --> 00:00:13.033
And welcome to your
PRINCE2 Foundation Series.

4
00:00:13.033 --> 00:00:16.574
In this particular series,
we are going to look at,

5
00:00:16.574 --> 00:00:20.851
well pretty much as it says on the can,
the Foundation 2.2.

6
00:00:20.851 --> 00:00:25.832
So what we're doing is we're covering
all of the terminology associated with

7
00:00:25.832 --> 00:00:26.940
PRINCE2.

8
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:30.290
We're looking at the life
cycle of a PRINCE2 project.

9
00:00:30.290 --> 00:00:33.730
We're also going to look at the themes and
the principles and

10
00:00:33.730 --> 00:00:38.160
the processes of the PRINCE2
project management methodology.

11
00:00:38.160 --> 00:00:43.980
And we're gonna prepare you for
the PeopleCert Foundation Accreditation,

12
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:46.020
with PRINCE2 of course.

13
00:00:46.020 --> 00:00:50.002
So, please join me in this
particular series and well,

14
00:00:50.002 --> 00:00:52.639
I hope to see you in our next episode.

15
00:00:52.639 --> 00:00:59.534
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: This episode answers the question “what is Prince2®?”, looking at the history of Prince2® and the justification of project management.
episodes.title: Intro to Prince2 Project Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:07.427
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host,
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:07.427 --> 00:00:08.358
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.358 --> 00:00:12.587
>> You're watching ITPro TV.
>> Greetings,

4
00:00:12.587 --> 00:00:16.190
everyone, and welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro TV.

5
00:00:16.190 --> 00:00:18.840
I'm your host, Justin Dennison,
and boy we have a treat for you.

6
00:00:18.840 --> 00:00:23.400
We're getting started with our
PRINCE2 Foundation 2017 series.

7
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:25.920
I was a little afraid I wasn't
gonna get all those words out.

8
00:00:25.920 --> 00:00:29.810
And in particular we're gonna be looking
at an intro to PRINCE2 project management.

9
00:00:29.810 --> 00:00:32.650
And here to help us along with that
very endeavor is Ms Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:35.330
How are you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, how are you, Justin?

11
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:36.791
>> I am doing fantastic.

12
00:00:36.791 --> 00:00:37.698
>> Now, PRINCE2,

13
00:00:37.698 --> 00:00:40.340
I've never actually heard of that before.

14
00:00:40.340 --> 00:00:43.782
What is it all about?
>> Okay, well, for a start,

15
00:00:43.782 --> 00:00:49.810
PRINCE2 is probably unknown to
you because of where you're from.

16
00:00:49.810 --> 00:00:53.170
No, and it's got nothing to do with
the mountains in the middle of nowhere,

17
00:00:53.170 --> 00:00:53.861
don't worry.

18
00:00:53.861 --> 00:00:58.710
But actually PRINCE2 is a project
management methodology that's actually

19
00:00:58.710 --> 00:01:04.470
being used more widely in Europe, and
in the UK, and in places like Australia.

20
00:01:04.470 --> 00:01:09.750
Over in North America it's not really
become as popular until fairly lately,

21
00:01:09.750 --> 00:01:11.210
to be perfectly honest.

22
00:01:11.210 --> 00:01:15.210
And here in the US, we tend to look
a project management methodology

23
00:01:15.210 --> 00:01:19.320
from the PMI, the Project Management
Institute's, sort of view point.

24
00:01:20.820 --> 00:01:27.080
There is, and we are trying to ensure
that there is, a synergy between the two.

25
00:01:27.080 --> 00:01:32.170
And the reason why you called
it PRINCE2 2017 is because,

26
00:01:32.170 --> 00:01:37.090
in 2017 PRINCE2 was updated,
and so, as I've said,

27
00:01:37.090 --> 00:01:41.282
we trying to ensure that we've got
that synergy between PMI and PRINCE2.

28
00:01:41.282 --> 00:01:46.060
But PRINCE2 is prevalent as the project
management methodology, as I've said,

29
00:01:46.060 --> 00:01:49.940
throughout Europe and throughout the UK,
and other places in the world.

30
00:01:49.940 --> 00:01:53.120
So it's not unusual for
you not to have heard of it but

31
00:01:53.120 --> 00:01:57.910
it is, as I said, very prevalent,
very popular in other parts of the world.

32
00:01:57.910 --> 00:02:01.376
So this is why we're actually
covering it here and now.

33
00:02:01.376 --> 00:02:06.565
It is completely accredited,
it is a certification that we expect

34
00:02:06.565 --> 00:02:12.230
all project managers to have certainly
within the UK and within Europe.

35
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:17.670
And so this is why I kinda wanted to take
a look at this in this particular series.

36
00:02:17.670 --> 00:02:22.433
And in this series we're gonna be looking
at the PRINCE2 foundation material,

37
00:02:22.433 --> 00:02:24.823
that's the introduction to PRINCE2.

38
00:02:24.823 --> 00:02:30.610
We also have another series
of PRINCE2 2017 practitioner.

39
00:02:30.610 --> 00:02:32.248
Now, I'm gonna warn you now,

40
00:02:32.248 --> 00:02:35.788
from here on outwards we're just
going to refer it to as PRINCE2.

41
00:02:35.788 --> 00:02:41.770
We're not going to give it the full title
of PRINCE2 2017, so don't try and work

42
00:02:41.770 --> 00:02:47.100
out how to say that mouthful all the time.
>> Well, [LAUGH] that definitely helps me,

43
00:02:47.100 --> 00:02:50.830
Jo, cuz I was like I'm getting winded
trying to get all these words in there.

44
00:02:50.830 --> 00:02:53.120
So from here on out we're
just gonna call it PRINCE2.

45
00:02:53.120 --> 00:02:54.405
>> We're just gonna call it PRINCE2

46
00:02:54.405 --> 00:02:55.020
from now.

47
00:02:55.020 --> 00:02:59.440
I mean, there are some differences between
the previous version of PRINCE2 and

48
00:02:59.440 --> 00:03:00.260
this version,

49
00:03:00.260 --> 00:03:03.810
but what we're going to do is we're
going to cover everything from scratch.

50
00:03:03.810 --> 00:03:05.890
This is not an update show.

51
00:03:05.890 --> 00:03:08.020
This is not a show where we're
going to look at the differences.

52
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:11.930
This is the show where we're going to
look at the entire PRINCE2 methodology.

53
00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:13.560
So we are going to start from scratch.

54
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:17.896
So the first question then
that I'm gonna ask Justin, but

55
00:03:17.896 --> 00:03:22.408
I know, given the fact that he says that
he doesn't know anything about this.

56
00:03:22.408 --> 00:03:27.953
What do you think PRINCE2 stands for?

57
00:03:27.953 --> 00:03:32.900
>> Projects in something, I don't know.

58
00:03:32.900 --> 00:03:36.880
Projects in something?
>> Projects in

59
00:03:36.880 --> 00:03:37.753
something.
>> No,

60
00:03:37.753 --> 00:03:41.250
I'm not saying something is
the actual answer [LAUGH].

61
00:03:41.250 --> 00:03:43.981
Projects in,
[SOUND] there's something there.

62
00:03:43.981 --> 00:03:44.815
>> Yeah there is.

63
00:03:44.815 --> 00:03:47.930
Okay, I'm surprised you got
the first two letters actually,

64
00:03:47.930 --> 00:03:49.132
I'm impressed.
>> Well,

65
00:03:49.132 --> 00:03:52.214
that was a total guess.
>> [LAUGH] It's actually projects in

66
00:03:52.214 --> 00:03:56.365
a controlled environment, and
that's what PRINCE2 stands for.

67
00:03:56.365 --> 00:03:57.677
And you'll see, I mean,

68
00:03:57.677 --> 00:04:01.465
we've got a little bit of a reminder
up there on the screen in front of you.

69
00:04:01.465 --> 00:04:07.125
Now, one thing I will tell you about this
particular series is that in order to

70
00:04:07.125 --> 00:04:12.800
support your accreditation, and you will
be able to sit your PRINCE2 Foundation

71
00:04:12.800 --> 00:04:17.698
exam once you've watched all of
the episodes in this series.

72
00:04:17.698 --> 00:04:20.100
So we do have available for

73
00:04:20.100 --> 00:04:24.170
you downloadable material that
will help you with your study.

74
00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:28.880
We're also, at the end of this series,
going to go over a sample exam as well.

75
00:04:30.140 --> 00:04:32.550
Everything that you see on
the screen in front of you and

76
00:04:32.550 --> 00:04:38.520
more is actually going to be available
to you so that you can download

77
00:04:38.520 --> 00:04:43.200
along with the very minimal show notes
that are gonna go along with this.

78
00:04:43.200 --> 00:04:46.000
Or the course descriptions that
are gonna go along with this.

79
00:04:46.000 --> 00:04:49.260
You're going to find this particular
PowerPoint available to you.

80
00:04:50.710 --> 00:04:52.176
So, Justin,

81
00:04:52.176 --> 00:04:57.160
where did you think PRINCE2 came from?
>> I'm going to

82
00:04:57.160 --> 00:05:00.540
go with some government entity.
>> [LAUGH]

83
00:05:00.540 --> 00:05:02.520
>> Maybe one of those countries you spoke

84
00:05:02.520 --> 00:05:03.510
about earlier.

85
00:05:03.510 --> 00:05:06.050
One of those government institutions
that came along with this

86
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:07.540
project management style?
>> Right,

87
00:05:07.540 --> 00:05:10.610
well I know that you've heard of ITIL.
>> I have.

88
00:05:10.610 --> 00:05:11.640
>> Right, I know this for

89
00:05:11.640 --> 00:05:14.270
a fact because I don't shut
up in the office about it,

90
00:05:14.270 --> 00:05:16.152
so I know that you've heard of that.

91
00:05:16.152 --> 00:05:19.327
And PRINCE2 came from the same
place that ITIL came from, okay?

92
00:05:19.327 --> 00:05:20.980
It came from the UK government.

93
00:05:22.220 --> 00:05:27.260
It started off in the mid 1980s and it
has a very very similar timeline to ITIL,

94
00:05:27.260 --> 00:05:30.160
and this was really about
the UK government, or

95
00:05:30.160 --> 00:05:35.120
rather the Office of Government Commerce,
the OGC, decided that they needed

96
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:40.620
a way to manage projects within
the government environment.

97
00:05:40.620 --> 00:05:42.820
The OGC,
the Office of Government Commerce,

98
00:05:42.820 --> 00:05:46.440
it was called the CCTA before that.

99
00:05:46.440 --> 00:05:51.420
But the Office of Government Commerce
were responsible for ensuring that

100
00:05:51.420 --> 00:05:57.220
government upheld and
still upholds certain,

101
00:05:57.220 --> 00:06:01.090
well, I was gonna say rules, but
more ethics, to be perfectly honest.

102
00:06:01.090 --> 00:06:03.990
Things like the fact that
we've gotta be impartial, and

103
00:06:03.990 --> 00:06:07.360
the fact that government has to make
best use of taxpayers money, which means

104
00:06:07.360 --> 00:06:12.480
the government has to have a focus on
efficiency as well as effectiveness.

105
00:06:12.480 --> 00:06:17.400
So what the OGC wanted to do was to
implement a way of managing projects

106
00:06:17.400 --> 00:06:21.270
with a consistent approach to
managing projects that applied to

107
00:06:21.270 --> 00:06:23.140
all government departments.

108
00:06:23.140 --> 00:06:28.220
So what they did way back in the mid-1980s
was they went out into the big wide world

109
00:06:28.220 --> 00:06:34.890
to find out how projects were implemented,
well, in other organizations.

110
00:06:34.890 --> 00:06:38.055
Organizations that were
more attune to managing IT,

111
00:06:38.055 --> 00:06:41.929
cuz don't forget back in the 1980s,
we didn't have that much IT around.

112
00:06:42.990 --> 00:06:45.574
And so this where PRINCE2 came from,

113
00:06:45.574 --> 00:06:50.824
it started off as something called Prompt
and then we changed that to PRINCE,

114
00:06:50.824 --> 00:06:55.942
because Projects In Controlled Environment
sounded a little bit better.

115
00:06:55.942 --> 00:07:00.934
And in 1996 it was changed to PRINCE2 and
now here we are,

116
00:07:00.934 --> 00:07:07.490
we're at PRINCE2 version 2017,
which is the latest version of PRINCE2.

117
00:07:07.490 --> 00:07:13.500
So, I've already told you that this
is your foundation test, okay?

118
00:07:13.500 --> 00:07:16.910
So, I'm gonna tell you a little bit more
about the exam, and on the screen in front

119
00:07:16.910 --> 00:07:20.530
of you, you'll see that we've got some,
I wouldn't say a cheat sheet.

120
00:07:20.530 --> 00:07:24.045
It just tells you a little
bit more about the test.

121
00:07:24.045 --> 00:07:28.615
The test itself is based on absolutely
everything that we've covered in this

122
00:07:28.615 --> 00:07:29.990
particular series.

123
00:07:29.990 --> 00:07:34.700
And that includes everything
we are about to cover and

124
00:07:34.700 --> 00:07:37.310
everything that we've covered so far.

125
00:07:37.310 --> 00:07:40.442
I'm not gonna tell you that you're
not gonna be asked questions

126
00:07:40.442 --> 00:07:42.014
about the history of PRINCE2.

127
00:07:42.014 --> 00:07:45.570
I'm not gonna tell you that you
are gonna be asked questions.

128
00:07:45.570 --> 00:07:48.780
But certainly I wouldn't gloss over it,
put it that way.

129
00:07:48.780 --> 00:07:54.439
It could be something where we
may ask you where it came from.

130
00:07:54.439 --> 00:07:58.272
We're not gonna ask you for specific
dates, so don't worry too much about that.

131
00:07:58.272 --> 00:08:00.127
It's a one hour test.

132
00:08:00.127 --> 00:08:04.028
It's a multiple choice,
it's a simple multiple choice for

133
00:08:04.028 --> 00:08:08.846
your foundation test and so you're gonna
get a question that may ask you A,

134
00:08:08.846 --> 00:08:11.696
B, C and D or A, B, C,
you have to pick one.

135
00:08:11.696 --> 00:08:15.680
There is only one right answer and
there is no negative marking.

136
00:08:17.580 --> 00:08:19.860
Look how many you get.

137
00:08:20.930 --> 00:08:23.810
You get 60 questions in 60 minutes.

138
00:08:23.810 --> 00:08:27.910
Now Justin, I know that your maths
is great, so can you work that out?

139
00:08:27.910 --> 00:08:29.330
>> That's one question a minute.

140
00:08:29.330 --> 00:08:31.370
You gotta get with it.
>> Yeah.

141
00:08:32.630 --> 00:08:37.330
This is gonna be a very quick test.

142
00:08:37.330 --> 00:08:40.300
Time's gonna go by really, really quickly.

143
00:08:40.300 --> 00:08:43.950
You are going to feel [LAUGH] as,
though, you've done nothing but read for

144
00:08:43.950 --> 00:08:46.520
that entire 60 minutes but that's true.

145
00:08:46.520 --> 00:08:49.680
Okay, you've got one question per minute.

146
00:08:49.680 --> 00:08:52.640
That said,
I don't want you to rush through it.

147
00:08:52.640 --> 00:08:54.900
You look as though you're worried
about that though, Justin.

148
00:08:54.900 --> 00:08:56.400
>> I'm not worried about rushing through

149
00:08:56.400 --> 00:08:59.180
it but whenever I encounter tests
like this, I always think about what

150
00:08:59.180 --> 00:09:03.000
are appropriate strategies
>> Can I skip a question if I don't

151
00:09:03.000 --> 00:09:07.480
immediately know the answer and return to
it, like market because that changes how I

152
00:09:07.480 --> 00:09:11.090
process one question a minute.
>> Right.

153
00:09:11.090 --> 00:09:15.170
So what you can do,
you can go through each one and

154
00:09:15.170 --> 00:09:18.750
consecutive, sort of chronological,
logical order.

155
00:09:18.750 --> 00:09:24.170
And if you don't know the answer to
a question, I will tell you to skip it.

156
00:09:24.170 --> 00:09:28.320
The reason why I do that is because there
might be a question a little bit later on

157
00:09:28.320 --> 00:09:30.740
in your test that might
give you the answer, or

158
00:09:30.740 --> 00:09:35.530
at least prompt your memory to answer
the question that you skipped.

159
00:09:35.530 --> 00:09:39.120
So if you don't know the answer to
something, then that's not a problem.

160
00:09:39.120 --> 00:09:41.370
Skip it and move on.

161
00:09:41.370 --> 00:09:44.780
I've had people that have said to me on
this test, when they come back to me and

162
00:09:44.780 --> 00:09:49.880
said to me afterwards I didn't do
the first term question, and that's okay.

163
00:09:49.880 --> 00:09:54.680
Don't get yourself stressed about it, and
don't worry about it, just skip it and

164
00:09:54.680 --> 00:09:59.370
skip as many as you need to until
you can answer one with confidence.

165
00:09:59.370 --> 00:10:02.130
And then carry on going through and
you can go back.

166
00:10:03.190 --> 00:10:07.155
Now if you skipped all 60,
that's a problem.

167
00:10:07.155 --> 00:10:11.630
[LAUGH] That means that you seriously
haven't done enough studying, so

168
00:10:11.630 --> 00:10:19.550
make sure that you have enough study time
before you take your test, be prepared.

169
00:10:19.550 --> 00:10:22.390
You don't have the time
with this particular

170
00:10:22.390 --> 00:10:26.460
test to read through the question
paper first, and then come back to it.

171
00:10:26.460 --> 00:10:28.200
Now I refer to it as a question paper.

172
00:10:28.200 --> 00:10:31.480
It's another interesting thing because
when you said could I skip it and

173
00:10:31.480 --> 00:10:33.000
come back to it.

174
00:10:33.000 --> 00:10:35.710
I was gonna answer that
question with it depends.

175
00:10:36.754 --> 00:10:40.610
And the reason I was gonna do that was
it depends on whether you are visiting

176
00:10:40.610 --> 00:10:45.460
a Prometric Center or
taking a physical test with a piece of

177
00:10:45.460 --> 00:10:50.250
paper at a particular parametric center,
which you're quite able to do or

178
00:10:50.250 --> 00:10:53.770
whether you're taking your test online,
which is what most people will do.

179
00:10:53.770 --> 00:10:57.350
If you've got a piece of paper
in front of you, it's really,

180
00:10:57.350 --> 00:11:00.830
really easy to skip through and
then just to go back to something.

181
00:11:00.830 --> 00:11:04.690
If you're doing it online,
it's not necessarily so easy.

182
00:11:04.690 --> 00:11:10.240
You will not be able to have a pen and
paper with you.

183
00:11:10.240 --> 00:11:14.450
So you won't be able to mark down,
which questions you've skipped.

184
00:11:14.450 --> 00:11:18.690
Bearing in mind that you go through
each question in a logical order,

185
00:11:18.690 --> 00:11:22.770
in numerical order that's
how it's presented to you.

186
00:11:22.770 --> 00:11:26.811
You need to make sure that you
answered all 60 questions.

187
00:11:26.811 --> 00:11:29.133
The pass mark is 55%.

188
00:11:29.133 --> 00:11:30.712
It's 33 points, so
you've got to get 33 right.

189
00:11:30.712 --> 00:11:38.140
You can only get 33 right
if you've answered 33.

190
00:11:39.420 --> 00:11:43.080
It is a closed book test.

191
00:11:43.080 --> 00:11:44.757
And to be perfectly,
honest, you know what,

192
00:11:44.757 --> 00:11:46.392
that's probably the best
thing it could be.

193
00:11:46.392 --> 00:11:49.735
Because if you've got an hour and
you've got a minute per question,

194
00:11:49.735 --> 00:11:52.400
you don't have time to be
reading through any books.

195
00:11:52.400 --> 00:11:56.740
And it doesn't matter whether you're using
the foundation handbook or whether you're

196
00:11:56.740 --> 00:12:01.970
using the entire PRINCE2 book, you don't
have time to be going through a book.

197
00:12:01.970 --> 00:12:06.110
So what I would recommend is you get
your study out of the way first.

198
00:12:06.110 --> 00:12:11.710
Approach every single question
in a logical order and

199
00:12:11.710 --> 00:12:16.680
then, go back and answer any questions
that you may have forgotten.

200
00:12:17.980 --> 00:12:20.900
Now I mentioned that it does
take a few people for that.

201

00:25:35.513 --> 00:25:39.060
I'm gonna tell you to read this over and
over again.

433
00:25:40.110 --> 00:25:44.790
Because a project cannot
be categorized as PRINCE2,

434
00:25:46.030 --> 00:25:52.110
or considered as PRINCE2,
unless it adheres to each one of these.

435
00:25:53.770 --> 00:25:56.350
This is an important slide.

436
00:25:56.350 --> 00:26:01.100
Now, that's not to say that PRINCE2
is inflexible, because it isn't.

437
00:26:02.290 --> 00:26:05.510
PRINCE2, well, should be tailored.

438
00:26:05.510 --> 00:26:09.100
It's based on these best practices but
it should be tailored.

439
00:26:09.100 --> 00:26:14.000
And PRINCE2 methodologies and
PRINCE2 themes and PRINCE2 processes

440
00:26:14.000 --> 00:26:19.480
can be applied to absolutely any project,
and they can be tailored.

441
00:26:19.480 --> 00:26:21.820
What we want from PRINCE2 and
what we need and

442
00:26:21.820 --> 00:26:24.720
what PRINCE2 gives us is
this common language.

443
00:26:25.860 --> 00:26:30.020
And I like the, I mentioned the word
consistency right at the beginning of

444
00:26:30.020 --> 00:26:33.720
this particular episode and
I like that word, consistency.

445
00:26:33.720 --> 00:26:36.180
That's what we want, a common language.

446
00:26:36.180 --> 00:26:40.310
Because if I don't talk the same
language as Justin, which I don't.

447
00:26:40.310 --> 00:26:40.816
Let's face, it I don't.
But

448
00:26:40.816 --> 00:26:45.655
if I don't talk the same language as him
the communication can be really difficult.

449
00:26:45.655 --> 00:26:51.070
And I might ask him for something and he
might do something completely different.

450
00:26:52.840 --> 00:26:55.492
If I ask you, Justin, or
I tell you that you need to go away and

451
00:26:55.492 --> 00:26:58.352
revise your notes now cuz you've
got a test a little bit later on,

452
00:26:58.352 --> 00:27:01.371
what are you gonna do?
>> I'm going to rewrite

453
00:27:01.371 --> 00:27:05.180
them.
>> And then I'll just laugh, because

454
00:27:05.180 --> 00:27:09.425
do you know what I asked him to do?
>> Review them, I'm going to guess.

455
00:27:09.425 --> 00:27:13.380
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, I asked him to study.

456
00:27:13.380 --> 00:27:16.190
Cuz where I come from revise means study.

457
00:27:17.220 --> 00:27:19.551
And where you come from-
>> It means make a revision.

458
00:27:19.551 --> 00:27:20.127
>> Right.

459
00:27:20.127 --> 00:27:20.950
>> Where you make changes and

460
00:27:20.950 --> 00:27:22.070
make it better.
>> Make a change.

461
00:27:22.070 --> 00:27:25.610
This is why we have to
have a common language.

462
00:27:25.610 --> 00:27:28.077
This is why PRINCE2 is important,

463
00:27:28.077 --> 00:27:33.352
cuz it establishes that common language
across the project organization.

464
00:27:33.352 --> 00:27:37.985
Now that's not necessarily a common
language across the whole of IT by

465
00:27:37.985 --> 00:27:42.869
the way, but this is a common language
across the project organization.

466
00:27:44.000 --> 00:27:46.550
All of the participants
of the project have got

467
00:27:46.550 --> 00:27:49.830
to work together to
focus on that viability.

468
00:27:51.310 --> 00:27:54.040
And all of our stakeholders
have got to be involved.

469
00:27:54.040 --> 00:27:57.910
But we've all got to be
talking the same language.

470
00:27:59.070 --> 00:28:03.698
Now, there's something on the bottom
bullet point there which talks

471
00:28:03.698 --> 00:28:05.900
about the maturity of PRINCE2.

472
00:28:05.900 --> 00:28:10.668
And within our AXELOS Suite,
we've got something called P3M3

473
00:28:10.668 --> 00:28:15.710
which is Portfolio Program and
Project Management Maturity Model.

474
00:28:15.710 --> 00:28:20.460
Now, if Justin couldn't say PRINCE2
2017 Foundation he's certainly not going

475
00:28:20.460 --> 00:28:22.585
to be able to say that, right?

476
00:28:22.585 --> 00:28:25.960
Portfolio, program, and
project management maturity model.

477
00:28:25.960 --> 00:28:27.270
It's an assessment.

478
00:28:27.270 --> 00:28:32.253
It's an assessment tool that we will
use and assess the efficiency and

479
00:28:32.253 --> 00:28:34.370
effectiveness of PRINCE2.

480
00:28:34.370 --> 00:28:38.395
And to assess where the PRINCE2,
where the project management and

481
00:28:38.395 --> 00:28:43.630
where the portfolio and program management
are working at their most efficient level.

482
00:28:45.390 --> 00:28:51.280
So just before we close for
this particular episode, I want to look at

483
00:28:51.280 --> 00:28:56.070
Project Management from
a PRINCE2 perspective.

484
00:28:56.070 --> 00:28:59.820
You'll see that we have four elements
listed on the right hand side there,

485
00:28:59.820 --> 00:29:03.620
and that's Plan, Delegate,
Monitor and Control.

486
00:29:03.620 --> 00:29:06.340
And project management is
about a planning, delegating,

487
00:29:06.340 --> 00:29:10.040
monitoring and
control of all aspects of a project.

488
00:29:11.050 --> 00:29:18.330
And look at what is really important
by the way, motivating team members.

489
00:29:19.420 --> 00:29:21.198
Why do you think we want
to motivate people?

490
00:29:21.198 --> 00:29:23.294
>> Because that's when you actually get

491
00:29:23.294 --> 00:29:23.954
work done.

492
00:29:23.954 --> 00:29:27.208
If you're just like, just do it already!

493
00:29:27.208 --> 00:29:28.760
And everybody is not motivated,

494
00:29:28.760 --> 00:29:32.476
then even if you do get it done you'll get
it done poorly or maybe it just doesn't

495
00:29:32.476 --> 00:29:34.478
get actually accomplished at all.
>> Well,

496
00:29:34.478 --> 00:29:36.722
there's been a big push
lately in the industry.

497
00:29:36.722 --> 00:29:38.796
And I don't know whether
you've noticed this, but

498
00:29:38.796 --> 00:29:41.592
there's been a big push towards
organizational change management.

499
00:29:41.592 --> 00:29:47.041
PMI have implemented a big push towards
organizational change management.If

500
00:29:47.041 --> 00:29:52.160
we look at the other frameworks and
methodologies within the Axila Suite,

501
00:29:52.160 --> 00:29:58.330
Certainly within ITIL they had a big push
towards organizational change management.

502
00:29:58.330 --> 00:30:00.980
If we look at other
methodologies such as Agile and

503
00:30:00.980 --> 00:30:04.120
Cyan, they've got a big
push towards OCM as well.

504
00:30:04.120 --> 00:30:09.750
And organizational change management is
about getting the people along with you.

505
00:30:09.750 --> 00:30:13.160
It's not good enough just to give them
something to do, you've got to really

506
00:30:13.160 --> 00:30:18.120
explain why they're doing it, and you've
got to bring them on board with you.

507
00:30:18.120 --> 00:30:21.020
If you don't, like you say,
it becomes a very sort of

508
00:30:21.020 --> 00:30:25.810
dictatorial environment to work in and
the work doesn't get done.

509
00:30:25.810 --> 00:30:30.490
If I'm not bold into something then I'm
not gonna work as hard as I should.

510
00:30:30.490 --> 00:30:34.710
And maybe that's, you might consider
that to be my bad character, but

511
00:30:34.710 --> 00:30:38.160
it's not really about character trade,
it's human nature.

512
00:30:38.160 --> 00:30:40.930
Unless you've convinced me that something
is a good idea, I'm going to do it

513
00:30:40.930 --> 00:30:43.850
begrudgingly and I'm certainly not
going to give it a hundred percent.

514
00:30:43.850 --> 00:30:46.547
And I know that you're the same.
>> I am exactly the same, and I would,

515
00:30:46.547 --> 00:30:50.730
say by and large, as generalization,
not everybody applies.

516
00:30:50.730 --> 00:30:54.650
External motivation is not as motivating,
right, this kind of external

517
00:30:55.710 --> 00:31:00.500
stimuli is not nearly as motivating as
internal stimulus, where you go, I get why

518
00:31:00.500 --> 00:31:04.440
we're doing this, I've bought into it,
let me make sure that it goes well,

519
00:31:04.440 --> 00:31:06.558
because I see the purpose of it.
>> Yeah,

520
00:31:06.558 --> 00:31:08.795
there's a lot of people that think well,
I'm paying you, so

521
00:31:08.795 --> 00:31:11.001
therefore you should come to work and
do what I want you to do.

522
00:31:11.001 --> 00:31:14.830
And you hear people all around say
it's not just about the money.

523
00:31:14.830 --> 00:31:16.540
But the fact of the matter is,

524
00:31:16.540 --> 00:31:20.700
Is that it doesn't really matter what
you get paid in certain circumstances.

525
00:31:20.700 --> 00:31:25.640
If you're not bought into it,
then you're really, really not going to

526
00:31:25.640 --> 00:31:31.130
undertake the work to 100% of your
sort of effort your motivation and

527
00:31:31.130 --> 00:31:34.800
your commitment so motivate people.

528
00:31:34.800 --> 00:31:38.910
We've gotta achieve those project
objectives within targets that time,

529
00:31:38.910 --> 00:31:42.140
cost, quality, scope,
benefits, risk targets, and

530
00:31:42.140 --> 00:31:46.150
we're gonna look at that in a lot
more detail in another episode.

531
00:31:46.150 --> 00:31:49.290
So the purpose of project
management is to organize,

532
00:31:49.290 --> 00:31:54.380
is to control the work that's
required to do the planning,

533
00:31:54.380 --> 00:31:58.730
the delegating, the monitoring and
the controlling.

534
00:31:58.730 --> 00:32:03.130
And so a PRINCE2 Project,
well, it looks at them.

535
00:32:03.130 --> 00:32:07.800
We just talked about these, the time, the
cost, scope, the risk, the benefits and

536
00:32:07.800 --> 00:32:12.270
the quality, and
we are going to in our next episode.

537
00:32:12.270 --> 00:32:15.250
Then we're going to get started
on the PRINCE2 environment, and

538
00:32:15.250 --> 00:32:18.700
we're going to look at
the PRINCE2 environment itself.

539
00:32:18.700 --> 00:32:23.400
So we're gonna be looking at the processes
and the themes within PRINCE2, but

540
00:32:23.400 --> 00:32:27.250
for now, I think this has been quite
enough for everybody to digest for

541
00:32:27.250 --> 00:32:30.260
this first episode in
this particular series.

542
00:32:30.260 --> 00:32:35.220
So I'm gonna ask you to go away and
download your material now, if you haven't

543
00:32:35.220 --> 00:32:39.503
already done so, because this is
your opportunity to print it out or

544
00:32:39.503 --> 00:32:42.001
to keep it in PDF and to make notes on it.

545
00:32:42.001 --> 00:32:47.022
But for this particular episode, well,
that's all we're gonna cover for now,

546
00:32:47.022 --> 00:32:51.380
and we will see you in our next episode.
>> Well, this has definitely been a fact

547
00:32:51.380 --> 00:32:53.870
filled episode and
this is just the first one, right?

548
00:32:53.870 --> 00:32:57.420
We learned a little bit about the exam,
a little bit about PRINCE2, and well,

549
00:32:57.420 --> 00:32:59.610
we have a lot more coming at you,
so definitely come on back.

550
00:32:59.610 --> 00:33:01.530
But for this one,
we're gonna go ahead and get outta here.

551
00:33:01.530 --> 00:33:04.520
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

552
00:33:04.520 --> 00:33:05.360
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

553
00:33:05.360 --> 00:33:06.014
>> And we'll see you next time.

554
00:33:06.014 --> 00:33:13.352
[MUSIC]

555
00:33:13.352 --> 00:33:16.204
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episodes Jo and Justin introduce the Prince2® project environment and the components of a Prince2® project.
episodes.title: Prince2 Environment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:06.481
Welcome to ITPRO.TV [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.481 --> 00:00:08.130
>> [MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.130 --> 00:00:11.876
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:11.876 --> 00:00:16.090
>> Greetings, everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:16.090 --> 00:00:17.320
I'm your host, Justin Dennison and

6
00:00:17.320 --> 00:00:21.410
we're coming back at you with
more PRINCE2 2017 foundation and

7
00:00:21.410 --> 00:00:24.980
in particular in this episode, we're gonna
be looking at the PRINCE2 environment.

8
00:00:24.980 --> 00:00:26.611
And here to help us along,
is Ms. Joe Peacock.

9
00:00:26.611 --> 00:00:27.910
How are you doing today, Joe?

10
00:00:27.910 --> 00:00:29.420
>> Absolutely great, thank you Justin.

11
00:00:29.420 --> 00:00:30.120
How are you?

12
00:00:30.120 --> 00:00:31.540
>> I am doing fantastic.

13
00:00:31.540 --> 00:00:34.870
Now, we left off talking about
like a prints to project,

14
00:00:34.870 --> 00:00:36.240
in the previous episode.

15
00:00:36.240 --> 00:00:38.920
But now we're going to talk about
the environment where that project

16
00:00:38.920 --> 00:00:39.520
takes place.

17
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:42.220
Or am I getting too far ahead here?

18
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:46.050
>> Well, we started off in the previous
episode we looked at the concept of

19
00:00:46.050 --> 00:00:47.280
a project.

20
00:00:47.280 --> 00:00:51.010
>> And we looked at what PRINCE2
project management was all about and

21
00:00:51.010 --> 00:00:54.780
now we're going to look more
closely at the themes and

22
00:00:54.780 --> 00:00:58.670
the principles of the PRINCE2
project environment.

23
00:00:58.670 --> 00:01:02.100
So, right now in this particular episode
we're going to pay very close attention to

24
00:01:02.100 --> 00:01:03.450
the PRINCE2 environments.

25
00:01:03.450 --> 00:01:05.770
And all of the definitions,

26
00:01:05.770 --> 00:01:10.850
the terminology that we use when we
associate a project with PRINCE2.

27
00:01:10.850 --> 00:01:12.040
So, if you remember and

28
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:16.070
we're gonna jump straight back in to
where we left off in our last episode.

29
00:01:16.070 --> 00:01:19.560
Because where we left off was
in this particular slide,

30
00:01:19.560 --> 00:01:22.800
which was looking at the aspects
of the PRINCE2 Project.

31
00:01:22.800 --> 00:01:25.950
Those aspects that had to be managed.

32
00:01:25.950 --> 00:01:30.899
Now we kind of left it hanging at
the end of the last episode and

33
00:01:30.899 --> 00:01:36.539
I wanted to just mention all that
of these aspects are interrelated.

34
00:01:36.539 --> 00:01:41.199
I didn't used the word interdependent
because they aren't interdependent but

35
00:01:41.199 --> 00:01:43.020
the are interrelated.

36
00:01:43.020 --> 00:01:46.210
So let's think about time and
cost and quality.

37
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:51.540
These are, well, these quite often appear
in project management in a triangle each.

38
00:01:51.540 --> 00:01:54.060
Just the three of them
where we have to balance.

39
00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:58.540
We have to have a trade off
between time and cost and quality.

40
00:01:58.540 --> 00:02:02.800
Because quite often and
this not cast in stone.

41
00:02:02.800 --> 00:02:05.600
This is just a sort of
a generalization here.

42
00:02:05.600 --> 00:02:11.800
But quite often, if we want it quicker,
it's probably going to cost us more money

43
00:02:11.800 --> 00:02:17.050
and we might have to take a hit,
a compromise, on the quality.

44
00:02:18.110 --> 00:02:20.990
But if we want higher quality,
then again that's

45
00:02:20.990 --> 00:02:25.560
quite often going to cost us more money,
but it might take us longer as well.

46
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:31.869
And if you want it cheaper,
then it might take longer to produce and

47
00:02:31.869 --> 00:02:35.940
we might be taking
shortcuts on the quality.

48
00:02:35.940 --> 00:02:38.030
So, all of these are interrelated.

49
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:42.830
We can not deliver a project
without considering

50
00:02:42.830 --> 00:02:47.720
all of these particular aspects include,
I heard risk brought into that triangle.

51
00:02:47.720 --> 00:02:49.280
So maybe you might want to.

52
00:02:49.280 --> 00:02:51.067
And you can substitute any of these,

53
00:02:51.067 --> 00:02:53.730
into that particular triangle and
into that balance.

54
00:02:53.730 --> 00:03:00.800
And then we got to think about
our tolerances, tolerances is.

55
00:03:00.800 --> 00:03:03.140
What do you think of when
you hear the word tolerance.

56
00:03:03.140 --> 00:03:08.010
>> I'm thinking an acceptable
variation from like a criteria or a.

57
00:03:08.010 --> 00:03:10.660
For me I actually think
of physical measurements.

58
00:03:10.660 --> 00:03:16.380
I'm like I can this measure to ten
millimeter plus or minus one millimeter.

59
00:03:16.380 --> 00:03:20.070
>> Right, so you using that plus or minus
there when you talk about a tolerance.

60
00:03:20.070 --> 00:03:25.030
That's what we're talking about,
we are really talking about the acceptable

61
00:03:25.030 --> 00:03:27.810
sort of levels within which
the project could be delivered.

62
00:03:28.930 --> 00:03:33.140
So, let's think about, for
instance, browsing a website.

63
00:03:33.140 --> 00:03:37.160
If we were browsing a website,
then an acceptable tolerance would be

64
00:03:37.160 --> 00:03:42.380
I want it to be displayed
within 0.0 five seconds.

65
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:45.600
Plus or minus 0.1 of a second.

66
00:03:45.600 --> 00:03:49.230
So that would be what we considered
to be an acceptably tolerance.

67
00:03:49.230 --> 00:03:52.700
So when we are defining the project and

68
00:03:52.700 --> 00:03:57.600
when we are defining what it is that
we're actually going to deliver.

69
00:03:57.600 --> 00:04:00.610
Then it would be within
that particular tolerance.

70
00:04:00.610 --> 00:04:06.050
And that particular tolerance would
be a quality tolerance, for instance.

71
00:04:06.050 --> 00:04:08.920
Now, there could be tolerances
in terms of cost as well.

72
00:04:08.920 --> 00:04:13.320
I want to come in roughly
round about half a million.

73
00:04:13.320 --> 00:04:19.170
Whether it's half million pounds or
dollars or euros.

74
00:04:19.170 --> 00:04:20.580
It doesn't really make any difference.

75
00:04:20.580 --> 00:04:26.070
But you might say, I want it to come in
around about a half a million, give or

76
00:04:26.070 --> 00:04:27.950
take 10,000 for instance.

77
00:04:27.950 --> 00:04:29.050
That would be our tolerances.

78
00:04:29.050 --> 00:04:32.730
So would you document these?

79
00:04:32.730 --> 00:04:34.400
>> I would absolutely document these.

80
00:04:34.400 --> 00:04:37.904
Because then it keeps it from going

81
00:04:37.904 --> 00:04:43.240
I thought you said 0.1
versus .01 versus 0.5.

82
00:04:43.240 --> 00:04:46.230
You need to make sure there is some.

83
00:04:46.230 --> 00:04:51.750
Durable and common, I guess proof,
for lack of a better word.

84
00:04:51.750 --> 00:04:55.280
>> Right and this is,
we're gonna talk in a later episode,

85
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:57.090
we wanna talk about the business case.

86
00:04:57.090 --> 00:04:59.810
But this is something that
has to be documented.

87
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:03.090
All of your tolerance, whether it's
the tolerance to do with cost,

88
00:05:03.090 --> 00:05:05.070
whether it's the tolerance
to do with quality.

89
00:05:05.070 --> 00:05:07.150
Or whether it's the tolerance
to do with risks or

90
00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:10.190
benefits, they should be documented.

91
00:05:10.190 --> 00:05:12.970
Because as Justin says, you want proof.

92
00:05:14.530 --> 00:05:17.590
Now I'm not talking about proof
because you want to sort of,

93
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:20.550
see, I told you so,
at the end of a project.

94
00:05:20.550 --> 00:05:22.470
Or I knew it was gonna
come in over budget.

95
00:05:22.470 --> 00:05:24.120
That's not what we're talking about.

96
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:27.300
But we want to know what the end user and

97
00:05:27.300 --> 00:05:32.510
what the customer will accept,
as an acceptable solution.

98
00:05:32.510 --> 00:05:37.580
There is absolutely no point in
me delivering a financial system,

99
00:05:37.580 --> 00:05:40.570
I talked about an Oracle
database in our last episode.

100
00:05:40.570 --> 00:05:44.310
There is no point in me
delivering an Oracle database

101
00:05:45.310 --> 00:05:49.680
if it doesn't allow me to
add two numbers together.

102

00:19:35.650 --> 00:19:39.940
of course,
this is an accredited course and this

327
00:19:39.940 --> 00:19:44.390
particular test that you will be taking
is obviously an accredited test as well.

328
00:19:44.390 --> 00:19:46.020
So all of the material that we're using,

329
00:19:46.020 --> 00:19:49.170
I just wanna mention that,
this comes straight out of the books.

330
00:19:49.170 --> 00:19:52.320
But where I have used these
diagrams that I'm gonna try and

331
00:19:52.320 --> 00:19:55.090
explain them as best as I can for you.

332
00:19:55.090 --> 00:19:56.360
So these are our themes.

333
00:19:56.360 --> 00:20:00.470
But following on from our themes,
we also have our PRINCE2 Principles.

334
00:20:00.470 --> 00:20:03.690
And these are over on
the right-hand side there.

335
00:20:03.690 --> 00:20:05.400
Which is that focus on products,

336
00:20:05.400 --> 00:20:10.720
managing by exception, managing by stages,
learning from experience.

337
00:20:10.720 --> 00:20:15.870
And all of those principles will
actually help us to tailor.

338
00:20:18.270 --> 00:20:22.130
We have to tailor our themes and
we have to tailor our processes.

339
00:20:22.130 --> 00:20:25.190
And so we're going to use
these principles, as I say,

340
00:20:25.190 --> 00:20:26.800
to help us with that.

341
00:20:26.800 --> 00:20:31.250
So, when it comes to, let's just
say we want to take the themes and

342
00:20:31.250 --> 00:20:32.590
the principles together.

343
00:20:32.590 --> 00:20:35.020
So let's just say we take
a look at the business case.

344
00:20:35.020 --> 00:20:40.901
And we want to tailor the business case
to ensure that it focuses on products.

345
00:20:42.390 --> 00:20:48.160
What does means is then, our business case
should look, should ensure that, not only

346
00:20:48.160 --> 00:20:54.030
are we being able to justify, remember
that ROI, that we turn on investment.

347
00:20:54.030 --> 00:20:58.970
We look that at so
many of our other series, that ROI,

348
00:20:58.970 --> 00:21:02.630
return on investment, is something that
has to appear in our business case.

349
00:21:02.630 --> 00:21:06.700
But we should ensure that we
focus on our products as well.

350
00:21:06.700 --> 00:21:07.930
In our business case,

351
00:21:07.930 --> 00:21:12.990
we identify what our product should
look like, remember our must-go list.

352
00:21:12.990 --> 00:21:16.120
We identify exactly what it is our

353
00:21:16.120 --> 00:21:21.350
organization require and
let's think about our plans then.

354
00:21:21.350 --> 00:21:27.590
Our plans, well we should tailor our plans
to scale, the scale of the organization.

355
00:21:27.590 --> 00:21:32.640
Tailor to suit the product environment,
the project environment.

356
00:21:32.640 --> 00:21:36.180
In other words, how we're going to
deliver that particular project.

357
00:21:36.180 --> 00:21:41.368
It also should be tailored to meet
our roles and responsibilities

358
00:21:41.368 --> 00:21:46.852
that we will be defining in our AC
matrices for all of our activities.

359
00:21:46.852 --> 00:21:52.740
There is an element of tailoring
in absolutely everything.

360
00:21:52.740 --> 00:21:56.414
And so
as we move through this particular series,

361
00:21:56.414 --> 00:22:02.361
I want you to consider that what we're
going to be doing in every single episode,

362
00:22:02.361 --> 00:22:06.560
is we're gonna be focusing
on the best practice.

363
00:22:06.560 --> 00:22:09.260
We're gonna be focusing on
what's in the PRINCE2 book.

364
00:22:10.510 --> 00:22:16.700
But remember, best practice is what has
worked in a number of organizations.

365
00:22:16.700 --> 00:22:19.770
And it is what is proven to work.

366
00:22:19.770 --> 00:22:22.220
Best practice is not plug and play.

367
00:22:22.220 --> 00:22:24.370
This is not a one size fits all approach.

368
00:22:24.370 --> 00:22:27.820
And this is not something that you
can simply take out of the book and

369
00:22:27.820 --> 00:22:30.220
apply to your organization.

370
00:22:30.220 --> 00:22:36.030
Absolutely everything in PRINCE2,
needs to be tailored to the project.

371
00:22:37.260 --> 00:22:39.650
Everything and
there's nothing exempt from this.

372
00:22:39.650 --> 00:22:45.080
So as we move through each particular
episode, we're going to be looking

373
00:22:45.080 --> 00:22:50.280
more in depth at the tailoring aspects and
exactly what we could tailor for

374
00:22:50.280 --> 00:22:53.970
a particular theme and for
each process and for each principle.

375
00:22:53.970 --> 00:22:57.042
And how we could tailor that.

376
00:22:57.042 --> 00:23:01.990
So for this particular episode, we've just
taken a very brief look at the aspects and

377
00:23:01.990 --> 00:23:04.546
the themes and the principles of PRINCE2.

378
00:23:04.546 --> 00:23:08.177
And when we come back,
we are going to, in our next episode,

379
00:23:08.177 --> 00:23:12.900
we're gonna be taking a more in depth
look at up PRINCE2 project principles.

380
00:23:12.900 --> 00:23:17.030
>> Well Jo, this is definitely something
that I need to get a little better at,

381
00:23:17.030 --> 00:23:21.060
so I'm gonna have to come on back for
that next episode and you should as well.

382
00:23:21.060 --> 00:23:22.900
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

383
00:23:22.900 --> 00:23:25.840
So signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison,

384
00:23:25.840 --> 00:23:26.580
>> And I'm Jo Peacot.

385
00:23:26.580 --> 00:23:28.586
>> And we'll see you next time.

386
00:23:28.586 --> 00:23:34.534
[MUSIC]

387
00:23:34.534 --> 00:23:38.166
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episodes Jo and Justin introduce the Prince2® project environment and the components of a Prince2® project.
episodes.title: Prince2 Environment Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.041 --> 00:00:02.150
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.150 --> 00:00:05.934
[INAUDIBLE]

3
00:00:05.934 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:13.020
>> You're watching ITPro.TV
>> Greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.020 --> 00:00:16.270
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:16.270 --> 00:00:17.540
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

7
00:00:17.540 --> 00:00:21.770
we're continuing on with our
PRINCE2 2017 foundation series.

8
00:00:21.770 --> 00:00:25.330
And well, this is like part two
on our PRINCE2 environment.

9
00:00:25.330 --> 00:00:28.160
If you have ever seen part one,
definitely go check that out and

10
00:00:28.160 --> 00:00:32.260
here to help us along to further expand
on the prints two environment is well,

11
00:00:32.260 --> 00:00:34.640
the one and only Ms.
Jo Peacock, how you doing today Jo?

12
00:00:34.640 --> 00:00:36.900
>> Absolutely great,
thank you Justin, how are you?

13
00:00:36.900 --> 00:00:41.606
>> I am doing fantastic and well there's
a lot to unpack with the PRINCE2

14
00:00:41.606 --> 00:00:43.710
environment, so,
where are we going from here?

15
00:00:43.710 --> 00:00:44.620
>> Well, we're going to carry on.

16
00:00:44.620 --> 00:00:46.690
We're in a Part 2,
as you've already said and

17
00:00:46.690 --> 00:00:50.440
we're going to carry on looking
at our project environment.

18
00:00:50.440 --> 00:00:54.440
Now, just a quick recap
over our previous episode.

19
00:00:54.440 --> 00:00:58.480
In our previous episode, we actually
looked at this particular diagram which

20
00:00:58.480 --> 00:01:02.250
came from the official PRINCE2 book.

21
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:06.040
And we talked about tailoring in our
last episode but in that episode,

22
00:01:06.040 --> 00:01:08.960
we introduced the PRINCE2 environment.

23
00:01:08.960 --> 00:01:11.330
And the PRINCE2 environment
is made up of processes,

24
00:01:11.330 --> 00:01:14.480
which we're going to address
in subsequent episodes.

25
00:01:14.480 --> 00:01:18.690
It's also made up with our themes and
our principles.

26
00:01:18.690 --> 00:01:22.680
And then, we took a look at this diagram,
which I, it's one I really, really like,

27
00:01:22.680 --> 00:01:25.860
where we kind of took the top
off our PRINCE2 themes and

28
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:27.260
we looked at our principles.

29
00:01:27.260 --> 00:01:32.020
And in this particular Episode, we're
going to carry on and we're just going to

30
00:01:32.020 --> 00:01:36.433
explore those principles and those
themes in just a little bit more depth.

31
00:01:36.433 --> 00:01:42.576
Now, bearing in mind, this is still
our introduction to PRINCE2 2017.

32
00:01:42.576 --> 00:01:47.553
This is not an in depth look and we're
going to be looking at each one of these

33
00:01:47.553 --> 00:01:52.140
in a lot more depth,
a little bit later in subsequent episodes.

34
00:01:52.140 --> 00:01:54.470
So we're going to be looking
at all the requirements for

35
00:01:54.470 --> 00:01:56.840
all of these in subsequent episodes.

36
00:01:56.840 --> 00:01:59.720
But what we're going to do right now,
is we're literally

37
00:01:59.720 --> 00:02:04.030
going to just take a quick glance at
the principles and the themes, etc.

38
00:02:05.460 --> 00:02:08.890
So let's start out by
looking at our principles.

39
00:02:08.890 --> 00:02:14.930
And as you've seen here, our principles
what was in the last diagram, I

40
00:02:14.930 --> 00:02:18.850
was just trying to get the right word for
that up there, that was diagram, it was.

41
00:02:18.850 --> 00:02:21.650
We've got here,
continued business justification.

42
00:02:24.040 --> 00:02:25.020
Just a quick word.

43
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:28.940
How long do you think
a PRINCE2 project will take?

44
00:02:31.050 --> 00:02:33.650
>> I'm just gonna make a complete guess,
nine months.

45
00:02:35.060 --> 00:02:36.016
>> There's no right answer to that.

46
00:02:36.016 --> 00:02:37.103
I mean,
I just deliberately try to trip him up.

47
00:02:37.103 --> 00:02:39.530
>> There you go with those
trick questions again.

48
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:41.155
How long does it take until it's done?

49
00:02:41.155 --> 00:02:42.438
[LAUGH]
>> Okay,

50
00:02:42.438 --> 00:02:44.942
yeah, that's about
the right answer actually.

51
00:02:44.942 --> 00:02:48.946
Yeah, no, a PRINCE2,
you should just turn around and say,

52
00:02:48.946 --> 00:02:51.365
as long as it takes, really, yeah.

53
00:02:51.365 --> 00:02:53.150
The Prince2 project,

54
00:02:53.150 --> 00:02:57.190
I don't expect the Prince2 project
to take three months, by the way.

55
00:02:57.190 --> 00:03:02.020
If you are looking at a three month
project, it's probably going to be a very,

56
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:04.360
very small scale project.

57
00:03:04.360 --> 00:03:08.020
In which case, then tailoring
would be very, very extreme.

58
00:03:08.020 --> 00:03:14.200
So, unless you've got a really
good set of sound principles and

59
00:03:14.200 --> 00:03:19.440
sound themes and consistency and
a methodology already in place.

60
00:03:19.440 --> 00:03:21.640
And then perhaps for
something like 3 months,

61
00:03:21.640 --> 00:03:25.950
you might just be looking at using
Change Management to manage that change.

62
00:03:27.270 --> 00:03:29.660
But throughout the length
of a PRINCE2 project and

63
00:03:29.660 --> 00:03:31.400
it doesn't matter how
long it is going to take.

64
00:03:31.400 --> 00:03:36.980
Whether it's going to take a year, whether
it's going to take 18 months, two years.

65
00:03:36.980 --> 00:03:40.380
Throughout the project,
you need to maintain these principles and

66
00:03:40.380 --> 00:03:42.170
that includes this first one.

67
00:03:42.170 --> 00:03:45.090
Continued, there's a clue in that word,
right?

68
00:03:45.090 --> 00:03:47.700
Continued business justification.

69
00:03:49.450 --> 00:03:51.270
I'm gonna ask Justin this question.

70
00:03:51.270 --> 00:03:54.280
I don't why I'm gonna ask him this
question because I dread to think what

71
00:03:54.280 --> 00:03:55.560
the answer's gonna be.

72
00:03:55.560 --> 00:03:57.420
But Justin,
have you ever started something and

73
00:03:57.420 --> 00:04:00.430
then wondered halfway through
why on Earth you're doing it?

74
00:04:00.430 --> 00:04:03.170
>> Most conversations that I start.

75
00:04:03.170 --> 00:04:06.870
Yeah, it's pretty common place for me but

76
00:04:06.870 --> 00:04:10.160
I've been in projects like this where you
get part of the way into the project and

77
00:04:10.160 --> 00:04:14.240
then someone goes,
what are we really doing here, anyway?

78
00:04:14.240 --> 00:04:18.400
We've lost sight of the entire impetus for
the project.

79
00:04:18.400 --> 00:04:22.160
>> Point, the fact to the matter is
that life changes, business changes,

80
00:04:22.160 --> 00:04:24.210
your organization changes.

81
00:04:24.210 --> 00:04:28.420
And the longer the project life span,

82
00:04:28.420 --> 00:04:33.210
the longer we are expecting to
have this project up and running.

83
00:04:33.210 --> 00:04:37.850
Then the more chance there is of the goals

84
00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:43.260
potentially moving and
of the justification changing.

85
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:46.230
In other words, what seemed like
good Idea right at the very start,

86
00:04:46.230 --> 00:04:49.530
might not be a good idea six
months into the project.

87
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:50.140
You never know.

88
00:04:50.140 --> 00:04:52.000
The organization will probably change.

89
00:04:52.000 --> 00:04:53.250
Maybe there's some mergers.

90
00:04:53.250 --> 00:04:54.820
Maybe there's some acquisitions.

91
00:04:54.820 --> 00:04:59.330
Maybe there's some growth or
maybe there's been a complete change and

92
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:04.240
there's actually less people there
than what you originally anticipated.

93
00:05:04.240 --> 00:05:05.630
Maybe the budget's decreased.

94
00:05:05.630 --> 00:05:07.060
Maybe the budget's increased.

95
00:05:07.060 --> 00:05:11.330
Maybe you've got and
change in regulations or

96
00:05:11.330 --> 00:05:13.810
change in the ethics of the organization.

97
00:05:15.000 --> 00:05:16.530
It doesn't matter what change is.

98
00:05:16.530 --> 00:05:17.840
In the real world environment,

99
00:05:17.840 --> 00:05:23.500
you need to have continued justification
throughout the length of the project.

100
00:05:23.500 --> 00:05:25.628
Throughout the duration of the project.

101
00:05:25.628 --> 00:05:28.850
Which means, that on a regular basis,

102
00:05:28.850 --> 00:05:34.410
we need to be verifying
that we are still on track.

103
00:05:34.410 --> 00:05:39.710
Not only to achieve ROI from the project
return on that investment but

104
00:05:39.710 --> 00:05:44.320
that it's actually a viable project,
that the business still wanted.

105
00:05:45.780 --> 00:05:51.820
I've seen a lot of projects that have
happened in some very, very large

106
00:05:51.820 --> 00:05:57.680
organizations where we didn't continue
to check the business justification.

107
00:05:57.680 --> 00:06:02.970
And business needs change and
that project becomes well, obsolete.

108
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:06.220
And it becomes obsolete halfway through.

109
00:06:06.220 --> 00:06:09.590
But don't worry cuz PRNCE2 has
got a way of dealing with that.

110
00:06:09.590 --> 00:06:13.600
But nevertheless, you've still
got to maintain justification.

111
00:06:13.600 --> 00:06:16.530
You've got to still ask yourself,
why are we doing this and

112
00:06:16.530 --> 00:06:19.120
we carry on doing that
throughout the project.

113
00:06:19.120 --> 00:06:20.795
You're looking very pensive there Justin.

114
00:06:20.795 --> 00:06:24.350
>> No, I'm just trying to think about
what's an appropriate frequency but

115
00:06:24.350 --> 00:06:26.455
then I thought to myself, it depends.

116
00:06:26.455 --> 00:06:29.567
>> [LAUGH]
>> I guess, based on the respective

117
00:06:29.567 --> 00:06:33.806
timeline of the project itself and
how frequently or

118
00:06:33.806 --> 00:06:38.719
how much the project could be
affected by internal changes,

119
00:06:38.719 --> 00:06:41.824
I guess could also be another factor.

120
00:06:41.824 --> 00:06:44.780
So, I kind of answered my own question but
that is what I was thinking about.

121
00:06:44.780 --> 00:06:49.041
>> We'll take a look at the, if we go
halfway down this particular slide,

122
00:06:49.041 --> 00:06:52.105
you'll see that we talk
about managing by stages.

123
00:06:52.105 --> 00:06:54.875
And then, of course, at the bottom
we talk about tailoring again.

124
00:06:54.875 --> 00:06:57.035
Tailoring to suit the project environment.

125
00:06:57.035 --> 00:07:03.180
And the fact of the matter is what you've
just said about the length of the project.

126
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:07.610
Well, we wanna chunk the project
up into manageable stages and

127
00:07:07.610 --> 00:07:10.100
we'll talk about that in
a little bit more depth.

128
00:07:10.100 --> 00:07:14.580
But manageable stages means
that on a regular basis,

129
00:07:14.580 --> 00:07:18.260
we're going to be performing
certain chunks of work.

130
00:07:18.260 --> 00:07:20.740
And as we perform these
certain chunks of work,

131
00:07:20.740 --> 00:07:25.550
we've still got to ask ourselves,
is this an appropriate time to say okay,

132
00:07:25.550 --> 00:07:31.040
are we still doing what we need to do,
is this still the right thing to do?

133
00:07:31.040 --> 00:07:33.930
So we should be doing
that within each stage.

134
00:07:33.930 --> 00:07:36.617
So, to answer the question
about how often,

135
00:07:36.617 --> 00:07:41.572
we'll we're still having that sort of
well, it depends answer but we're getting

136
00:07:41.572 --> 00:07:46.770
a little more specific because we're
talking about each individual stage.

137
00:07:46.770 --> 00:07:50.890
And during each stage, we want to
be continuing to ask the question,

138
00:07:50.890 --> 00:07:52.889
is this project still relevant?

139
00:07:52.889 --> 00:07:59.024
Are we still delivering what we need to do
deliver to meet the needs of the business?

140
00:07:59.024 --> 00:08:02.371
And of course we're brining that to
learn from experience as well and.

141
00:08:02.371 --> 00:08:05.444
None of these should be
treated in isolation?

142
00:08:05.444 --> 00:08:10.011
I do not expect you to have one person
managing the business justification, and

143
00:08:10.011 --> 00:08:12.604
another person looking at lessons learned,

144
00:08:12.604 --> 00:08:16.580
and another person who defines roles and
responsibilities.

145
00:08:16.580 --> 00:08:20.350
All of these are the responsibility
of the project board.

146
00:08:20.350 --> 00:08:23.200
But again, that's something else we'll
look at in a little bit more depth.

147
00:08:24.350 --> 00:08:25.430
He's still looking pensive.

148
00:08:25.430 --> 00:08:26.520
That worries me.

149
00:08:26.520 --> 00:08:27.110
>> No.

150
00:08:27.110 --> 00:08:31.325
I was just thinking, I'm a little
bitter about some previous experiences.

151
00:08:31.325 --> 00:08:33.160
[LAUGH]
>> But I was like, so

152
00:08:33.160 --> 00:08:36.570
we shouldn't put people in silos
with single responsibilities and

153
00:08:36.570 --> 00:08:39.160
no communication between
respective channels.

154
00:08:39.160 --> 00:08:41.818
Because that's not an effective
way to manage a project?

155
00:08:41.818 --> 00:08:43.604
>> Funnily enough, no, it's not, no.

156
00:08:43.604 --> 00:08:45.700
>> Aw, man, I tell you what.

157
00:08:45.700 --> 00:08:47.610
It's eye-opening, Jo, eye-opening.

158
00:08:47.610 --> 00:08:50.430
>> I mean, personally I like
to work in asylum, but no,

159
00:08:50.430 --> 00:08:53.690
it's not really an efficient
way of working.

160
00:08:53.690 --> 00:08:57.520
>> Not when, now, if you're the only
person responsible for all these pieces

161
00:08:57.520 --> 00:09:01.830
and it's a very small scope project,
I doubt it's going to happen.

162
00:09:01.830 --> 00:09:02.360
>> No.

163
00:09:02.360 --> 00:09:04.140
Even then, right?

164
00:09:04.140 --> 00:09:07.370
If you're the only person working on that
project, and it was a really small scale

165
00:09:07.370 --> 00:09:10.370
project, you still need to be
interacting with the business.

166
00:09:10.370 --> 00:09:13.000
You still need to be interacting
with your suppliers.

167
00:09:13.000 --> 00:09:16.130
You still need to be interacting

There is no reason that we should

00:10:33.560 --> 00:10:36.600

00:11:31.220 --> 00:11:36.000
What that means is once we put our
plan in place, then we manage when

206
00:11:36.000 --> 00:11:41.310
something goes wrong but
other than that, we don't micromanage.

207
00:11:41.310 --> 00:11:46.440
The project manager doesn't need to
be involved in absolutely everything

00:11:46.440 --> 00:11:48.060

00:11:49.270 --> 00:11:53.598
There should be an understanding

00:11:56.146 --> 00:12:01.146

00:12:01.146 --> 00:12:06.727

00:12:12.160 --> 00:12:14.570

00:12:15.800 --> 00:12:20.190
that's when project management

216
00:12:20.190 --> 00:12:25.310
We manage by exception,
we do not micro manage.

I know that that's not true,

Justin you've been involved in a lot

00:12:34.400 --> 00:12:40.500
>> Yeah, micromanaging is the preferred

00:12:40.500 --> 00:12:41.760

00:12:41.760 --> 00:12:44.520
Without an appropriate line of

00:12:44.520 --> 00:12:49.310
to some extent trust,
I can kind of understand why people kinda

00:12:53.260 --> 00:12:54.330
I wanna know what's going on, I wanna,

00:12:54.330 --> 00:12:59.020

00:12:59.020 --> 00:13:04.420
If you're my manager and something goes

00:13:04.420 --> 00:13:08.820

this went wrong, what do we need to do?

00:13:08.820 --> 00:13:10.840
Let's make a plan, right?

00:13:10.840 --> 00:13:15.030
>> Right, if I'm project manager,

00:13:15.030 --> 00:13:17.540
And if I can't trust my team,

232
00:13:17.540 --> 00:13:22.110
then this is where you end up getting
into the realms of micromanaging.

233
00:13:22.110 --> 00:13:25.940
But as a project manager,
you have to have that self restraint.

234
00:13:25.940 --> 00:13:29.640
To understand that if you
micromanage somebody,

00:13:29.640 --> 00:13:33.520
it goes back to what we said in a previous

00:13:33.520 --> 00:13:36.100

00:13:36.100 --> 00:13:40.250

00:13:40.250 --> 00:13:42.600

00:13:42.600 --> 00:13:44.370
It goes back to trust, as you just said.

The focus for a project manager and

00:13:59.500 --> 00:14:01.300

We need to assemble the right team in

00:14:06.030 --> 00:14:10.150

00:14:10.150 --> 00:14:13.890

00:14:32.070 --> 00:14:37.360

00:14:37.360 --> 00:14:39.040

00:14:39.040 --> 00:14:43.310

Learn from experience is not just
