396
00:23:22.682 --> 00:23:25.376
well, can be found here
in our PRINCE2 book.

397
00:23:25.376 --> 00:23:28.897
So I would recommend,
it's not a requirement for this, but

398
00:23:28.897 --> 00:23:32.720
I would certainly recommend that
you obtain that PRINCE2 book.

399
00:23:32.720 --> 00:23:36.072
Now for this particular episode.

400
00:23:36.072 --> 00:23:39.186
Well, that's all we're gonna look out for
right now,

401
00:23:39.186 --> 00:23:42.232
because what we're going to
do is in our next episode,

402
00:23:42.232 --> 00:23:46.223
we are going to take a much deeper
dive into these PRINCE2 principles.

403
00:23:46.223 --> 00:23:49.473
And we're going to take a look
at each one of these in turn and

404
00:23:49.473 --> 00:23:52.203
how they actually apply
to the PRINCE2 project.

405
00:23:52.203 --> 00:23:56.859
So I'm going to invite you to join
us back again for our next episode.

406
00:23:56.859 --> 00:23:58.155
Well, Jo, I'm definitely excited.

407
00:23:58.155 --> 00:24:01.950
Now, before we get out of here,
I'm actually gonna ask you a question.

408
00:24:01.950 --> 00:24:05.332
So, I've met some resistence in
previous roles about people like,

409
00:24:05.332 --> 00:24:06.858
don't document the process.

410
00:24:06.858 --> 00:24:07.730
We've gotta move fast.

411
00:24:07.730 --> 00:24:09.170
We gotta get things done.

412
00:24:09.170 --> 00:24:14.170
So there may be some people out there who
go, documenting the process slows me down.

413
00:24:14.170 --> 00:24:16.220
What are your thoughts on that?

414
00:24:16.220 --> 00:24:18.086
>> Well,
I'm gonna talk to you about bureaucracy.

415
00:24:18.086 --> 00:24:23.188
Again, we talked about this a little while
ago in one of our previous episodes,

416
00:24:23.188 --> 00:24:28.289
and let's face it, none of us like red
tape, and I don't like red tape either,

417
00:24:28.289 --> 00:24:33.239
and this is why we'll tell you that you
should be tailoring prints to suit your

418
00:24:33.239 --> 00:24:38.630
environment, but also you should be
tailoring it for efficiency as well.

419
00:24:38.630 --> 00:24:42.241
So if I want you to do documentation,
you know what I'm gonna do?

420
00:24:42.241 --> 00:24:44.910
I'm gonna give you an efficient
process to do the documentation.

421
00:24:44.910 --> 00:24:46.772
I'm gonna create templates for you.

422
00:24:46.772 --> 00:24:52.620
I'm gonna do a lot of the leg work for

423
00:24:52.620 --> 00:24:55.500
you so that all you need to
do is just complete a form.

424
00:24:55.500 --> 00:24:58.880
I'm gonna give you the software
that's going to facilitate that.

425
00:24:58.880 --> 00:25:02.414
So as a project manager all I
need to do is just manage, and

426
00:25:02.414 --> 00:25:07.351
all you need to do is just undertake
the activities, and if you're undertaking

427
00:25:07.351 --> 00:25:11.498
the activities then the software,
the tools are going to help us.

428
00:25:11.498 --> 00:25:14.450
Now, a tool will facilitate
project management.

429
00:25:14.450 --> 00:25:17.780
It's not going to facilitate anything
though if it's not configured

430
00:25:17.780 --> 00:25:18.880
the right way.

431
00:25:18.880 --> 00:25:23.750
So what we have to do,
is we have to ensure that we do all of

432
00:25:23.750 --> 00:25:29.010
the configuration up front, and this is
why we talk about having consistency.

433
00:25:29.010 --> 00:25:32.710
If we've got consistant processes, and
we've got consistant ways of working, and

434
00:25:32.710 --> 00:25:35.360
we've got a tool to
facilitate that consistency,

435
00:25:35.360 --> 00:25:38.650
then your documentation should
be as minimal as possible.

436
00:25:38.650 --> 00:25:44.120
That's what I want to do, cuz I know as
a project manager, you hate documentation.

437
00:25:44.120 --> 00:25:45.480
I know that.

438
00:25:45.480 --> 00:25:47.020
I hate documentation.

439
00:25:47.020 --> 00:25:53.510
So I'm going to use
whaterver tools are at my

440
00:25:53.510 --> 00:25:59.540
fingertips to be able to remove
the documentation from you, why?

441
00:25:59.540 --> 00:26:02.892
Because if I ask you to do documentation,
it's gonna be of poor quality,

442
00:26:02.892 --> 00:26:04.405
because you hate doing it, and so

443
00:26:04.405 --> 00:26:07.972
there is no point in me banging my head
against a brick wall trying to get quality

444
00:26:07.972 --> 00:26:11.790
documentation [LAUGH] out of you when
I know you're not going to deliver it.

445
00:26:11.790 --> 00:26:16.130
So, much better for me to look for
a tool that can actually facilitate that.

446
00:26:17.310 --> 00:26:20.847
>> Now, Jo, I agree with you,
I hate doing documentation, but

447
00:26:20.847 --> 00:26:23.920
you know what I hate worse
than doing documentation?

448
00:26:23.920 --> 00:26:27.980
Having to pick up where someone left
off with absolutely zero documentation.

449
00:26:27.980 --> 00:26:31.269
So, I just wanted to get your perspective
on that, and well, we definitely have more

450
00:26:31.269 --> 00:26:34.559
to talk about when it comes to Prince2, so
you should definitely join us on back, but

451
00:26:34.559 --> 00:26:36.639
for now we're just gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

452
00:26:36.639 --> 00:26:39.633
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

453
00:26:39.633 --> 00:26:40.666
>> and I'm Jo Peacock.

454
00:26:40.666 --> 00:26:42.586
>> And we'll see you next time.

455
00:26:42.586 --> 00:26:48.660
>> [MUSIC]

456
00:26:48.660 --> 00:26:51.633
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Here we introduce the concepts of the principles that underly the Prince2® methodology and that are an integral part of each Prince2® project.
episodes.title: Prince2 Principles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.180
Welcome ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:07.533
I'm your host Don Pezet.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.533 --> 00:00:08.332
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.332 --> 00:00:12.430
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Greetings everyone and

5
00:00:12.430 --> 00:00:13.907
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:13.907 --> 00:00:16.099
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

7
00:00:16.099 --> 00:00:20.416
we're coming back at you with
more PRINCE2 2017 foundation.

8
00:00:20.416 --> 00:00:24.720
And in this episode, we're gonna be
talking about PRINCE2 principles.

9
00:00:24.720 --> 00:00:26.900
I was real scared I wasn't gonna
get that out, but luckily,

10
00:00:26.900 --> 00:00:32.840
we have someone who's a lot more masterful
over when talking about PRINCE2.

11
00:00:32.840 --> 00:00:34.480
And that's the one and
only Miss Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:34.480 --> 00:00:36.390
How are you doing today Jo?
>> I was great,

13
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:39.670
I was wondering where you were going
with that at that point in time.

14
00:00:39.670 --> 00:00:43.430
But no, we're okay.
>> Yeah, we're doing what, see?

15
00:00:43.430 --> 00:00:47.500
Already more masterful than
I even after that intro.

16
00:00:47.500 --> 00:00:48.609
>> Well, I don't know.

17
00:00:48.609 --> 00:00:49.363
>> [LAUGH]

18
00:00:49.363 --> 00:00:50.743
>> I haven't tried to say it yet, so,

19
00:00:50.743 --> 00:00:53.080
it might be that's just a huge,
big assumption.

20
00:00:53.080 --> 00:00:56.521
But yes, Justin's right, today,
in this particular episode,

21
00:00:56.521 --> 00:00:59.665
we're going to be looking more
at the PRINCE2 principles.

22
00:00:59.665 --> 00:01:04.452
I managed it, you just need practice.
>> Well, there's no arguing in that.

23
00:01:04.452 --> 00:01:05.842
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

24
00:01:05.842 --> 00:01:10.810
in terms of these principles and
you looked at these in the last episode.

25
00:01:10.810 --> 00:01:11.890
And in our last episode,

26
00:01:11.890 --> 00:01:18.270
we examined the principles that applied to
absolutely every single PRINCE2 project.

27
00:01:18.270 --> 00:01:22.070
What I want you to remember and
what I want you to take away from the last

28
00:01:22.070 --> 00:01:26.235
episode and something that's important to
carry through all of these other episodes

29
00:01:26.235 --> 00:01:30.560
are the fact that these principles haven't
just materialized out of thin air.

30
00:01:30.560 --> 00:01:33.980
These principles came from
that best practice but

31
00:01:33.980 --> 00:01:36.940
these principles need to be tailored.

32
00:01:38.150 --> 00:01:45.830
And the simple fact is that I've already
mentioned, PRINCE2 is not plug-and-play.

33
00:01:45.830 --> 00:01:48.880
We're going to give you principles, we're
going to give you themes, we're going to

34
00:01:48.880 --> 00:01:52.600
give you processes and we're gonna
tell you what these processes and

35
00:01:52.600 --> 00:01:55.560
what these themes and
what these principles should achieve.

36
00:01:55.560 --> 00:02:01.960
But we are not going to give you a perfect
solution to manage all of your projects.

37
00:02:01.960 --> 00:02:06.070
It is up to you to take
what's in that PRINCE2 book.

38
00:02:06.070 --> 00:02:06.840
Remember the book?

39
00:02:06.840 --> 00:02:08.650
I think I've got a copy
of it on my desk here.

40
00:02:08.650 --> 00:02:09.820
Look at that.

41
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:15.420
You're gonna take what's in there and you
are gonna tailor it to meet your needs and

42
00:02:15.420 --> 00:02:18.280
to meet your project requirements.

43
00:02:19.550 --> 00:02:23.350
I can't do that for you,
certainly not standing from here.

44
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:25.830
And so when it comes to taking your test,
which of course,

45
00:02:25.830 --> 00:02:28.870
you do have that Foundation test at
the end of this particular series.

46
00:02:28.870 --> 00:02:30.570
When it comes to the test,

47
00:02:30.570 --> 00:02:35.390
you will need to remember that everything
that we're talking about is tailorable.

48
00:02:35.390 --> 00:02:38.330
Now on your Foundation test,
we're going to be testing the theory.

49
00:02:38.330 --> 00:02:42.220
So everything that we've covered here
is going to be based on the theory.

50
00:02:42.220 --> 00:02:46.450
But in your practitioner test, we're going
to be looking at how we can tailor and

51
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:50.760
how we tailor all of our principles and
our themes and our processes to meet

52
00:02:50.760 --> 00:02:54.840
the needs of each individual project and
to meet the needs of the organization.

53
00:02:56.390 --> 00:03:02.020
Which is why we talk about these
principles as being empowering.

54
00:03:02.020 --> 00:03:06.350
As, well, giving you confidence to

55
00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:10.520
manage your projects in a way
that is well, efficient.

56
00:03:10.520 --> 00:03:13.030
But it also meets the needs
of the organization.

57
00:03:13.030 --> 00:03:14.880
We're gonna give you
a really good foundation.

58
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:16.950
We're gonna give you
a really good framework.

59
00:03:16.950 --> 00:03:19.950
And it's up to you to
build on that framework.

60
00:03:19.950 --> 00:03:22.540
So do you remember what
these principles were then?

61
00:03:22.540 --> 00:03:23.700
Because right now,

62
00:03:23.700 --> 00:03:28.190
on the screen infront of you, you will
see exactly what the principles were.

63
00:03:28.190 --> 00:03:31.330
We mentioned in our last episode.

64
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:33.940
So this was continued
business justification,

65
00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:38.120
learning from experience,
having defined roles and responsibilities,

66
00:03:38.120 --> 00:03:43.390
managing by stages and by exception,
with the focus on products.

67
00:03:43.390 --> 00:03:46.600
And then as we've already mentioned,
tailored to suit the environment.

68
00:03:46.600 --> 00:03:50.490
And in this episode, what we're gonna
do is I'm gonna break these down and

69
00:03:50.490 --> 00:03:52.786
I'm gonna look at these
in a lot more depth.

70
00:03:52.786 --> 00:03:55.827
Okay, so we're gonna look at each one.

71
00:03:55.827 --> 00:04:00.733
Now, I've already mentioned in a previous
episode, that the slides that you see

72
00:04:00.733 --> 00:04:04.445
on the screen in front of you
are available to you to download.

73
00:04:04.445 --> 00:04:08.180
These are something that you
are going to need for your study.

74
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:11.060
We don't show all of the slides
by the way in these episodes.

75
00:04:11.060 --> 00:04:14.540
So take a look at what's available to you.

76
00:04:14.540 --> 00:04:18.300
They're going to help you in your
study when it comes to your test.

77
00:04:18.300 --> 00:04:22.020
But more importantly than that, they're
gonna help you when you are looking to

78
00:04:22.020 --> 00:04:27.000
apply PRINCE2 within the organization,
as a project management methodology.

79
00:04:28.100 --> 00:04:29.710
So let's take a look at
this first one then.

80
00:04:29.710 --> 00:04:34.090
The first principle we're gonna look
at is continued business justification.

81
00:04:34.090 --> 00:04:35.615
I mentioned in a previous episode,

82
00:04:35.615 --> 00:04:39.160
the business justification
is an ongoing thing.

83
00:04:39.160 --> 00:04:40.440
It's a continual thing.

84
00:04:40.440 --> 00:04:45.490
And if you remember, Justin asked
the question, how often should we look for

85
00:04:45.490 --> 00:04:47.390
business justification?

86
00:04:47.390 --> 00:04:50.580
Can you remember what the answer was?
>> Typically,

87
00:04:50.580 --> 00:04:53.450
at the end of stages is something
that we've talked about,

88
00:04:53.450 --> 00:04:58.060
where you reevaluate is what we're moving
toward, after this particular stage, is

89
00:04:58.060 --> 00:05:03.170
that still what we mean to move toward to.
>> Right, this is not, you're right,

90
00:05:03.170 --> 00:05:08.620
this is on a, well, I was going
to say a secular basis, secular?

91
00:05:08.620 --> 00:05:10.744
Does that make any, I don't know.
>> Cyclic?

92
00:05:10.744 --> 00:05:11.614
>> Cyclic, okay.

93
00:05:11.614 --> 00:05:12.280
>> Cyclic,

94
00:05:12.280 --> 00:05:15.547
like we reevaluate this at the end.
>> I hate that word.

95
00:05:15.547 --> 00:05:16.596
Right, yeah.

96
00:05:16.596 --> 00:05:18.980
Continual, I like the word continual.

97
00:05:18.980 --> 00:05:22.500
On a continual basis,
which is iterative, it's regular.

98
00:05:22.500 --> 00:05:25.329
Then we want to be reviewing
business justification

99
00:05:28.283 --> 00:05:33.234
We're not just interested
in whether the project is

100
00:05:33.234 --> 00:05:38.540
going to deliver what
it's supposed to deliver.

101
00:05:38.540 --> 00:05:41.250
In other words,
what's in our business case?

102
00:05:42.980 --> 00:05:44.847
That's part of it.

103
00:05:44.847 --> 00:05:49.401
But the other part of it, and you could
say, well, I was gonna say you could say

104
00:05:49.401 --> 00:05:53.700
it's the more important part but
it's certainly the first part.

105
00:05:53.700 --> 00:05:57.780
And the first part of this
continued business justification

106
00:05:57.780 --> 00:06:02.710
is actually asking yourself, whether
the justification is still validated.

107
00:06:03.810 --> 00:06:08.302
In other words, is it gonna meet
the needs of the organization.

108
00:06:08.302 --> 00:06:13.747
Cuz I guarantee that the needs of
the organization have changed.

109
00:06:13.747 --> 00:06:18.461
If you take a look at a project,
maybe once every six months, depending on

110
00:06:18.461 --> 00:06:24.120
the lifespan of the project, then who's
to say that what's happening now.

111
00:06:24.120 --> 00:06:26.690
And what's happening in six months time,
well,

112
00:06:26.690 --> 00:06:30.550
who's to say that they are both gonna
meet the needs of the organization?

113
00:06:30.550 --> 00:06:31.890
They're probably not.

114
00:06:31.890 --> 00:06:36.830
What I'm trying to say is, if I look
back six months ago, did my phone,

115
00:06:36.830 --> 00:06:40.940
the cell phone that I had, did my
phone meet my needs, six months ago?

116
00:06:40.940 --> 00:06:41.759
Yes, it did.

117
00:06:43.030 --> 00:06:44.870
Have I got a new cell phone now?

118
00:06:44.870 --> 00:06:45.780
Yes, I have.

119
00:06:47.080 --> 00:06:48.490
Why have I got a new cell phone?

120
00:06:50.120 --> 00:06:51.450
It's not just because I want one.

121
00:06:51.450 --> 00:06:53.251
All right,
that's got something to do with it.

122
00:06:53.251 --> 00:06:54.357
I know, I'll admit that.

123
00:06:54.357 --> 00:06:58.263
But actually the reason why I've got
a new cell phone is because they released

124
00:06:58.263 --> 00:07:00.790
a new cell phone and
it had better features.

125
00:07:00.790 --> 00:07:04.150
It had something that I actually wanted.

126
00:07:04.150 --> 00:07:07.320
Which means that my wants,
my requirements changed.

127
00:07:09.820 --> 00:07:16.430
We talk about value having,
well, a perishable life.

128
00:07:16.430 --> 00:07:17.470
Value is perceived.

129
00:07:18.470 --> 00:07:22.940
The wants and needs of the organization
have a perishable life,

130
00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:24.690
value has a perishable life.

131
00:07:26.370 --> 00:07:32.030
If I gave you an Excel spreadsheet, or
a version of Excel from ten years ago,

132
00:07:32.030 --> 00:07:35.470
would you value that?
>> Absolutely not, it

133
00:07:35.470 --> 00:07:38.783
seems more of a headache than it's worth.
>> Right, well,

134
00:07:38.783 --> 00:07:42.220
it's exactly the same as any operating
system or anything else for that matter.

135
00:07:42.220 --> 00:07:46.041
We're in IT, we're in technology and
then the technology arena,

136
00:07:46.041 --> 00:07:48.328
something has a perishable shelf life.

137
00:07:48.328 --> 00:07:50.674
And you know what,
we're in the 21st century now and

138
00:07:50.674 --> 00:07:53.997
that perishable shelf life is just
getting shorter and shorter and shorter.

139
00:07:53.997 --> 00:07:58.779
Why do you think we start talking about
Agile when it comes to deployment,

140
00:07:58.779 --> 00:08:02.798
when it comes to project management and
intuitive projects?

141
00:08:02.798 --> 00:08:05.849
Because we want iterative releases that

142
00:08:05.849 --> 00:08:10.442
are going to meet the needs of
the organization at that time.

143
00:08:10.442 --> 00:08:14.980
We have to acknowledge,
we have to be smarter at this and

144
00:08:14.980 --> 00:08:19.990
this is why Prince2, certainly in 2017,
we acknowledged that we

145
00:08:19.990 --> 00:08:25.700
have to be smarter at recognizing that
the needs of the organization will change.

146
00:08:25.700 --> 00:08:28.370
In the same way that your
needs change variety,

147
00:08:28.370 --> 00:08:31.490
the organization's needs
variety will change.

148
00:08:31.490 --> 00:08:34.060
And they change very, very rapidly now.

149
00:08:34.060 --> 00:08:38.310
Which is why we have to ensure
continued business justification.

150
00:08:38.310 --> 00:08:40.780
And so
the first part of that is that validation.

151
00:08:40.780 --> 00:08:46.400
But then the second part of the continued
business justification is well, making

152
00:08:46.400 --> 00:08:52.490
sure that what we're doing, still achieves
the goal that we had set out to achieve.

153
00:08:53.780 --> 00:08:56.310
Sometimes, throughout
the course of a project,

154
00:08:56.310 --> 00:08:59.940
sometimes, certain
technologies may become, well,

155
00:08:59.940 --> 00:09:02.870
I was just gonna use the word redundant
but we don't like to use that word.

156
00:09:02.870 --> 00:09:03.806
I might say obsolete.

157
00:09:03.806 --> 00:09:05.779
I think that's probably
a better word to use.

158
00:09:07.190 --> 00:09:10.380
Certain technologies become obsolete,
they're replaced.

159
00:09:10.380 --> 00:09:15.710
Certain software becomes obsolete or it is
replaced, it's superseded by new software.

160
00:09:15.710 --> 00:09:19.201
Which means that,
what we're working on right now, well,

161
00:09:19.201 --> 00:09:23.241
we might have to change because if
that particular piece of software or

162
00:09:23.241 --> 00:09:27.144
that operating system has just
received an urgent security patch,

163
00:09:27.144 --> 00:09:31.457
then what we're working on right now
is gonna have to change to accommodate

164
00:09:31.457 --> 00:09:35.448

fall short of where I thought I would be,

392
00:23:26.690 --> 00:23:29.770
and all of that planning that I've
just done is a waste of effort.

393
00:23:30.860 --> 00:23:34.640
And so therefore, it's not just about
easiness, it's about predictability and

394
00:23:34.640 --> 00:23:36.810
it's about efficiency too.

395
00:23:36.810 --> 00:23:40.670
So I'm going to plan for
the short term in detail.

396
00:23:40.670 --> 00:23:44.590
I still have the same long term goal
in mind and at the end of every step,

397
00:23:44.590 --> 00:23:47.740
I'm gonna check that that long
term goal is still valid.

398
00:23:47.740 --> 00:23:52.470
I'm gonna check that I'm going
in the right direction, but

399
00:23:52.470 --> 00:23:55.350
I'm going to manage stage by stage.

400
00:23:55.350 --> 00:24:00.512
And I'm also going to manage by exception,
which as you see

401
00:24:00.512 --> 00:24:06.408
in the screen in front of you,
You'll see what our exceptions are.

402
00:24:06.408 --> 00:24:11.508
And so we want to think about tolerances,
for instance, where we've breached

403
00:24:11.508 --> 00:24:16.390
those tolerances in terms of time and
quality and scope and benefits.

404
00:24:16.390 --> 00:24:20.650
And again, we looked at those in a lot
more detail in a previous episode.

405
00:24:22.020 --> 00:24:23.830
We talk here about forecasting.

406
00:24:23.830 --> 00:24:30.610
Now, I'm not too sure, if we can go full
screen, you'll see the rest of that slide.

407
00:24:30.610 --> 00:24:36.910
We talk about forecasting tolerances, and
we also talk about efficiency, yet again.

408
00:24:36.910 --> 00:24:41.410
We're bringing efficiency
into our project management.

409
00:24:41.410 --> 00:24:46.291
And I always want us,
when we continue on managing

410
00:24:46.291 --> 00:24:51.288
that project,
I want us to focus on efficiencies,

411
00:24:51.288 --> 00:24:57.699
as well as focusing on another
one of our principles, products.

412
00:24:57.699 --> 00:25:00.533
PRINCE2 is, as it says there,
output-orientated.

413
00:25:00.533 --> 00:25:04.850
We deliver products to our organization.

414
00:25:04.850 --> 00:25:08.860
And a product is defined, and by the way,
any time during these notes that you see

415
00:25:08.860 --> 00:25:11.760
something in bold, that's something
that you'll need to remember

416
00:25:11.760 --> 00:25:15.750
because it's a definition that
could be tested in your exam.

417
00:25:17.060 --> 00:25:18.900
But a product is an input or

418
00:25:18.900 --> 00:25:21.720
an output that's described in
advance that's been tested.

419
00:25:21.720 --> 00:25:24.430
It's something tangible that we deliver.

420
00:25:24.430 --> 00:25:27.278
Or it could be something
that's fairly intangible, but

421
00:25:27.278 --> 00:25:29.486
nevertheless we still have to describe it.

422
00:25:29.486 --> 00:25:31.663
And we have management products,

423
00:25:31.663 --> 00:25:35.930
products that are going to help
us to manage our organization.

424
00:25:35.930 --> 00:25:42.072
And you've also got specialist products
that do certain specialist activities,

425
00:25:42.072 --> 00:25:46.730
that fulfill certain requirements
as needed by the business.

426
00:25:48.590 --> 00:25:51.845
We also mentioned scope-creep
in this particular slide, and

427
00:25:51.845 --> 00:25:57.460
scope-creep is something that, well,
I wanna draw your attention to.

428
00:25:57.460 --> 00:26:00.455
This is why we manage stage-by-stage.

429
00:26:00.455 --> 00:26:05.319
Because we are aware that if we've
got a focus on continued business

430
00:26:05.319 --> 00:26:10.050
justification, we are aware that
there could be scope-creep.

431
00:26:10.050 --> 00:26:14.290
That our requirements could change,
another reason for

432
00:26:14.290 --> 00:26:18.080
managing stage-by-stage.

433
00:26:18.080 --> 00:26:22.530
And then what we've also got to do,
lastly, and our last principle here is

434
00:26:22.530 --> 00:26:28.570
ensure that we can tailor to meet
the needs of the project environment.

435
00:26:28.570 --> 00:26:33.416
And that includes things like size,
complexity, a team's capability and

436
00:26:33.416 --> 00:26:35.774
skills, and also our risks as well.

437
00:26:35.774 --> 00:26:41.991
So every aspect of the project can be
tailored, including all of our themes,

438
00:26:41.991 --> 00:26:46.977
including our principles, and
including all of our skills.

439
00:26:46.977 --> 00:26:53.180
And well, even when you think about it, we
even tailor what we're going to deliver.

440
00:26:53.180 --> 00:26:56.810
We tailor it to meet the needs
of the organization at that

441
00:26:56.810 --> 00:26:59.120
particular point in time.

442
00:26:59.120 --> 00:27:03.050
Now, I mentioned the word tailoring
because in our next episode

443
00:27:03.050 --> 00:27:08.070
when we come back, we're going to look
at tailoring in a lot more detail.

444
00:27:08.070 --> 00:27:12.371
But for now what I want you to do is I
want you to download the information that

445
00:27:12.371 --> 00:27:17.445
we've got, the slide deck that you've got,
accompanying this particular episode.

446
00:27:17.445 --> 00:27:21.910
And I'd like you to take a look back
through everything that we've covered.

447
00:27:21.910 --> 00:27:24.450
As always, we're always here in our forum.

448
00:27:24.450 --> 00:27:28.410
And so if you do have any questions,
especially leading up to your test,

449
00:27:28.410 --> 00:27:32.680
if you do have any questions,
then by all means, shoot us a question

450
00:27:32.680 --> 00:27:37.250
through on the Q&A that's available
on our course library on our website.

451
00:27:37.250 --> 00:27:40.100
And I'll be happy to
help as much as I can.

452
00:27:40.100 --> 00:27:44.135
But for now, well, we've taken a look
at our project principles, and

453
00:27:44.135 --> 00:27:48.640
when we come back in our next episode,
here's a little teaser, we're gonna be

454
00:27:48.640 --> 00:27:51.857
taking a further look at tailoring.
>> Well, I can't wait.

455
00:27:51.857 --> 00:27:55.111
And goodness knows that I have to
have things tailored for me, and

456
00:27:55.111 --> 00:27:57.790
I guess project management
is very much the same way.

457
00:27:57.790 --> 00:28:00.500
So definitely come on back, but for now
we're gonna go ahead and get out of here.

458
00:28:00.500 --> 00:28:03.260
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

459
00:28:03.260 --> 00:28:04.125
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

460
00:28:04.125 --> 00:28:05.122
>> And we'll see you next time.

461
00:28:06.856 --> 00:28:12.322
[MUSIC]

462
00:28:12.322 --> 00:28:15.453
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Prince2® is not a “plug-and-play” methodology and this episode discusses the need to tailor the project environment to suit the project objectives and the organisational environment.
episodes.title: Prince2 Tailoring
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.596 --> 00:00:03.177
To ITProTV, I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.177 --> 00:00:06.824
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.824 --> 00:00:08.382
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.382 --> 00:00:13.120
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.120 --> 00:00:15.703
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.703 --> 00:00:17.154
I’m your host Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:17.154 --> 00:00:20.965
And well, we’re coming back at you
with more PRINCE2 2017 Foundation.

8
00:00:20.965 --> 00:00:23.967
And in this episode we’re actually
gonna be looking at Tailoring,

9
00:00:23.967 --> 00:00:25.502
that's very interesting there.

10
00:00:25.502 --> 00:00:27.241
And here to help us along is Ms.
Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:27.241 --> 00:00:29.356
How are you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great.

12
00:00:29.356 --> 00:00:30.064
Thank you Justin.

13
00:00:30.064 --> 00:00:32.450
How are you?
>> I am doing fantastic as well.

14
00:00:32.450 --> 00:00:36.354
And we kinda left this off as a teaser
in the previous episode tailoring,

15
00:00:36.354 --> 00:00:37.830
that makes sense, right?

16
00:00:37.830 --> 00:00:41.955
We're kinda gonna make things fit,
kind of like the off-the-rack suits

17
00:00:41.955 --> 00:00:44.863
that I have to have tailored for myself.
>> [LAUGH] Well,

18
00:00:44.863 --> 00:00:46.937
that's pretty much what we're doing.

19
00:00:46.937 --> 00:00:50.256
We're not gonna talk about
off the rack suits, but yeah,

20
00:00:50.256 --> 00:00:53.586
this is exactly what we're doing,
we're making it fit.

21
00:00:53.586 --> 00:00:56.623
I mentioned in previous episodes,
and I say this a lot, actually,

22
00:00:56.623 --> 00:00:58.180
the PRINCE2 is not plug and play.

23
00:00:58.180 --> 00:01:01.529
You're not going to pick up all of
the principles it brings to and

24
00:01:01.529 --> 00:01:05.436
all of the things and all of the processes
is that all we need to have a project

25
00:01:05.436 --> 00:01:08.184
management methodology I
know that this will work.

26
00:01:08.184 --> 00:01:11.176
And then just take everything
straight out of the PRINCE2 books and

27
00:01:11.176 --> 00:01:12.551
then expect it to work for you.

28
00:01:12.551 --> 00:01:14.492
Cuz guess what's gonna happen?

29
00:01:14.492 --> 00:01:17.023
Chaos, that's what's going to happen.

30
00:01:17.023 --> 00:01:21.639
You cannot take a methodology
straight out of the book.

31
00:01:21.639 --> 00:01:26.756
Expect to apply it in your
organization and expect it to work.

32
00:01:26.756 --> 00:01:29.234
It's just simply not
going to work like that.

33
00:01:29.234 --> 00:01:37.207
You have to tailor before you can apply
the methodology in you organization.

34
00:01:37.207 --> 00:01:38.800
So what do I mean by tailor?

35
00:01:38.800 --> 00:01:43.787
Well, there's an explanation again in
your downloadable material that looks at

36
00:01:43.787 --> 00:01:45.677
the definition of tailoring.

37
00:01:45.677 --> 00:01:50.953
Now, I've mentioned before that wherever
we have a word in bold in the downloadable

38
00:01:50.953 --> 00:01:55.206
material, then that's something
that you will need to remember.

39
00:01:55.206 --> 00:01:58.692
You'll certainly need to remember
the principle for your test.

40
00:01:58.692 --> 00:02:02.140
So tailoring is described as, well,

41
00:02:02.140 --> 00:02:06.899
adapting a method or
process to suit the situation.

42
00:02:06.899 --> 00:02:08.793
This is not squeezing it in, right?

43
00:02:08.793 --> 00:02:13.194
This is not sort of trying to fit
a round peg into a square hole or

44
00:02:13.194 --> 00:02:14.812
the other way around.

45
00:02:14.812 --> 00:02:17.856
This is not a case of squeezing it in,

46
00:02:17.856 --> 00:02:21.899
this is making it viable for
your organization.

47
00:02:21.899 --> 00:02:25.394
So this is taking a process and
saying okay then,

48
00:02:25.394 --> 00:02:30.185
this particular process is to
initiate a project, for instance.

49
00:02:30.185 --> 00:02:34.292
So let me look at what I
need to have happened in my

50
00:02:34.292 --> 00:02:39.554
organization in order to achieve
that particular outcome.

51
00:02:39.554 --> 00:02:44.984
We're not going to give you something that
is going to fit straight out of the book.

52
00:02:44.984 --> 00:02:48.027
We're not gonna give you something that's
going to work straight out of the book.

53
00:02:48.027 --> 00:02:52.399
What we're gonna do is tell you
what sort of steps you need and

54
00:02:52.399 --> 00:02:58.169
it's up to you to then define those
processes to fit within your organization.

55
00:02:58.169 --> 00:03:03.648
And you can tailor processes or themes,
you can tailor roles, you can tailor

56
00:03:03.648 --> 00:03:09.126
your management and your hierarchy and
how your project team is structured,

57
00:03:09.126 --> 00:03:14.361
you can tailor products, obviously,
you can even tailor terminology.

58
00:03:14.361 --> 00:03:18.017
Now, there's an interesting one.

59
00:03:18.017 --> 00:03:22.773
I have a lot of people that come to me,
because obviously my,

60
00:03:22.773 --> 00:03:26.506
I guess,
specialty is in governance models and

61
00:03:26.506 --> 00:03:31.383
things like PRINCE2 and PMI and,
you know, ITIL and Agile.

62
00:03:31.383 --> 00:03:35.828
And I have a lot of people who come
to me and say to me, but this is what

63
00:03:35.828 --> 00:03:40.771
it means in the PRINCE2 book and this
is the definition out of the ITIL book.

64
00:03:40.771 --> 00:03:46.752
And I say to them, that's great,
I'm pleased that you remember this,

65
00:03:46.752 --> 00:03:51.473
but what you need to remember
is the principle behind it.

66
00:03:51.473 --> 00:03:56.109
Because having a definition that comes
straight out of the PRINCE2 book is gonna

67
00:03:56.109 --> 00:04:00.759
help you pass your foundation test, but
it's not gonna help you apply any of it.

68
00:04:00.759 --> 00:04:03.068
What you need to do is make it fit.

69
00:04:03.068 --> 00:04:08.884
I don't care what you call your process,
I don't care.

70
00:04:08.884 --> 00:04:13.475
What I care is about the fact that
you have a process that facilitates

71
00:04:13.475 --> 00:04:17.435
the start up of a project but
I don't care what you call it.

72
00:04:17.435 --> 00:04:20.396
And so when it comes to terminology,
yes for

73
00:04:20.396 --> 00:04:26.089
your test you're going to need to remember
the terms and definitions for your test.

74
00:04:26.089 --> 00:04:30.234
But in order to tailor project
management to suit your organization,

75
00:04:30.234 --> 00:04:32.070
I don't care what you call it.

76
00:04:32.070 --> 00:04:34.314
I don't care what you call
any of the processes.

77
00:04:34.314 --> 00:04:41.587
You must adapt this methodology
to suit your organization.

78
00:04:41.587 --> 00:04:45.309
You adopt it as a methodology, but
then you adapt it to suit you.

79
00:04:45.309 --> 00:04:47.957
And then once we've done that, and

80
00:04:47.957 --> 00:04:53.518
this is another important part of
the tailoring, is that the processes and

81
00:04:53.518 --> 00:04:59.005
the principles and the themes are then
embedded into your organization.

82
00:04:59.005 --> 00:05:01.820
In previous episode,
I've talked about consistency and

83
00:05:01.820 --> 00:05:04.067
I've talked about the need for
consistency.

84
00:05:04.067 --> 00:05:07.495
So that everybody is aware
what they should be doing and

85
00:05:07.495 --> 00:05:10.857
everyone is aware of how
to achieve certain outputs.

86
00:05:10.857 --> 00:05:15.893
So that if I'm no longer around, well,
or not for the rest of this week,

87
00:05:15.893 --> 00:05:19.937
then if I have a consistent
product that is documented, or

88
00:05:19.937 --> 00:05:25.389
consistent process that's documented,
and Justin can pick up the pieces and

89
00:05:25.389 --> 00:05:28.799
Justin can run with this for
the rest of the week.

90
00:05:28.799 --> 00:05:30.149
So I've decided then that for

91
00:05:30.149 --> 00:05:33.887
the rest of these episodes that Justin's
gonna run with this for the rest of them.

92
00:05:33.887 --> 00:05:35.868
Is that all right?
>> Well, I tell you what, Jo,

93
00:05:35.868 --> 00:05:37.424
it's gonna be a totally different show.

94
00:05:37.424 --> 00:05:41.218
[LAUGH] It's gonna be, I'll tell you what,

95
00:05:41.218 --> 00:05:45.039
I probably making up a lot of terms.
>> [LAUGH]

96
00:05:45.039 --> 00:05:46.716
>> But since we are tailoring it,

97
00:05:46.716 --> 00:05:49.174
I'm gonna tailor the show
to my own use case.

98
00:05:49.174 --> 00:05:51.539
I don't think that's where
we are going with this, but

99
00:05:51.539 --> 00:05:54.724
you don't want me doing that.
>> Well, put it this way, it's not gonna

100
00:05:54.724 --> 00:05:58.207
get any body past the test, is it?
>> That would be a absolute no.

101
00:05:58.207 --> 00:05:58.793
>> That'll be a no,

102
00:05:58.793 --> 00:05:59.567
right?
>> Yeah.

103
00:05:59.567 --> 00:06:02.246
[LAUGH]
>> So who is responsible for

104
00:06:02.246 --> 00:06:04.294
doing all of these tailoring then?

105
00:06:04.294 --> 00:06:07.993
Well, you'll notice that on this
particular slide we've got a list

106
00:06:07.993 --> 00:06:11.566
here the responsibilities and
documentation as well Justin asked

107
00:06:11.566 --> 00:06:15.606
a question in the previous episode about
why do I have to do documentation?

108
00:06:15.606 --> 00:06:18.254
Or because you do [LAUGH] no,
it's not that.

109
00:06:18.254 --> 00:06:20.536
It's we run that consistency.

110
00:06:20.536 --> 00:06:23.395
If I don't document anything that I do,

111
00:06:23.395 --> 00:06:28.944
then when it comes to handing it over to
Justin for Justin to pick up the pieces,

112
00:06:28.944 --> 00:06:33.086
he won't know what to do,
which is why I have to document.

113
00:06:33.086 --> 00:06:36.391
I'm not saying that document
needs to be complex.

114
00:06:36.391 --> 00:06:41.671
And we want to have the tools in place
to facilitate the documentation.

115
00:06:41.671 --> 00:06:45.009
But we also need to define roles and
responsibilities.

116
00:06:45.009 --> 00:06:47.325
And those roles and responsibilities and

117
00:06:47.325 --> 00:06:51.043
the activities that they need to
undertake need to be documented.

118
00:06:51.043 --> 00:06:55.119
So responsibilities for
tailoring of PRINCE2 then, for

119
00:06:55.119 --> 00:07:00.524
tailoring the project management
methodology lie with the project board and

120
00:07:00.524 --> 00:07:04.532
the project manager,
within each team manager as well.

121
00:07:04.532 --> 00:07:08.925
So within each team that
manager has a responsibility

122
00:07:08.925 --> 00:07:13.034
to tailor activities,
to suit the environment.

123
00:07:13.034 --> 00:07:17.604
Remembering that every single
project is going to be different.

124
00:07:17.604 --> 00:07:21.132
No two projects are going to be the same.

125
00:07:21.132 --> 00:07:22.808
There needs to be consistency.

126
00:07:22.808 --> 00:07:27.209
But we have to tailor to meet
the needs of the project and

127
00:07:27.209 --> 00:07:30.378
to meet the needs of the organization.

128
00:07:30.378 --> 00:07:36.656
So we want to ensure that we have
assurance for every single project.

129
00:07:36.656 --> 00:07:41.876
And that we have, well, QA,
Quality Assurance and Project Assurance.

130
00:07:41.876 --> 00:07:45.197
Making sure that the project's
going to do the right thing,

131
00:07:45.197 --> 00:07:49.179
but also making sure that the product
that we deliver is the right thing.

132
00:07:49.179 --> 00:07:51.249
Well, that's gonna be tailored for

133
00:07:51.249 --> 00:07:54.535
every single project because
each project is different.

134
00:07:54.535 --> 00:07:58.057
It has a different outcome that's
required, a different output.

135
00:08:00.211 --> 00:08:02.526
That's a pensive look that I
see coming from you Justin.

136
00:08:02.526 --> 00:08:03.811
>> It's probably nothing mindblowing.

137
00:08:03.811 --> 00:08:07.118
I'm just trying to figure out what PID
stands for, but we haven't go there yet.

138
00:08:07.118 --> 00:08:09.442
>> We haven't got there yet, no.

139
00:08:09.442 --> 00:08:11.017
>> I'm jumping ahead a little bit,

140
00:08:11.017 --> 00:08:15.009
I'm like what is it cuz all I can think of
is process identifier, but I'm pretty sure

141
00:08:15.009 --> 00:08:19.610
that's not what it is or maybe I'm wrong.
>> Maybe you are.

142
00:08:19.610 --> 00:08:24.241
Maybe I should just give you a quiz.
>> We do enough of that in these episodes,

143
00:08:24.241 --> 00:08:25.145
Jo.
>> [LAUGH]

144
00:08:25.145 --> 00:08:26.217
>> Most of the time it's just,

145
00:08:26.217 --> 00:08:26.802
I don't know.

146
00:08:26.802 --> 00:08:29.615
By the way, is there a I don't know

147
00:08:29.615 --> 00:08:31.464
checkbox on the exam?

148
00:08:31.464 --> 00:08:32.597
>> No.
>> Okay.

149
00:08:32.597 --> 00:08:33.287
>> No, no, no,

150
00:08:33.287 --> 00:08:34.789
there isn't an I don't know.

151
00:08:34.789 --> 00:08:37.817
And you're never gonna be asked about
acronyms by the way on your exam.

152
00:08:37.817 --> 00:08:41.360
Your acronyms are always
going to be spelled out.

And we're gonna use that to help us
to implement a consistent approach

381
00:23:32.950 --> 00:23:34.960
to project management.

382
00:23:34.960 --> 00:23:38.188
Cuz all I need is one person who's
gonna be negative about this and

383
00:23:38.188 --> 00:23:40.784
that's going to undermine
absolutely everybody.

384
00:23:40.784 --> 00:23:47.254
So I want to ensure that we have
got everybody on board with this.

385
00:23:47.254 --> 00:23:53.718
And that I develop those capabilities for
project management in everybody,

386
00:23:53.718 --> 00:24:00.189
including in all of the processes and
the people and their behaviors as well.

387
00:24:00.189 --> 00:24:03.898
So think about the size of
the organization when we're actually

388
00:24:03.898 --> 00:24:05.416
implementing Prince2.

389
00:24:05.416 --> 00:24:09.126
When we're implementing a project
management methodology,

390
00:24:09.126 --> 00:24:12.070
do we do it all in one go
across all of our projects?

391
00:24:12.070 --> 00:24:17.688
Or do we do it from what we
call an incremental approach?

392
00:24:17.688 --> 00:24:21.924
Which is every new project that comes in,

393
00:24:21.924 --> 00:24:25.322
we will use the new methodology.

394
00:24:25.322 --> 00:24:30.143
And then we've also got
something called stealth.

395
00:24:30.143 --> 00:24:34.101
Stealth is not about being sneaky.

396
00:24:34.101 --> 00:24:38.658
Stealth is also about
organizational change management.

397
00:24:38.658 --> 00:24:42.693
If we make a big fun fair about
doing something and then we try and

398
00:24:42.693 --> 00:24:45.740
implement it and
we find that it doesn't work,

399
00:24:45.740 --> 00:24:49.181
that can have quite
a demotivating effect on people.

400
00:24:49.181 --> 00:24:54.054
So what we may do is we may
actually implement Prince2

401
00:24:54.054 --> 00:24:59.146
methodologies in an incremental
way that is pretty much

402
00:24:59.146 --> 00:25:04.691
unnoticeable to the organization and
to the project teams.

403
00:25:04.691 --> 00:25:08.646
So we may start by using certain
terminology and we may say, okay,

404
00:25:08.646 --> 00:25:12.614
I've defined this terminology and
this is what I'm going to use.

405
00:25:12.614 --> 00:25:16.780
We may start by bringing in
elements of certain processes.

406
00:25:16.780 --> 00:25:19.080
So we're actually implementing by stealth.

407
00:25:20.700 --> 00:25:24.446
That's not a bad thing, that's not
something that you want to avoid.

408
00:25:24.446 --> 00:25:25.877
The use of the word stealth,

409
00:25:25.877 --> 00:25:29.701
you quite often think of as having
sort of negative, sneaky connotations.

410
00:25:29.701 --> 00:25:31.451
And that's not what it means,

411
00:25:31.451 --> 00:25:35.033
what it actually means is we
implement sort of incrementally.

412
00:25:35.033 --> 00:25:39.443
But the one thing that we've really got
to do is the bottom bullet point on

413
00:25:39.443 --> 00:25:41.477
that slide is really important.

414
00:25:41.477 --> 00:25:43.488
It's about engaging stakeholders.

415
00:25:43.488 --> 00:25:45.695
And it's about communicating with them.

416
00:25:45.695 --> 00:25:50.131
Including communicating where
we did something wrong.

417
00:25:50.131 --> 00:25:55.015
Just on that last bullet point, do you
think that we should communicate when we

418
00:25:55.015 --> 00:25:57.074
do something wrong?
>> Absolutely,

419
00:25:57.074 --> 00:26:00.943
mainly because I've been in positions
where people have not done that, and

420
00:26:00.943 --> 00:26:05.127
all it did was make a lot of other things
more difficult than they should have been.

421
00:26:05.127 --> 00:26:05.655
>> Right,

422
00:26:05.655 --> 00:26:08.824
it's also about establishing
trust as well, and

423
00:26:08.824 --> 00:26:13.133
it's one of the principles of
organizational change management.

424
00:26:13.133 --> 00:26:17.792
Which, we have to ensure that when
we are making improvements we

425
00:26:17.792 --> 00:26:20.915
make improvements in an incremental way.

426
00:26:20.915 --> 00:26:25.471
But that we not only communicate success,
but we communicate failure as well,

427
00:26:25.471 --> 00:26:27.789
because we've got to establish trust.

428
00:26:27.789 --> 00:26:32.201
If I think that everything
that you do goes perfectly.

429
00:26:32.201 --> 00:26:35.989
Do you think I believe that?
>> I think you create-

430
00:26:35.989 --> 00:26:36.814
>> The answer's no.

431
00:26:36.814 --> 00:26:37.452
>> Either-

432
00:26:37.452 --> 00:26:38.165
>> No.

433
00:26:38.165 --> 00:26:38.904
>> Either you don't believe it-

434
00:26:38.904 --> 00:26:39.894
>> The answer is definitely,

435
00:26:39.894 --> 00:26:40.467
no, right?
>> Or

436
00:26:40.467 --> 00:26:43.450
you're creating unrealistic
expectations of me, for yourself, or-

437
00:26:43.450 --> 00:26:44.176
>> Right.

438
00:26:44.176 --> 00:26:45.930
>> For me that I cannot possibly attained.

439
00:26:45.930 --> 00:26:48.667
But either way, it's a negative thing.
>> In other words, I idolize you and

440
00:26:48.667 --> 00:26:49.676
I think you're perfect.

441
00:26:49.676 --> 00:26:53.325
Is that what you're saying?
>> Well, those are your words not mine.

442
00:26:53.325 --> 00:26:56.917
But, it's one of those things where-
>> We'll let him dream, all right?

443
00:26:56.917 --> 00:26:58.352
>> It can lead to that negativity that

444
00:26:58.352 --> 00:26:59.396
you're talking about.

445
00:26:59.396 --> 00:27:03.864
Like if you're always expecting
me to be perfection, and

446
00:27:03.864 --> 00:27:07.159
I'm telling you I'm not always perfect.

447
00:27:07.159 --> 00:27:11.078
But you lead me to that,
you make sure that I have that unrealistic

448
00:27:11.078 --> 00:27:15.370
standard to try to upheld,
then that would possibly make me negative.

449
00:27:15.370 --> 00:27:20.074
And now, I'm less likely to buy in
trying these things even if they

450
00:27:20.074 --> 00:27:24.206
are incremental in nature.
>> Right, I mean all of those are true.

451
00:27:24.206 --> 00:27:26.752
To be perfectly honest,
all of those are true.

452
00:27:26.752 --> 00:27:28.902
We've gotta communicate
not just the successes,

453
00:27:28.902 --> 00:27:30.807
but we've gotta communicate the failures.

454
00:27:30.807 --> 00:27:35.448
And I have got to make sure that
if I'm talking about you and

455
00:27:35.448 --> 00:27:40.968
I want to give you something to do and
I want to promote you as a person.

456
00:27:40.968 --> 00:27:43.725
Then, I can't promote you
as somebody who is, and

457
00:27:43.725 --> 00:27:45.917
I mean promoted you o the big wide world.

458
00:27:45.917 --> 00:27:48.664
I don't mean give you a pay raise
because that's not happening.

459
00:27:48.664 --> 00:27:50.607
By the way, just saying.

460
00:27:50.607 --> 00:27:54.552
[LAUGH] I want to be able to
show you as a human being, and

461
00:27:54.552 --> 00:27:59.465
to show that you're not necessarily
infallible, because people

462
00:27:59.465 --> 00:28:04.483
aren't gonna believe if I make you
out to be something you're not.

463
00:28:04.483 --> 00:28:07.086
And so
it's the same with all of our projects.

464
00:28:07.086 --> 00:28:10.531
It's not just about our people,
it's not just about our skills.

465
00:28:10.531 --> 00:28:12.636
It's the same with project progress.

466
00:28:12.636 --> 00:28:17.148
We've gotta ensure that we communicate,
not just our successes but

467
00:28:17.148 --> 00:28:19.731
that we communicate our failures too.

468
00:28:19.731 --> 00:28:21.638
Because that will bring people on board.

469
00:28:21.638 --> 00:28:23.795
That will get them to trust us.

470
00:28:23.795 --> 00:28:27.564
And that will ensure that,
actually, we do make progress and

471
00:28:27.564 --> 00:28:31.928
that people are not afraid of speaking
up during the project progress.

472
00:28:31.928 --> 00:28:36.735
And that people are not afraid of saying,
look, I didn't quite achieve this,

473
00:28:36.735 --> 00:28:39.695
I didn't quite get to where
I was going to get to.

474
00:28:39.695 --> 00:28:42.812
And that again,
is something that's really important,

475
00:28:42.812 --> 00:28:44.661
that honesty from our people too.

476
00:28:44.661 --> 00:28:48.860
We're not going to come after you if
you didn't quite achieve something or

477
00:28:48.860 --> 00:28:51.471
if you had an error in
doing your development.

478
00:28:51.471 --> 00:28:56.779
So in terms of then tailoring Prince2.

479
00:28:56.779 --> 00:29:00.108
Remember, as I've said
in previous episodes,

480
00:29:00.108 --> 00:29:03.608
we can tailor absolutely
any element of Prince2.

481
00:29:03.608 --> 00:29:09.140
Whether, it's the themes, or whether
it is our principles, or our processes.

482
00:29:09.140 --> 00:29:12.787
And as we move into our next episode,
I want you to come back for

483
00:29:12.787 --> 00:29:13.917
our next episode.

484
00:29:13.917 --> 00:29:17.826
Because we're gonna look at those
Prince2 themes in a lot more depth.

485
00:29:17.826 --> 00:29:18.330
>> Well Joe,

486
00:29:18.330 --> 00:29:21.586
I can tell you that Prince2 is starting
to fit me a little bit better.

487
00:29:21.586 --> 00:29:23.213
So hopefully, there you are as well.

488
00:29:23.213 --> 00:29:25.570
But you're gonna have to come
back to hear more about themes.

489
00:29:25.570 --> 00:29:27.382
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

490
00:29:27.382 --> 00:29:30.243
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

491
00:29:30.243 --> 00:29:31.211
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

492
00:29:31.211 --> 00:29:32.748
>> And we'll see you next time.

493
00:29:34.594 --> 00:29:39.909
[MUSIC]

494
00:29:39.909 --> 00:29:43.903
Thank you for watching, ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: The business case is a requirement of every project to provide a justification for the project and the Prince2® project has a focus on the continual justification of return (financial and non-financial) on the investment for the project.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes Business Case
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.582
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pazet.

2
00:00:02.582 --> 00:00:06.718
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:06.718 --> 00:00:08.462
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.462 --> 00:00:13.044
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:13.044 --> 00:00:15.594
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.594 --> 00:00:17.409
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

7
00:00:17.409 --> 00:00:20.558
we're coming back at you with
more PRINCE2 2017 Foundation.

8
00:00:20.558 --> 00:00:25.316
And in particular we're gonna be talking
about themes today, business case,

9
00:00:25.316 --> 00:00:26.318
in particular.

10
00:00:26.318 --> 00:00:29.202
And here to help us along is the one,
the only, Miss Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:29.202 --> 00:00:32.016
How are you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, thank you Justin.

12
00:00:32.016 --> 00:00:34.681
How are you?
>> I am doing fantastic as well.

13
00:00:34.681 --> 00:00:38.397
And, themes for some reason I always think
of pretty colors and stuff when I hear

14
00:00:38.397 --> 00:00:41.840
the word theme, but I don't think
that's where we're going with this,

15
00:00:41.840 --> 00:00:42.505
right?
>> Well,

16
00:00:42.505 --> 00:00:43.906
[LAUGH] I mean it's entirely up to you.

17
00:00:43.906 --> 00:00:48.306
If you wanna do your business case in pink
and pale purple, something like that,

18
00:00:48.306 --> 00:00:51.099
that's entirely up to you,
I'm not gonna judge.

19
00:00:51.099 --> 00:00:52.439
I mean but
that's not what I was going to [CROSSTALK]

20
00:00:52.439 --> 00:00:53.263
>> I feel like you're

21
00:00:53.263 --> 00:00:56.178
judging me right now.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah that is a possibility.

22
00:00:56.178 --> 00:00:57.861
>> [LAUGH]

23
00:00:57.861 --> 00:00:59.413
>> That's all I'm saying.

24
00:00:59.413 --> 00:01:04.181
Now what we're gonna do is we're actually
just going to pick up on the PRINCE2

25
00:01:04.181 --> 00:01:04.770
themes.

26
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:09.211
We explored them in really high level
in one of our previous episodes.

27
00:01:09.211 --> 00:01:13.270
And we've got a graphic aid just
to remind you what the themes are.

28
00:01:13.270 --> 00:01:16.760
And that graphic's coming up
on your screen right now.

29
00:01:16.760 --> 00:01:21.020
So remember, the themes are those
aspects of the project that

30
00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:23.720
have gotta be addressed
throughout the project.

31
00:01:23.720 --> 00:01:28.110
And you'll see here we've got
seven themes, business case,

32
00:01:28.110 --> 00:01:33.870
organization, progress, change,
quality, risk, and plans.

33
00:01:33.870 --> 00:01:35.400
And the first thing that
we're gonna look at,

34
00:01:35.400 --> 00:01:40.400
then in this particular episode is
the theme of the business case.

35
00:01:40.400 --> 00:01:43.380
So what is a business case?

36
00:01:43.380 --> 00:01:48.610
Well, the business case theme,
as an aspect of the project,

37
00:01:48.610 --> 00:01:52.960
is here to ensure that we
compile a business case.

38
00:01:54.130 --> 00:02:00.010
And that we've got mechanisms to judge
whether the project is desirable,

39
00:02:00.010 --> 00:02:01.920
viable, and achievable.

40
00:02:03.650 --> 00:02:07.248
It's about supporting decision making.

41
00:02:07.248 --> 00:02:12.638
A business case is a document, and we
think of it traditionally as a document.

42
00:02:12.638 --> 00:02:17.756
It doesn't necessarily have to
be a specific document itself,

43
00:02:17.756 --> 00:02:22.778
but it is certainly a representation,
not even a reputation,

44
00:02:22.778 --> 00:02:28.274
but a representation of the return
on investment of any new product,

45
00:02:28.274 --> 00:02:30.670
or any change to any product.

46
00:02:31.950 --> 00:02:36.770
Let's think about this as being
the reason why we want to

47
00:02:36.770 --> 00:02:39.360
implement a particular product.

48
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:43.885
It's the reason why we want to,
well deliver this

49
00:02:43.885 --> 00:02:48.755
particular project, and
we wanna make this change.

50
00:02:48.755 --> 00:02:51.127
This is what a business case is.

51
00:02:51.127 --> 00:02:54.441
And so the business case theme,
not only makes sure

52
00:02:54.441 --> 00:03:00.220
that we have a viable business case,
but also that we have a viable product.

53
00:03:00.220 --> 00:03:05.660
And that we are going to
evaluate that viable product and

54
00:03:05.660 --> 00:03:09.700
the viable business case
throughout the project.

55
00:03:09.700 --> 00:03:14.660
Remember, we're going to continually
justify the business base.

56
00:03:14.660 --> 00:03:18.160
This is just a one off thing that we do.

57
00:03:18.160 --> 00:03:22.407
We don't just want a business case
at the beginning of our project,

58
00:03:22.407 --> 00:03:26.431
we want a business case throughout
our project that is viable and

59
00:03:26.431 --> 00:03:29.131
that meets the needs of the organization.

60
00:03:29.131 --> 00:03:30.315
In other words,

61
00:03:30.315 --> 00:03:35.647
ensuring that what we are delivering
meets the needs of the organization.

62
00:03:35.647 --> 00:03:36.826
So let's take a look.

63
00:03:36.826 --> 00:03:42.284
And again, this is from our PRINCE2, I had
to think about what work we were on there.

64
00:03:42.284 --> 00:03:45.430
[LAUGH] This is from our PRINCE2 manual.

65
00:03:45.430 --> 00:03:48.310
So this is our official PRINCE2 manual.

66
00:03:48.310 --> 00:03:52.100
And here you'll see, that what we
have are the outputs, outcomes, and

67
00:03:52.100 --> 00:03:55.275
benefits of the business case thing.

68
00:03:57.030 --> 00:04:01.800
Now what we want to do,
is make sure that we have got all

69
00:04:01.800 --> 00:04:07.080
of our business changes considered
within the business case thing.

70
00:04:07.080 --> 00:04:10.330
That we have considered
any side effects and

71
00:04:10.330 --> 00:04:14.670
any consequences when we
document the business case.

72
00:04:14.670 --> 00:04:17.518
That we've considered any risks, or

73
00:04:17.518 --> 00:04:22.700
anything that might jeopardize
this particular new product.

74
00:04:22.700 --> 00:04:26.216
Or anything that might come
out of this new product

75
00:04:26.216 --> 00:04:30.750
that is not necessarily gonna be
a benefit to the organisation.

76
00:04:30.750 --> 00:04:32.077
What do I mean by that?

77
00:04:32.077 --> 00:04:34.772
Well let's think about this from
a more practical perspective.

78
00:04:34.772 --> 00:04:39.476
Sometimes we implement a new
operating system for instance.

79
00:04:39.476 --> 00:04:42.408
And by implementing that
new operating system,

80
00:04:42.408 --> 00:04:46.310
we might implement tighter
security measures.

81
00:04:46.310 --> 00:04:51.492
But as a result of that it means
that we have a new password policy,

82
00:04:51.492 --> 00:04:57.729
and that new password policy is so tight,
that it actually becomes insecure.

83
00:04:57.729 --> 00:05:02.052
Because people then start writing
passwords down on post it notes and

84
00:05:02.052 --> 00:05:05.489
pieces of paper and
leaving it under keyboards, etc.

85
00:05:05.489 --> 00:05:08.481
That's what we'd call a disbenefit.

86
00:05:08.481 --> 00:05:12.820
That's actually, well,
a risk that we have to consider.

87
00:05:12.820 --> 00:05:17.140
It's something that is not
a benefit to the organization.

88
00:05:17.140 --> 00:05:23.527
Something that is a result of
implementing that new product.

89
00:05:23.527 --> 00:05:26.652
What I really want you to remember
is the fact, [INAUDIBLE] and

90
00:05:26.652 --> 00:05:30.467
what I want you to consider is the fact
that, not everything is positive.

91
00:05:30.467 --> 00:05:34.954
And when we bring in a new product,
when we do something new for

92
00:05:34.954 --> 00:05:39.980
the organization, sometimes
the results are not always positive.

93
00:05:39.980 --> 00:05:45.690
And so we have to ensure that our business
case documents all of the results,

94
00:05:45.690 --> 00:05:47.480
including the benefits.

95
00:05:47.480 --> 00:05:51.040
We have to ensure that we are meeting
the needs of the organization,

96
00:05:51.040 --> 00:05:55.820
maybe the strategic objectives as we have
in the bottom right hand corner, but

97
00:05:55.820 --> 00:06:01.130
that we are also able to
quantify any potential, well,

98
00:06:01.130 --> 00:06:03.160
this benefits as they're called.

99
00:06:03.160 --> 00:06:07.280
Something that is an adverse effect

100
00:06:07.280 --> 00:06:12.290
of that particular implementation
of that particular new product.

101
00:06:12.290 --> 00:06:14.750
That also has to be mentioned
in the business case.

102
00:06:14.750 --> 00:06:20.630
So the business case itself, well, as
I've said, it doesn't necessarily have to

103
00:06:20.630 --> 00:06:25.340
be a specific document, but it's something
that does need to be recorded somewhere.

104
00:06:25.340 --> 00:06:30.370
So if we have a project
management tool that we use,

105
00:06:30.370 --> 00:06:33.500
we might have the business
case recorded in there.

106
00:06:33.500 --> 00:06:36.260
But it's about justification for
the project,

107
00:06:36.260 --> 00:06:41.120
it's about ensuring that we keep
the business case up to date.

108
00:06:42.730 --> 00:06:46.865
I was gonna be really sneaky and just ask
Justin another trick question as to how

109
00:06:46.865 --> 00:06:51.001
many versions of the business case are
there, but to be perfectly honest there

110
00:06:51.001 --> 00:06:55.156
could be as many versions as you need,
depending on how long that project was.

111
00:06:55.156 --> 00:06:56.562
Justin is looking pleased
with himself now.

112
00:06:56.562 --> 00:06:58.183
>> It wasn't gonna be a trick question cuz

113
00:06:58.183 --> 00:07:01.585
that's actually how I was gonna answer it,
as many versions as there needs to be.

114
00:07:01.585 --> 00:07:02.897
>> Yeah, yeah.

115
00:07:02.897 --> 00:07:04.940
And the business case is not just,

116
00:07:04.940 --> 00:07:09.943
I guess a common misconception is that the
