00:21:06.446 --> 00:21:09.637
That's definitely something that have
in organizations but it's not at

345
00:21:09.637 --> 00:21:12.735
the forefront of decision making and
could call some definite issues.

346
00:21:12.735 --> 00:21:16.379
But definitely come on back as we
continue to look at Prince2 themes,

347
00:21:16.379 --> 00:21:18.003
organization in particular.

348
00:21:18.003 --> 00:21:19.822
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

349
00:21:19.822 --> 00:21:22.622
So, signing off for ITPROTV,
I’ve been your host Justin Dennison.

350
00:21:22.622 --> 00:21:23.486
>> And I’m Jo Peacock.

351
00:21:23.486 --> 00:21:25.960
>> And we'll see you next time.

352
00:21:25.960 --> 00:21:31.775
[MUSIC]

353
00:21:31.775 --> 00:21:35.147
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: These 3 episodes cover the Prince2® Organisation theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Organisation Theme
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.143
Welcome to ITPROTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.143 --> 00:00:06.583
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.583 --> 00:00:08.263
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.263 --> 00:00:12.150
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

5
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:12.860
>> Greetings everyone.

6
00:00:12.860 --> 00:00:16.170
And welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPROTV.

7
00:00:16.170 --> 00:00:17.262
I'm your host Justin Dennison.

8
00:00:17.262 --> 00:00:22.020
And we're continuing on with our
Prince2 2017 foundation series.

9
00:00:22.020 --> 00:00:25.270
In this episode, we're going to be
looking at the organization theme.

10
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:27.275
And here to help us along is Ms.
Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:27.275 --> 00:00:28.240
How are you doing today, Jo?

12
00:00:28.240 --> 00:00:29.530
>> Absolutely great, thank you, Justin.

13
00:00:29.530 --> 00:00:30.300
How are you?

14
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:32.164
>> I am doing fantastic.

15
00:00:32.164 --> 00:00:37.273
Now, organization,
seems like that could be macroscopic,

16
00:00:37.273 --> 00:00:40.330
talking about the actual business.

17
00:00:40.330 --> 00:00:43.155
Or are we talking about how I
put the pencils on my desk?

18
00:00:43.155 --> 00:00:47.517
>> [LAUGH] What probably a little bit of
both to be perfectly honest, it depends on

19
00:00:47.517 --> 00:00:52.770
how sort you obsessive you wanna get with
putting your pencil in your desk, really.

20
00:00:52.770 --> 00:00:56.190
No, I'll be serious, I am not interested
in putting a pencils on your desk.

21
00:00:56.190 --> 00:00:58.440
What I am interested in though,

22
00:00:58.440 --> 00:01:02.690
is how we organize ourselves to
be able to deliver a project?

23
00:01:02.690 --> 00:01:05.602
You've seen an organizational chart,
right?

24
00:01:05.602 --> 00:01:09.298
>> Are we talking about like hierarchical,
like the chief executive, and COO,

25
00:01:09.298 --> 00:01:10.492
CIO and-
>> Yep.

26
00:01:10.492 --> 00:01:11.507
>> And who reports to them?

27
00:01:11.507 --> 00:01:14.455
Yeah, I've seen this.
>> Right, so what we're going to do is

28
00:01:14.455 --> 00:01:19.279
we're going to take a look at
an organization chart for a project.

29
00:01:19.279 --> 00:01:22.790
Now, there are a couple of things that
I want you to remember for a project.

30
00:01:22.790 --> 00:01:27.370
And the first is the fact that
a project is a temporary entity.

31
00:01:27.370 --> 00:01:33.140
So a project is something that is set
up to deliver a specific product.

32
00:01:33.140 --> 00:01:35.750
So when we have our business
case established and

33
00:01:35.750 --> 00:01:37.620
our business case is
given the sign off and

34
00:01:37.620 --> 00:01:42.700
we have that justification,
then we will collect our project team.

35
00:01:42.700 --> 00:01:45.810
And that means collecting people
with all of the right skills, and

36
00:01:45.810 --> 00:01:50.800
assigning them the right roles and
responsibilities within the project.

37
00:01:52.010 --> 00:01:55.930
The bigger the scale of the project,
the more people you're likely to have.

38
00:01:55.930 --> 00:02:00.570
And that could include internal people,
it could include external people.

39
00:02:00.570 --> 00:02:05.200
So think about an organizational chart,
and

40
00:02:05.200 --> 00:02:07.830
then add in roles and responsibilities.

41
00:02:09.120 --> 00:02:13.870
Add in a hierarchy and
that's what we're gonna end up with.

42
00:02:15.690 --> 00:02:17.465
>> There's a lot of stuff going on there,
Jo.

43
00:02:17.465 --> 00:02:20.847
All right, so roles of responsibilities we
need a high ark a key, a high ark a key,

44
00:02:20.847 --> 00:02:21.444
a hierarchy.

45
00:02:21.444 --> 00:02:22.458
>> Yeah, one of those them.

46
00:02:22.458 --> 00:02:26.990
>> Yeah, one of those and this is just
an organizational chart where we have

47
00:02:26.990 --> 00:02:31.823
the list of respected individuals or
with roles and responsibilities is that

48
00:02:31.823 --> 00:02:37.090
now I'm going to abstract a way into
the departments or anything like that?

49
00:02:37.090 --> 00:02:40.480
>> Well, remember of course PRINCE2
is cross functional as well.

50
00:02:40.480 --> 00:02:43.770
So cross functional means you
cross the functional teams and

51
00:02:43.770 --> 00:02:48.540
the functional sort of,
the set up that we have within our IT.

52
00:02:48.540 --> 00:02:52.675
So we're gonna be pulling people with
different skills from different teams.

53
00:02:54.007 --> 00:02:57.481
And yeah, by the way, we're probably
not going to be needing the same people

54
00:02:57.481 --> 00:03:00.020
throughout the duration
of the project too.

55
00:03:00.020 --> 00:03:03.940
So we're going to be pulling
them in as and when we need.

56
00:03:05.200 --> 00:03:09.554
So let's take a look at
what's on the screen.

57
00:03:09.554 --> 00:03:11.068
Do you like the look of that?

58
00:03:11.068 --> 00:03:13.435
>> That's a lot of words Jo,
I'm not gonna lie.

59
00:03:13.435 --> 00:03:15.930
There's a lot of words and lines on that.

60
00:03:15.930 --> 00:03:20.880
>> You'll notice that what we've got
on the screen in front of you is just

61
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:23.210
a list of the roles that
we've got to fill and

62
00:03:23.210 --> 00:03:26.220
the responsibilities
that they have as well.

63
00:03:26.220 --> 00:03:30.171
So we've got somebody that
needs to provide guidance.

64
00:03:30.171 --> 00:03:34.981
And that means, providing sort of minimum
requirements of the actual project,

65
00:03:34.981 --> 00:03:38.093
guidance on how we're going
to manage the project,

66
00:03:38.093 --> 00:03:40.680
what are the stages going to be like, etc.

67
00:03:40.680 --> 00:03:43.640
And then all of the documentation
that goes along with that.

68
00:03:43.640 --> 00:03:47.256
We do like documentation, and
then we've got somebody that's gonna

69
00:03:47.256 --> 00:03:51.200
manage stakeholders, or we've got
a role that will manage stakeholders.

70
00:03:51.200 --> 00:03:53.340
We've got a role that will
deal with support and

71
00:03:53.340 --> 00:03:55.360
then all of the activities
that are under that.

72
00:03:56.830 --> 00:04:01.560
This is not an exhaustive, exhaustive
is easy for me to say, isn't it?

73
00:04:01.560 --> 00:04:04.285
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is not a definitive list.

74
00:04:04.285 --> 00:04:07.355
All right, this is not supposed
to be a definitive list.

75
00:04:07.355 --> 00:04:10.975
Over on the left-hand side, what you have
got there, and I wonder if we could just

76
00:04:10.975 --> 00:04:15.085
go full-screen for a moment,
because that left-hand side here,

77
00:04:15.085 --> 00:04:20.845
if I can find my mouse, just here, this
has come straight out of the PRINCE2 book.

78
00:04:20.845 --> 00:04:26.935
And you'll see that we've got corporate
program management or the customer.

79
00:04:26.935 --> 00:04:31.258
And then you've got a directing level,
you've got a managing level, and

80
00:04:31.258 --> 00:04:34.000
you've got a delivering level.

81
00:04:34.000 --> 00:04:36.070
And all of these have
got managers in them.

82
00:04:37.620 --> 00:04:40.560
So let's just take a look at this for
a moment,

83
00:04:40.560 --> 00:04:42.740
and we're gonna go through
this one slide at a time.

84
00:04:42.740 --> 00:04:46.970
But at the corporate level,
at the program management level.

85
00:04:46.970 --> 00:04:49.440
You've got somebody that's
going to be making decisions.

86
00:04:49.440 --> 00:04:53.043
What sort of decisions do you
think their gonna be making?

87
00:04:53.043 --> 00:04:54.750
>> The program management.

88
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:55.250
>> Yeah.

89
00:04:56.610 --> 00:05:00.660
>> I guess like a,
I have no idea Jo, I don't know.

90
00:05:00.660 --> 00:05:03.431
[LAUGH] It's above my pay grade,
I'm not at that level.

91
00:05:03.431 --> 00:05:04.684
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I'm like, I don't know.

92
00:05:04.684 --> 00:05:07.382
>> Well, that's probably above
a lot of our pay grades, but

93
00:05:07.382 --> 00:05:09.715
they're gonna be making
decisions on strategy.

94
00:05:09.715 --> 00:05:12.725
So the decisions that they're
going to be making there,

95
00:05:12.725 --> 00:05:17.020
are the decisions that are based on
the prioritization of the project.

96
00:05:17.020 --> 00:05:21.860
So we're here in PRINCE2 and
we're looking at project management, but

97
00:05:21.860 --> 00:05:25.530
somebody's got to give us,
well, direction.

98
00:05:25.530 --> 00:05:27.120
Somebody's got to give us strategy.

99
00:05:27.120 --> 00:05:31.370
Somebody has got to say, this is
how much money you've got to spend.

100
00:05:31.370 --> 00:05:33.612
This is how quickly I want it.

101
00:05:33.612 --> 00:05:38.858
And this is who we want it delivered to
and this is who's going to use it and

102
00:05:38.858 --> 00:05:43.120
this is who's gonna benefit and
this is why we need it.

103
00:05:43.120 --> 00:05:44.830
This is our justification.

104
00:05:44.830 --> 00:05:47.030
So that happens at that level,

105
00:05:47.030 --> 00:05:50.390
if I can find my cursor again,
that happens at this level here.

106
00:05:50.390 --> 00:05:54.293
That's this corporate management level.

107
00:05:54.293 --> 00:05:56.270
I mean, let's be honest.

108
00:05:56.270 --> 00:05:59.620
I have never come across an organization

109
00:05:59.620 --> 00:06:03.770
that has only ever had one project
in play at any one point in time.

110
00:06:03.770 --> 00:06:04.850
I mean, I don't know whether you have.

111
00:06:05.890 --> 00:06:08.060
No, there's usually
many irons in the fire.

112
00:06:08.060 --> 00:06:09.729
>> Right.
>> Regardless of where you are.

113
00:06:09.729 --> 00:06:14.632
>> And so, what's happening at that level,
and that's where the decisions are being

114
00:06:14.632 --> 00:06:17.824
made and that's where your
priorities are being set.

115
00:06:17.824 --> 00:06:21.927
This is also where decisions would be made
sort of part way through the project.

116
00:06:21.927 --> 00:06:25.468
But we discussed in a previous episode
about the fact that some projects

117
00:06:25.468 --> 00:06:27.450
are terminated unexpectedly.

118
00:06:27.450 --> 00:06:32.614
Some projects just, you know, we just
have to shelve them for whatever reason.

119
00:06:32.614 --> 00:06:35.970
Maybe they're no longer viable
from a business perspective or

120
00:06:35.970 --> 00:06:39.282
maybe the business has changed direction.

121
00:06:39.282 --> 00:06:42.120
And that's where that decision
is made at that level.

122
00:06:42.120 --> 00:06:44.670
So think about all of the roles and
responsibilities and

123
00:06:44.670 --> 00:06:47.690
who is involved at that particular level.

124
00:06:47.690 --> 00:06:52.550
This is not even at the project level,
but they're going to direct the project.

125
00:06:52.550 --> 00:06:56.023
So that's our corporate or
program management level.

126
00:06:56.023 --> 00:07:00.020
These are generally senior people,
these are our customers.

127
00:07:01.120 --> 00:07:04.300
While we're on the subject, do you know
what the difference between a customer and

128
00:07:04.300 --> 00:07:05.050
a user is?

129
00:07:06.420 --> 00:07:09.756
>> Customer pays for it, a user uses it?

130
00:07:09.756 --> 00:07:12.770
I guess maybe a customer is a paying user.

131
00:07:12.770 --> 00:07:17.510
>> [LAUGH] Not necessarily, no, you should
have just stopped with the first bit,

132
00:07:17.510 --> 00:07:19.110
cuz it really was that simple.

133
00:07:19.110 --> 00:07:20.950
>> That's when you gave me that sideways.

134
00:07:20.950 --> 00:07:23.083
I was like, I should keep talking.

135
00:07:23.083 --> 00:07:25.680
>> No, no, don't keep talking, stop.

136
00:07:25.680 --> 00:07:30.607
Know when to stop,
a customer pays, simple as that,

137
00:07:30.607 --> 00:07:33.901
but a customer is sometimes a user.

138
00:07:33.901 --> 00:07:36.380
That one could be a fairly difficult
concept to get your head around.

139
00:07:36.380 --> 00:07:39.030
So let's come up with another example,
okay.

140
00:07:39.030 --> 00:07:43.910
Justin, let me say that I took you
out to the coffee shop today and

141
00:07:43.910 --> 00:07:44.870
I bought you a coffee.

142
00:07:46.230 --> 00:07:48.050
Am I the customer or am I a user?

143
00:07:49.980 --> 00:07:51.280
>> You bought me a coffee.

144
00:07:51.280 --> 00:07:53.960
You're the one who paid,
so you're a customer.

145
00:07:53.960 --> 00:07:54.826
>> And what are you?

146
00:07:54.826 --> 00:07:56.510
>> I am the user of said coffee.

147
00:07:56.510 --> 00:08:02.636
>> Right, I didn't buy myself one though I
was just feeling really, really generous.

148
00:08:02.636 --> 00:08:05.300
So I'm a customer, and he's a user.

149
00:08:05.300 --> 00:08:08.200
However, I might buy myself one, too.

150
00:08:08.200 --> 00:08:14.440
And if I buy myself one as well, then
I am a customer, but I am also a user.

151
00:08:14.440 --> 00:08:16.190
How does that relate to IT?

152
00:08:16.190 --> 00:08:17.940
Well, really simple.

153
00:08:17.940 --> 00:08:23.460
Generally, our customers, well, they
could be users but generally they're not.

154
00:08:23.460 --> 00:08:27.210
A customer is somebody who has influence
over whether the money is spent.

155
00:08:27.210 --> 00:08:28.970
So it's somebody with the purse strings.

156
00:08:28.970 --> 00:08:32.420
It's somebody with
the budget to give to IT so

157
00:08:32.420 --> 00:08:36.690
a customer is generally somebody
in a senior management position.

158
00:08:36.690 --> 00:08:40.300
It might be a cost center manager,
or it might your CFO.

159
00:08:40.300 --> 00:08:44.490
It might be your sales director,
for instance.

160
00:08:44.490 --> 00:08:45.512
They would be a customer.

161
00:08:45.512 --> 00:08:49.250
So they're not necessarily using
the product that you are delivering.

162
00:08:50.490 --> 00:08:52.548
That's an important
differentiation to make.

163
00:08:52.548 --> 00:08:55.440
And it's just something
that I kind of want to

164
00:08:55.440 --> 00:08:59.650
pay a little bit of attention to because
I'm gonna go back to this coffee shop now.

165
00:09:01.180 --> 00:09:03.800
So we're going into a coffee shop.

166
00:09:03.800 --> 00:09:08.860
And I'm taking you for a coffee,
and I'm not having more myself.

167
00:09:08.860 --> 00:09:10.160
I'm just a customer.

168
00:09:12.600 --> 00:09:14.150
What am I interested in?

169
00:09:15.600 --> 00:09:19.614
In that relationship with that coffee
shop, what am I interested in?

170
00:09:19.614 --> 00:09:22.230
>> All right, so if you are not a user,
you're not having a coffee.

171
00:09:22.230 --> 00:09:23.449
You are only buying the coffee.

172
00:09:23.449 --> 00:09:25.528
I'm guessing price of said coffee.

173
00:09:25.528 --> 00:09:30.496
>> Price of said coffee, and
also whether the cup is full.

174
00:09:30.496 --> 00:09:32.938
>> Yeah, I wanna get value for money.

175
00:09:32.938 --> 00:09:34.711
Do I care about the taste?

176
00:09:34.711 --> 00:09:37.760
>> I'm the one drinking it,
so I would suspect not.

177
00:09:37.760 --> 00:09:40.938
>> No, right, but you're the user.

178
00:09:40.938 --> 00:09:43.500
What do you care about?

179
00:09:43.500 --> 00:09:50.350
>> The taste, the temperature,
what additives, if any, the texture.

180
00:09:50.350 --> 00:09:51.960
>> We're talking about quality, right?

181
00:09:51.960 --> 00:09:52.874
>> Yeah, yeah.

182
00:09:52.874 --> 00:09:55.463
>> I know he's gonna drag me outside for
a coffee in a minute.

183
00:09:55.463 --> 00:09:59.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You care about the quality, and

184
00:09:59.250 --> 00:10:04.412
yet as a customer, I don't
necessarily care about the quality.

185
00:10:04.412 --> 00:10:08.022
>> Now, I know every single one of you now
is sitting there going, that's not true,

186
00:10:08.022 --> 00:10:08.825
that's not true.

187
00:10:08.825 --> 00:10:11.610
But hang on a minute,
because we're building on this.

188
00:10:13.392 --> 00:10:15.800
And now I'm gonna get to the however.

189
00:10:15.800 --> 00:10:17.500
As a customer, I'm interested in value for

190
00:10:17.500 --> 00:10:20.850
money, because I am not
actually drinking the coffee.

191
00:10:20.850 --> 00:10:22.450
Therefore, I'm not a user.

192
00:10:23.880 --> 00:10:25.910
There is a but, and there is a however.

193
00:10:27.060 --> 00:10:30.900
Because you see,
if Justin doesn't like his coffee,

194
00:10:30.900 --> 00:10:34.840
if Justin's not happy with it,
maybe he gets burned with the temperature.

195
00:10:34.840 --> 00:10:41.030
Or maybe he doesn't like the taste,
there's something wrong with the quality.

196
00:10:42.110 --> 00:10:45.620
What's gonna happen next time I say
come on, Justin, let's go for a coffee?

197
00:10:46.740 --> 00:10:47.892
>> I'm gonna say no, or

198
00:10:47.892 --> 00:10:52.131
I'm gonna ask you, is it that place where
I got my face burned or it tasted bad?

199
00:10:52.131 --> 00:10:54.010
>> [LAUGH] Right, okay.

200
00:10:54.010 --> 00:10:58.140
And so you're gonna say no, or
you're gonna say, let's go somewhere else.

201
00:10:58.140 --> 00:11:01.030
So you are going to influence me.

202
00:11:02.250 --> 00:11:04.976
So users influence customers.

203
00:11:06.478 --> 00:11:10.680
Now, a customer can also be a user.

204
00:11:10.680 --> 00:11:14.140
So it gets a little bit
complicated there because then

205
00:11:14.140 --> 00:11:18.390
if I was also drinking the coffee and
I liked the coffee but

206
00:11:18.390 --> 00:11:23.030
Justin didn't,
then I would still have to listen to him.

207
00:11:23.030 --> 00:11:26.370
Now, I could choose to override him, but

208
00:11:26.370 --> 00:11:29.880
I'm not gonna do that because
I respect him too much.

209
00:11:29.880 --> 00:11:33.830
But ultimately, one customer and
500 users are saying,

210
00:11:33.830 --> 00:11:37.670
no, we don't like that coffee, then we're
not gonna go to that coffee shop again.

211
00:11:39.210 --> 00:11:43.910
So it's really important, then,
that the customer has a say.

212
00:11:43.910 --> 00:11:47.860
Because in that top left
of that particular diagram,

213
00:11:47.860 --> 00:11:51.620
we had our corporate program management or
the customer.

214
00:11:51.620 --> 00:11:54.626
The customer is paying for this.

215
00:11:54.626 --> 00:11:57.560
But the customer's influenced by the user.

216
00:11:57.560 --> 00:12:00.500
So this is our interaction
with the business.

217
00:12:02.210 --> 00:12:07.680
After all, we are here to give
the business what they need.

218
00:12:09.270 --> 00:12:11.361
That's why we're here.

219
00:12:11.361 --> 00:12:14.680
Still on that left-hand corner
then of this particular diagram,

220
00:12:14.680 --> 00:12:19.410

Do you know what language that is?

455
00:25:35.980 --> 00:25:37.825
>> A pre-agreed upon language?

456
00:25:37.825 --> 00:25:39.709
>> No.

457
00:25:41.681 --> 00:25:42.510
>> I-
>> [LAUGH]

458
00:25:42.510 --> 00:25:43.253
>> [CROSSTALK]

459
00:25:43.253 --> 00:25:45.094
>> I want to say English [LAUGH] but

460
00:25:45.094 --> 00:25:47.385
it's not what you're looking for.

461
00:25:48.625 --> 00:25:52.155
>> You don't communicate in English as far
as I'm concerned, so don't even go there.

462
00:25:52.155 --> 00:25:57.095
>> Well, we're not gonna get into
an argument of whose English is better.

463
00:25:57.095 --> 00:25:57.965
There's a word for it.

464
00:25:57.965 --> 00:25:59.605
It's at the tip of my tongue.

465
00:25:59.605 --> 00:26:03.890
I just can't remember It's not coming.

466
00:26:03.890 --> 00:26:06.280
>> Well, that wasn't the right thing-
>> No, it's not.

467
00:26:06.280 --> 00:26:07.425
I know it's not.

468
00:26:07.425 --> 00:26:09.370
[LAUGH]
>> The word is audience.

469
00:26:11.660 --> 00:26:12.970
You've heard me say this before.

470
00:26:12.970 --> 00:26:17.170
You know I have,
it's the language of the audience.

471
00:26:17.170 --> 00:26:20.760
If I'm talking to you,
it is not your job to try and

472
00:26:20.760 --> 00:26:23.500
figure out what on Earth I'm saying.

473
00:26:23.500 --> 00:26:27.550
It's my job to make sure that I
communicate in a way that I'm understood.

474
00:26:28.830 --> 00:26:31.960
Yeah, sometimes that just involves
me shouting at you, I know right?

475
00:26:31.960 --> 00:26:34.560
Because that's just
the relationship that we have.

476
00:26:34.560 --> 00:26:39.030
But that's okay, I'm all right with that
cuz Justin will just shout back at me.

477
00:26:40.290 --> 00:26:45.270
But ultimately, it's your responsibility
to make sure that you're understood.

478
00:26:45.270 --> 00:26:48.230
It is not your audience's responsibility.

479
00:26:49.310 --> 00:26:53.190
If I try and work out what Justin is
saying to me sometimes I just stand there

480
00:26:53.190 --> 00:26:55.750
and look at him blankly because I
don't understand what he's saying.

481
00:26:55.750 --> 00:26:57.410
But then he's used to that.

482
00:26:59.630 --> 00:27:03.300
But it's not my job to figure out
what somebody else is saying.

483
00:27:03.300 --> 00:27:06.680
It is the job of the communicator.

484
00:27:06.680 --> 00:27:10.590
It's the job of the person that is
doing the communicating to make sure

485
00:27:10.590 --> 00:27:13.440
that they are communicating in
the language of the audience.

486
00:27:13.440 --> 00:27:17.270
And therefore,
the responsibility lies on all of us.

487
00:27:17.270 --> 00:27:21.680
Whether we're at senior leadership level
or whether we are at developer level,

488
00:27:21.680 --> 00:27:24.460
the responsibility lies
on all of us to make sure

489
00:27:24.460 --> 00:27:28.520
that the person that you're
talking to understands.

490
00:27:28.520 --> 00:27:30.790
Whether that is an email
that you're sending.

491
00:27:30.790 --> 00:27:33.740
Whether that is a status
update that you're sending.

492
00:27:33.740 --> 00:27:39.310
Whether that is a conversation that you're
having on the phone or face-to-face.

493
00:27:39.310 --> 00:27:42.350
It's your job to ensure that
that person understands you.

494
00:27:42.350 --> 00:27:47.410
So you should be asking simple
questions just to ensure understanding.

495
00:27:47.410 --> 00:27:50.690
Clarifying questions like,
did you get that?

496
00:27:50.690 --> 00:27:52.690
Does that make sense to you?

497
00:27:52.690 --> 00:27:53.950
Put that in your own language.

498
00:27:53.950 --> 00:27:56.020
What do you think I meant by that?

499
00:27:56.020 --> 00:27:57.780
And I know that that sounds simple.

500
00:27:57.780 --> 00:28:01.747
And I know that that sounds as though it's
kind of what we have the same in England,

501
00:28:01.747 --> 00:28:04.780
it's kind of teaching your
grandmother to suck eggs.

502
00:28:04.780 --> 00:28:07.590
Which I've never really understood
that saying because [LAUGH] it doesn't

503
00:28:07.590 --> 00:28:08.221
make any sense.

504
00:28:08.221 --> 00:28:13.681
>> I would tell you that's an odd [LAUGH]
I can't say that we had some odd sayings

505
00:28:13.681 --> 00:28:18.680
but you did say it just like teaching
your grandmother to suck eggs, right?

506
00:28:18.680 --> 00:28:21.926
>> Yeah I know, I know-
>> I'm pretty sure that grandma got

507
00:28:21.926 --> 00:28:25.890
the word she used today, she already knows
>> I don't think my grandmother ever

508
00:28:25.890 --> 00:28:26.780
sucked an egg.

509
00:28:26.780 --> 00:28:28.490
>> Yeah, I don't know.
>> Anyway.

510
00:28:28.490 --> 00:28:31.660
>> This does bring up
an interesting point for me.

511
00:28:31.660 --> 00:28:35.090
So when I've done things like this,
when I say, does that make sense,

512
00:28:35.090 --> 00:28:36.910
can you give that back to me?

513
00:28:36.910 --> 00:28:39.790
Actually, there's kind of
this implicit trust or

514
00:28:39.790 --> 00:28:44.430
there's this understanding that you're
going to tell me if you don't understand.

515
00:28:44.430 --> 00:28:46.200
We're going to have open communication.

516
00:28:46.200 --> 00:28:50.160
Because I've spoken to people where I've
said, do you understand, and they go.

517
00:28:51.940 --> 00:28:55.700
And then a day later,
they finally come to me and

518
00:28:55.700 --> 00:29:01.030
go, well, I don't really understand,
that's not efficient.

519
00:29:01.030 --> 00:29:04.635
Do we have to make sure that is
the case when we're doing this

520
00:29:04.635 --> 00:29:08.200
audience-specific kind of interaction.

521
00:29:08.200 --> 00:29:09.430
>> It's a difficult one.

522
00:29:09.430 --> 00:29:13.040
It really, really is cuz culture has
a big part to play in this one as well.

523
00:29:13.040 --> 00:29:16.540
So it's not necessarily just about
the language that we're using,

524
00:29:16.540 --> 00:29:18.255
you've got culture too.

525
00:29:18.255 --> 00:29:22.200
And some cultures, it's considered
disrespectful to use the word no.

526
00:29:22.200 --> 00:29:26.400
So if I was asking somebody,
have you done this?

527
00:29:26.400 --> 00:29:30.130
The answer, if they consider
the word no to be disrespectful,

528
00:29:30.130 --> 00:29:34.400
I need to know that the answer that I'm
gonna get back is always gonna be yes.

529
00:29:34.400 --> 00:29:36.360
So if I say, have you done this?

530
00:29:36.360 --> 00:29:38.700
Then I'm always gonna get the answer yes.

531
00:29:38.700 --> 00:29:43.190
So the question that I then ask,
I have to modify what I'm asking, and

532
00:29:43.190 --> 00:29:49.130
the question that I then ask is, where
have you got to with this particular task?

533
00:29:49.130 --> 00:29:54.950
So we have to take responsibility
ourselves to modify our language.

534
00:29:54.950 --> 00:29:59.340
Which is why you'll quite often hear
me say, did you understand that,

535
00:29:59.340 --> 00:30:00.830
repeat it back to me.

536
00:30:00.830 --> 00:30:03.820
Did you understand that,
what does that mean to you?

537
00:30:03.820 --> 00:30:07.080
Did you understand that,
what are you going to do now?

538
00:30:07.080 --> 00:30:11.075
So it's not just a case of
accepting the word yes.

539
00:30:11.075 --> 00:30:13.835
If somebody just looks at me blankly and
says, yeah,

540
00:30:13.835 --> 00:30:19.025
okay, that shows that maybe they're
being slightly intimidated by me.

541
00:30:19.025 --> 00:30:20.428
I can't think why.

542
00:30:20.428 --> 00:30:24.305
[LAUGH] Or maybe they just simply
don't understand, in which case,

543
00:30:24.305 --> 00:30:29.420
then I need to take the time to find out
what it is that they don't understand.

544
00:30:29.420 --> 00:30:30.720
It's my responsibility.

545
00:30:32.070 --> 00:30:36.920
If I don't clarify understanding,
I'm going to ask you to do something.

546
00:30:36.920 --> 00:30:37.970
You are not gonna do it.

547
00:30:37.970 --> 00:30:39.740
You're gonna come back.

548
00:30:39.740 --> 00:30:41.850
You're gonna ask for
further clarification.

549
00:30:41.850 --> 00:30:44.208
After you sat there for
a day and thought about it.

550
00:30:44.208 --> 00:30:49.440
In the meantime, not only have we
wasted a day, which we have, but

551
00:30:49.440 --> 00:30:51.150
you've also wasted my time too.

552
00:30:52.230 --> 00:30:54.560
Because when I spoke to you, you said yes.

553
00:30:54.560 --> 00:30:58.840
And now you're coming back and
you're asking me again for

554
00:30:58.840 --> 00:31:04.920
clarification, and now I'm having to take
the time again to explain it to you.

555
00:31:04.920 --> 00:31:06.930
So it's not efficient.

556
00:31:06.930 --> 00:31:09.950
This is not about sort of apportion and
blame.

557
00:31:09.950 --> 00:31:11.780
This is simply about efficiency.

558
00:31:11.780 --> 00:31:17.010
It's not efficient for me to allow
you just to walk off having said yes.

559
00:31:17.010 --> 00:31:22.400
I'm always going to make sure that
you understand what the direction is.

560
00:31:22.400 --> 00:31:25.840
And while we're talking about this, and
we're talking about organization too.

561
00:31:25.840 --> 00:31:27.710
And we are gonna come back and

562
00:31:27.710 --> 00:31:31.070
we're gonna carry on this conversation
in another episode, by the way.

563
00:31:31.070 --> 00:31:36.330
But I want to leave you with this
thought for this particular episode.

564
00:31:36.330 --> 00:31:39.020
And that thought is, well,
it's a question really to Justin.

565
00:31:39.020 --> 00:31:42.540
How many meetings have you been and
that absolutely make no sense whatsoever.

566
00:31:42.540 --> 00:31:44.680
And didn't achieve anything at all?

567
00:31:44.680 --> 00:31:47.470
>> All the ones that could
have become an email.

568
00:31:47.470 --> 00:31:51.300
[LAUGH]
>> Send me a PDF or some check boxes.

569
00:31:51.300 --> 00:31:55.056
And I tend to try to read my
e-mail as much as possible.

570
00:31:55.056 --> 00:31:59.440
But I have been in a few meetings where
I just went, I don't really know why

571
00:31:59.440 --> 00:32:03.898
we're here or was I supposed to There
have been times where I've thought,

572
00:32:03.898 --> 00:32:05.845
did I come to the wrong meeting?

573
00:32:05.845 --> 00:32:10.620
Was that supposed to be for other people
because it was just crazy stuff going on.

574
00:32:10.620 --> 00:32:14.510
Now, Joe you said that we still have
a lot more to cover with, as far as

575
00:32:14.510 --> 00:32:17.890
the organization theme, which means we're
gonna have to come back with part two.

576
00:32:17.890 --> 00:32:21.249
Are there any final kind of parting
words for us before we get out of here.

577
00:32:21.249 --> 00:32:24.621
>> Well I kind of, while we were just
talking about this, I just kind of wanted

578
00:32:24.621 --> 00:32:27.640
to look at the last slide here
that we'd got about communication.

579
00:32:27.640 --> 00:32:29.840
Because we've been talking about this.

580
00:32:29.840 --> 00:32:34.191
And one of the things that we say in
PRINCE2 is that the project manager

581
00:32:34.191 --> 00:32:36.864
defines how we're going to communicate.

582
00:32:36.864 --> 00:32:40.547
And those meetings that I
was talking about there,

583
00:32:40.547 --> 00:32:44.670
I ask that question as kind
of a final question, really.

584
00:32:44.670 --> 00:32:51.080
Because I know that every single one of
you, every person watching this right now,

585
00:32:51.080 --> 00:32:55.615
including the two of us stood in this
studio, have been in meeting where

586
00:32:55.615 --> 00:32:59.480
we walked away and said, well that was
meeting that could have been an e-mail.

587
00:32:59.480 --> 00:33:04.353
Because we discussed a lot,
nothing was actually achieved, and

588
00:33:04.353 --> 00:33:10.567
everybody has walked away feeling as
though they don't know what they're doing.

589
00:33:10.567 --> 00:33:15.447
Or the most common ones that I've
come across are the meetings where we

590
00:33:15.447 --> 00:33:18.600
encourage what we call passive resistance.

591
00:33:18.600 --> 00:33:21.450
I say we encourage passive resistance.

592
00:33:21.450 --> 00:33:26.300
Passive resistance is
that type of person that

593
00:33:26.300 --> 00:33:31.020
walks away from a meeting, having said yes
and agree to absolutely everything and

594
00:33:31.020 --> 00:33:34.700
then does nothing about it
once they leave the room.

595
00:33:34.700 --> 00:33:36.990
That's what we call passive resistance.

596
00:33:36.990 --> 00:33:38.560
They're not being actively resistant.

597
00:33:38.560 --> 00:33:40.770
They're not sort of getting
their pitchforks out and

598
00:33:40.770 --> 00:33:43.560
campaigning against a particular proposal.

599
00:33:43.560 --> 00:33:45.310
They're just agreeing to a proposal.

600
00:33:45.310 --> 00:33:49.030
They're just placating the person
speaking and then walking away, and

601
00:33:49.030 --> 00:33:50.810
not getting actively behind it.

602
00:33:50.810 --> 00:33:54.210
And it goes back into
the executive leadership.

603
00:33:54.210 --> 00:33:57.350
But it also goes back
to the communication.

604
00:33:57.350 --> 00:34:03.050
And the fact that if you have passive
resistance within your organization and

605
00:34:03.050 --> 00:34:10.605
within your project, then you have
clearly got a communication issue.

606
00:34:10.605 --> 00:34:13.225
So that's where I'm gonna leave this.

607
00:34:13.225 --> 00:34:17.715
You know whether you've got communication
issues within your project.

608
00:34:17.715 --> 00:34:22.475
And when we come back we're gonna
go further into the layers of

609
00:34:22.475 --> 00:34:26.340
organization for
the project itself, and we're going

610
00:34:26.340 --> 00:34:29.950
to look at the various responsibilities
that there are at each layer.

611
00:34:29.950 --> 00:34:31.910
>> Well Jo, there's a lot to unpack there.

612
00:34:31.910 --> 00:34:35.470
I don't know, it's like it's bringing
back good and bad memories for me,

613
00:34:35.470 --> 00:34:37.870
so I'm kind of interested in
seeing how this resolves itself,

614
00:34:37.870 --> 00:34:39.700
and hopefully you're interested as well.

615
00:34:39.700 --> 00:34:42.620
So definitely come on back, but for now
we're gonna go ahead and get out of here.

616
00:34:42.620 --> 00:34:45.560
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

617
00:34:45.560 --> 00:34:46.310
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

618
00:34:46.310 --> 00:34:47.677
>> And we'll see you next time.

619
00:34:47.677 --> 00:34:54.136
[MUSIC]

620
00:34:54.136 --> 00:34:56.957
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: These 3 episodes cover the Prince2® Organisation theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes Organisation Theme Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.200 --> 00:00:01.160
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.160 --> 00:00:05.919
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.919 --> 00:00:06.616
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:06.616 --> 00:00:10.570
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:12.010 --> 00:00:16.290
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:16.290 --> 00:00:17.460
I'm your host, Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:17.460 --> 00:00:21.620
And we're continuing on with
our PRINCE2 2017 Foundation.

8
00:00:21.620 --> 00:00:25.120
And well, we're coming back with
a part two of our organization theme.

9
00:00:25.120 --> 00:00:28.110
And yeah, if you haven't seen it,
definitely go check out part one.

10
00:00:28.110 --> 00:00:31.546
This is part two, and here to help us
along and to further the conversion is Ms.

11
00:00:31.546 --> 00:00:32.130
Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:32.130 --> 00:00:33.810
How are you doing today, Jo?

13
00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:35.972
>> Absolutely great, thank you,
Justin, how are you?

14
00:00:35.972 --> 00:00:41.120
>> I am doing fantastic as well, and
I feel like we left off talking about

15
00:00:41.120 --> 00:00:45.830
communication and how that plays into
things, but Where are we going from here?

16
00:00:45.830 --> 00:00:49.060
>> Right, so in part one,
we took a look at, well,

17
00:00:49.060 --> 00:00:51.140
we took a look at the actual
structure itself.

18
00:00:51.140 --> 00:00:54.980
So we took a look at the executive level,
and then the project board, and

19
00:00:54.980 --> 00:00:57.550
project manager, and
the team manager level.

20
00:00:57.550 --> 00:01:00.050
And we just had a quick,
brief look at those.

21
00:01:00.050 --> 00:01:03.837
So we're going to go into those in a
little bit more detail in this particular

22
00:01:03.837 --> 00:01:06.160
episode and
we also looked at communication.

23
00:01:06.160 --> 00:01:10.306
And where I left off was asking
the question really simply is,

24
00:01:10.306 --> 00:01:14.308
what communication or
what language do we communicate in?

25
00:01:14.308 --> 00:01:17.315
And how many times, oh,no,
he knows the answer to this,

26
00:01:17.315 --> 00:01:18.945
already got your hands out now.

27
00:01:18.945 --> 00:01:20.255
Go on then, you're desperate to ask this.

28
00:01:20.255 --> 00:01:23.955
>> Audience specific language
is the language of the audience.

29
00:01:23.955 --> 00:01:26.165
>> Right, it is,
it's the language of the audience.

30
00:01:26.165 --> 00:01:27.935
That's what language we communicate in.

31
00:01:27.935 --> 00:01:33.600
And I also asked you the question, how
many meetings have you actually been in?

32
00:01:33.600 --> 00:01:36.235
[LAUGH] He's hanging his head here.

33
00:01:36.235 --> 00:01:41.224
But it could literally just been
a meeting that could have been an email.

34
00:01:41.224 --> 00:01:44.611
>> Could have been an, or it was just
a meeting for the sake of a meeting.

35
00:01:44.611 --> 00:01:47.310
>> Mm-hm.
>> There was like this compulsion,

36
00:01:47.310 --> 00:01:48.840
we should meet.

37
00:01:48.840 --> 00:01:50.065
I'm like, about what?

38
00:01:50.065 --> 00:01:52.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because, seems like a horrible reason,

39
00:01:52.910 --> 00:01:54.940
it takes a lot of time out.

40
00:01:54.940 --> 00:01:55.920
I can't tell you how many.

41
00:01:55.920 --> 00:01:57.398
I'm getting bad flashbacks.

42
00:01:57.398 --> 00:02:00.353
We're just gonna leave it as a lot.

43
00:02:00.353 --> 00:02:04.140
>> Yeah, and you know, I see sometimes,
client, I was gonna say diaries, but

44
00:02:04.140 --> 00:02:08.240
apparently, I've been told diary is not
the right word to use, it's a schedule.

45
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:13.160
A diary is something that you write
personal things in, so I've been told.

46
00:02:13.160 --> 00:02:14.420
Is that right?

47
00:02:14.420 --> 00:02:16.600
>> Are we talking about
language differences?

48
00:02:16.600 --> 00:02:21.300
Because a diary is definitely something
you write your deepest darkest secrets in.

49
00:02:21.300 --> 00:02:23.790
I've never heard that diary as a schedule.

50
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:26.268
I'm not saying it's wrong,
I just never heard of it.

51
00:02:26.268 --> 00:02:30.400
>> Yeah, yeah, I would look at my
diary for what I'm gonna do today.

52
00:02:30.400 --> 00:02:32.020
>> The more you know.

53
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:35.004
>> There you go.
>> Just a little added bonus right there.

54
00:02:35.004 --> 00:02:37.847
>> [LAUGH] So there, because this is
why it's important to communicate in

55
00:02:37.847 --> 00:02:39.110
the language of the audience.

56
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:41.380
Because sometimes you can make mistakes,

57
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:44.400
especially when I turn around to somebody
saying, let me check my diary and

58
00:02:44.400 --> 00:02:48.870
I'll get back to you and then they looked
at me going, why, what's written in there?

59
00:02:48.870 --> 00:02:52.430
So language of the audience,
remember that one.

60
00:02:52.430 --> 00:02:57.410

The organizational charts can take many

We're going to look specifically at this

So in our project board,

So the executive is somebody who

It's somebody senior because

So the executive is somebody that you go

So the executive is looking

interest in the project.

523
00:29:52.210 --> 00:29:56.613
>> Somebody who's got an interest in the
project whether it's a financial interest

524
00:29:56.613 --> 00:29:59.240
or any type of interest,
that is a stakeholder.

525
00:29:59.240 --> 00:30:02.360
So we're gonna be looking at
stakeholders in our next episode.

526
00:30:02.360 --> 00:30:05.240
So I'm gonna invite you back for
the next episode.

527
00:30:05.240 --> 00:30:07.090
>> Well, I tell you what, Jo.

528
00:30:07.090 --> 00:30:11.240
If there's anything I've learned working
with you just when I think I know what I'm

529
00:30:11.240 --> 00:30:13.227
talking about, it comes back around and

530
00:30:13.227 --> 00:30:16.050
I'm kinda interested to see
what all the stakeholders.

531
00:30:16.050 --> 00:30:17.830
We're gonna take a look at it.

532
00:30:17.830 --> 00:30:19.905
And well, you should join us back
as we continue our look into

533
00:30:19.905 --> 00:30:20.810
the organization theme.

534
00:30:20.810 --> 00:30:23.050
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

535
00:30:23.050 --> 00:30:24.810
So signing off for ITPro.TV.

536
00:30:24.810 --> 00:30:26.090
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

537
00:30:26.090 --> 00:30:27.240
>> I'm Jo Peacock.

538
00:30:27.240 --> 00:30:34.750
>> And we'll see you next time.
[MUSIC]

539
00:30:34.750 --> 00:30:37.280
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: These 3 episodes cover the Prince2® Organisation theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes Organisation Theme Part 3

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Quality theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes Quality
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.859
Welcome to ITProTV.
>> I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.859 --> 00:00:04.796
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:04.796 --> 00:00:05.505
California.

4
00:00:05.505 --> 00:00:06.800
[CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:06.800 --> 00:00:08.323
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.323 --> 00:00:12.981
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:12.981 --> 00:00:15.985
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:15.985 --> 00:00:19.895
I'm your host, Justin Dennison,
and we're continuing our Prince2

9
00:00:19.895 --> 00:00:22.500
2017 Foundation Course and
we're still on themes.

10
00:00:22.500 --> 00:00:25.597
In particular, in this episode, we're
gonna be talking about the quality theme.

11
00:00:25.597 --> 00:00:29.437
And well, how can we talk about quality
without having someone very special to,

12
00:00:29.437 --> 00:00:30.497
well, teach us all about it.

13
00:00:30.497 --> 00:00:31.827
The one and only, Miss Jo Peacock.

14
00:00:31.827 --> 00:00:34.517
How are you doing today, Jo?
>> I'm feeling incredibly flattered,

15
00:00:34.517 --> 00:00:35.377
thank you, Justin.

16
00:00:35.377 --> 00:00:36.787
How are you?
>> I am doing well.

17
00:00:36.787 --> 00:00:43.106
They say flattery is the, I don't know,
they say something about it.

18
00:00:43.106 --> 00:00:44.275
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, [LAUGH] yeah,

19
00:00:44.275 --> 00:00:45.417
I'm not sure about that.

20
00:00:45.417 --> 00:00:48.680
I think we'll just leave that one there,
yeah.

21
00:00:48.680 --> 00:00:50.810
Okay, but thank you anyway, Justin.

22
00:00:50.810 --> 00:00:55.741
How are you enjoying our theme so far?
>> I keep finding out that just

23
00:00:55.741 --> 00:01:00.204
when I think I've learned something, that
makes sense, you throw me a curve ball and

24
00:01:00.204 --> 00:01:03.214
I go there's so much more to learn.

25
00:01:03.214 --> 00:01:05.253
And I guess that's just
the nature of the beast,

26
00:01:05.253 --> 00:01:08.020
right?
>> Well, remember, we're in foundation,

27
00:01:08.020 --> 00:01:13.230
and in any foundation class,
what you are learning, and

28
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:16.990
the same with the series here,
what you are learning is the foundation.

29
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:18.619
In other words,
you're learning all of the terms,

30
00:01:18.619 --> 00:01:20.710
you're learning all of the definitions.

31
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:26.290
So I know that in all of the episodes so
far, what you do have to remember,

32
00:01:26.290 --> 00:01:31.360
especially for your test, are the
terminology, and it is the definition.

33
00:01:31.360 --> 00:01:34.250
Unfortunately, this is what
I need you to make note of.

34
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:39.112
Now, just like pretty much every other
governance class that we have and

35
00:01:39.112 --> 00:01:43.190
every other governance episode that
we've done with all of our other series,

36
00:01:43.190 --> 00:01:45.870
there is downloadable
material available for you.

37
00:01:45.870 --> 00:01:49.230
And anything that you see on
the screens in front you,

38
00:01:49.230 --> 00:01:51.990
all of these slides are available for
you to download.

39
00:01:53.030 --> 00:01:55.840
You'll need to do that for your test.

40
00:01:55.840 --> 00:01:57.220
You'll need to do that to study.

41
00:01:58.330 --> 00:02:00.740
You will also,
if you're a practitioner test,

42
00:02:00.740 --> 00:02:04.040
you will also need a copy
of the Prince2 book.

43
00:02:04.040 --> 00:02:07.020
That's the official Prince2 book,
in order to be

44
00:02:07.020 --> 00:02:11.450
able to sit your practitioner test
because you can use that as reference.

45
00:02:11.450 --> 00:02:17.100
However, for this particular foundation,
well, your foundation test is closed book.

46
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:19.294
Justin, now here's a quick pop quiz,

47
00:02:19.294 --> 00:02:22.095
because I just like doing this to Justin,
right?

48
00:02:22.095 --> 00:02:23.839
Do you remember how many questions
there were in the foundations test?

49
00:02:23.839 --> 00:02:26.260
>> There were 60 and you have an hour.

50
00:02:26.260 --> 00:02:30.325
It's one minute a question, and
you have to get, I think you

51
00:02:30.325 --> 00:02:33.144
have to get, you got to get 33 right.
>> That's

52
00:02:33.144 --> 00:02:33.920
right.
>> Is that right?

53
00:02:33.920 --> 00:02:35.230
>> Yep, yeah.

54
00:02:35.230 --> 00:02:36.879
See, well remembered.

55
00:02:36.879 --> 00:02:39.110
But he has been paying attention.

56
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:40.410
I'm definitely impressed.

57
00:02:40.410 --> 00:02:42.530
But yeah, you've got 60 questions.

58
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:46.820
You've got one hour to do them,
that's one question per minute.

59
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:49.450
So that's not a long period of time.

60
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:53.160
That's one of the reasons why it's not
closed book because let's face it, I mean,

61
00:02:53.160 --> 00:02:54.220
open book, sorry.

62
00:02:54.220 --> 00:02:57.000
Because, let's face it, you don't have
time to be leafing through a book.

63
00:02:57.000 --> 00:02:59.410
If you've only got a minute per question,

64
00:02:59.410 --> 00:03:01.950
you definitely don't
have time to be looking.

65
00:03:01.950 --> 00:03:04.630
So let's get back to our themes then,
shall we?

66
00:03:04.630 --> 00:03:06.700
Now we've just had a quick recap.

67
00:03:06.700 --> 00:03:09.330
And we're on this third theme of quality.

68
00:03:10.420 --> 00:03:13.410
And in our last episode I actually

69
00:03:13.410 --> 00:03:18.370
asked Justin if he knew what quality
assurance was within a project.

70
00:03:20.000 --> 00:03:22.270
Do you remember what your answer was?
>> I said,

71
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:26.020
I typically think about software
when I think of quality assurance.

72
00:03:26.020 --> 00:03:31.150
And you're doing tests to make sure
things, features, the bells and whistles,

73
00:03:31.150 --> 00:03:36.220
so to speak, that are purported to do
certain things actually do those things to

74
00:03:36.220 --> 00:03:40.363
make sure you're getting what is expected.
>> Okay, so

75
00:03:40.363 --> 00:03:45.082
in Prince2 we define quality.

76
00:03:45.082 --> 00:03:48.600
Well, the purpose of this
quality theme is about,

77
00:03:48.600 --> 00:03:50.570
you'll see it on the screen
in front of you right now.

78
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:53.530
It's to define and implement the means by

79
00:03:53.530 --> 00:03:56.800
which the project will verify that
everything is fit for purpose.

80
00:03:56.800 --> 00:03:59.770
In other words,
that everything is as it should be.

81
00:04:02.060 --> 00:04:04.420
What does quality really mean?

82
00:04:06.270 --> 00:04:10.160
One of the biggest challenge
is quality is a seed.

83
00:04:10.160 --> 00:04:14.100
It's defined by the customer and
it is completely subjective.

84
00:04:14.100 --> 00:04:18.460
Now in a previous episode,
I used a particular example

85
00:04:18.460 --> 00:04:23.210
to help us to identify the difference
between a customer and a user.

86
00:04:23.210 --> 00:04:26.550
And what I said was, and so
this is a quick recap for you,

87
00:04:26.550 --> 00:04:28.660
because this is gonna be important.

88
00:04:28.660 --> 00:04:34.470
In that a customer is somebody who pays
and an user is somebody that uses.

89
00:04:34.470 --> 00:04:37.550
And I offered, and
I haven't done it, by the way, but

90
00:04:37.550 --> 00:04:40.970
I did offer to take Justin out for
a cup of coffee.

91
00:04:40.970 --> 00:04:42.250
He's only getting one.

92
00:04:42.250 --> 00:04:43.639
But it was an offer.

93
00:04:43.639 --> 00:04:46.858
And if I take Justin out for
a cup of coffee,

94
00:04:46.858 --> 00:04:51.890
then I am the customer,
because I am buying him a cup of coffee.

95
00:04:51.890 --> 00:04:55.280
Now, if I had a cup of coffee myself,
but I'm more likely to drink tea,

96
00:04:55.280 --> 00:04:57.720
because I like to conform to a stereotype.

97
00:04:57.720 --> 00:05:00.719
But if I had a cup of coffee myself,

98
00:05:00.719 --> 00:05:05.793
then I would also be a user,
as well as a customer, right?

99
00:05:05.793 --> 00:05:10.760
So a customer pays, the user uses.

100
00:05:10.760 --> 00:05:15.719
Do you remember the difference
between what I valued and

101
00:05:15.719 --> 00:05:20.588
what you valued?
>> [SOUND] I gotta get things right when

102
00:05:20.588 --> 00:05:21.569
I can.
>> [LAUGH]

103
00:05:21.569 --> 00:05:22.847
>> So as a customer,

104
00:05:22.847 --> 00:05:26.420
you essentially want bang for your buck.
>> Right.

105
00:05:26.420 --> 00:05:28.030
>> Is the coffee full?

106
00:05:28.030 --> 00:05:29.290
How much is it?

107
00:05:29.290 --> 00:05:31.440
Am I getting the most for my money?
>> Okay.

108
00:05:31.440 --> 00:05:33.740
>> As a user, I'm looking for

109
00:05:33.740 --> 00:05:36.210
taste, temperature,

110
00:05:36.210 --> 00:05:38.990
what I would say as quality attributes.
>> Ooh.

111
00:05:38.990 --> 00:05:40.610
>> Does it taste good to me?

112
00:05:40.610 --> 00:05:41.400
>> Right, so

113
00:05:41.400 --> 00:05:45.860
you used the right word there
because you used the word quality.

114
00:05:45.860 --> 00:05:50.710
Hm, I've also said up on that slide
there that quality is subjective.

115
00:05:52.300 --> 00:05:57.612
So if you are using then the word
quality to describe the taste,

116
00:05:57.612 --> 00:06:02.033
you're using it to describe the,
what else was it?

117
00:06:02.033 --> 00:06:03.782
Was it taste, was it temperature?
>> Mouth feel,

118
00:06:03.782 --> 00:06:05.814
I guess is something I heard.
>> Mouth feel?

119
00:06:05.814 --> 00:06:07.335
>> So what I mean is-

120
00:06:07.335 --> 00:06:10.475
>> You really have to explain that one.

121
00:06:10.475 --> 00:06:11.680
>> How would I explain that?

122
00:06:11.680 --> 00:06:16.260
So I've had cups of coffee that
leave like this weird after,

123
00:06:16.260 --> 00:06:18.960
almost like a film, if that makes sense.

124
00:06:18.960 --> 00:06:20.770
So you're like, ew, that's nasty.

125
00:06:20.770 --> 00:06:22.030
I don't like that.

126
00:06:22.030 --> 00:06:23.560
So I want the absence of it,

127
00:06:23.560 --> 00:06:26.242
I want something that's a little cleaner.
>> Like that kind of coffee that leaves

128
00:06:26.242 --> 00:06:28.209
a coating on your teeth, is that what
you're saying, you don't want that?

129
00:06:28.209 --> 00:06:29.980
>> Yeah, that's bad.

130
00:06:29.980 --> 00:06:32.216
>> Right, so that's subjective.

131
00:06:32.216 --> 00:06:33.320
How do I measure that?

132
00:06:34.430 --> 00:06:37.547
So measuring is difficult, but I think-
>> And

133
00:06:37.547 --> 00:06:40.760
I'm not talking about measuring
the volume of coffee in the cup.

134
00:06:40.760 --> 00:06:44.100
How do I measure what you
perceive to be quality?

135
00:06:44.100 --> 00:06:47.022
>> I guess you're gonna have to

136
00:06:47.022 --> 00:06:48.735
have me test it.

137
00:06:48.735 --> 00:06:51.599
But is this one of those
things where you're wondering,

138
00:06:51.599 --> 00:06:52.860
do I tell you what I want?

139
00:06:52.860 --> 00:06:56.000
For instance, if we go along with this,
what I think tastes good,

140
00:06:56.000 --> 00:06:57.910
I typically like dark roast coffees.

141
00:06:57.910 --> 00:07:00.010
I like French roast and things like that.

142
00:07:00.010 --> 00:07:04.515
If you like light coffees,
which I do not, it's still coffee.

143
00:07:04.515 --> 00:07:08.545
But what I perceive, what is good to me,
is different than you, right?

144
00:07:08.545 --> 00:07:10.638
Is that where we are going with this, Jo?
>> Well,

145
00:07:10.638 --> 00:07:14.395
kind of because you see,
I like dark roast coffee, too.

146
00:07:14.395 --> 00:07:16.685
And we are not getting off
subject here by the way.

147
00:07:16.685 --> 00:07:17.885
This is really important.

148
00:07:17.885 --> 00:07:20.645
This is something important for
you to understand.

149
00:07:20.645 --> 00:07:22.095
I like dark roast coffee, too.

150
00:07:22.095 --> 00:07:25.716
I prefer an Italian to a French,
but that's okay.

151
00:07:25.716 --> 00:07:30.400
But you see the thing is that I have
a preference and you have a preference.

152
00:07:31.670 --> 00:07:36.790
But that preference doesn't necessarily
constitute quality, because I've had

153
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:42.870
a really good Italian dark roast and I've
also had really bad Italian dark roast.

154
00:07:42.870 --> 00:07:45.360
So how do I denote quality then?

155
00:07:45.360 --> 00:07:48.920
So let me say, let me just put this into
a little bit of a different perspective.

156
00:07:48.920 --> 00:07:52.890
And let's pretend that I am,
no, no, forget this.

157
00:07:52.890 --> 00:07:54.503
I'm the customer, you're the user.

158
00:07:54.503 --> 00:07:59.289
So we've got a director with us today,
the one who is, well,

159
00:07:59.289 --> 00:08:03.999
making us Sort of work to certain
standards, should we say.

160
00:08:03.999 --> 00:08:06.250
The one who's keeping us in check.

161
00:08:06.250 --> 00:08:09.280
So let's pretend that Megan,
our director then.

162
00:08:09.280 --> 00:08:10.840
Megan is the coffee shop.

163
00:08:10.840 --> 00:08:12.890
She owns the coffee shop.

164
00:08:12.890 --> 00:08:19.830
How does she ensure that we come back?
>> So, are we

165
00:08:19.830 --> 00:08:21.970
talking from both of our perspectives?
>> Right,

166
00:08:21.970 --> 00:08:24.800
yes because she is not
gonna be successful.

167
00:08:24.800 --> 00:08:28.920
I say what we call a service provider,
she is not going to be successful if she

168
00:08:28.920 --> 00:08:32.440
doesn't get, well,
if she doesn't get our trade,

169
00:08:32.440 --> 00:08:36.880
that's both of our trades.
>> So, as a customer, she want.

170
00:08:36.880 --> 00:08:39.700
You are making sure that
the cup is full and

171
00:08:39.700 --> 00:08:40.840
it's a fair price.
>> Yup.

172
00:08:40.840 --> 00:08:41.750
>> Then you are likely

173
00:08:41.750 --> 00:08:42.410
to come back.
>> Right.

174
00:08:42.410 --> 00:08:44.720
>> I'm over simplifying that a great deal.

175
00:08:44.720 --> 00:08:47.880
But for me as a user, she has to conform.

176
00:08:47.880 --> 00:08:49.270
Doesn't she have to conform to my

177
00:08:49.270 --> 00:08:50.870
preference?
>> Right.

178
00:08:50.870 --> 00:08:52.050
>> So she has to say,

179
00:08:52.050 --> 00:08:53.980
do you want a dark roast coffee but

180
00:08:53.980 --> 00:08:57.340
here is a really good one.
>> I'm not gonna pay for this for

181
00:08:57.340 --> 00:08:59.530
you if you don't like it, okay?

182
00:09:00.880 --> 00:09:02.150
And that makes sense, okay?

183
00:09:02.150 --> 00:09:04.290
So I'm not gonna pay for it for
you if you don't like it.

184
00:09:05.390 --> 00:09:10.310
So, you have certain preferences
that Megan then has to

185
00:09:11.360 --> 00:09:14.480
well, she's the one that has
to supply those preferences.

186
00:09:14.480 --> 00:09:16.890
But I have some preferences, too.

187
00:09:16.890 --> 00:09:18.921
Both of those together
would denote quality.

188
00:09:18.921 --> 00:09:22.257
How's she going to find out
what we consider to be quality?

189
00:09:22.257 --> 00:09:24.106
>> I'm guessing she would take a survey.

190
00:09:24.106 --> 00:09:26.930
>> Right.

191
00:09:26.930 --> 00:09:30.220
So we talk about qualities
being subjective.

192
00:09:30.220 --> 00:09:31.420
And it's completely subjective.

193
00:09:31.420 --> 00:09:33.740
And in the case of a coffee shop,
it's completely subjective.

194
00:09:33.740 --> 00:09:38.650
So let's try and flip this into an I.T.
perspective then, should we?

195
00:09:38.650 --> 00:09:43.575
So, you have a very,
very similar laptop to me,

196
00:09:43.575 --> 00:09:48.315
that's probably because we both
got a fairly similar perspective.

197
00:09:48.315 --> 00:09:51.625
This is quite sort of
eerie in one respect.

198
00:09:51.625 --> 00:09:54.435
But most users don't have
the same perspective.

199
00:09:54.435 --> 00:09:58.485
I can tell you now, that my keyboard
setup completely different to yours.

200
00:09:58.485 --> 00:10:01.152
>> I will suspect that's a yes because,

201
00:10:01.152 --> 00:10:07.230
as a matter of fact, I have played with
operating systems that have a UK default.

202
00:10:07.230 --> 00:10:09.070
And I'm like, my keys aren't working, so

203
00:10:09.070 --> 00:10:12.000
I have to remap them.
>> Right, yeah.

204
00:10:12.000 --> 00:10:15.830
So I have preferences and
you have different preferences as well.

205
00:10:15.830 --> 00:10:19.500
And as it happens, those preferences
are based on, at the moment,

206
00:10:19.500 --> 00:10:21.680
those preferences
are based on our culture.

207
00:10:22.790 --> 00:10:26.640
You see,
it's not that I can't use a US keyboard.

208
00:10:26.640 --> 00:10:30.060
But some of the keys are in a different
place and it makes it difficult for me.

209
00:10:30.060 --> 00:10:33.330
So I'm always going to set my keyboard and
my language and

210
00:10:33.330 --> 00:10:37.589
my spelling intent to English.

211
00:10:38.730 --> 00:10:41.210
And so, that's the way I'm gonna work.

212
00:10:41.210 --> 00:10:41.770
But you're not.

213
00:10:41.770 --> 00:10:44.250
Look at the look he's giving me right now.

214
00:10:44.250 --> 00:10:44.780
You're gonna,

215
00:10:44.780 --> 00:10:47.930

>> I want civet coffee that is sourced by

445
00:25:05.254 --> 00:25:08.650
hand, blah blah blah, I give you these-
>> Yeah.

446
00:25:09.740 --> 00:25:10.790
>> Number one, civet coffee is

447
00:25:10.790 --> 00:25:12.232
an interesting thing.
>> I was just gonna say,

448
00:25:12.232 --> 00:25:14.640
let's not go there [LAUGH].
>> Yeah, let's not go there.

449
00:25:14.640 --> 00:25:18.350
But I guess I could get super specific,
and

450
00:25:18.350 --> 00:25:22.770
then that can cause some weirdness, right?
>> Well,

451
00:25:22.770 --> 00:25:26.130
not just that, but you can get really,
really specific about this.

452
00:25:26.130 --> 00:25:29.880
But then there's an expectation there
that I'm gonna do something about it.

453
00:25:29.880 --> 00:25:33.040
If I ask you what coffee do you prefer,
and do you prefer this and

454
00:25:33.040 --> 00:25:38.905
do you like this and do you like that, and
then you look at me to provide something,

455
00:25:38.905 --> 00:25:43.725
you look at me to make a change,
if that coffee doesn't change at all,

456
00:25:43.725 --> 00:25:47.105
after I've asked all of these questions,
then you're gonna be pretty disappointed.

457
00:25:49.599 --> 00:25:52.975
So it's not just a case of
gathering customer expectations.

458
00:25:52.975 --> 00:25:55.465
We've also go to manage
those expectations,

459
00:25:55.465 --> 00:25:59.780
which is why we need to
maintain that quality register.

460
00:25:59.780 --> 00:26:04.173
So on our next slide, remember I said
to you that we're going to look at

461
00:26:04.173 --> 00:26:07.385
this particular slide in
a little bit more detail?

462
00:26:07.385 --> 00:26:10.460
That was that one that was at
the bottom right-hand corner.

463
00:26:10.460 --> 00:26:13.710
You'll see that we have got,
if we can do a fullscreen on this,

464
00:26:13.710 --> 00:26:15.600
because it's quite small, isn't it.

465
00:26:15.600 --> 00:26:19.070
Now again, this is one of those diagrams,
it's in that nice shade of purple, so

466
00:26:19.070 --> 00:26:23.390
this is one of those diagrams that's
come straight from our PRINCE2 book.

467
00:26:23.390 --> 00:26:27.470
And you'll see that we have in
quality planning from the customer,

468
00:26:27.470 --> 00:26:29.448
we gather their expectations.

469
00:26:29.448 --> 00:26:33.030
And then PRINCE2 then takes over and

470
00:26:33.030 --> 00:26:36.130
conducts what we call
the project response,

471
00:26:36.130 --> 00:26:41.540
which is where we actually look at how
we're planning for delivering quality.

472
00:26:41.540 --> 00:26:45.250
How are we going to plan
to meet those expectations?

473
00:26:45.250 --> 00:26:48.000
And then we also then
document the tolerances and

474
00:26:48.000 --> 00:26:51.840
the methods for
meeting those expectations.

475
00:26:51.840 --> 00:26:57.400
But then you'll notice it goes back to
the customer again for the acceptance.

476
00:26:57.400 --> 00:26:59.770
They have to sign off acceptance.

477
00:26:59.770 --> 00:27:01.540
After we have done our QA,

478
00:27:01.540 --> 00:27:06.460
our Quality Assurance testing, it then
goes back to the customer for acceptance.

479
00:27:07.580 --> 00:27:13.100
Which means that at the beginning, that
second box down underneath that customer

480
00:27:13.100 --> 00:27:19.340
column, you'll see that we have to
define the acceptance criteria.

481
00:27:21.240 --> 00:27:23.952
And I asked Justin in a previous
episode about MoSCoW.

482
00:27:23.952 --> 00:27:31.238
Do you remember what MoSCoW was?
>> Must have, should have, could have,

483
00:27:31.238 --> 00:27:36.453
and wants, like it would be nice if-
>> Yeah, would like in the future or

484
00:27:36.453 --> 00:27:40.035
want to have right now, yeah,
either one of those will do, yeah.

485
00:27:40.035 --> 00:27:44.504
So MoSCoW is about a list of requirements,
and

486
00:27:44.504 --> 00:27:51.090
we wanna aim to met at least
80% of the must have criteria.

487
00:27:51.090 --> 00:27:53.614
And then some of the should have and
the could have.

488
00:27:53.614 --> 00:27:57.614
And if it's got some of the wanna have
right now or would like in the future,

489
00:27:57.614 --> 00:28:00.791
well, maybe that's what we'd
consider to be a bonus, but

490
00:28:00.791 --> 00:28:04.115
it's certainly not a priority for
this particular product.

491
00:28:05.175 --> 00:28:08.675
So all of these are captured right
at the very beginning as you saw.

492
00:28:08.675 --> 00:28:12.865
If we go back a slide and
we look at that customer column,

493
00:28:12.865 --> 00:28:16.425
you'll see that these are captured
right at the very beginning.

494
00:28:16.425 --> 00:28:20.885
And then, once we've defined
the acceptance criteria,

495
00:28:20.885 --> 00:28:27.220
this is when we define the approach
to delivering quality.

496
00:28:27.220 --> 00:28:30.218
And this is what we define right now,

497
00:28:30.218 --> 00:28:34.200
after we've defined
the acceptance criteria.

498
00:28:34.200 --> 00:28:36.577
In other words,
how are we going to deliver that?

499
00:28:36.577 --> 00:28:38.376
So planning and controlling and

500
00:28:38.376 --> 00:28:41.980
how we're going to measure
whether we've delivered quality.

501
00:28:41.980 --> 00:28:44.590
How are we going to test quality?

502
00:28:44.590 --> 00:28:50.000
Notice, Don, and I've gotta say this,
this is not about testing functionality.

503
00:28:51.790 --> 00:28:54.990
Testing functionality is completely
different to testing quality.

504
00:28:54.990 --> 00:28:59.324
Do you know what I mean by that?
>> So

505
00:28:59.324 --> 00:29:05.609
actually this plays into a question I had
kind of about these acceptance criteria,

506
00:29:05.609 --> 00:29:09.044
because it seems like there's an implicit.

507
00:29:09.044 --> 00:29:11.940
Like, this should work or this should do.

508
00:29:11.940 --> 00:29:14.380
But some of them, I guess, let me back up.

509
00:29:15.680 --> 00:29:18.110
When we talk about measurable,
they have to be measurable,

510
00:29:18.110 --> 00:29:21.920
does that measurement have to
be thumbs up, thumbs down?

511
00:29:21.920 --> 00:29:28.570
Or does it have to say,
I want X to be able to.

512
00:29:28.570 --> 00:29:33.921
I'm having a hard time just putting
into words how to best relate,

513
00:29:33.921 --> 00:29:39.083
because I've dealt with this before,
but I'm not necessarily

514
00:29:39.083 --> 00:29:44.740
saying that I've had a good survey
of appropriate criteria, right?

515
00:29:44.740 --> 00:29:46.960
People are like, yeah,
these are the acceptance criteria.

516
00:29:46.960 --> 00:29:49.450
But a lot of times they're nebulous or
very ambiguous.

517
00:29:49.450 --> 00:29:51.000
They're not necessarily always measurable.

518
00:29:51.000 --> 00:29:55.643
And you go, I don't know if I'm gonna
be able to do that, because it's not

519
00:29:55.643 --> 00:29:59.190
necessarily something I can say yes or no.
>> Right,

520
00:29:59.190 --> 00:30:02.905
so let me put this in another way, then.

521
00:30:02.905 --> 00:30:06.125
Cuz I asked you a question
about functionality.

522
00:30:06.125 --> 00:30:11.835
And I said, the difference between,
well, in terms of defining quality,

523
00:30:11.835 --> 00:30:14.655
functionality is not
necessarily exactly the same.

524
00:30:14.655 --> 00:30:17.335
And you asked about how we quantify this.

525
00:30:17.335 --> 00:30:20.895
Well, let's just think about the fact that

526
00:30:20.895 --> 00:30:24.760
functionality is about whether
you've got a coffee or not.

527
00:30:24.760 --> 00:30:29.840
Yeah, that's functionality.
>> I guess,

528
00:30:29.840 --> 00:30:30.810
yeah.
>> But

529
00:30:32.210 --> 00:30:36.840
what I'm interested in as a project
manager, or rather as a coffee shop owner,

530
00:30:36.840 --> 00:30:39.568
I'm interested in whether you really,
really liked that coffee.

531
00:30:39.568 --> 00:30:42.930
So I'm gonna ask you a question about,
on a scale of one to ten,

532
00:30:42.930 --> 00:30:48.148
how was your coffee?
>> So I'm trying to reconcile.

533
00:30:48.148 --> 00:30:52.821
I see where you're going, you've
given me more quantitative measures,

534
00:30:52.821 --> 00:30:56.168
would I also drill down on
respective portions of it?

535
00:30:56.168 --> 00:30:58.211
Like, on a scale of one to ten,

536
00:30:58.211 --> 00:31:00.990
how was the temperature?
>> Right, yeah.

537
00:31:00.990 --> 00:31:02.511
>> On a scale of one to ten,

538
00:31:02.511 --> 00:31:05.068
how was the flavor?
>> And there's nothing wrong with that,

539
00:31:05.068 --> 00:31:06.018
but you've gotta be really,

540
00:31:06.018 --> 00:31:08.543
really careful.
>> Because you can end up having these

541
00:31:08.543 --> 00:31:11.313
implicit biases that you've built in,
right?

542
00:31:11.313 --> 00:31:12.144
>> No, you know what I"m gonna do?

543
00:31:12.144 --> 00:31:17.815
I'm gonna irritate the life out of you,
that's what I"m gonna do.

544
00:31:17.815 --> 00:31:22.189
How many times do you get a survey and you
not fill it out, because you get three or

545
00:31:22.189 --> 00:31:25.386
four sort of sentences into it or
four questions into it and

546
00:31:25.386 --> 00:31:28.282
think, I can't be dealing
with this anymore.

547
00:31:28.282 --> 00:31:32.908
I'm just not gonna bother doing it.
>> So this is one of those things where

548
00:31:32.908 --> 00:31:36.979
you wanna pick the metrics that are most
important to you or provide the best

549
00:31:36.979 --> 00:31:41.972
intelligence for decision making without
over-burdening the respective individuals.

550
00:31:41.972 --> 00:31:44.653
>> Let's just say that we were trying to

551
00:31:44.653 --> 00:31:48.000
implement an email service, right?

552
00:31:48.000 --> 00:31:51.867
I am not gonna ask questions
based on the functionality.

553
00:31:51.867 --> 00:31:56.036
I am not gonna give you, as a customer,
I'm not going to present to

554
00:31:56.036 --> 00:31:59.611
you Microsoft Outlook and
then side by side with Gmail and

555
00:31:59.611 --> 00:32:04.247
then ask you the question of, does it
allow you to send and receive email?

556
00:32:06.266 --> 00:32:09.990
Because of course they both allow
you to send and receive email.

557
00:32:09.990 --> 00:32:13.180
So am I going to test whether it sends and
receives email?

558
00:32:13.180 --> 00:32:15.740
Yes, but is that important to you?

559
00:32:15.740 --> 00:32:19.374
No, because there's
implicit assumption there,

560
00:32:19.374 --> 00:32:23.100
that both of them are going to send and
receive email.

561
00:32:23.100 --> 00:32:27.903
So as the supplier of that product,
there's part of me that can even turn

562
00:32:27.903 --> 00:32:31.839
around and say well you know what,
the fact that it sends and

563
00:32:31.839 --> 00:32:37.730
receives email is barely incidental
because let's assume it's implied.

564
00:32:37.730 --> 00:32:43.530
What I need to understand, is whether
all of the other features work for

565
00:32:43.530 --> 00:32:45.190
you and how they work for you.

566
00:32:45.190 --> 00:32:49.100
Do you see what I mean?
>> I get what you're saying,

567
00:32:49.100 --> 00:32:53.550
so would say that there,
let me think about this.

568
00:32:53.550 --> 00:32:58.300
Would you say there is almost implicit
acceptance criteria about functionality?

569
00:32:58.300 --> 00:33:05.390
Like, if this doesn't work, so let me
get back to a more tangible product.

570
00:33:05.390 --> 00:33:08.380
Let's say I buy a super car,
some kind of exotic car right?

571
00:33:08.380 --> 00:33:10.540
And I'm like this gorgeous beautiful.

572
00:33:11.780 --> 00:33:15.045
And I'm driving along the road and
periodically just cuts off.

573
00:33:15.045 --> 00:33:16.970
>> Yup.

574
00:33:16.970 --> 00:33:18.472
>> If I were to ask a survey,

575
00:33:18.472 --> 00:33:21.909
like I'm trying to reconcile
that because if you ask me,

576
00:33:21.909 --> 00:33:24.360
do you like how the car looks and drives?

577
00:33:24.360 --> 00:33:28.920
And I go, yeah, except when it cuts off.

578
00:33:28.920 --> 00:33:30.590
That would be about functionality.

579
00:33:30.590 --> 00:33:33.620
I don't see how you tease
apart those respective things.

580
00:33:33.620 --> 00:33:37.800
If it's a pre-existing solution,
I understand like Outlook versus Gmail.

581
00:33:37.800 --> 00:33:39.320
They both send email.

582
00:33:39.320 --> 00:33:43.126
You assume that they both send the email,
but what if they don't?

583
00:33:43.126 --> 00:33:46.299
>> Right, but there's a difference between

584
00:33:46.299 --> 00:33:50.450
actually being able to do the job and
doing it reliably.

585
00:33:50.450 --> 00:33:53.397
In the example that you gave me,

586
00:33:53.397 --> 00:34:00.175
we get into the rooms of sort of
warranty here really of a service.

587
00:34:00.175 --> 00:34:04.475
Because you see, it's a difference
between can it do what it suppose to do.

588
00:34:04.475 --> 00:34:08.785
Your super car can it get you from A to B,
yes it can.

589
00:34:10.290 --> 00:34:13.430
Does it get you from A to B all the time?

590
00:34:13.430 --> 00:34:15.140
No, it doesn't.

591
00:34:15.140 --> 00:34:18.460
So we're not actually testing the output,

592
00:34:18.460 --> 00:34:23.520
we're testing whether it is
reliable at that point in time.

593
00:34:23.520 --> 00:34:28.010
So, it's not the functionality, it's about
whether the functionality is maintained.

594
00:34:28.010 --> 00:34:31.310
The functionality is there,

595
00:34:31.310 --> 00:34:35.798
it's whether it can actually perform at

596
00:34:35.798 --> 00:34:40.777
an acceptable warranty level for you.
>> All right,

597
00:34:40.777 --> 00:34:42.850
so I have a follow up to that then.

598
00:34:42.850 --> 00:34:44.740
So tha'ts a sinle entity.

599
00:34:44.740 --> 00:34:45.760
It is not reliable.

600
00:34:45.760 --> 00:34:47.120
I get what you're saying there.

601
00:34:48.140 --> 00:34:52.450
But would that change, let's say if I'm
a mass producer of these entities but

602
00:34:52.450 --> 00:34:57.750
then it's not that one
sporadically misbehaves.

603
00:34:57.750 --> 00:34:59.340
It's out of every thousand,

604
00:34:59.340 --> 00:35:00.900
I have three that just doesn't work.
>> Right.

605
00:35:00.900 --> 00:35:03.790
>> Is that still a question of quality?

606
00:35:03.790 --> 00:35:06.280
Am I getting too confused about this?

607
00:35:06.280 --> 00:35:07.942
Am I overthinking this a little bit.
>> Well no,

608
00:35:07.942 --> 00:35:12.120
because this is exactly what
a project manager has to do.

609
00:35:12.120 --> 00:35:14.080
We have to remember in a previous episode.

610
00:35:14.080 --> 00:35:15.420
So then we talked about tolerances.

611
00:35:16.740 --> 00:35:19.350
And this is where our
tolerance is coming to play.

612
00:35:19.350 --> 00:35:22.640
We have to work out what our
acceptable tolerances are.

613
00:35:22.640 --> 00:35:26.242
If we've only got one, and say we've
got a production line of cars, and

614
00:35:26.242 --> 00:35:29.090
we've got 10,000, and
we've got 1 that fails.

615
00:35:29.090 --> 00:35:32.750
And whether it fails,
a complete catastrophic failure or

616
00:35:32.750 --> 00:35:37.606
whether it is just failing intermittently,
that's up to your tolerances to

617
00:35:37.606 --> 00:35:42.230
decide right at the very onset
whether that's acceptable or not.

618
00:35:42.230 --> 00:35:45.840
Quality assurance will
test your tolerances.

619
00:35:45.840 --> 00:35:51.000
And it will test to ensure that
the functionality of a service

620
00:35:51.000 --> 00:35:56.412
remains within those columns.
>> All right Jo, I'm gonna tell you,

621
00:35:56.412 --> 00:36:00.712
I'm gonna have to think on this because
you said we're gonna have to come back for

622
00:36:00.712 --> 00:36:01.356
a part two.

623
00:36:01.356 --> 00:36:04.634
So maybe I'll just let this dance
because I'm getting in my head, and

624
00:36:04.634 --> 00:36:08.358
I think I might be overthinking this,
and maybe there's some other things that

625
00:36:08.358 --> 00:36:11.160
should be revealed to me.
>> We are gonna do a part two.

626
00:36:11.160 --> 00:36:15.190
We have got a lot more to cover
when it comes to quality.

627
00:36:15.190 --> 00:36:19.615
And so what I'd like you to do right now,
is I would like you to

628
00:36:19.615 --> 00:36:23.425
review all of the downloadable
material that is available to you.

629
00:36:23.425 --> 00:36:28.975
And when we come back in part two, we're
going to take a photo look at so that of

630
00:36:28.975 --> 00:36:34.955
describing in our products themselves, and
we are be able to articulate the products.

631
00:36:34.955 --> 00:36:36.617
We gonna look at tolerances.

632
00:36:36.617 --> 00:36:40.580
And we're also going to look at
how we test the quality as well.

633
00:36:40.580 --> 00:36:42.350
>> Well Jo, I'm pretty interested.

634
00:36:42.350 --> 00:36:45.630
This is one of those things that I'm,
this is a lot of questions.

635
00:36:45.630 --> 00:36:46.690
And I gotta have them answered.

636
00:36:46.690 --> 00:36:49.280
And if you still have questions,
definitely come on back for our part two.

637
00:36:49.280 --> 00:36:51.430
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

638
00:36:51.430 --> 00:36:54.380
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

639
00:36:54.380 --> 00:36:55.270
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

640
00:36:55.270 --> 00:37:03.233
>> And we'll see you next time.

641
00:37:03.233 --> 00:37:06.150
[MUSIC]
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Quality theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Quality Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.313
Welcome ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:02.313 --> 00:00:04.735
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.735 --> 00:00:08.265
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.265 --> 00:00:11.722
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.722 --> 00:00:16.102
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome
back to another episode of ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:16.102 --> 00:00:17.900
I'm your host Justin Dennison, and

7
00:00:17.900 --> 00:00:21.330
we're continuing on with our
Prince2 2017 Foundation Series.

8
00:00:21.330 --> 00:00:23.838
And we're back with a part
two on our Quality Theme.

9
00:00:23.838 --> 00:00:26.690
If you haven't seen part one,
definitely go back and check that one out.

10
00:00:26.690 --> 00:00:29.793
And here to further our discussion on
the Quality Theme, is none other than Ms.

11
00:00:29.793 --> 00:00:30.315
Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:30.315 --> 00:00:31.034
How are you doing today, Jo?

13
00:00:31.034 --> 00:00:33.850
>> Absolutely great,
thank you Justin, how are you?

14
00:00:33.850 --> 00:00:36.477
>> I am doing fantastic today Jo,
I tell you what,

15
00:00:36.477 --> 00:00:38.589
we had some really good discussions.

16
00:00:38.589 --> 00:00:42.004
And you really made me think
about the Quality Theme, but

17
00:00:42.004 --> 00:00:44.080
we had to cut the last episode off.

18
00:00:44.080 --> 00:00:46.345
And, well, we had to come back and
talk more about it, so

19
00:00:46.345 --> 00:00:47.538
where are we going from here?

20
00:00:47.538 --> 00:00:49.007
>> Well to be perfectly honest,

21
00:00:49.007 --> 00:00:53.003
if you haven't seen episode one of our
Quality Theme, then I would definitely,

22
00:00:53.003 --> 00:00:56.090
definitely recommend that you go back and
watch episode one.

23
00:00:56.090 --> 00:01:00.202
And I would recommend that you sort of
do these in, well, quick succession.

24
00:01:00.202 --> 00:01:03.669
Because, where we left off
at the end of episode one,

25
00:01:03.669 --> 00:01:08.380
we had a really good discussion about
quality, and what quality meant.

26
00:01:08.380 --> 00:01:10.532
And the fact that quality was perceived.

27
00:01:10.532 --> 00:01:14.213
And of course, the biggest issue is,

00:14:04.910 --> 00:14:06.460

00:14:06.460 --> 00:14:09.760

The other thing that we're going to do,

00:14:27.140 --> 00:14:30.700
Prior to release,
what we're going to achieve and

00:14:30.700 --> 00:14:35.230

261
00:14:35.230 --> 00:14:38.930
This is what our product looks like now.

00:14:40.500 --> 00:14:43.660
This is our product at

00:15:04.710 --> 00:15:06.910

00:15:06.910 --> 00:15:08.450
