271
00:15:08.450 --> 00:15:10.358

00:15:10.358 --> 00:15:15.230

00:15:15.230 --> 00:15:17.470

00:15:17.470 --> 00:15:21.170
Anything that Justin does to the [LAUGH],

00:15:21.170 --> 00:15:24.660

look at what it looked like

00:15:37.830 --> 00:15:40.070

00:15:41.790 --> 00:15:44.360

00:16:09.940 --> 00:16:13.250

00:16:13.250 --> 00:16:17.170
maybe they want to add a pair of

00:16:17.170 --> 00:16:18.530

00:16:25.840 --> 00:16:27.360
Have you ever been in a position,

00:16:27.360 --> 00:16:31.830

00:16:31.830 --> 00:16:35.600
whether it's Windows or

00:16:35.600 --> 00:16:39.840

00:16:39.840 --> 00:16:43.540

00:16:49.340 --> 00:16:52.500
And one of the reasons why that happens

00:16:54.330 --> 00:16:57.730
That was what you accepted

00:16:57.730 --> 00:16:58.940
So with every new release,

00:16:58.940 --> 00:17:04.350

00:17:05.400 --> 00:17:08.800
So this is why we want

00:17:08.800 --> 00:17:14.680
And we want to ensure that whenever we

00:17:14.680 --> 00:17:20.310

00:17:20.310 --> 00:17:25.370
We've also got to ensure that

00:17:25.370 --> 00:17:28.355
And if we don't meet quality, then we've
got to ensure that we have got all of our

00:17:28.355 --> 00:17:34.040
records [COUGH] and
that we've got all of our [COUGH]

00:17:34.040 --> 00:17:37.860
excuse me, all of our notes for

00:17:37.860 --> 00:17:43.770
instance on what we did to remediate

314
00:17:45.200 --> 00:17:48.260
Of course, remember,
we've got these stages.

00:17:48.260 --> 00:17:51.100
And during these stages,
at the end of every stage, we're going to

00:17:51.100 --> 00:17:55.560

00:17:55.560 --> 00:17:59.550

00:17:59.550 --> 00:18:01.040

00:18:01.040 --> 00:18:03.910
I said I wanted it in this color,

00:18:07.370 --> 00:18:08.580

00:18:10.030 --> 00:18:11.120
Is that scope creep?

00:18:12.940 --> 00:18:17.520
That's kind of one of those ambiguous

00:18:17.520 --> 00:18:21.280

325
00:18:21.280 --> 00:18:24.970

00:18:24.970 --> 00:18:28.166
And it also depends on whether

00:18:28.166 --> 00:18:29.810

00:18:29.810 --> 00:18:32.345

00:18:55.881 --> 00:18:59.390
And then after that you go, I don't know,

00:19:06.160 --> 00:19:08.370

00:19:08.370 --> 00:19:10.387
And I will hold my hands up and

00:19:10.387 --> 00:19:11.913

And I've mentioned this before in previous

00:19:17.740 --> 00:19:23.250
And we expect customers to be able to

00:19:23.250 --> 00:19:25.810

00:19:25.810 --> 00:19:27.890

00:19:29.090 --> 00:19:33.560
What they come to us with,

00:19:33.560 --> 00:19:34.740
It's, I want an iPad.

00:19:35.810 --> 00:19:40.174
And what we've got to do, and it is our

00:19:40.174 --> 00:19:44.599

What do you want to be able to

Do you wanna be able to write on it?

Do you need a pen or a stylus?

00:19:58.210 --> 00:20:00.800
Do you need to be able to use a keyboard?

00:20:00.800 --> 00:20:02.560
Do you need to connect the keyboard?

00:20:02.560 --> 00:20:05.470
Do you want to attach USB devices?

00:20:05.470 --> 00:20:09.880
All of that sort of thing, that's what

00:20:09.880 --> 00:20:14.820

00:20:14.820 --> 00:20:19.930
But they'll be very very quick to

00:20:19.930 --> 00:20:21.360

00:20:22.450 --> 00:20:26.994
And this is why we have what

00:20:26.994 --> 00:20:31.344
You hear of customer acceptance testing or

00:20:31.344 --> 00:20:36.219
CAP tests and UATs, and remember the

00:20:41.960 --> 00:20:45.360
Well, quite often it's not

UAT that somebody comes back to us and

00:20:50.250 --> 00:20:55.820
Now in an agile environment what would

00:20:55.820 --> 00:20:59.405

371
00:21:06.540 --> 00:21:11.335
And so, here in our PRINCE2 environment,

00:21:11.335 --> 00:21:16.265

00:21:16.265 --> 00:21:18.120

00:21:18.120 --> 00:21:22.765
Because sometimes, that I want

00:21:22.765 --> 00:21:27.240
I don't want it in blue it

00:21:27.240 --> 00:21:30.290
Sometimes that's a show stopper, and

00:21:31.300 --> 00:21:34.120
So we have to have some

00:21:34.120 --> 00:21:38.360

00:21:38.360 --> 00:21:43.280

By the way, we don't like rigidity,

00:21:48.480 --> 00:21:51.030

00:21:52.430 --> 00:21:55.628
What we do have to do, and

00:21:57.305 --> 00:22:02.138
Okay, we have to have the sufficient

00:22:06.656 --> 00:22:11.120

00:22:12.570 --> 00:22:17.285
The other thing that I want to mention

I don't think that there is enough

00:22:20.015 --> 00:22:22.955
And lessons learned is not just

00:22:22.955 --> 00:22:24.995

It's about, when we're developing,

00:22:34.185 --> 00:22:37.720
In our communication with the customers,

00:22:37.720 --> 00:22:41.140
What worked really well

00:22:41.140 --> 00:22:44.880
And so we can also take lessons

00:22:44.880 --> 00:22:47.940

00:22:47.940 --> 00:22:50.300
Yes, I know they've asked for it in blue.

But, to be perfectly honest,

00:22:51.730 --> 00:22:56.150

00:23:22.020 --> 00:23:27.092
But it's funny that you talk about this

00:23:32.388 --> 00:23:37.482

00:23:37.482 --> 00:23:41.194

00:23:49.112 --> 00:23:52.434
And part of it is lack of documentation,

00:23:52.434 --> 00:23:57.434

00:23:57.434 --> 00:23:59.287
Well, if you carry on

00:23:59.287 --> 00:24:02.812

[LAUGH] I mean,

00:24:06.451 --> 00:24:11.254
The other thing that does happen within IT

00:24:11.254 --> 00:24:15.250

00:24:15.250 --> 00:24:18.360
And another project team working on this,

00:24:18.360 --> 00:24:20.836
that lessons learned isn't shared.

00:24:20.836 --> 00:24:25.860
And so really, there isn't anything

00:24:25.860 --> 00:24:29.480
for them to say, look,
this didn't work over there.

00:24:29.480 --> 00:24:31.640
And sometimes,
even with different customers, and

00:24:31.640 --> 00:24:34.180
it confuses the life out

00:24:34.180 --> 00:24:37.790
Because even if you've got the same

00:24:37.790 --> 00:24:42.210

teams aren't talking to each other.

00:24:42.210 --> 00:24:47.892
You can bet your soul that that customer's

00:24:47.892 --> 00:24:52.370

00:24:52.370 --> 00:24:55.800
And even if it's talking to one person

00:24:55.800 --> 00:24:58.010

00:24:58.010 --> 00:25:02.120
IT should be facilitating

00:25:02.120 --> 00:25:05.980

00:25:05.980 --> 00:25:08.650
IT should not be making
life more complicated and

00:25:08.650 --> 00:25:10.420

00:25:10.420 --> 00:25:13.340
And it gets even worse if

444
00:25:13.340 --> 00:25:16.200
teams that are speaking two

00:25:16.200 --> 00:25:20.260
such as a supplier and
an internal IT group, for instance.

00:25:20.260 --> 00:25:22.240
Customer doesn't want that.

447
00:25:22.240 --> 00:25:26.350
Ultimately, we have to deliver

00:25:26.350 --> 00:25:28.840
It's not up to us, and

00:25:28.840 --> 00:25:33.246
To deliver what we want to deliver, we've

00:25:33.246 --> 00:25:38.670
so we've gotta have the right measures
in place to be able to control

451
00:25:38.670 --> 00:25:40.720
that quality as well.

452
00:25:40.720 --> 00:25:47.170
And so, as it says right at the top there,

453
00:25:47.170 --> 00:25:50.260
and we've got to ensure
that that approach and

454
00:25:50.260 --> 00:25:53.570
all of the results from our

455
00:25:54.730 --> 00:25:57.470
If we get it right, and
these are our benefits.

456
00:25:57.470 --> 00:26:00.478
I always like to call benefits
sort of a if we get it right.

457
00:26:00.478 --> 00:26:04.339
If we get it right, this is what we'll
achieve, and if we get it right, we'll

458
00:26:04.339 --> 00:26:08.569
have quality documentation, and we'll
have a culture that's focused on quality.

459
00:26:08.569 --> 00:26:13.033
The word collaboration's not in there,
because this comes straight out

460
00:26:13.033 --> 00:26:16.910
of the PRINCE2 book, but
we'll also have collaboration.

461
00:26:16.910 --> 00:26:21.100
And that's what I like to see,

462
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:25.640
not just within our project teams,
but also across our project teams.

463
00:26:25.640 --> 00:26:29.610
So within our portfolio, as a whole,
I want to see collaboration.

464
00:26:29.610 --> 00:26:33.730
And I also want to see quality, well,

465
00:26:33.730 --> 00:26:39.585
addressed in project teams, and in support
teams, and in our suppliers as well.

466
00:26:39.585 --> 00:26:46.366
Cuz ultimately, quality is actually
the responsibility of everyone within IT.

467
00:26:46.366 --> 00:26:50.984
And the last thing that you need,
as a project manager, is to hand over

468
00:26:50.984 --> 00:26:55.942
a project to support, to have it

469
00:26:55.942 --> 00:26:59.609
And then for the support team to be
sitting there going, well, you know what,

470
00:26:59.609 --> 00:27:03.180
the project team just threw it over
the wall to us, we don't know what to do.

471
00:27:03.180 --> 00:27:07.688
And so whenever you've got a problem,
or any sort of incident, any issue,

472
00:27:07.688 --> 00:27:09.598
we don't know how to handle it.

473
00:27:09.598 --> 00:27:16.420
And then the quality of service suffers
to the customer, and guess what?

474
00:27:16.420 --> 00:27:19.084
It reflects on you, as a project manager,

475
00:27:19.084 --> 00:27:23.600
cuz you're the person that is
responsible for delivering the product.

476
00:27:24.680 --> 00:27:29.550
And so if the product is being delivered
and it's not particularly reliable, or

477
00:27:29.550 --> 00:27:33.490
if it's failed and they don't know
how to fix it, then guess what?

478
00:27:33.490 --> 00:27:38.240
It reflects on you, so it's really
important that we do take those

479
00:27:38.240 --> 00:27:43.285
lessons learned, and we actually develop
an entire culture within our project and

480
00:27:43.285 --> 00:27:46.025
our portfolio management for quality.

481
00:27:46.025 --> 00:27:51.980
So at this point in time, we've had two
episodes where we've looked at quality,

482
00:27:51.980 --> 00:27:56.350
and we spent a little bit of time talking
about it, and what quality means,

483
00:27:56.350 --> 00:27:58.093
and how quality is perceived.

484
00:27:58.093 --> 00:28:02.959
So that's what we need to really look at,
in any great depth,

485
00:28:02.959 --> 00:28:05.840
for our foundation tech.

486
00:28:05.840 --> 00:28:09.840
So when we come back, in our next episode,
we're going to take a look at another

487
00:28:09.840 --> 00:28:14.300
theme, and we're going to be looking at
the theme of planning in our next episode.

488
00:28:14.300 --> 00:28:19.020
>> Well, I'll tell you what, Jo,
it's funny, because as you talk about what

489
00:28:19.020 --> 00:28:22.870
may seem like to you kinda these
very abstract topics, I'm like, yep,

490
00:28:22.870 --> 00:28:27.110
I've been there, yep,
I've seen that happen, yep, that's bad.

491
00:28:27.110 --> 00:28:28.470
So definitely pay attention.

492
00:28:28.470 --> 00:28:30.618
So I'm interested to see how
planning goes, and well,

493
00:28:30.618 --> 00:28:33.330
hopefully you're interested as well,
but definitely come on back.

494
00:28:33.330 --> 00:28:35.060
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

495
00:28:35.060 --> 00:28:37.418
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

496
00:28:37.418 --> 00:28:38.146
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

497
00:28:38.146 --> 00:28:38.858
>> And we'll see you next time.

498
00:28:38.858 --> 00:28:46.201
[MUSIC]

499
00:28:46.201 --> 00:28:49.267
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Plans theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Plans
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.210 --> 00:00:01.376
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.376 --> 00:00:04.734
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.734 --> 00:00:06.376
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.376 --> 00:00:08.242
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.242 --> 00:00:11.820
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.820 --> 00:00:15.657
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.657 --> 00:00:19.367
I'm your host Justin Dennison and well you
asked for it so we're bringing it back for

8
00:00:19.367 --> 00:00:21.560
you, more PRINCE2 2017 Foundation.

9
00:00:21.560 --> 00:00:24.460
And in this episode we're gonna
be talking about the plan thing.

10
00:00:24.460 --> 00:00:26.892
And here to help us along in that
very endeavor is Ms. Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:26.892 --> 00:00:27.872
How're you doing today, Jo?

12
00:00:27.872 --> 00:00:29.120
>> Great, thank you Justin.

13
00:00:29.120 --> 00:00:29.940
How are you?

14
00:00:29.940 --> 00:00:33.991
>> I am doing fantastic and I said at the
end of the previous episode I was like,

15
00:00:33.991 --> 00:00:36.322
I'm interested to see how planning goes.

16
00:00:36.322 --> 00:00:41.463
So I'm actually really interested
to see how this plays out and

17
00:00:41.463 --> 00:00:44.470
what PRINCE2 says about planning.

18
00:00:44.470 --> 00:00:48.990
Because I have seen people make
what they say were great plans, and

19
00:00:48.990 --> 00:00:52.760
the whole time I'm standing off to
the side going, that's a horrible plan.

20
00:00:52.760 --> 00:00:57.755
So is that what we're gonna talk about,
the structure, or the ideals?

21
00:00:57.755 --> 00:01:01.240
>> Yeah, what we're gonna talk about
right now in this particular episode

22
00:01:01.240 --> 00:01:02.510
is the theme of planning.

23
00:01:02.510 --> 00:01:04.420
We're gonna talk about
the importance of planning,

24
00:01:04.420 --> 00:01:07.044
we're gonna talk about
the reason behind planning.

25
00:01:07.044 --> 00:01:10.370
Will we look at some structure?

26
00:01:10.370 --> 00:01:12.096
Well, we will look at
a little bit of structure.

27
00:01:12.096 --> 00:01:18.990
But planning is gonna be really purely
dependent on not only the project itself,

28
00:01:18.990 --> 00:01:23.750
and the type of project that we have, what
it is that we're delivering as a product.

29
00:01:23.750 --> 00:01:26.200
But also how we're delivering
it as a product, as well.

30
00:01:26.200 --> 00:01:31.143
When it comes to things like a waterfall
approach or maybe an agile approach,

31
00:01:31.143 --> 00:01:36.010
how are we actually going to be delivering
our product will have a huge effect

32
00:01:36.010 --> 00:01:38.155
on the type of plans that we make.

33
00:01:38.155 --> 00:01:41.319
Now funnily enough,
just before this episode, Justin and

34
00:01:41.319 --> 00:01:43.350
I were talking about documentation.

35
00:01:43.350 --> 00:01:47.951
And we were talking about sort of
planning and we were just talking about

36
00:01:47.951 --> 00:01:52.715
the fact that let's face it, here in IT,
we don't like documentation.

37
00:01:52.715 --> 00:01:53.314
Look, see?

38
00:01:53.314 --> 00:01:54.658
I know he doesn't.

39
00:01:54.658 --> 00:01:58.842
>> I don't like writing it, but
you know what I dislike more?

40
00:01:58.842 --> 00:02:00.138
Not having it.

41
00:02:00.138 --> 00:02:01.314
>> Right.

42
00:02:01.314 --> 00:02:02.706
>> Which is kind of this weird dichotomy.

43
00:02:02.706 --> 00:02:04.090
>> You can't have it both ways, right?

44
00:02:04.090 --> 00:02:07.150
>> You're like, I hate writing it, but
I really hate more when I don't have it.

45
00:02:07.150 --> 00:02:10.744
So sometimes I just suck it up and
I write minimal documentation.

46
00:02:10.744 --> 00:02:14.960
If nothing else then a quick reference or
I can hand it to you and go, hey,

47
00:02:14.960 --> 00:02:16.563
here's a quick overview.

48
00:02:16.563 --> 00:02:19.140
>> Sometimes, and
I'm gonna be honest here.

49
00:02:19.140 --> 00:02:22.515
This is my confession time
here because sometimes,

50
00:02:22.515 --> 00:02:27.343
I feel a little bit out of place at here
at ITproTV because I am the only person

51
00:02:27.343 --> 00:02:32.193
that has anything to do with governance
whatsoever, [LAUGH] in this place.

52
00:02:32.193 --> 00:02:37.689
And I am surrounded by other edutainers
who are very, very technical.

53
00:02:37.689 --> 00:02:40.585
Now, I have to admit that I'm not young.

54
00:02:40.585 --> 00:02:45.454
And so I left all of my sorta technical
world behind quite a long time ago, and

55
00:02:45.454 --> 00:02:48.512
I'm surrounded by people
that are technical.

56
00:02:48.512 --> 00:02:52.546
But then, I often look at these people and
I think, and

57
00:02:52.546 --> 00:02:55.023
this is the reason why I'm here.

58
00:02:55.023 --> 00:02:58.312
Because it's really easy.

59
00:02:58.312 --> 00:03:00.100
It's really, really easy for

60
00:03:00.100 --> 00:03:04.993
technical people to just get themselves
concentrated just on the technicalities.

61
00:03:04.993 --> 00:03:10.950
Just on configuration of servers,
just on the development of products.

62
00:03:10.950 --> 00:03:16.472
And if we don't have any documentations,
if we don't have any plans,

63
00:03:16.472 --> 00:03:20.994
if we don't have any governance,
then it's just chaos.

64
00:03:20.994 --> 00:03:23.690
And, it's great having technical people.

65
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:29.134
And in fact, I wouldn't be here, and none
of us would be here, in our IT environment

66
00:03:29.134 --> 00:03:33.833
and in our business environment,
if we didn't have technical people.

67
00:03:33.833 --> 00:03:37.873
But if there isn't any governance
behind the technical people,

68
00:03:37.873 --> 00:03:42.206
if there isn't a way of working,
if there isn't any documentation,

69
00:03:42.206 --> 00:03:44.198
if there isn't any structure.

70
00:03:44.198 --> 00:03:47.669
Then what happens is everybody
just does what they want to do,

71
00:03:47.669 --> 00:03:49.020
when they want to do it.

72
00:03:49.020 --> 00:03:51.821
And you can imagine,
not just the chaos, but

73
00:03:51.821 --> 00:03:56.121
also the quality of the work that's
then delivered to the business.

74
00:03:56.121 --> 00:04:02.370
Without any structured processes, without
any plans, without any documentation.

75
00:04:02.370 --> 00:04:07.210
What we do is, well,
we drive our business to use somebody

76
00:04:07.210 --> 00:04:10.620
else as an IT service provider,
that's exactly what we do.

77
00:04:10.620 --> 00:04:13.650
Because we do have to
have some governance,

78
00:04:13.650 --> 00:04:16.420
we do have to have some structure.

79
00:04:16.420 --> 00:04:20.290
Now I'm a big advocate of
the keep it simple approach.

80
00:04:20.290 --> 00:04:24.440
And certainly within any of our
management methodologies and

81
00:04:24.440 --> 00:04:28.591
frameworks here at ITProTV and
certainly when we're looking

82
00:04:28.591 --> 00:04:33.555
at in this particular instance,
we're looking at an AXELOS framework.

83
00:04:33.555 --> 00:04:37.215
Or when we're looking at
EXIN-based frameworks,

84
00:04:37.215 --> 00:04:41.800
when we're looking at other
frameworks such as TOGAF and COBIT.

85
00:04:41.800 --> 00:04:43.600
And even when we're looking at CMMI for

86
00:04:43.600 --> 00:04:48.780
process maturity, there has to be
an element of keep it simple there.

87
00:04:48.780 --> 00:04:51.830
But there also has to be
element of structure.

88
00:04:51.830 --> 00:04:56.457
We want mature processes, and by maturity
we mean that we want processes and

89
00:04:56.457 --> 00:05:01.630
we want methodologies that are attuned
to the needs of the organization.

90
00:05:01.630 --> 00:05:05.270
We want processes and
methodologies that are developed for

91
00:05:05.270 --> 00:05:08.790
the needs of the organization, but
you know the one thing that we don't want?

92
00:05:08.790 --> 00:05:13.220
And I have to say I sent
an email earlier on today and

93
00:05:13.220 --> 00:05:15.230
somebody asked me what my pet peeve was.

94
00:05:15.230 --> 00:05:16.720
And you know what my pet peeve is, and

95
00:05:16.720 --> 00:05:18.920
that's probably because
I'm a process person and

96
00:05:18.920 --> 00:05:22.860
because I'm a governance person,
my pet peeve though is bureaucracy.

97
00:05:22.860 --> 00:05:25.450
I hate bureaucracy and I hate red tape.

98
00:05:25.450 --> 00:05:28.290
And if you've got too much bureaucracy and
you've got too much red tape,

99
00:05:28.290 --> 00:05:30.280
then you're doing all of this wrong.

100
00:05:30.280 --> 00:05:34.100
So, if you perceive, and
I'll go back to Justin now.

101
00:05:34.100 --> 00:05:39.670
If you perceive your documentation to
be a complete pain to have to complete,

102
00:05:39.670 --> 00:05:42.560
then it's been configured wrong.

103
00:05:42.560 --> 00:05:45.700
Cuz your documentation,
we should be keeping it simple,

104
00:05:45.700 --> 00:05:49.900
it should be explicit enough and
this is the same in our plans.

105
00:05:49.900 --> 00:05:53.530
They should be explicit enough
to be able to do the work.

106
00:05:53.530 --> 00:05:57.480
They should also be flexible enough to
allow you tolerances within which to

107
00:05:57.480 --> 00:05:58.630
do the work.

108
00:05:58.630 --> 00:06:06.684
But it also should be simple enough
to not restrict you doing your work.

109
00:06:06.684 --> 00:06:10.296
And simple enough to not restrict
you in your day-to-day business.

110
00:06:10.296 --> 00:06:13.290
It shouldn't be over-complex and
it shouldn't be.

111
00:06:13.290 --> 00:06:18.339
None of your plans, none of your
documentation, they definitely shouldn't

112
00:06:18.339 --> 00:06:23.170
be bureaucratic and filled with red
tape and lots of hoops to jump through.

113
00:06:23.170 --> 00:06:26.950
Because if that's the way that you have
your project management structured.

114
00:06:26.950 --> 00:06:29.580
If that's the way you have
your services structured,

115
00:06:29.580 --> 00:06:32.030
then what's going to happen is
you're gonna end up with chaos.

116
00:06:32.030 --> 00:06:36.522
Cuz you're gonna end up with a lot of IT
technical people that want to bypass these

117
00:06:36.522 --> 00:06:39.720
processes because that's just what we do.

118
00:06:39.720 --> 00:06:42.707
We don't like paperwork really.

119
00:06:42.707 --> 00:06:44.325
>> I can't argue that I
don't like paper work.

120
00:06:44.325 --> 00:06:46.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I am seeing people use those

121
00:06:46.600 --> 00:06:50.450
excuses as a, well,
it's gonna take up a lot of time.

122
00:06:50.450 --> 00:06:51.520
It's a lot of energy.

123
00:06:51.520 --> 00:06:53.630
It takes so much.

124
00:06:53.630 --> 00:06:56.990
And I guess initially
when you first start out.

125
00:06:56.990 --> 00:06:58.901
Sometimes you're like, this is simple.

126
00:06:58.901 --> 00:07:02.094
But you may find out that it's not
quite as simple as possible but

127
00:07:02.094 --> 00:07:06.250
that's where continual improvement of
your respective process comes into play.

128
00:07:06.250 --> 00:07:11.110
If I say, hey Jo, we fill out this
documentation for this thing and

129
00:07:11.110 --> 00:07:16.235
then you go, well hey, so
this takes me like 20 minutes per thing.

130
00:07:16.235 --> 00:07:17.000
>> Yeah.

131
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:19.780
>> Then at that point you go,
well let's reevaluate.

132
00:07:19.780 --> 00:07:21.310
>> Right.
>> Because it's not as simple

133
00:07:21.310 --> 00:07:23.760
as we originally thought we had made it,
right?

134
00:07:23.760 --> 00:07:27.970
>> We talk about documentation and
planning specifically, but

135
00:07:27.970 --> 00:07:31.780
documentation is meeting
the needs of the organization.

136
00:07:31.780 --> 00:07:35.840
We talk about our processes as needing
to meet the needs of the organization.

137
00:07:35.840 --> 00:07:39.058
If the needs of the organization
are that we want efficiency and

138
00:07:39.058 --> 00:07:40.766
we want things to be kept simple.

139
00:07:40.766 --> 00:07:45.099
Then bringing in a process and bringing in
documentation that is too bureaucratic,

140
00:07:45.099 --> 00:07:47.783
that has too many steps,
that is not simple enough,

141
00:07:47.783 --> 00:07:50.358
well that's not meeting your needs then,
is it?

142
00:07:50.358 --> 00:07:53.153
Because your needs are for simplicity.

143
00:07:53.153 --> 00:07:59.647
So we have to consider that our needs
are not separate to the processes.

144
00:07:59.647 --> 00:08:03.370
The processes are actually
part of our needs.

145
00:08:03.370 --> 00:08:08.620
One of the other things that organizations
do, is that organizations will say well,

146
00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:11.180
I understand that our IT people need to,

147
00:08:11.180 --> 00:08:16.510
well they need to have
some degree of structure.

148
00:08:16.510 --> 00:08:20.590
Our IT people need to have
some degree of management.

149
00:08:20.590 --> 00:08:23.864
And so what we're gonna do is instead
of actually sitting them down and

150
00:08:23.864 --> 00:08:27.927
saying this is the way we do things here,
here's our standard operating procedures.

151
00:08:27.927 --> 00:08:32.052
We're going to compensate for
these standard operating procedures,

152
00:08:32.052 --> 00:08:36.252
by sending them on a PRINCE2 course or,
sending them on an ITIL course.

153
00:08:36.252 --> 00:08:39.650
Because then that way,
they can get their foundation training,

154
00:08:39.650 --> 00:08:43.123
they'll understand why we need to
have this sort of bureaucracy.

155
00:08:43.123 --> 00:08:48.630
And then because we need this sort of
structure, now they understand it.

156
00:08:48.630 --> 00:08:51.990
Well we don't need to give them any more
training and they should be able to come

157
00:08:51.990 --> 00:08:57.080
up with their own structure in terms of
documentation and in terms of planning.

158
00:08:57.080 --> 00:08:57.760
Well guess what?

159
00:08:57.760 --> 00:08:59.560
It doesn't work like that.

160
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:01.320
It really doesn't.

161
00:09:01.320 --> 00:09:05.090
Just because you being on a training
course, just because you have watched

162
00:09:05.090 --> 00:09:09.540
these episodes, does not mean that
you're then able to apply it.

163
00:09:09.540 --> 00:09:13.960
And the whole idea of project
management is to manage a product,

164
00:09:13.960 --> 00:09:18.570
that manage a product through
to delivery to the real world,

165
00:09:18.570 --> 00:09:20.550
to the live environment, to your business.

166
00:09:21.640 --> 00:09:24.900
The whole idea of PRINCE2
of a framework and

167
00:09:24.900 --> 00:09:29.690
of a methodology is to deliver quality.

168
00:09:29.690 --> 00:09:31.980
But it's to deliver it in a way,

169
00:09:31.980 --> 00:09:36.790
that is not bound by bureaucracy,
that is not too cumbersome.

170
00:09:36.790 --> 00:09:41.530
Because if it was a cumbersome approach,
and it was just tied up in red tape,

171
00:09:41.530 --> 00:09:44.170
then we'd never get anything delivered.

172
00:09:44.170 --> 00:09:47.570
So we need to have structure, but
we also need to have flexibility.

173
00:09:49.100 --> 00:09:49.780
You think?

174
00:09:49.780 --> 00:09:53.090
>> So it's funny Jo because
kinda what I'm hearing and

175
00:09:53.090 --> 00:09:58.280
definitely correct me if I'm wrong is,
we should agree as an organization like,

176
00:09:58.280 --> 00:10:01.536
here's what I've seen,
we need documentation.

177
00:10:01.536 --> 00:10:02.395
>> Yeah.

178
00:10:02.395 --> 00:10:06.144
>> And then,
there's this very abstract decree.

179
00:10:06.144 --> 00:10:11.350
You shall write documentation, and
then it's just a free for all.

180
00:10:11.350 --> 00:10:15.430
But if we have structure,
kind of a pre-agreed upon set of,

181
00:10:15.430 --> 00:10:18.810
like this is how it's done,
then by doing that,

182
00:10:18.810 --> 00:10:22.440
number one, we can evaluate whether
it's working for us or not.

183
00:10:22.440 --> 00:10:24.960
But also, even if we're
working on different projects,

184
00:10:24.960 --> 00:10:29.810
we now share that common thought process,
and we're going to become more

185
00:10:29.810 --> 00:10:33.380
efficient over time even if it does
take us a little bit of time initially.

186
00:10:33.380 --> 00:10:36.330
You go, I know how to do this,
regardless of whether it's project A,

187
00:10:36.330 --> 00:10:37.208
project B, project C.

188
00:10:37.208 --> 00:10:39.289
>> Yeah, so
we're looking at consistency there.

189
00:10:39.289 --> 00:10:42.283
But the other thing is, do you know
what the word efficiency means?

190
00:10:42.283 --> 00:10:43.621
Do you know what efficient means?

191
00:10:43.621 --> 00:10:47.928
>> So, how much output I'm getting for
a given input.

192
00:10:47.928 --> 00:10:49.366
I'm sorry, I've went physics on you.

193
00:10:49.366 --> 00:10:50.933
>> And yeah, all right, yeah.

194
00:10:50.933 --> 00:10:55.303
>> Yeah, so if I put in 300 joules,
then I get out 270 joules,

195
00:10:55.303 --> 00:10:57.214
I have a 90% efficiency.

196
00:10:57.214 --> 00:10:59.680
>> So you're looking at how
efficient something is, but

197
00:10:59.680 --> 00:11:00.920
what does efficient mean?

198
00:11:02.220 --> 00:11:05.240
I don't mean how efficient is something,
it's an assumption.

199
00:11:05.240 --> 00:11:06.800
What do you mean by efficient?

200
00:11:06.800 --> 00:11:12.468
>> Efficient, again,
sorry physics, science brain.

201
00:11:12.468 --> 00:11:13.072
>> Go on.

202
00:11:13.072 --> 00:11:16.948
>> When I think efficient,
I'm like there is a threshold,

203
00:11:16.948 --> 00:11:22.310
of how much output I'm getting for a given
input for me to term it as efficient.

204

doesn't it?

00:23:53.070 --> 00:23:54.870
But you know what I mean by that.

430
00:23:54.870 --> 00:23:57.400
So what we wanna do is we
want to have a plan for

431
00:23:57.400 --> 00:24:01.350
how we're going to plan every
single individual project.

432
00:24:01.350 --> 00:24:05.440
And that plan, that initial plan,
that's going to be our, and

433
00:24:05.440 --> 00:24:08.000
I hate the use of the word template but
it's the best word to use,

434
00:24:08.000 --> 00:24:10.420
that's gonna be our template for
moving forward.

435
00:24:12.130 --> 00:24:16.740
So what I'm gonna do, because we've had
quite a good discussion really on planning

436
00:24:16.740 --> 00:24:21.560
and the need for planning and the reason
for planning, what I'm gonna do now is

437
00:24:21.560 --> 00:24:26.386
before we get into the levels of planning
that we need, we're gonna take a break.

438
00:24:26.386 --> 00:24:28.622
And we're gonna come
back in our next episode.

439
00:24:28.622 --> 00:24:32.400
And in our next episode, we're gonna
take a look at the types of plans and

440
00:24:32.400 --> 00:24:34.490
the level of planning that we really need.

441
00:24:34.490 --> 00:24:37.763
>> Well, Jo, we definitely need a little
time to digest all of that, because we got

442
00:24:37.763 --> 00:24:40.960
a little meta there near the end,
we're gonna plan out how we're gonna plan.

443
00:24:40.960 --> 00:24:43.532
>> [LAUGH]
>> But there's still some details to flesh

444
00:24:43.532 --> 00:24:46.430
out there, so
definitely join us back for part two.

445
00:24:46.430 --> 00:24:48.350
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

446
00:24:48.350 --> 00:24:51.160
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

447
00:24:51.160 --> 00:24:51.920
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

448
00:24:51.920 --> 00:24:53.114
>> And we'll see you next time.

449
00:24:53.114 --> 00:24:59.425
[MUSIC]

450
00:24:59.425 --> 00:25:02.443
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Plans theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Plans Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.868
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.868 --> 00:00:04.952
Coming to you live from San Francisco.

3
00:00:04.952 --> 00:00:06.272
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.272 --> 00:00:08.138
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.138 --> 00:00:12.860
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings everyone and

6
00:00:12.860 --> 00:00:15.870
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:15.870 --> 00:00:17.010
I'm your host Justin Dennison and

8
00:00:17.010 --> 00:00:21.000
we're continuing on with our
PRINCE2 2017 Foundation series.

9
00:00:21.000 --> 00:00:23.480
And well, we're coming back with
a part two, yeah, that's right,

10
00:00:23.480 --> 00:00:25.540
a part two in our plan theme.

11
00:00:25.540 --> 00:00:28.004
If you haven't checked out part one,
definitely go check that out.

12
00:00:28.004 --> 00:00:32.621
And here to help us further along our
understanding of the plan theme is Ms.

13
00:00:32.621 --> 00:00:33.437
Jo Peacock.

14
00:00:33.437 --> 00:00:35.932
How are you doing today Jo?
>> Absolutely great, thank you Justin,

15
00:00:35.932 --> 00:00:36.490
how are you?

16
00:00:36.490 --> 00:00:41.075
I am doing fantastic and in the previous
episode we looked at that giant chart but

17
00:00:41.075 --> 00:00:43.958
we were like,
well it's a little overwhelming.

18
00:00:43.958 --> 00:00:48.222
But it was really like you should think
about these things, how make these like

19
00:00:48.222 --> 00:00:50.490
a templated, what you said.
>> Yep.

20
00:00:50.490 --> 00:00:51.870
>> The word is

21
00:00:51.870 --> 00:00:53.940
kinda difficult to come up
with an appropriate word.

22
00:00:53.940 --> 00:00:55.073
But where are we're going here?

23
00:00:55.073 --> 00:00:57.580
We talked about that templated thing.
>> Well, what we

24
00:00:57.580 --> 00:01:00.930
talked about in our last episode was we
talked about having some consistency.

25
00:01:00.930 --> 00:01:04.410
We talked about having
a standardized approach to.

26
00:01:04.410 --> 00:01:06.080
Yeah, that makes a better word?

27
00:01:06.080 --> 00:01:06.840
Yeah.
>> Yeah,

28
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:12.150
I think that when we think templated,
I think we'll go print out form.

29
00:01:12.150 --> 00:01:13.831
Let me go to the printer and,

30
00:01:13.831 --> 00:01:17.627
but that's not templated in
the construct of this is what we do.

31
00:01:17.627 --> 00:01:18.739
I think standardized is
a more appropriate provision.

32
00:01:18.739 --> 00:01:20.587
>> Yeah, we want a standardized approach.

33
00:01:20.587 --> 00:01:25.516
We want an approach that can be applied
to absolutely every single project,

34
00:01:25.516 --> 00:01:27.960
but that is not too specific.

35
00:01:27.960 --> 00:01:29.751
So we need an approach that's flexible.

36
00:01:29.751 --> 00:01:34.069
We need an approach that can be customized
to every single project but it's

37
00:01:34.069 --> 00:01:39.350
a standard approach so that we know that
our project has to go through these steps.

38
00:01:39.350 --> 00:01:41.890
These people need to be involved.

39
00:01:41.890 --> 00:01:46.870
And we know that that there are certain
things that have to happen as part

40
00:01:46.870 --> 00:01:48.034
of the project.

41
00:01:48.034 --> 00:01:52.683
So let's take a look then at the levels of
planning that we have within a project.

42
00:01:52.683 --> 00:01:56.546
Now, anything that, and
I know that I've said this before, but

43
00:01:56.546 --> 00:01:59.074
anything that is purple in your diagrams,

44
00:01:59.074 --> 00:02:04.007
that comes straight out of your PRINCE2
book, your PRINCE2 manual from AXELOS.

45
00:02:04.007 --> 00:02:06.839
Whilst you don't necessarily
need that book for

46
00:02:06.839 --> 00:02:10.993
your foundation exam, you will need
that for your practitioner exam.

47
00:02:10.993 --> 00:02:15.682
So these materials that available to
you for download are suitable for

48
00:02:15.682 --> 00:02:17.279
your foundation exam.

49
00:02:17.279 --> 00:02:22.670
And your foundation exam is a closed book
exam, but you will need to have the book

50
00:02:22.670 --> 00:02:28.170
for your practitioner test if you wish to
go on to do your PRINCE2 practitioner.

51
00:02:28.170 --> 00:02:32.390
So you'll see here what we've
got are levels of plan here.

52
00:02:32.390 --> 00:02:37.240
Now, you'll notice that we've kind of
split it into two, so right at the very

53
00:02:37.240 --> 00:02:40.950
top you've got what the customer
requirements are and the customer's plans.

54
00:02:40.950 --> 00:02:46.260
And of course the customer is going to
give you lots of input in terms of time,

55
00:02:46.260 --> 00:02:52.550
in terms of the cost or basically what
their budget is when they want it.

56
00:02:52.550 --> 00:02:54.010
What it is that they want to see.

57
00:02:54.010 --> 00:02:56.610
And what we're going to do
is we're gonna come up with

58
00:02:56.610 --> 00:02:58.860
what we call an initiation plan.

59
00:02:58.860 --> 00:03:01.940
And that initiation plan is the, well,

60
00:03:01.940 --> 00:03:06.110
it's all of the information that I
need to be able to start my project.

61
00:03:06.110 --> 00:03:09.490
So, what is my project going to look like?

62
00:03:09.490 --> 00:03:10.980
Is it gonna be an agile approach?

63
00:03:10.980 --> 00:03:12.790
Is it going to be a waterfall approach?

64
00:03:13.810 --> 00:03:16.480
How many people
are involved in my project?

65
00:03:16.480 --> 00:03:19.340
Who's going to be on my project board?

66
00:03:19.340 --> 00:03:21.550
What time scales are we talking about?

67
00:03:21.550 --> 00:03:24.280
How much money do we have to spend?

68
00:03:24.280 --> 00:03:28.920
All of that is going to be
in our initiation plan.

69
00:03:28.920 --> 00:03:30.340
And then that next column,

70
00:03:30.340 --> 00:03:33.180
the column in the middle is
the actual project plan itself.

71
00:03:33.180 --> 00:03:37.550
So this is how are we going
to get through the project?

72
00:03:37.550 --> 00:03:39.180
Managing by stages.

73
00:03:39.180 --> 00:03:43.270
How are we moving from
one stage to the next?

74
00:03:43.270 --> 00:03:45.420
How many stages are there?

75
00:03:45.420 --> 00:03:47.940
How do we get from this stage?

76
00:03:47.940 --> 00:03:52.630
What boxes do we have to take in order
to be able to move from here to here?

77
00:03:52.630 --> 00:03:54.460
So these are our stage plan.

78
00:03:54.460 --> 00:03:59.306
So we have that overarching project
plan and then we have the stage plans.

79
00:03:59.306 --> 00:04:05.370
Underpinning the plan for each stage
are going to be individual team plans.

80
00:04:05.370 --> 00:04:09.594
And these are the plans that are for
the developers.

81
00:04:09.594 --> 00:04:13.109
So these are the plans where
each developer gets to say, and

82
00:04:13.109 --> 00:04:17.160
this is what I should be working
on at his particular point.

83
00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:19.850
Now don't forget what's on
the right-hand side here, and

84
00:04:19.850 --> 00:04:22.810
I see Justin's looking at
this with a little bit of,

85
00:04:22.810 --> 00:04:27.890
I don't know, concern I think.
>> I don't know if it's concern but

86
00:04:27.890 --> 00:04:30.590
I just want to make sure I'm not.

87
00:04:30.590 --> 00:04:32.361
So when we create our plan,

88
00:04:32.361 --> 00:04:34.091
this overarching goal.
>> Yep.

89
00:04:34.091 --> 00:04:36.130
>> These stage plans.

90
00:04:36.130 --> 00:04:40.009
We don't go crazy with putting
all of that out front, do we?

91
00:04:40.009 --> 00:04:43.534
Are these stage plans more of
an incremental like I have these first two

92
00:04:43.534 --> 00:04:47.472
stages and once I get to there, I know
what my end goal is, I still have an idea,

93
00:04:47.472 --> 00:04:49.525
but I still make it a further stage plan.

94
00:04:49.525 --> 00:04:52.186
Am I continuously, now wait a minute,

95
00:04:52.186 --> 00:04:55.655
continually planning at
the end of those stages and

96
00:04:55.655 --> 00:04:59.239
not trying to do all of that upfront?
>> Right, okay, and

97
00:04:59.239 --> 00:05:00.989
that's an important point to make.

98
00:05:00.989 --> 00:05:08.135
So your vision, your long-term project
goal, you don't want to plan in detail.

99
00:05:08.135 --> 00:05:12.910
You have your long-term project goal and
that should always be your goal.

100
00:05:12.910 --> 00:05:17.710
You have to bear in mind [COUGH] excuse
me, that that could be subject to change.

101
00:05:17.710 --> 00:05:22.340
Yeah, we've talked about scope creep and
we talked about sort of exceptions,

102
00:05:22.340 --> 00:05:25.010
things that might happen
that you weren't expecting.

103
00:05:25.010 --> 00:05:28.120
Your long-term goal is going to be there,
but

104
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:32.844
how you get to that long-term goal,
you plan the next step in detail.

105
00:05:32.844 --> 00:05:37.382
But because what each subsequent stage
is going to be, well it's not even

106
00:05:37.382 --> 00:05:42.860
predominantly based, it's purely based
on what happened in the previous stage.

107
00:05:42.860 --> 00:05:47.160
You cannot plan the long
term in great detail.

108
00:05:47.160 --> 00:05:48.111
Let's think about this.

109
00:05:48.111 --> 00:05:53.611
If I was walking towards an end goal,
and I was gonna take one

110
00:05:53.611 --> 00:05:59.115
step after another,
then I am going to plan this next step.

111
00:05:59.115 --> 00:06:05.340
And I'm not gonna plan the next step
until after I've got here, why?

112
00:06:05.340 --> 00:06:07.921
Because this first step
might not actually go,

113
00:06:07.921 --> 00:06:10.831
well I might not take as wide
a stride as I expected to.

114
00:06:10.831 --> 00:06:13.701
I might not get to where
I wanted to get to or

115
00:06:13.701 --> 00:06:16.904
I might actually overshoot and
achieve more.

116
00:06:16.904 --> 00:06:21.140
And if that happens,
that's why we have exception planning.

117
00:06:21.140 --> 00:06:22.130
If that happens,

118
00:06:22.130 --> 00:06:25.950
then any plans that I've done from
here on outwards will be obsolete.

119
00:06:25.950 --> 00:06:28.484
And that will be
an inefficient thing to do.

120
00:06:28.484 --> 00:06:31.681
It's not efficient to plan
the long term in great detail,

121
00:06:31.681 --> 00:06:36.070
because we simply don't know where we're
gonna get to with every single step.

122
00:06:36.070 --> 00:06:38.701
Does that make sense?
>> Then that makes sense, for

123
00:06:38.701 --> 00:06:42.046
some reason the vision of coming
up to a rickety bridge over

124
00:06:42.046 --> 00:06:44.036
a canyon river with a rope bridge.

125
00:06:44.036 --> 00:06:46.157
And I know this is negative imagery.
>> But

126
00:06:46.157 --> 00:06:46.848
okay.
>> But

127
00:06:46.848 --> 00:06:50.167
you're really focused on the couple
of steps in front of you, right?

128
00:06:50.167 --> 00:06:51.648
The one-
>> No, I'm focused on turning around and

129
00:06:51.648 --> 00:06:53.576
going back the other way.
>> Well, there's that,

130
00:06:53.576 --> 00:06:55.421
we're using this as a metaphor.

131
00:06:55.421 --> 00:06:57.125
I would not be on that bridge either,
right?

132
00:06:57.125 --> 00:06:57.711
>> [LAUGH]

133
00:06:57.711 --> 00:06:59.096
>> But you're like okay,

134
00:06:59.096 --> 00:07:01.726
I can't look at that
plank that might be broke

135
00:07:01.726 --> 00:07:05.690
halfway across the bridge until I
make those first couple of steps.

136
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:07.533
I need to get to the other side,
that's my goal.

137
00:07:07.533 --> 00:07:09.811
For some reason that's what came to mind,
Jo.

138
00:07:09.811 --> 00:07:13.221
It is somewhat of an odd imagery, but
I'm like okay, that really make sense,

139
00:07:13.221 --> 00:07:16.683
I wanna look directly [CROSSTALK]
>> I mean, this face says it all.

140
00:07:16.683 --> 00:07:19.523
I mean, I kind of understand
where you are going to

141
00:07:19.523 --> 00:07:22.229
with that one but
seriously I would be running in

142
00:07:22.229 --> 00:07:25.179
the opposite direction.
>> Maybe there's lions in the other

143
00:07:25.179 --> 00:07:25.753
direction.

144
00:07:25.753 --> 00:07:28.455
[LAUGH]
>> Do you know what,

145
00:07:28.455 --> 00:07:30.532
I'd rather face the lions.
>> I don't know,

146
00:07:30.532 --> 00:07:32.720
I'd take my chances with the bridge.

147
00:07:32.720 --> 00:07:35.780
But if you do decide to take your chances,
you're looking right in front of you.

148
00:07:35.780 --> 00:07:39.880
>> One step at a time, one step at a time.

149
00:07:39.880 --> 00:07:43.566
And one of the things we talk about
when we talk about continual improvement

150
00:07:43.566 --> 00:07:46.912
is that continual improvement is
making iterative improvements.

151
00:07:46.912 --> 00:07:48.717
It's iterative progress.

152
00:07:48.717 --> 00:07:51.214
And that's what we need
to do every single step.

153
00:07:51.214 --> 00:07:55.504
Every single stage must build on
the progress that's been made by

154
00:07:55.504 --> 00:07:56.917
the previous stage.

155
00:07:56.917 --> 00:08:02.492
And so we do have those exception plans
that you can see on the right hand side

156
00:08:02.492 --> 00:08:09.310
that are there just simply to accommodate
where things have not gone as expected.

157
00:08:09.310 --> 00:08:12.700
I am not going to say where
things have gone wrong, okay?

158
00:08:12.700 --> 00:08:15.060
Cuz that's not always the case.

159
00:08:15.060 --> 00:08:17.190
Sometimes things don't go wrong, but

160
00:08:17.190 --> 00:08:20.910
sometimes customers change
their requirements.

161
00:08:20.910 --> 00:08:23.620
Or maybe, it's not the customers
that change their requirements,

162
00:08:23.620 --> 00:08:26.110
sometimes the business
changes their requirements.

163
00:08:26.110 --> 00:08:28.960
So it's not all about things going wrong,

164
00:08:28.960 --> 00:08:31.960
it's just about the fact
that things change.

165
00:08:31.960 --> 00:08:36.580
And so any exception planning
has to be planning for well,

166
00:08:36.580 --> 00:08:40.750
what do we need to do to change
in our subsequent stage?

167
00:08:40.750 --> 00:08:43.030
So here, and again,

168
00:08:43.030 --> 00:08:48.750
this comes from our PRINCE2 book,
here again we have a plan and approach.

169
00:08:48.750 --> 00:08:53.332
This is a PRINCE2 out of
the box planning approach.

170
00:08:53.332 --> 00:08:57.532
Now, I have already said that
I expect you to tailor this,

171
00:08:57.532 --> 00:09:03.220
that's the word that we use,
we're going to tailor this approach.

172
00:09:03.220 --> 00:09:07.990
Now, from your foundation, before your
foundation test you're gonna be expected

173
00:09:07.990 --> 00:09:10.575
to know what our plan and approach is.

174
00:09:10.575 --> 00:09:14.890
For your practitioner you're
gonna be expected to be able to

175
00:09:14.890 --> 00:09:16.470
tailor this approach.

176
00:09:16.470 --> 00:09:21.051
So you're gonna be expected to be able
to know what we should modify in certain

177
00:09:21.051 --> 00:09:24.857
situations and what it should
look like in certain situations,

178
00:09:24.857 --> 00:09:29.374
just bearing in mind that every single
organization is completely unique.

179
00:09:29.374 --> 00:09:31.850
And every single project is
completely unique as well.

180
00:09:33.410 --> 00:09:36.150
So what we're going to do is
we're gonna design our plan.

181
00:09:36.150 --> 00:09:38.970
That's a pre-requisite,
but that comes out front.

182
00:09:38.970 --> 00:09:42.480
This is what our consistent
approach is going to look like.

183
00:09:42.480 --> 00:09:46.400
And then we define and analyze
the products, that's what's needed, okay?

184
00:09:47.920 --> 00:09:52.710
Defining and
analyzing what is needed as an end goal.

185
00:09:52.710 --> 00:09:56.590
Remember, in this particular stage,
in this particular process,

186
00:09:56.590 --> 00:10:01.570
what we're doing is simply
defining an approach to planning.

187
00:10:02.860 --> 00:10:03.840
That's what we're doing.

188
00:10:03.840 --> 00:10:06.740
This is not delivering the product, okay?

189
00:10:06.740 --> 00:10:10.050
But this is just defining
the approach to planning.

190
00:10:10.050 --> 00:10:14.110
So we're going to design what
our plan should look like.

191
00:10:14.110 --> 00:10:18.470
We're gonna analyze the product,
we're gonna identify any activities and

192
00:10:18.470 --> 00:10:23.570
any dependencies that may exist on these
activities and then prepare estimates and

193
00:10:23.570 --> 00:10:28.620
prepare a schedule, or schedule,
as Justin might say, and

194
00:10:28.620 --> 00:10:31.480
then we document our project plan, okay?

195
00:10:31.480 --> 00:10:38.367
And documenting our project plan,
well, generally looks like this.

196
00:10:38.367 --> 00:10:40.380
Do you know what this is
on the right hand side?

197
00:10:42.290 --> 00:10:46.519
>> Is that a Gantt chart?

198
00:10:46.519 --> 00:10:48.264
>> Yeah, it's not normally purple,

199
00:10:48.264 --> 00:10:49.696
all right [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, a lot of times [CROSSTALK]

200
00:10:49.696 --> 00:10:50.744
>> [LAUGH]

201
00:10:50.744 --> 00:10:52.359
>> So there are a lot of programs that

202
00:10:52.359 --> 00:10:56.227
make them super fanciful or whatever but
this is something you can legitimately

203
00:10:56.227 --> 00:11:00.460
draw on a common whiteboard or something.
>> You can draw this on a whiteboard and

204
00:11:00.460 --> 00:11:05.324
quite often, when we're using Agile
approaches, then you will see what we call

205
00:11:05.324 --> 00:11:09.687
information radiators, and
information radiators are whiteboards or

206
00:11:09.687 --> 00:11:14.646
a central repository, a drop box, for
instance, where we keep out Gantt chart.

207
00:11:14.646 --> 00:11:19.800
And it'll actually allow us to track
progress through the project itself.

208
00:11:19.800 --> 00:11:23.910
So we can see just how far we've got and
we can see what's been achieved and

209
00:11:23.910 --> 00:11:25.580
what hasn't been achieved.

210
00:11:25.580 --> 00:11:29.800
And we should also be able to see when
things are needed by what management

211
00:11:29.800 --> 00:11:32.520
stage they should be in,
who's responsible for

212
00:11:32.520 --> 00:11:36.200
those activities and
where the dependencies lies as well.

213
00:11:36.200 --> 00:11:39.760
Ordinarily, what I will see on
those lines of that gap chart,

214
00:11:39.760 --> 00:11:43.740
is I will see little drop down
arrows that show dependencies.

215
00:11:43.740 --> 00:11:48.890
So, the fact that the detailed design
has got to be completed before

216
00:11:48.890 --> 00:11:51.830
the build happens, for instance.

217
00:11:51.830 --> 00:11:54.007
So I'll see dependencies quite often.

218
00:11:54.007 --> 00:11:56.230
Like I said, they're not often in purple.

219
00:11:57.810 --> 00:12:00.560
In fact, no, this has just come
straight out of the PRINCE2 book,

220
00:12:00.560 --> 00:12:02.670
I've not really seen
any that are in purple,

221
00:12:02.670 --> 00:12:06.445
it doesn't make for
really good reading for everybody, that.

222
00:12:07.540 --> 00:12:10.860
There are lots of tools out there, there
are a lot of free tools out there that

223
00:12:10.860 --> 00:12:16.010
will help you to achieve
a project Gantt chart.

224
00:12:16.010 --> 00:12:18.950
I would tell you, and
this is just my own personal opinion,

225
00:12:18.950 --> 00:12:24.380
I have seen projects where a Gantt
chart hasn't been created.

226
00:12:24.380 --> 00:12:29.280
Because you don't then have a high level
view of how that project is going to

227
00:12:29.280 --> 00:12:33.280
progress, it can be quite demoralizing for

228
00:12:33.280 --> 00:12:37.670
the team that are trying to
actually deliver the product,

229
00:12:37.670 --> 00:12:43.800
because they don't see how
much progress they're making,

230
00:12:43.800 --> 00:12:48.910
they don't see how close they
are getting towards their goal.

231
00:12:48.910 --> 00:12:51.660
And it can be quite demoralizing
if you're just working away and

232
00:12:51.660 --> 00:12:53.770
you're not seeing any achievement.

233
00:12:53.770 --> 00:12:58.890
So, it's always good, I find,
from a visibility perspective and

234
00:12:58.890 --> 00:13:04.600
from a motivational perspective, to have
some sort of Gantt chart visibility,

235
00:13:04.600 --> 00:13:07.660
something that allows the teams and

236
00:13:07.660 --> 00:13:10.870
all of your stakeholders to
see what the progress is.

237
00:13:10.870 --> 00:13:14.640
Now, one of the common questions that I
get asked at this point in time is do we

238
00:13:14.640 --> 00:13:17.030
make this Gantt chart
available to our customer?

239
00:13:17.030 --> 00:13:19.840
I can't answer that for you.

240
00:13:19.840 --> 00:13:22.540
I don't know, is the answer to that.

241
00:13:22.540 --> 00:13:27.000
You've got to decide, and
you've gotta decide based on things like

242
00:13:28.150 --> 00:13:30.860
how transparent do you want
to be to your customer, and

243
00:13:30.860 --> 00:13:33.780
how transparent do you want
to be to the business?

244
00:13:33.780 --> 00:13:37.510
But you've also gotta
temper that with well,

245
00:13:37.510 --> 00:13:41.600
what about setting expectations and
missetting expectations, rather?

246
00:13:41.600 --> 00:13:46.437
Cuz sometimes you promise something, and
you promise it by a certain time, and then

247
00:13:46.437 --> 00:13:50.936
what you're able to deliver is kind of
like half of that particular product and

248
00:13:50.936 --> 00:13:53.820
it's a month later than
you originally thought.

249
00:13:53.820 --> 00:13:58.030
So, do you choose to make
that public to the customers?

250
00:13:58.030 --> 00:14:02.808
That's entirely up to you,
we like transparency but at the same

251
00:14:02.808 --> 00:14:07.029
time it has to be your decision.
>> It seems that this would come

252
00:14:07.029 --> 00:14:11.135
with an appropriate education
about the usage of these tools for

253
00:14:11.135 --> 00:14:14.810
your respective teams or
a project particularly.

254
00:14:14.810 --> 00:14:19.200
Because, if someone has
not used a Gantt chart,

255
00:14:19.200 --> 00:14:23.470
right, they're not necessarily
difficult to read,

256
00:14:23.470 --> 00:14:27.097
I think there maybe
a misalignment of expectations.

257
00:14:27.097 --> 00:14:29.643
Say, this is when the delivery dated.

258
00:14:29.643 --> 00:14:33.830
No, no, this is our plan [LAUGH].

259
00:14:33.830 --> 00:14:38.920
There are things that can happen
that will continually alter this.

260
00:14:38.920 --> 00:14:41.700
>> It's like communication of any sort of

261
00:14:41.700 --> 00:14:43.300
schedule, it really is.

262
00:14:43.300 --> 00:14:51.830
You've gotta be really, really careful
because you could misset the expectations.

263
00:14:51.830 --> 00:14:55.950
And it's not just with the customers,
also with the team as well.

264
00:14:55.950 --> 00:15:01.667
And it can, if you don't keep it updated
and you don't keep to your time-frames,

265
00:15:01.667 --> 00:15:07.551
and you don't achieve your goals when you
think you're going to achieve your goals,

266
00:15:07.551 --> 00:15:10.104
it can be incredibly demoralizing.

267
00:15:10.104 --> 00:15:14.521
And it can have a negative effect,
because you would actually see, and

268
00:15:14.521 --> 00:15:19.085
the teams will actually see that maybe
a particular person is not actually

269
00:15:19.085 --> 00:15:23.796
keeping up with their activities, or
maybe a particular team doesn't seem

270
00:15:23.796 --> 00:15:27.366
to have as big a workload as
say some of the other teams do.

271
00:15:27.366 --> 00:15:32.858
So, I've seen Gantt charts that are used
as a weapon, a weapon to beat up other

272
00:15:32.858 --> 00:15:39.140
teams, and a weapon to justify why certain
teams don't get bonuses for instance.

273
00:15:39.140 --> 00:15:45.044
But I've also seen Gantt charts used
as a really good communication tool

274
00:15:45.044 --> 00:15:50.191
to add visibility to a project and
to the progress of a project.

275
00:15:50.191 --> 00:15:54.714
I like transparency but
I also like accuracy as well.

276
00:15:54.714 --> 00:16:00.624
And I am not a huge big fan of
displaying the Gantt chart for

277
00:16:00.624 --> 00:16:06.677
everybody to see,
when that Gantt chart is not accurate.

278
00:16:06.677 --> 00:16:11.531
And there are organizations where I
have performed some consultancy, and

279
00:16:11.531 --> 00:16:13.611
done some program management,

280
00:16:13.611 --> 00:16:19.017
in where I find that these organizations
don't want to make a Gantt chart visible.

281
00:16:19.017 --> 00:16:23.541
Because it's almost as though they are
then committing to certain deadlines and

282
00:16:23.541 --> 00:16:25.162
they don't want to do that.

283
00:16:25.162 --> 00:16:29.830
Well do you know what, if you do that then
you're not particularly being transparent.

284
00:16:29.830 --> 00:16:34.360
The customer has no visibility whatsoever
and therefore if the customer has

285
00:16:34.360 --> 00:16:37.560
no visibility then there's very
little trust there for the customer.

286
00:16:38.920 --> 00:16:39.950
You have to weigh that up.

287
00:16:39.950 --> 00:16:44.460
I can't answer the question for
you, but I would always say as

288
00:16:44.460 --> 00:16:48.150
long as your Gantt chart is accurate and
as long as you have your estimation and

289
00:16:48.150 --> 00:16:52.090
your planning correct, and
you know how many stages you want.

290
00:16:52.090 --> 00:16:56.280
And you know exactly what's going to
happen in each stage then there is

291
00:16:56.280 --> 00:17:01.100
absolutely no reason whatsoever why you
shouldn't communicate your Gantt chart and

292
00:17:01.100 --> 00:17:02.330
ensure that it's visible.

293
00:17:03.390 --> 00:17:05.420
One thing I will tell you about
your Gantt chart is though,

294
00:17:05.420 --> 00:17:08.290
you must keep it up to date,
it must be accurate.

295
00:17:09.490 --> 00:17:13.100
You don't put your Gantt chart at the
beginning of a project because that's your

296
00:17:13.100 --> 00:17:17.120
plan, that's your high-level plan and
then that's it, it doesn't happen.

297
00:17:17.120 --> 00:17:20.950
It doesn't get updated at all for
throughout the rest of the project.

298
00:17:20.950 --> 00:17:25.560
The other thing that the Gantt chart
doesn't contain, are detailed plans for

299
00:17:25.560 --> 00:17:27.160
every single team.

300
00:17:27.160 --> 00:17:33.110
If you remember,
if we go back to this particular diagram,

301
00:17:33.110 --> 00:17:37.630
you see your team plans
are underneath your project plan, so

302
00:17:37.630 --> 00:17:41.860
your project plan is displayed in
a pictorial way using the Gantt Chart.

303
00:17:41.860 --> 00:17:47.240
But your team plans are underneath that
and your team plans are where we find

304
00:17:47.240 --> 00:17:51.269
our individual development activities and

305
00:17:51.269 --> 00:17:54.690
individuals like QA and
testing activities.

306
00:17:54.690 --> 00:17:56.546
They will be in the team plans.

307
00:17:56.546 --> 00:18:03.780
I do not expect this Gantt chart to
have anything detailed in there.

308
00:18:03.780 --> 00:18:08.192
That is gonna be one heck of a cumbersome
document if that is what you have got

309
00:18:08.192 --> 00:18:08.830
in there.

310
00:18:10.380 --> 00:18:11.740
You're thinking.
>> I am.

311
00:18:11.740 --> 00:18:12.550
>> That's dangerous.

312
00:18:12.550 --> 00:18:14.460
>> I am, it sometimes is.

313
00:18:16.160 --> 00:18:19.980
And I'm a little over focused
on the Gantt chart, but

314
00:18:19.980 --> 00:18:25.070
I'm trying to make sure that I have
kind of this approach to planning.

315
00:18:25.070 --> 00:18:28.270
So, would you have a chart
like this that is for

316
00:18:28.270 --> 00:18:32.140
the entire scope of the project
that may be less detailed.

317
00:18:32.140 --> 00:18:37.440
We're talking very microscopic,
these are overall kinda thought process.

318
00:18:37.440 --> 00:18:42.000
But then would you have these also for
the respective stage plans,

319
00:18:42.000 --> 00:18:46.390
where it is more detailed or
more kind of zoomed in.

320
00:18:46.390 --> 00:18:50.276
So you would have, here's my overall goal,
here's our ultimate timeline but

321
00:18:50.276 --> 00:18:51.621
they are very broad goals.

322
00:18:51.621 --> 00:18:54.981
We're gonna finish our
plan during this time or

323
00:18:54.981 --> 00:18:57.240
design rather.
>> Yeah.

324
00:18:57.240 --> 00:18:59.400
>> But then for that stage you would have

325
00:18:59.400 --> 00:19:03.520
kind of this inset, the subset where you
go in order to do that, this is what we're

326
00:19:03.520 --> 00:19:05.940
going to do over these set of times.
>> What I'm.

327
00:19:05.940 --> 00:19:06.900
>> Or I'm over thinking this?

328
00:19:06.900 --> 00:19:07.960
>> No, no, no, you know what

329
00:19:07.960 --> 00:19:11.550
I'm expecting to see is my overall
project plan is going to look like that.

330
00:19:11.550 --> 00:19:13.280
What's on the screen in
front of you right now.

331
00:19:13.280 --> 00:19:16.360
That's what my overall project
plan is gonna look like.

332
00:19:16.360 --> 00:19:19.880
But then, let's say for instance,
for management stage two.

333
00:19:19.880 --> 00:19:22.470
You will see that we've
got two things going on.

334
00:19:22.470 --> 00:19:25.890
We've got a detail design and
we've got a training syllabus.

335
00:19:25.890 --> 00:19:30.920
So, I'd expect both of those bars to be

336
00:19:30.920 --> 00:19:36.500
exploded out into individual plans for
the teams that are working on those.

337
00:19:36.500 --> 00:19:39.340
Bear in mind that they might
be cross functional as well.

338
00:19:39.340 --> 00:19:41.360
But I'd expect those to be exploded out.

339
00:19:41.360 --> 00:19:45.140
And I expect the hierarchy
to look like that.

340
00:19:46.370 --> 00:19:53.710
So my overall plan is, well,
it's my overarching project plan.

341
00:19:53.710 --> 00:19:58.109
But underneath that project plan,
then, underneath each of those lines,

342
00:19:58.109 --> 00:19:59.903
I expect to see them blown out.

343
00:19:59.903 --> 00:20:05.276
Now, whether you're gonna use
exactly the same tool to do that.

344
00:20:05.276 --> 00:20:06.717
That would be the most efficient and

345
00:20:06.717 --> 00:20:08.985
that's what we're talking
about is efficiency here.

346
00:20:08.985 --> 00:20:11.907
That would certainly be
the most efficient, but

347
00:20:11.907 --> 00:20:15.978
that again is something that's
entirely up to your organization.

348
00:20:15.978 --> 00:20:18.684
We're not going to tell
you what tools to use, but

349
00:20:18.684 --> 00:20:21.338
that's certainly something
that you could do.

350
00:20:21.338 --> 00:20:26.718
I've also seen other tools being used
at that point in time where each

351
00:20:26.718 --> 00:20:32.350
individual team plan is then,
presented and a different tool.

352
00:20:32.350 --> 00:20:34.930
There's a danger in that
in that you update one and

353
00:20:34.930 --> 00:20:36.910
it doesn't necessarily update the other.

354
00:20:36.910 --> 00:20:41.940
And of course, again what I'd said to
you previously about letting the tools

355
00:20:41.940 --> 00:20:46.820
actually facilitate our efficiency
in our previous episode.

356
00:20:46.820 --> 00:20:50.975
That's exactly where we want to be, and
having separate tools, having disparate

357
00:20:50.975 --> 00:20:56.455
tools to mange our project planning
is not going to promote efficiency.

358
00:20:56.455 --> 00:20:59.845
It's going to promote duplication
which is not efficient.

359
00:20:59.845 --> 00:21:03.855
It's also going to promote
errors potentially as well.

360
00:21:03.855 --> 00:21:07.885
Those errors being that if I've
got one plan that says this and

361
00:21:07.885 --> 00:21:11.975
has this timeline, and I've got
another plan that has this timeline,

362
00:21:11.975 --> 00:21:13.845
then how do I know which is accurate?

363
00:21:14.990 --> 00:21:21.045
And so we wanna have, well, we wanna
be as efficient as we possibly can.

364
00:21:21.045 --> 00:21:24.020
And we really wanna have just
one central repository for

365
00:21:24.020 --> 00:21:27.830
our project planning, as much as we can.

366
00:21:27.830 --> 00:21:32.730
And then that central repository
allows us the ability to

367
00:21:32.730 --> 00:21:35.903
drill into each individual stages.

368
00:21:35.903 --> 00:21:39.034
So, at this point in time
what we're gonna do is,

369
00:21:39.034 --> 00:21:44.346
now that we've taken a look at high level
planning, what I'm going to ask you to do.

370
00:21:44.346 --> 00:21:49.112
In your downloadable material,
we have a few slides that

371
00:21:49.112 --> 00:21:53.877
look at appendix D and
appendix D is from your ITIL book and

372
00:21:53.877 --> 00:21:57.552
I would like you to
download those slides and

373
00:21:57.552 --> 00:22:03.660
just take a look at the diagrams
that are contained in appendix D.

374
00:22:03.660 --> 00:22:07.510
And then when we come
back in our next episode,

375
00:22:07.510 --> 00:22:13.560
we're going to take a look at certain
activities that happen within planning.

376
00:22:13.560 --> 00:22:17.730
So for now, appendix d,
take a look at the downloadable material.

377
00:22:17.730 --> 00:22:21.090
You can either go to that
appendix in your ITIL book.

378
00:22:21.090 --> 00:22:25.340
Sorry, in your PRINCE2 book see I've got,
sometimes I just have ITIL on the brain.

379
00:22:25.340 --> 00:22:29.388
[LAUGH] And go to the appendix
D in your PRINCE2 book, or

380
00:22:29.388 --> 00:22:32.563
take a look at the downloadable material.

381
00:22:32.563 --> 00:22:37.404
Take a look at those particular diagrams
and then when we come back we're just

382
00:22:37.404 --> 00:22:42.243
gonna expound on those a little bit more.
>> Well Jo I've taken a quick look

383
00:22:42.243 --> 00:22:46.204
at those myself and
there's still a lot to cover here.

384
00:22:46.204 --> 00:22:47.970
So we're gonna have to come back for
a part three.

385
00:22:47.970 --> 00:22:52.390
And it seems we're just kind of zooming
in with each subsequent part and well,

386
00:22:52.390 --> 00:22:54.340
there's always time to
digest between those.

387
00:22:54.340 --> 00:22:57.250
So definitely come on back but for now,
we're gonna go ahead and get out of here.

388
00:22:57.250 --> 00:22:58.420
So signing off for ITPROTV.

389
00:22:58.420 --> 00:23:01.000
I've been your host Justin Dennison.
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

390
00:23:01.000 --> 00:23:01.840
>> And we'll see you next time.

391
00:23:01.840 --> 00:23:05.534
[MUSIC]

392
00:23:05.534 --> 00:23:10.790
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Plans theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Plans Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.312 --> 00:00:02.578
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.578 --> 00:00:06.303
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.303 --> 00:00:08.468
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.468 --> 00:00:13.113
>> You are watching ITPro.TV.
>> Greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.113 --> 00:00:15.816
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.816 --> 00:00:17.615
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and

7
00:00:17.615 --> 00:00:20.733
we're continuing on with our
Prints 2017 Foundation series.

8
00:00:20.733 --> 00:00:23.209
And this is a part three,
yeah, a part three,

9
00:00:23.209 --> 00:00:25.444
there's a lot when it comes to planning.

10
00:00:25.444 --> 00:00:28.615
We're continuing to talk
about our planning theme,

11
00:00:28.615 --> 00:00:31.175
our plan theme, I put an ing on there.
>> [LAUGH]

12
00:00:31.175 --> 00:00:32.075
>> I'm sure Jo wouldn't like that.

13
00:00:32.075 --> 00:00:35.121
And speaking of Jo, well she's gonna
help us along in this very endeavor.

14
00:00:35.121 --> 00:00:37.217
How are you doing today, Jo?
>> I'm great, thank you, Justin.

15
00:00:37.217 --> 00:00:39.298
How are you?
>> I'm doing fantastic.

16
00:00:39.298 --> 00:00:42.924
And y we've had some pretty good
conversations in the last two episodes,

17
00:00:42.924 --> 00:00:44.750
part one and part two of this series.

18
00:00:44.750 --> 00:00:46.951
If you haven't checked those out,
definitely go check those out.

19
00:00:46.951 --> 00:00:50.999
But what else do we have to talk
about when it comes to plans?

20
00:00:50.999 --> 00:00:52.724
>> What you said go and check these out,

21
00:00:52.724 --> 00:00:56.619
but to be perfectly honest, I mean let's
face it, part three is not gonna make much

22
00:00:56.619 --> 00:00:59.753
sense unlease you've already
checked out parts one and part two.

23
00:00:59.753 --> 00:01:03.384
Because in part one and part two we
looked at why we need to plan and

24
00:01:03.384 --> 00:01:07.237
why we need documentation and
why we need to have some consistency.

25
00:01:07.237 --> 00:01:11.375
And in part two, we actually paid
attention to the plans themselves.

26
00:01:11.375 --> 00:01:15.730
So we paid attention to the full matter
plans and we looked at Gantt chart, and

27
00:01:15.730 --> 00:01:18.889
we looked at the other activities and
team plans, etc.

28
00:01:18.889 --> 00:01:20.709
And now here in part three,

29
00:01:20.709 --> 00:01:24.679
we're actually going to look
at what should be in our plan.

30
00:01:24.679 --> 00:01:27.489
So in previous episodes,
we looked at structure, but

31
00:01:27.489 --> 00:01:30.186
now we're gonna look at what
should be in our plans.

32
00:01:30.186 --> 00:01:31.489
So let's tart off then,

33
00:01:31.489 --> 00:01:35.285
and very simply all of this is available
in your downloadable material.

34
00:01:35.285 --> 00:01:39.845
So we're gonna start off with, well what's
