a milestone is when
something has been achieved.

260
00:14:10.300 --> 00:14:15.050
So there may be milestones at the end of
stage two in that particular example and

261
00:14:15.050 --> 00:14:20.105
then again, at the end of stage
three in that example there.

262
00:14:20.105 --> 00:14:24.580
And what else have we got then,
calculating resources and costs.

263
00:14:24.580 --> 00:14:27.510
Resources does not necessarily
just mean the people.

264
00:14:27.510 --> 00:14:31.497
It can also mean the money and
the software, hardware, etc,

265
00:14:31.497 --> 00:14:35.804
that they need in order to be able
to complete various activities.

266
00:14:37.064 --> 00:14:41.384
Now we have got another thing on risk and
we're going to look at that in,

267
00:14:41.384 --> 00:14:43.480
actually, in the next episode.

268
00:14:43.480 --> 00:14:49.110
But part of planning any project
is going to be analyzing the risk.

269
00:14:49.110 --> 00:14:53.890
So, making sure that we have activities
that allow us to analyze the risk for

270
00:14:53.890 --> 00:14:54.840
that project.

271
00:14:56.540 --> 00:15:02.320
So not only do we analyze the risks for
project management.

272
00:15:02.320 --> 00:15:05.730
But we analyze the risk
before we start a project and

273
00:15:05.730 --> 00:15:09.320
also during the project
we'll do risk management.

274
00:15:09.320 --> 00:15:12.860
And I'm not gonna spend too much time
looking at this because we're gonna look

275
00:15:12.860 --> 00:15:14.160
at this in our next episode.

276
00:15:14.160 --> 00:15:19.410
And we're also going to look at risk
management as we go through all of

277
00:15:19.410 --> 00:15:24.850
our themes that are processes
within the project itself.

278
00:15:24.850 --> 00:15:30.600
So, in subsequent episodes,
we're gonna spend more time on this but

279
00:15:30.600 --> 00:15:34.210
one thing I do want to point out is
that third bullet point down there that

280
00:15:34.210 --> 00:15:39.620
it's still a draft until we have
identified all of our risks.

281
00:15:39.620 --> 00:15:42.220
Well, of the risks that
were evident at the point

282
00:15:42.220 --> 00:15:45.390
in time where we completed the plan.

283
00:15:45.390 --> 00:15:48.250
It's really important that
we perform risk management.

284
00:15:48.250 --> 00:15:52.355
When I asked to see a risk register for
a particular project plan and

285
00:15:52.355 --> 00:15:54.124
it's blank, it's empty.

286
00:15:54.124 --> 00:15:57.616
And then that tells me we haven't
been doing effective planning at all

287
00:15:57.616 --> 00:16:00.516
because I'll guarantee that
something is gonna happen,

288
00:16:00.516 --> 00:16:04.306
something that will need mitigation or
something that will need some sort of

289
00:16:04.306 --> 00:16:07.992
immediate action That should have been
picked up right at the very start.

290
00:16:07.992 --> 00:16:10.430
And we talk about SMART planning.

291
00:16:10.430 --> 00:16:14.880
And of course SMART means specific,
and measurable, and achievable, and

292
00:16:14.880 --> 00:16:18.430
realistic, and timely or timebound.

293
00:16:18.430 --> 00:16:23.590
And we use that term with objectives, but
we also use that with planning as well.

294
00:16:23.590 --> 00:16:24.780
You know what?

295
00:16:24.780 --> 00:16:29.600
Be realistic with your planning, but
be very smart with your planning.

296
00:16:29.600 --> 00:16:34.030
And if you plan your chunks in manageable,
bite-size pieces,

297
00:16:34.030 --> 00:16:37.970
then you will actually see that you will
get more achieved rather than trying to do

298
00:16:37.970 --> 00:16:39.520
everything all at the same time.

299
00:16:40.670 --> 00:16:45.270
And then, of course with any plan, we
know that we've got to document the plan.

300
00:16:46.590 --> 00:16:49.809
So I know that you've already seen
this particular diagram before.

301
00:16:49.809 --> 00:16:52.880
At least you've seen
this Gantt chart before.

302
00:16:52.880 --> 00:16:56.110
One thing that I want to draw
to your attention, really is,

303
00:16:56.110 --> 00:16:59.230
the fact that we've got
an executive summary here.

304
00:16:59.230 --> 00:17:01.530
That there's a hard or soft copy.

305
00:17:01.530 --> 00:17:03.690
And that it's subject to version control.

306
00:17:05.230 --> 00:17:07.350
Do you think, you know,
I'm gonna ask you a question.

307
00:17:07.350 --> 00:17:10.640
Do you really think that there is only
gonna be one version of this Gant chart?

308
00:17:10.640 --> 00:17:11.520
>> Absolutely not,

309
00:17:11.520 --> 00:17:15.640
and I'm a bit proponent of I try to do
everything I do in a version-controlled

310
00:17:15.640 --> 00:17:17.630
system, even if it's just for me.

311
00:17:17.630 --> 00:17:23.360
So, I'm a full proponent of versioning so
I can go, what was this, what was that.

312
00:17:23.360 --> 00:17:27.750
And it just keeps things nice.
>> But well, certainly with this,

313
00:17:27.750 --> 00:17:31.140
at the end of every stage,
this is going to be updated.

314
00:17:31.140 --> 00:17:35.520
Now, we do not want to update
this on an ad-hoc basis.

315
00:17:35.520 --> 00:17:38.225
We don't want to be updating
it every single day

316
00:17:38.225 --> 00:17:42.935
unless we're updating it to say that yes,
we've completed a specific task.

317
00:17:42.935 --> 00:17:45.835
We certainly don't want to
be reordering tasks and

318
00:17:45.835 --> 00:17:50.175
making changes other than to say yes,
something has been completed.

319
00:17:50.175 --> 00:17:53.985
That happens at the end-of-stage reviews.

320
00:17:53.985 --> 00:17:57.600
And so
that's when we would do those updates.

321
00:17:57.600 --> 00:18:00.450
Now, it mentions executive summary and
hard or soft copy.

322
00:18:00.450 --> 00:18:05.030
And in a previous episode, you mentioned,
Justin, about zooming in on this, and

323
00:18:05.030 --> 00:18:10.760
about actually having sort of plans for
each team level and for each stage.

324
00:18:12.450 --> 00:18:17.190
But what we've got right in front of us
here is just that, sort of, that one page,

325
00:18:17.190 --> 00:18:18.680
that executive view.

326
00:18:18.680 --> 00:18:20.760
Now, it says hard or soft copy, but

327
00:18:20.760 --> 00:18:23.860
I don't know whether you've ever
tried to print out a Gantt chart?

328
00:18:23.860 --> 00:18:27.152
Have you tried to print out a Gantt chart?
>> Every time I've tried to print out

329
00:18:27.152 --> 00:18:28.703
a chart of any type, I'm like,

330
00:18:28.703 --> 00:18:30.195
where does this page go?
>> Right.

331
00:18:30.195 --> 00:18:32.916
[LAUGH]
>> It's like my printer goes, well,

332
00:18:32.916 --> 00:18:35.000
I printed it over 12 pages.
>> Right.

333
00:18:35.000 --> 00:18:35.860
>> Well what?

334
00:18:35.860 --> 00:18:37.140
And four of them are blank.

335
00:18:37.140 --> 00:18:37.930
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

336
00:18:37.930 --> 00:18:39.140
>> And there's no numbers on

337
00:18:39.140 --> 00:18:39.890
them.
>> Right.

338
00:18:39.890 --> 00:18:41.834
>> And there's no numbering scheme, yeah,

339
00:18:41.834 --> 00:18:43.628
so.
>> It's a bit like trying to put a jigsaw

340
00:18:43.628 --> 00:18:44.320
together.

341
00:18:44.320 --> 00:18:48.710
And so if you are going to
print your Gantt chart,

342
00:18:48.710 --> 00:18:52.990
I would ask you to think twice
before you print it as a hard copy.

343
00:18:52.990 --> 00:18:58.280
It's gonna have to be so high level
as a hard copy that it's going to be

344
00:18:58.280 --> 00:19:01.340
pretty, well, unreadable to be fair.

345
00:19:02.490 --> 00:19:04.610
If it's not really, really high level,

346
00:19:04.610 --> 00:19:07.470
then you're gonna get exactly
what Justin just described.

347
00:19:07.470 --> 00:19:09.430
You print out a project Gantt chart,
you're gonna get 12,

348
00:19:09.430 --> 00:19:14.250
15 pages, and you're going to have quite
a few of them that are gonna be blank.

349
00:19:14.250 --> 00:19:17.200
And you're going to have to try and
piece it all together.

350
00:19:17.200 --> 00:19:21.600
And even then, by the time you're finished
with the tape and the staples and

351
00:19:21.600 --> 00:19:24.760
everything else, you're still not
really going to be any better off.

352
00:19:24.760 --> 00:19:28.130
So it says hard or soft copy,
but to be perfectly honest,

353
00:19:28.130 --> 00:19:30.530
you're better off with a soft copy.

354
00:19:30.530 --> 00:19:32.410
You're better off with it online.

355
00:19:33.410 --> 00:19:36.590
What about our minimum requirements,
then, for our planning?

356
00:19:37.620 --> 00:19:43.210
It mentions here that the project plan
has got to enable the business case.

357
00:19:43.210 --> 00:19:45.580
In other words, we've got to justify.

358
00:19:45.580 --> 00:19:47.960
If you remember, in our business case,
when we looked at this,

359
00:19:47.960 --> 00:19:49.820
this was our first thing.

360
00:19:49.820 --> 00:19:52.530
And we have to justify
in our business case

361
00:19:52.530 --> 00:19:56.730
why the business wants
this particular product.

362
00:19:56.730 --> 00:20:01.540
And we also have to justify how
much the project is gonna cost, and

363
00:20:01.540 --> 00:20:03.630
how long it's going to run for.

364
00:20:03.630 --> 00:20:08.280
So the plan that we have has got to
meet the needs of the business case.

365
00:20:08.280 --> 00:20:12.860
So it's got to enable the business
case to be, well, to be,

366
00:20:12.860 --> 00:20:16.140
I was gonna say to come to fruition,
really.

367
00:20:16.140 --> 00:20:20.360
We've got to enable us to turn
the business case into a reality.

368
00:20:20.360 --> 00:20:22.942
The business case has got requirements.

369
00:20:22.942 --> 00:20:27.778
And the plan has got to demonstrate how
we're going to turn those requirements

370
00:20:27.778 --> 00:20:28.810
into a reality.

371
00:20:30.100 --> 00:20:32.515
We have to have a minimum of two stages,
and we know that.

372
00:20:32.515 --> 00:20:35.356
We've looked at that in
a previous episode as well,

373
00:20:35.356 --> 00:20:37.820
because we have to have
an initiation stage.

374
00:20:37.820 --> 00:20:41.960
And we have to have at least one other
stage, such as the closing stage and

375
00:20:41.960 --> 00:20:44.630
then maybe many stages in between as well.

376
00:20:45.660 --> 00:20:48.200
And so, other things that
we should have in our plan,

377
00:20:48.200 --> 00:20:51.430
we already spoke about roles and
responsibilities.

378
00:20:51.430 --> 00:20:54.890
And we've already looked at
the levels of planning as well, and

379
00:20:54.890 --> 00:20:59.120
we've looked at exception plans too,
in the previous episode.

380
00:20:59.120 --> 00:21:04.750
One thing I will say, is that when we
are doing planning, just a reiteration.

381
00:21:04.750 --> 00:21:07.670
Think about your lessons
learned from other projects,

382
00:21:07.670 --> 00:21:10.710
and maybe from previous
stages in this project.

383
00:21:10.710 --> 00:21:13.585
And remember, as we've just talked about,

384
00:21:13.585 --> 00:21:17.379
we want to review our project
plan at the end of every stage.

385
00:21:17.379 --> 00:21:22.121
Just to see, sort of where we've got to
and whether there are any exception plans,

386
00:21:22.121 --> 00:21:25.330
and then what changes we need to make for
the next stage.

387
00:21:26.360 --> 00:21:28.710
So when we are thinking about planning,

388
00:21:28.710 --> 00:21:32.430
think about what approach we're
going to use to planning.

389
00:21:32.430 --> 00:21:35.153
In other words,
are we using an agile-based approach?

390
00:21:35.153 --> 00:21:39.250
Are we conducting our project
in a waterfall approach?

391
00:21:40.910 --> 00:21:43.210
How are we going to plan our stages?

392
00:21:43.210 --> 00:21:45.034
What length should our stages be?

393
00:21:45.034 --> 00:21:47.020
What about our resource planning?

394
00:21:47.020 --> 00:21:49.620
And what are we going
to do with exceptions?

395
00:21:49.620 --> 00:21:53.930
And all of these need to be
considered in our planning.

396
00:21:55.340 --> 00:21:58.460
And then, of course, at the bottom
there it mentions again estimation and

397
00:21:58.460 --> 00:21:59.440
scheduling.

398
00:21:59.440 --> 00:22:02.100
One thing that we haven't talked about so
far.

399
00:22:02.100 --> 00:22:04.890
And I just want to touch on this, and
this is the thought that I'm gonna leave

400
00:22:04.890 --> 00:22:09.670
you with for this particular episode,
and that is prioritization.

401
00:22:09.670 --> 00:22:12.620
Quite often,
when we're planning our projects,

402
00:22:12.620 --> 00:22:15.303
we plan our activities
in a sequential basis.

403
00:22:15.303 --> 00:22:18.867
Because we understand what's required,

404
00:22:18.867 --> 00:22:22.880
what our prerequisites are for
our next step.

405
00:22:22.880 --> 00:22:26.270
And then, those are prerequisites for
our next activity,

406
00:22:26.270 --> 00:22:29.540
and those become the prerequisites for
our next activity.

407
00:22:29.540 --> 00:22:32.330
So quite often,
we don't think about prioritization,

408
00:22:32.330 --> 00:22:34.250
because they are sequential.

409
00:22:34.250 --> 00:22:39.932
But nevertheless, in a lot of projects,
especially the large-scale projects,

410
00:22:39.932 --> 00:22:44.210
you may be delivering
functionality in certain blocks.

411
00:22:44.210 --> 00:22:47.030
So we might deliver this
particular functionality, and

412
00:22:47.030 --> 00:22:50.140
we might have this functionality
as well that's required.

413
00:22:50.140 --> 00:22:53.060
Think about Microsoft Outlook,
it's a perfect example.

414
00:22:53.060 --> 00:22:54.270
What is the priority?

415
00:22:54.270 --> 00:22:57.500
Is the priority to send and
receive email, or is the priority for

416
00:22:57.500 --> 00:23:00.320
our business to have a shared calendar?

417
00:23:01.370 --> 00:23:04.890
Think about which is the priority, and
that's the functionality that we want to

418
00:23:04.890 --> 00:23:09.900
work on first,
unless you've got any prerequisites.

419
00:23:09.900 --> 00:23:13.300
If we've got prerequisites and
dependencies, then obviously,

420
00:23:13.300 --> 00:23:18.350
that's gonna drive your prioritization and
potentially drive your planning as well.

421
00:23:19.960 --> 00:23:23.660
So, in terms of, sort of our foundation
level here, we are at PRINCE2.

422
00:23:23.660 --> 00:23:28.330
And then,
we have now finished our planning or

423
00:23:28.330 --> 00:23:33.560
plan theme for PRINCE2 Foundation,
as I've already said.

424
00:23:33.560 --> 00:23:37.490
So in our next episode, we're gonna ask
you to come back, and we're gonna be

425
00:23:37.490 --> 00:23:42.020
looking at the PRINCE2 theme of risk.
>> Well, Jo,

426
00:23:42.020 --> 00:23:44.380
I will tell you,
there have been discussions that you and

427
00:23:44.380 --> 00:23:47.530
I have had where I've misused
terminology on risk, so.

428
00:23:47.530 --> 00:23:50.140
That one should definitely be
an interesting show, so I would definitely

429
00:23:50.140 --> 00:23:52.390
come on back, but for now, we're going
to go ahead and get out of here.

430
00:23:52.390 --> 00:23:55.350
Signing off for IT Pro TV I'm your host,
Justin Dennison.

431
00:23:55.350 --> 00:23:56.016
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

432
00:23:56.016 --> 00:23:58.310
>> And we'll see you next time.

433
00:23:58.310 --> 00:24:04.407
[MUSIC]

434
00:24:04.407 --> 00:24:07.351
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Risk theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Risk
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.140
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.140 --> 00:00:04.066
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.066 --> 00:00:05.061
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:05.061 --> 00:00:12.491
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.
>> Greetings everyone and

5
00:00:12.491 --> 00:00:16.040
welcome back to another
exciting episode of IT Pro TV.

6
00:00:16.040 --> 00:00:20.250
I'm your host, Justin Dennison and we're
continuing on with Prince2 2017 foundation

7
00:00:20.250 --> 00:00:23.880
series and in this episode we're going
to be looking at the risk theme.

8
00:00:23.880 --> 00:00:28.170
And here to help us along and well,
to make sure we don't get in any

9
00:00:28.170 --> 00:00:30.370
risky business, is the one and
only Miss Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:30.370 --> 00:00:32.693
How you doing today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great, thank you, Justin.

11
00:00:32.693 --> 00:00:34.680
How are you?
>> I am doing fantastic.

12
00:00:34.680 --> 00:00:37.440
Probably need to slow down that,
how are you doing today, Jo,

13
00:00:37.440 --> 00:00:40.510
cause that just kind of ran
together in that previous one.

14
00:00:40.510 --> 00:00:43.795
But we've been talking
about Prince2 themes.

15
00:00:43.795 --> 00:00:48.650
We talked about the plan, the,
wait a minute, I totally forgot.

16
00:00:48.650 --> 00:00:50.350
What was the one before that?

17
00:00:50.350 --> 00:00:51.370
Organization.

18
00:00:51.370 --> 00:00:52.070
There we go.

19
00:00:52.070 --> 00:00:53.970
But now we're onto risk.

20
00:00:55.180 --> 00:00:57.699
What do we need to know about risk?

21
00:00:59.260 --> 00:01:01.890
What don't you need to know about risk?

22
00:01:01.890 --> 00:01:06.279
I mean, you mentioned just a little while
ago about slowing down on our intro,

23
00:01:06.279 --> 00:01:10.800
well i mean, you know that's a risk and
that's a risk, it's a threat that maybe

24
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:14.856
our director couldn't get all of our
titles in at the bottom there in time

25
00:01:14.856 --> 00:01:18.548
because you were talking too fast.
>> It was just on that one transition.

26
00:01:18.548 --> 00:01:20.150
The rest of it it's fine.

27
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:25.280
It's the, how are you doing today that for
some reason I feel compelled to say

28
00:01:25.280 --> 00:01:29.110
it 700 miles an hour.
>> [LAUGH] And you know why?

29
00:01:29.110 --> 00:01:33.707
That's because he really doesn't care,
he's not interested in the answer.

30
00:01:33.707 --> 00:01:36.027
That's what it is, and I'm hurt.
>> I do,

31
00:01:36.027 --> 00:01:40.325
you'll know if I'm not interested in
the answer, I'm like, how you doing, Jo?

32
00:01:40.325 --> 00:01:42.350
>> [LAUGH]

33
00:01:42.350 --> 00:01:43.950
>> It'll just be me, kind of.

34
00:01:43.950 --> 00:01:44.750
>> I don't know whether I should

35
00:01:44.750 --> 00:01:49.000
be flattered at this point in time or not,
but I'm gonna start talking about risk.

36
00:01:49.000 --> 00:01:54.140
What do you think a risk is?
>> Something that can have

37
00:01:54.140 --> 00:02:00.260
impact on a particular
event in a negative manner.

38
00:02:00.260 --> 00:02:04.870
Okay, let's take a look at the screen
that is in front of us because this is

39
00:02:04.870 --> 00:02:06.850
the Prince2 definition of a risk.

40
00:02:06.850 --> 00:02:13.200
A risk is an uncertain event that's going
to have an effect on the achievement.

41
00:02:13.200 --> 00:02:16.950
Now you said something about an event
that something that could happen,

42
00:02:16.950 --> 00:02:18.960
that would have a negative effect.

43
00:02:18.960 --> 00:02:20.420
But look at what it says there.

44
00:02:21.770 --> 00:02:25.360
There are two types of risk or
rather there's one type of risk but

45
00:02:25.360 --> 00:02:27.270
it can be divided into two.

46
00:02:27.270 --> 00:02:31.350
And we've got negative threats and
we've got opportunities.

47
00:02:33.850 --> 00:02:38.630
He's thinking, this is why I
pause here because he's thinking.

48
00:02:38.630 --> 00:02:41.390
>> So Jo, I will say for the most part

49
00:02:41.390 --> 00:02:46.090
when I'm speaking to other individuals,
when I hear a risk or, and I could be

50
00:02:46.090 --> 00:02:50.470
wrong when I say risk to other people,
we tend to think it's a negative thing.

51
00:02:50.470 --> 00:02:56.250

00:15:35.280 --> 00:15:40.380
The Internet is full of what I'd
call complementary guidance,

286
00:15:40.380 --> 00:15:45.580

itself, and complementary to PRINCE2.

If you don't know something, generally
what we do is we'll go to the Internet,

290

So they'll be an answer there.

291
00:15:59.431 --> 00:16:02.183
So what we'll do is we'll take that.

That would also be part

293
00:16:04.560 --> 00:16:07.210
And we'll take the information

294

And we'll say, okay then, let's try and
apply this in our particular project.

295
00:16:12.760 --> 00:16:15.560
So we would use the Internet.

296

Remember that what's on the Internet

it's what's happened to them.

298

It's not necessarily what's

299

However, we're looking for probable,

300

likely, uncertain events.

301

There's a whole heap of

302
00:16:36.960 --> 00:16:41.640
There's a whole heap of,
sort of, the unknown there.

303
00:16:41.640 --> 00:16:44.170
So if we don't know something, well,

304

305
00:16:46.880 --> 00:16:48.630
You might find that it might not be.

306
00:16:48.630 --> 00:16:52.720
But hey, if we're trying to identify
something that might happen.

307

Then we're gonna go to as
many sources of data and

308
00:16:56.225 --> 00:16:59.910
as many sources of information
as we possibly can.

309
00:17:01.030 --> 00:17:03.741

because I've seen things on the Internet.

And then I've seen people

00:17:32.460 --> 00:17:33.010
else here.

We're still just identifying risk.

00:17:35.650 --> 00:17:39.130
We're not talking about

322
00:17:39.130 --> 00:17:42.804
We're talking about just identifying risk.

Advice as I'd like to call it that goes

First of all, we've got to

Now, we've talked about lessons learned

Then there's gonna be temperature

So there are things like this that

And then don't forget about brainstorming.

>> That's

>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

this is going to be a risk but

00:20:21.610 --> 00:20:25.200
a noodle is something you put in a wok and

This is a brainstorm.

The one thing that we didn't do

Because we need to know

discussing.

And so sometimes you have

[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

Seems like a good source

me.
>> So let's take a look at the last item

then that's on that slide and the last

00:21:12.562 --> 00:21:16.315
What we're gonna do with
the risks that we've identified,

00:21:16.315 --> 00:21:18.750
no matter how we have identified them.

00:21:18.750 --> 00:21:21.420
And we have identified
the risk that Justin and

I can't speak the same language.

It doesn't matter how

Remember what I said,

We've also then got to, well, prioritize

So let's go back to that previous slide.

And if we could just blow that slide up

00:21:59.490 --> 00:22:04.940

We're then going to identify, now we get

Now that we've identified the risk,

We still haven't got to that point where

Not right now.

But then we have to put some

00:22:29.026 --> 00:22:31.266
What the customer expectations are, and

this is what I was saying just a little

00:22:35.042 --> 00:22:39.604
And our priorities will help us

00:22:39.604 --> 00:22:44.740

00:22:44.740 --> 00:22:49.480

Identifying risks.

00:22:52.040 --> 00:22:57.815
And then, once we got to identifying risk,

00:24:07.508 --> 00:24:10.976

We've given them numbers,

00:24:30.680 --> 00:24:35.720

00:24:38.670 --> 00:24:43.675
And so if the probability is really high,

00:24:43.675 --> 00:24:47.297

00:24:47.297 --> 00:24:51.859
In other words, if it's gonna have a

And so the risk tolerance line means

We've gotta do something about it,

00:25:21.637 --> 00:25:25.965
Now, I'm getting into the realms of

Because quite simply,

00:25:33.485 --> 00:25:37.745

466
00:25:46.285 --> 00:25:50.784
And so what we've got to do is make
a decision as to what we're going to

00:25:50.784 --> 00:25:51.800

00:25:52.950 --> 00:25:56.010
So going back here,

We'll have to identify what our

00:26:14.100 --> 00:26:16.510
This is part of our assessment, and

And what we're gonna do, we're gonna leave

482

So come back, because we've got a part

00:13:52.679 --> 00:13:57.271
But it has been a decision based
on the fact that they have

244
00:13:57.271 --> 00:14:01.690
better capabilities to manage
the risk than we have.

245
00:14:01.690 --> 00:14:03.950
That's why we would transfer a risk.

246
00:14:03.950 --> 00:14:08.670
Because they've got better capabilities
than us to manage that risk, and

247
00:14:08.670 --> 00:14:12.720
to deal with that risk, and
to manage the impact of the risk, as well.

248
00:14:13.800 --> 00:14:15.720
That's why we would do that.

249
00:14:15.720 --> 00:14:20.950
We wouldn't transfer a risk to somebody
else just because we wanted to offload it,

250
00:14:20.950 --> 00:14:23.210
just because we wanted to get rid of it.

251
00:14:23.210 --> 00:14:25.190
That's not why we transfer risk.

252
00:14:25.190 --> 00:14:30.310
We transfer risk because somebody else
is better suited to deal with it.

253
00:14:31.940 --> 00:14:36.110
And we always have to, the last bullet
point on this particular slide,

254
00:14:36.110 --> 00:14:40.160
we always have to prepare
sort of contingent plans.

255
00:14:40.160 --> 00:14:43.470
What are we gonna do if
something goes wrong?

256
00:14:44.610 --> 00:14:47.650
What are we gonna do if that risk happens?

257
00:14:48.780 --> 00:14:52.423
Because it doesn't matter how
much mitigation you put in.

258
00:14:52.423 --> 00:14:56.282
It doesn't matter whether
you transfer the risk,

259
00:14:56.282 --> 00:15:00.769
whether you share the risk,
there is still a probability,

260
00:15:00.769 --> 00:15:05.633
no matter how small,
a likelihood that that risk could happen.

261
00:15:05.633 --> 00:15:10.608
And so at that point in time,
you have to have contingent plans for

262
00:15:10.608 --> 00:15:12.500
when it does happen.

263
00:15:12.500 --> 00:15:15.530
It's not an if, it's when it does happen.

264
00:15:15.530 --> 00:15:18.810
Because you've prepared,
and if you've prepared,

265
00:15:18.810 --> 00:15:21.200
you know what to do
when something happens.

266
00:15:23.200 --> 00:15:26.430
And your response is to risk,
well, whatever they are,

267
00:15:26.430 --> 00:15:30.640
whatever those contingent plans
are you're responses should be smart.

268
00:15:30.640 --> 00:15:32.190
They should be realistic.

269
00:15:32.190 --> 00:15:33.325
They should be very specific.

270
00:15:33.325 --> 00:15:39.170
Nobody should have any ambiguity as to
what they should be doing in a certain

271
00:15:39.170 --> 00:15:43.170
instance, but they should be actionable.

272
00:15:43.170 --> 00:15:44.530
They should be achievable.

273
00:15:44.530 --> 00:15:46.281
They should be realistic.

274
00:15:46.281 --> 00:15:50.736
Don't expect somebody to learn
you skills overnight just in case

275
00:15:50.736 --> 00:15:52.359
something goes wrong.

276
00:15:52.359 --> 00:15:57.454
If I'm not equipped to do that,
if I don't have the skills to be

277
00:15:57.454 --> 00:16:03.360
able to react to a particular type
of risk, then don't ask me to do it.

278
00:16:03.360 --> 00:16:07.815
Or at least give me the training in order
to be able to respond to that risk.

279
00:16:07.815 --> 00:16:12.284
I see this with risk mitigation,
quite often where certain things,

280
00:16:12.284 --> 00:16:16.090
certain actions are allocated
to certain people.

281
00:16:16.090 --> 00:16:17.870
They're given those responsibilities, and

282
00:16:17.870 --> 00:16:19.500
they've never done
anything like that before.

283
00:16:20.582 --> 00:16:24.350
But then, the caveat there is that
the project manager will say,

284
00:16:24.350 --> 00:16:26.590
well it's okay because it's
not gonna happen anyway.

285
00:16:26.590 --> 00:16:28.292
Yeah, all right then.

286
00:16:28.292 --> 00:16:31.097
[LAUGH] I've heard that so many times and

287
00:16:31.097 --> 00:16:35.920
I've seen it go horribly wrong so
many times as well.

288
00:16:35.920 --> 00:16:39.080
All risks should have an owner,
but it should be somebody that is

289
00:16:39.080 --> 00:16:44.780
capable of dealing with that risk and
capable of dealing with

290
00:16:44.780 --> 00:16:49.990
what we'd call the contingent action,
should that risk actually occur.

291
00:16:49.990 --> 00:16:53.690
Now the risk owner doesn't necessarily
have to be the same person as the risk

292
00:16:53.690 --> 00:16:59.670
actionee, as the person that's actually
actioning or dealing with the risk.

293
00:16:59.670 --> 00:17:05.380
But, nevertheless,
all risks should have a risk owner.

294
00:17:05.380 --> 00:17:09.230
And then we get into the last step here,
and in risk management.

295
00:17:10.270 --> 00:17:15.550
And that step is communication,
communicating the risks,

296
00:17:15.550 --> 00:17:20.290
communicating the likelihood,
communicating the responses to the risks.

297
00:17:20.290 --> 00:17:25.818
We have to communicate what should
happen if a risk should happen.

298
00:17:27.568 --> 00:17:30.040
So we communicate to all
of our stakeholders.

299
00:17:31.050 --> 00:17:33.220
We know who our stakeholders are,

300
00:17:33.220 --> 00:17:37.060
because during project initiation we
have identified our stakeholders and

301
00:17:37.060 --> 00:17:41.720
we look to roll some responsibilities
during our organization theme as well.

302
00:17:41.720 --> 00:17:46.420
So we communicate what should happen,
we communicate using many, many tools.

303
00:17:46.420 --> 00:17:49.860
And we should have a communication
plan for how we communicate with

304
00:17:49.860 --> 00:17:54.640
all of our stakeholders and we are going
to look at that during our processes.

305
00:17:54.640 --> 00:17:56.000
When we start to look at our,

306
00:17:56.000 --> 00:17:59.360
our project processes we'll start
to look at how we communicate.

307
00:17:59.360 --> 00:18:04.270
But we've got some examples of how
we communicate here such as report

308
00:18:04.270 --> 00:18:06.530
that happen at the end of every stage, for

309
00:18:06.530 --> 00:18:12.940
instance information radiators that
happen throughout stages, dashboards.

310
00:18:12.940 --> 00:18:15.820
There's no right or
wrong way of communicating, you know your

311
00:18:15.820 --> 00:18:20.960
stakeholders and you know how you should
communicate to your stakeholders.

312
00:18:20.960 --> 00:18:23.570
There's a word there though
that's really important

313
00:18:23.570 --> 00:18:26.750
when it comes to communication and
that is the word continual.

314
00:18:28.310 --> 00:18:31.140
You don't just communicate
on a one off thing and

315
00:18:31.140 --> 00:18:33.355
then expect somebody to remember it.

316
00:18:33.355 --> 00:18:37.012
I has Justin shaking his head here,
what I see,

317
00:18:37.012 --> 00:18:40.690
things like our service continuity plan.

318
00:18:40.690 --> 00:18:43.700
I quite often see that when
I go inside and I'll see

319
00:18:43.700 --> 00:18:48.080
a service continuity plan that was last
communicated to people three years ago.

320
00:18:48.080 --> 00:18:50.440
And I'll say to people,
where is your service continuity plan?

321
00:18:50.440 --> 00:18:57.200
Especially if we're doing an ISO
27001 audit, or an ISO 20000 audit.

322
00:18:57.200 --> 00:19:01.328
And I'll go out to people and I'll say,
so where is your service continuity plan?

323
00:19:01.328 --> 00:19:06.220
And they got, well,
it was communicated three years ago, but

324
00:19:06.220 --> 00:19:10.940
I don't know where it is right now,
hang on a minute, let me find it.

325
00:19:10.940 --> 00:19:14.960
I mean in those instances
when we're talking audits,

326
00:19:14.960 --> 00:19:19.450
in those instances then
the organization will fairly audit.

327
00:19:19.450 --> 00:19:22.380
But other than that, it's very dangerous,

328
00:19:22.380 --> 00:19:25.430
especially when we're talking
about risk-management.

329
00:19:25.430 --> 00:19:32.390
We should all know what to do in
case of a threat actually happening.

330
00:19:32.390 --> 00:19:35.920
And so, whether that's invoking
service continuity or not,

331
00:19:35.920 --> 00:19:41.060
we should all know what we need to do and
how to do that.

332
00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:44.420
And like I said, we should all have
the relevant skills as well in order to be

333
00:19:44.420 --> 00:19:46.080
able to action our items.

334
00:19:47.610 --> 00:19:53.220
So for any project then, we do need to
have a defined risk management approach.

335
00:19:54.250 --> 00:19:59.792
Which includes, the procedure for dealing
with all of our risks, how to identify

336
00:19:59.792 --> 00:20:05.109
risks, what would be considered acceptable
tolerances for all of our risks.

337
00:20:05.109 --> 00:20:10.410
And then how to evaluate and asses each
risk, how to allocate responsibilities for

338
00:20:10.410 --> 00:20:15.010
each risk, and then how to actually
deal with each risk as well.

339
00:20:15.010 --> 00:20:18.210
The risks are managed right the way
throughout project duration and

340
00:20:18.210 --> 00:20:22.500
in fact the risks may even be
transferred over to support

341
00:20:22.500 --> 00:20:25.650
when we transition our live service.

342
00:20:25.650 --> 00:20:29.870
Cuz if there is risk that a server
may fail during development,

343
00:20:29.870 --> 00:20:33.650
that server may fail in
the live environment also.

344
00:20:33.650 --> 00:20:39.370
So some risks are transitioned along
with the actual product itself.

345
00:20:39.370 --> 00:20:43.670
So, a risk budget will be established and
that may not just be a budget for

346
00:20:43.670 --> 00:20:46.960
the actual project,
it may be a risk budget for

347
00:20:46.960 --> 00:20:52.490
the life cycle of the product
itself that we are delivering.

348
00:20:52.490 --> 00:20:55.250
Above all, our risk management approach

349
00:20:55.250 --> 00:20:59.690
has to align with the needs of the
organization, it has to be what they want.

350
00:20:59.690 --> 00:21:02.500
It's not about what we want,
it's about what they want.

351
00:21:03.630 --> 00:21:07.595
And so,
we have to have an attitude to risk that

352
00:21:07.595 --> 00:21:12.184
aligns ourselves with what
the organization wants.

353
00:21:12.184 --> 00:21:15.954
And if the organization wants us to
transfer all risk outside to say,

354
00:21:15.954 --> 00:21:19.160
you mentioned cloud service
providers earlier on.

355
00:21:19.160 --> 00:21:21.940
Then, that's what we should do.

356
00:21:21.940 --> 00:21:25.320
But if the organization wants
us to keep all of our data, and

357
00:21:25.320 --> 00:21:29.589
manage all of our data in-house,
then again, that's what we should do.

358
00:21:31.521 --> 00:21:35.110
Whatever we do has to be aligned
with what the organization wants.

359
00:21:36.590 --> 00:21:41.375
You are thinking again.
>> So we talked about transferring risk,

360
00:21:41.375 --> 00:21:43.837
but correct me if I'm wrong.

361
00:21:43.837 --> 00:21:48.243
I think of transferring a risk
almost as trading risk.

362
00:21:48.243 --> 00:21:49.126
>> Okay.

363
00:21:49.126 --> 00:21:50.418
>> What I'm doing is,

364
00:21:50.418 --> 00:21:55.586
yeah I'm putting this over here, but it
almost seems like when I offload this one

365
00:21:55.586 --> 00:22:00.690
then I get another one in it's place,
like there's an equal exchange of risk.

366
00:22:00.690 --> 00:22:02.880
So, cloud service providers in particular.

367
00:22:02.880 --> 00:22:07.301
Okay, I offloaded that over there, but
now what if my connection goes down?

368
00:22:07.301 --> 00:22:09.844
What if my storage gateway goes down?
>> Yep.

369
00:22:09.844 --> 00:22:12.897
>> What if there's these other things that

370
00:22:12.897 --> 00:22:16.640
are now risk to you that weren't before?
>> But

371
00:22:16.640 --> 00:22:20.400
it goes back to what we were saying
before about transferring risk and

372
00:22:20.400 --> 00:22:25.640
there you have to do then additional risk
management in order to transfer risk.

373
00:22:25.640 --> 00:22:28.550
And that's exactly the same thing,
it could be a trade-off.

374
00:22:28.550 --> 00:22:31.510
By transferring a risk,

375
00:22:31.510 --> 00:22:37.000
you could be transferring a big risk but
accepting a smaller risk instead.

376
00:22:37.000 --> 00:22:40.150
So that could be a trade-off
that you're making.

377
00:22:40.150 --> 00:22:44.933
But what you may do, is you may transfer
a risk, but you may actually make that

378
00:22:44.933 --> 00:22:49.735
risk or compound that risk, and actually
have double the risk by doing that.

379
00:22:49.735 --> 00:22:54.198
But you might not have a choice, because
you might not have the skills in house so

380
00:22:54.198 --> 00:22:56.064
you might transfer it outside but

381
00:22:56.064 --> 00:22:59.740
there may only be one supplier
available to transfer it to.

382
00:22:59.740 --> 00:23:03.700
So what you're doing is you're compounding
the risk of something happening

383
00:23:03.700 --> 00:23:08.290
along with, and in addition to the risk
of having just one supplier or having

384
00:23:08.290 --> 00:23:13.220
all your eggs in one basket as it were.
>> How does this play out

385
00:23:13.220 --> 00:23:17.310
if you have some kind of regulation or
regulatory individual who says

386
00:23:17.310 --> 00:23:19.690
this is how you have to do it?
>> Yep.

387
00:23:22.680 --> 00:23:24.841
>> I guess you just figure out a plan and

388
00:23:24.841 --> 00:23:27.010
necessary to deal with it, right?

389
00:23:27.010 --> 00:23:30.410
But if it introduces additional
risk that you did not have,

390
00:23:30.410 --> 00:23:33.394
if it was in-house or of your choosing.
>> Well,

391
00:23:33.394 --> 00:23:37.258
think about I guess the latest
regulation to come into play,

392
00:23:37.258 --> 00:23:41.216
which is a big one for
everybody at the moment, which is GDPR.

393
00:23:41.216 --> 00:23:45.949
Now GDPR is, it's built on
the European Data Protection laws which is

394
00:23:45.949 --> 00:23:49.491
something that we've had in Europe for
a long time.

395
00:23:49.491 --> 00:23:52.364
It's not something that we've
had in the US for a long time.

396
00:23:52.364 --> 00:23:57.052
And so now that there is a risk
that our current suppliers,

397
00:23:57.052 --> 00:24:03.668
suppliers that we may have data with for
instance, they may not comply with GDPR.

398
00:24:03.668 --> 00:24:09.182
And so we have to, at that point in time,
we would have to then say,

399
00:24:09.182 --> 00:24:14.511
well you know what,
unfortunately we have to comply with GDPR?

400
00:24:14.511 --> 00:24:18.484
And because you're keeping some of our
data, if you can't, it's been a great

401
00:24:18.484 --> 00:24:22.661
relationship, thanks very much, but
we're gonna have to go with somebody else.

402
00:24:22.661 --> 00:24:27.450
Because regulations state
that we have to comply.

403
00:24:27.450 --> 00:24:32.474
And it's gonna cost us money to move
to somebody else, it's either that,

404
00:24:32.474 --> 00:24:37.196
or it's gonna cost you more money
to make your databases more secure.

405
00:24:37.196 --> 00:24:42.350
However, that's the situation that we're
in, you can't get around regulations.

406
00:24:42.350 --> 00:24:45.902
Well, you can, you can move out of
that particular industry sector, but

407
00:24:45.902 --> 00:24:49.420
then you might as well say goodbye to
your business at that point in time.

408
00:24:49.420 --> 00:24:52.065
You can't get around
regulations no matter how hard

409
00:24:52.065 --> 00:24:55.299
you try.
>> That seems like a maybe do

410
00:24:55.299 --> 00:24:58.045
something shady, but the next risk itself.
>> Let's

411
00:24:58.045 --> 00:25:00.676
not go there, right?
>> Don't do that, I'm not saying we

412
00:25:00.676 --> 00:25:03.211
should, I wanna be perfectly clear.
>> [LAUGH]

413
00:25:03.211 --> 00:25:04.077
>> Some people are like,

414
00:25:04.077 --> 00:25:04.990
well I could just do this.

415
00:25:04.990 --> 00:25:09.253
Yeah, but that in and
of itself is a huge risk that has a high

416
00:25:09.253 --> 00:25:10.920
probability of.
>> Going wrong.

417
00:25:10.920 --> 00:25:12.660
>> Of causing things to go wrong.

418
00:25:12.660 --> 00:25:15.134
>> Yeah, definitely.

419
00:25:15.134 --> 00:25:18.701
But as far as risk management goes,
the only thing that I can really

420
00:25:18.701 --> 00:25:22.971
tell you about risk management is the fact
that you have to identify your risks,

421
00:25:22.971 --> 00:25:26.520
they are completely unique
to your organization.

422
00:25:26.520 --> 00:25:30.649
And yes when we looked in our previous
episode about using Google or

423
00:25:30.649 --> 00:25:35.367
Justin's mum for that matter, for some
advice on what to do with our risk and

424
00:25:35.367 --> 00:25:37.228
advice on identifying risk.

425
00:25:37.228 --> 00:25:39.785
The simple fact is that
no two organizations

426
00:25:39.785 --> 00:25:41.970
are gonna be exactly the same.

427
00:25:41.970 --> 00:25:46.438
So your risks are going to be
fairly unique to you and therefore,

428
00:25:46.438 --> 00:25:50.183
you are going to have to accommodate for
those risks.

429
00:25:50.183 --> 00:25:54.533
You're gonna have to make
decisions on those risks based on

430
00:25:54.533 --> 00:25:56.970
the needs of your organization.

431
00:25:58.220 --> 00:26:01.096
So if Justin's got no more questions,

432
00:26:01.096 --> 00:26:06.510
then we've actually reached the end
of our second part of our risk theme.

433
00:26:06.510 --> 00:26:11.800
And when we come back in our next episode,
we are going to start with a part one

434
00:26:11.800 --> 00:26:17.215
of the change theme and I can guarantee
that change will go into two episodes.

435
00:26:17.215 --> 00:26:20.715
[LAUGH] It always does,
it's always a big challenge to change.

436
00:26:20.715 --> 00:26:25.377
So, I'm gonna invite you to come back and
when you see us again we'll be talking

437
00:26:25.377 --> 00:26:28.616
about change.
>> Well Jo, I feel like I know more than

438
00:26:28.616 --> 00:26:31.880
when we started on risk,
I still have some of the terminology.

439
00:26:31.880 --> 00:26:36.826
A little shaky but that's something
that I'm gonna have to work on myself to

440
00:26:36.826 --> 00:26:39.840
reduce the possibility of
Jo being mad at me for

441
00:26:39.840 --> 00:26:41.840
getting terminology wrong.
>> [LAUGH]

442
00:26:41.840 --> 00:26:42.959
>> But definitely come on back,

443
00:26:42.959 --> 00:26:45.690
we're gonna be talking about change but
for now we're gonna go ahead and

444
00:26:45.690 --> 00:26:46.680
get out of here.

445
00:26:46.680 --> 00:26:49.391
So signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

446
00:26:49.391 --> 00:26:49.990
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

447
00:26:49.990 --> 00:26:50.653
>> And we'll see you next time.

448
00:26:50.653 --> 00:26:53.519
[MUSIC]

449
00:26:53.519 --> 00:26:57.047
>> Thank you for

450
00:26:57.047 --> 00:27:02.471
watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Change theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Change
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.230
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.230 --> 00:00:02.792
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.792 --> 00:00:06.119
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.119 --> 00:00:08.124
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.124 --> 00:00:11.320
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:11.320 --> 00:00:15.850
>> Greetings, everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPROTV.

7
00:00:15.850 --> 00:00:19.510
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
we're continuing on with our PRINCE2

8
00:00:19.510 --> 00:00:23.260
2017 Foundation Series and we're
continuing our discussion about themes.

9
00:00:23.260 --> 00:00:27.100
In particular in this episode we're gonna
be talking about the change theme and here

10
00:00:27.100 --> 00:00:32.370
to help maybe change my mind about all of
this is the one and only Miss Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:32.370 --> 00:00:33.510
How are you doing today, Jo?

12
00:00:33.510 --> 00:00:36.310
>> Absolutely great,
thank you Justin, how are you?

13
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:38.470
>> I am doing fantastic and well,

14
00:00:38.470 --> 00:00:42.890
I just wanna say where I'm from
most people say change is bad.

15
00:00:42.890 --> 00:00:47.490
So I don't know if we're talking
about overarching social change or

16
00:00:47.490 --> 00:00:51.680
actually talking about change within
a project or an organization, right?

17
00:00:51.680 --> 00:00:54.350
>> I'm not gonna try and
change the world, all right?

18
00:00:54.350 --> 00:00:57.160
I mean, once upon a time

ITL Service Transition is because both

252
00:14:10.395 --> 00:14:15.020
CIs and RFCs are covered
in the service transition.

253
00:14:15.020 --> 00:14:20.271
Well, we've got a complete series
on both change management and

254
00:14:20.271 --> 00:14:26.330
configuration management in service
transition, and in the ITL series.

255
00:14:26.330 --> 00:14:28.530
Now, what I want you to
do is if you're really,

256
00:14:28.530 --> 00:14:34.020
really not sure,
then go back to your ITL series.

257
00:14:34.020 --> 00:14:38.079
Take a look at the service transition
series and then pay very close attention

258
00:14:38.079 --> 00:14:42.152
to both change management and service
asset and configuration management.

259
00:14:42.152 --> 00:14:47.763
Because they will give you a lot more
detail, or in that series, I'll give

260
00:14:47.763 --> 00:14:53.870
you a lot more detail descriptions of what
a change is, an RFC and what a CI is.

261
00:14:53.870 --> 00:14:59.090
A configuration item is
the item of our configuration

262
00:14:59.090 --> 00:15:01.590
of our infrastructure, basically.

263
00:15:01.590 --> 00:15:03.980
So that laptop is a CI.

264
00:15:03.980 --> 00:15:07.860
This laptop is a CI, a configuration item.

265
00:15:07.860 --> 00:15:11.180
And a CI record, well,

266
00:15:11.180 --> 00:15:15.700
that's the record of that CI in
the configuration management database.

267
00:15:17.070 --> 00:15:22.700
So all of our CIs will have an asset
number on them, for instance.

268
00:15:22.700 --> 00:15:27.372
And the CI record makes
reference to that asset number.

269
00:15:27.372 --> 00:15:29.983
And then it stores all of the data,

270
00:15:29.983 --> 00:15:35.490
all of the attributes of that
particular CI, that configuration item.

271
00:15:36.870 --> 00:15:39.860
You might ask, what that's got
to do with project management?

272
00:15:39.860 --> 00:15:40.634
And I understand that.

273
00:15:40.634 --> 00:15:43.988
You're gonna say, well, that's ITL, it's
got absolutely nothing to do with PRINCE2,

274
00:15:43.988 --> 00:15:45.720
nothing to do with project management.

275
00:15:45.720 --> 00:15:47.030
Yes, it does.

276
00:15:47.030 --> 00:15:54.251
Because when you are compiling a product,
when you are releasing a product and

277
00:15:54.251 --> 00:15:58.520
transitioning it into
the live environment,

278
00:15:58.520 --> 00:16:05.720
Not only are you effecting a change,
but you are also releasing CIs.

279
00:16:05.720 --> 00:16:09.430
Whether you're releasing software or
whether you're releasing hardware,

280
00:16:09.430 --> 00:16:13.980
you are releasing CIs into
the live environment.

281
00:16:13.980 --> 00:16:15.134
And therefore,

282
00:16:15.134 --> 00:16:20.990
you need to be updating the CI records in
the configuration management database, or

283
00:16:20.990 --> 00:16:26.941
in your configuration management system
if you have multiple federated databases.

284
00:16:29.010 --> 00:16:33.639
If there's anything there that you
don't quite understand in these

285
00:16:33.639 --> 00:16:38.508
particular definitions,
if you don't understand the term baseline,

286
00:16:38.508 --> 00:16:43.374
if you don't understand the term CI,
or you want further clarification

287
00:16:43.374 --> 00:16:48.560
on the term Change or RFC, then please
take a look at our ITIL series.

288
00:16:48.560 --> 00:16:53.420
We've got quite a few series
within the ITIL subsection,

289
00:16:53.420 --> 00:16:56.390
go take a look at our ITIL landing page.

290
00:16:56.390 --> 00:17:00.757
In Foundation, you will see a couple
of episodes on Service Transition, and

291
00:17:00.757 --> 00:17:04.200
that's gonna give you a very,
very high-level view.

292
00:17:04.200 --> 00:17:06.770
Go into the Service Transition series, and

293
00:17:06.770 --> 00:17:09.610
you will see some episodes
on Change Management and

294
00:17:09.610 --> 00:17:13.120
some episodes of Service Asset and
Configuration Management.

295
00:17:13.120 --> 00:17:16.273
And they're the episodes that you wanna
concentrate on if you want further

296
00:17:16.273 --> 00:17:17.970
clarification.

297
00:17:17.970 --> 00:17:21.562
I don't want you to dismiss that, okay?

298
00:17:21.562 --> 00:17:26.709
I really, really, really don't want you,
and to be honest, in terms of your test,

299
00:17:26.709 --> 00:17:30.427
please don't just think ITIL's
got nothing to do with you and

300
00:17:30.427 --> 00:17:33.878
therefore it doesn't matter,
because it does matter.

301
00:17:33.878 --> 00:17:36.073
And certainly when it comes
to your Practitioner,

302
00:17:36.073 --> 00:17:37.560
you will be expected to know this.

303
00:17:37.560 --> 00:17:41.380
And if you don't understand those
particular concepts, you're not going to

304
00:17:41.380 --> 00:17:46.210
be able to apply the PRINCE2 project
management methodology without

305
00:17:46.210 --> 00:17:50.738
understanding what it is that you're
applying into the live environment, okay?

306
00:17:50.738 --> 00:17:55.620
So please, that's just sort
of a almost begging there,

307
00:17:55.620 --> 00:17:59.420
but go back and take a look at
those episodes, they will help you.

308
00:18:00.960 --> 00:18:05.140
I'm going to take a look at
this particular slide then now.

309
00:18:05.140 --> 00:18:09.021
And you'll see that Change, and
I'm not calling it change management,

310
00:18:09.021 --> 00:18:10.845
I'm calling it the Change theme.

311
00:18:10.845 --> 00:18:14.912
And I'm deliberately not
calling it change management,

312
00:18:14.912 --> 00:18:19.850
cuz I do not want you to be
confused with change management.

313
00:18:19.850 --> 00:18:24.200
Change is about making a change
to what we're going to deliver

314
00:18:24.200 --> 00:18:24.887
to the project, okay?

315
00:18:26.430 --> 00:18:29.050
Now, we've already looked at the bottom
right-hand corner there because we've

316
00:18:29.050 --> 00:18:30.940
talked about the types of issues.

317
00:18:30.940 --> 00:18:33.940
But we have to define in
the top right-hand corner,

318
00:18:33.940 --> 00:18:39.210
we have to define what an issue looks
like, how an issue is reported,

319
00:18:39.210 --> 00:18:45.600
how an issue is authorized, and
how we change the baseline.

320
00:18:45.600 --> 00:18:50.620
So how we record the current baseline and
then make a change once we

321
00:18:50.620 --> 00:18:56.000
have accepted and
approved that particular issue.

322
00:18:56.000 --> 00:19:00.400
And that would be part of then what
we'd call our change control procedure,

323
00:19:00.400 --> 00:19:05.820
which is capturing issues, assessing them,
and then deciding what to do about them,

324
00:19:05.820 --> 00:19:07.990
and deciding whether they're
going to be approved.

325
00:19:09.550 --> 00:19:13.750
And then in that top left-hand corner
then, I want us to think about roles and

326
00:19:13.750 --> 00:19:18.690
responsibilities and
the fact that people have got to not

327
00:19:18.690 --> 00:19:23.620
just identify any issues, but we've
also got to have somebody that's going

328
00:19:23.620 --> 00:19:29.250
to authorize those issues and authorize
their acceptance into the project plan.

329
00:19:29.250 --> 00:19:32.720
And then we're going to have people
that are actually, like our developers,

330
00:19:32.720 --> 00:19:35.520
that are actually going to
incorporate those issues and

331
00:19:35.520 --> 00:19:39.485
incorporate the changes into
the project plan, okay?

332
00:19:41.520 --> 00:19:46.340
So I'm gonna ask Justin right now,
does that kinda make sense to you?

333
00:19:46.340 --> 00:19:49.240
>> It does,
I was just sitting here thinking,

334
00:19:49.240 --> 00:19:54.720
I'm really gonna have to be specific in
how I think about the word issue, though.

335
00:19:54.720 --> 00:19:57.770
Because you just talking now, you're like,
well, they're gonna integrate,

336
00:19:57.770 --> 00:20:00.440
they're gonna implement, but

337
00:20:00.440 --> 00:20:04.370
when I say the word issue-
>> It's got a negative connotation, right?

338
00:20:04.370 --> 00:20:07.030
>> It's like, something bad has happened.

339
00:20:07.030 --> 00:20:09.677
It's almost more akin to a risk event,

340
00:20:09.677 --> 00:20:14.380
like something bad went wrong
than necessarily a change.

341
00:20:14.380 --> 00:20:18.630
>> Right, well-
>> And I understand why they've chosen

342
00:20:18.630 --> 00:20:23.620
to pick, to say, this is what we're gonna
talk about and give it another definition,

343
00:20:23.620 --> 00:20:24.940
so that's handy.

344
00:20:24.940 --> 00:20:28.072
It's just my everyday usage of the word,
issue,

345
00:20:28.072 --> 00:20:30.466
it kinda puts my mind in a weird place.

346
00:20:30.466 --> 00:20:32.644
>> I'm gonna say, yeah, and I get that.

347
00:20:32.644 --> 00:20:36.321
Think of it like this, okay,
and this is the best way for

348
00:20:36.321 --> 00:20:38.294
you to think about it as well.

349
00:20:38.294 --> 00:20:42.039
Think about it like this, an issue's
something we have to deal with, okay?

350
00:20:43.530 --> 00:20:48.000
So in that way you kinda, what I'm
trying to do is kinda making a bridge

351
00:20:48.000 --> 00:20:52.580
between where you are with the negative
place, and the request for change,

352
00:20:52.580 --> 00:20:55.360
which is more of a, I'd like to do this.

353
00:20:55.360 --> 00:20:59.730
Yeah, so think about an issue as being
something you have to deal with.

354
00:20:59.730 --> 00:21:00.924
Does that kinda make sense?

355
00:21:00.924 --> 00:21:03.370
Does that sort of appease?

356
00:21:03.370 --> 00:21:07.821
>> That does, I'm just gonna have to trick
my brain and go, you gotta deal with it,

357
00:21:07.821 --> 00:21:11.960
it's not necessarily a bad,
it's just something you gotta deal with.

358
00:21:11.960 --> 00:21:13.635
>> Right.
>> I'm just gonna have to think of it very

359
00:21:13.635 --> 00:21:14.266
consciously.

360
00:21:14.266 --> 00:21:17.560
>> Well,
what I'm gonna do right now is, and

361
00:21:17.560 --> 00:21:22.450
I did say that we're gonna take this
one into a Part Two, because in

362
00:21:22.450 --> 00:21:27.370
order to look at the change process
itself, or to look at the actual theme,

363
00:21:27.370 --> 00:21:31.050
and to look at what we do with Change,
we're gonna come back in Part Two.

364
00:21:31.050 --> 00:21:34.890
Because what I wanna give you opportunity
to do is kind of digest that,

365
00:21:34.890 --> 00:21:37.860
download the material that
you have available to you.

366
00:21:37.860 --> 00:21:45.100
Take a look at maybe at our ITIL series,
and see what's said in Service Transition

367
00:21:45.100 --> 00:21:50.650
about change management, and about an RFC,
and about configuration items.

368
00:21:50.650 --> 00:21:55.140
Because when we come back in Part Two, I'm
not gonna sort of redefine any of that,

369
00:21:55.140 --> 00:21:58.830
what we're gonna do in Part Two is
we're just gonna look at the activities

370
00:21:58.830 --> 00:22:02.430
that have to happen
within the Change theme.

371
00:22:02.430 --> 00:22:05.440
>> Well, Jo, it seems like I've got a
little bit of homework before we come back

372
00:22:05.440 --> 00:22:08.828
for Part Two, and you probably need
to go do those things that she said.

373
00:22:08.828 --> 00:22:12.310
Check out ITIL, look at those
downloadable materials, because if

374
00:22:12.310 --> 00:22:16.990
you're anything like me, well, those word
choices will get you a little bit twisted.

375
00:22:16.990 --> 00:22:19.331
But definitely come on back cuz we're
gonna continue on talking about

376
00:22:19.331 --> 00:22:19.973
the Change theme.

377
00:22:19.973 --> 00:22:23.000
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

378
00:22:23.000 --> 00:22:25.940
So, signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

379
00:22:25.940 --> 00:22:26.640
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

380
00:22:26.640 --> 00:22:27.519
>> And we'll see you next time.

381
00:22:27.519 --> 00:22:34.383
[MUSIC]

382
00:22:34.383 --> 00:22:36.905
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: These 2 episodes cover the Prince2® Change theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Change Part 2

2

3
