[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.177 --> 00:00:11.712
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.712 --> 00:00:15.051
>> Greeting everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.051 --> 00:00:20.383
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and
we're back with Prince2 2017 Foundation.

7
00:00:20.383 --> 00:00:26.071
And well, we're continuing on with part
two in our change theme and you know what?

8
00:00:26.071 --> 00:00:27.281
We assigned you a little bit of homework.

9
00:00:27.281 --> 00:00:29.972
I tried to do mine and
hopefully you did yours,

10
00:00:29.972 --> 00:00:32.601
cuz we're gonna continue that discussion.

11
00:00:32.601 --> 00:00:36.008
And here to help us with that continuation
of the discussion, is the one and only Ms.

12
00:00:36.008 --> 00:00:36.541
Jo Peacock.

13
00:00:36.541 --> 00:00:37.910
How you doing today, Jo?

14
00:00:37.910 --> 00:00:39.530
>> Absolutely, great.
Thank you, Justin.

15
00:00:39.530 --> 00:00:41.905
How are you?
>> I am doing fantastic.

16
00:00:41.905 --> 00:00:46.358
The whole time I'm talking,
a lot of times Jo's giving me these looks,

17
00:00:46.358 --> 00:00:48.780
I don't know if I'm doing good or not.

18
00:00:48.780 --> 00:00:50.643
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I guess she'll tell me if I need

19
00:00:50.643 --> 00:00:54.410
to change something and we'll kind
of have a pow-wow over it, right?

20
00:00:54.410 --> 00:00:57.200
>> Yeah, well if you need to change
something then I'll raise an RFC, and

21
00:00:57.200 --> 00:00:59.820
now that you've done your homework
you know what that is, right?

22
00:00:59.820 --> 00:01:01.612
>> That's a request for change.

23
00:01:01.612 --> 00:01:04.761
>> Hey, see, see, it does work sometimes,

24
00:01:04.761 --> 00:01:08.800
I can assign some homework and
actually he might do it.

25
00:01:08.800 --> 00:01:10.270
I mean that's a risk in itself.

26
00:01:10.270 --> 00:01:12.314
>> [LAUGH]
>> Again that goes back to our previous

27
00:01:12.314 --> 00:01:13.560
episode, right?

28
00:01:13.560 --> 00:01:18.260
Okay, so
can you remember what we called a change?

29
00:01:18.260 --> 00:01:19.893
>> It was an issue.

30
00:01:19.893 --> 00:01:22.600
>> It was an issue, right, it was.

31
00:01:22.600 --> 00:01:24.340
I'm impressed.

32
00:01:24.340 --> 00:01:29.675
>> And furthermore, an event that
occurs that was not planned for,

33
00:01:29.675 --> 00:01:34.140
that requires admin, or
a management intervention?

34
00:01:34.140 --> 00:01:37.960
>> Right, okay, so not planned for where?

35
00:01:37.960 --> 00:01:39.790
>> At the beginning of the project?

36
00:01:39.790 --> 00:01:41.650
>> Right, as part of the project plan.

37
00:01:41.650 --> 00:01:45.562
Yep, exactly, so it wasn't part
of the original project baseline,

38
00:01:45.562 --> 00:01:47.230
that's what we're saying.

39
00:01:47.230 --> 00:01:53.140
And we took a look just sort of
as we left on our last episode,

40
00:01:53.140 --> 00:01:56.950
we took a look at this
particular slide in front of us.

41
00:01:56.950 --> 00:01:57.820
Do you remember this one?

42
00:01:57.820 --> 00:02:03.040
This was the confusing one I guess or the
complex one, should I say, not confusing.

43
00:02:03.040 --> 00:02:07.369
>> Yeah, this one is not too bad cuz it's
very similar to our other themes where you

44
00:02:07.369 --> 00:02:11.455
go, okay, here are all the things that
need to come under consideration.

45
00:02:11.455 --> 00:02:13.180
>> Yeah.

46
00:02:13.180 --> 00:02:16.440
>> It took me a little while to wrap
my head around some of the verbiage.

47
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:18.737
>> Right, and
this is why I wanted you to go away and

48
00:02:18.737 --> 00:02:20.350
just do a little bit of research.

49
00:02:20.350 --> 00:02:25.333
Download the materials, but
also do a little bit of research into what

50
00:02:25.333 --> 00:02:28.720
an RFC is,
what a configuration item or a CI is.

51
00:02:28.720 --> 00:02:33.036
And the difference between a CI and
a CI record, which is of course,

52
00:02:33.036 --> 00:02:37.230
the form where we describe all of
the attributes of a specific CI.

53
00:02:37.230 --> 00:02:41.960
And a CI is of course what you're going to
be deploying into the live environment.

54
00:02:41.960 --> 00:02:46.822
So now that we've taken a look at that
diagram again, and this is all available

55
00:02:46.822 --> 00:02:51.640
in your downloadable material,
I want you to take a look at this, okay?

56
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:54.160
Now this one is,
I know that this is small.

57
00:02:54.160 --> 00:02:57.930
This is going to be easy for you, in your
downloadable material, but you know what?

58
00:02:57.930 --> 00:03:01.140
It's in purple and
you know what that means?

59
00:03:03.170 --> 00:03:03.990
>> It's from the Prince2 book.

60
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:06.490
>> It's from the Prince2 book,
yep, exactly that, okay?

61
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:08.240
>> I'm learning things.
>> [LAUGH] It was in purple,

62
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:10.250
it's from the Prince2 book,

63
00:03:10.250 --> 00:03:15.630
which means that you have this available
to you if you have got your Prince2 book.

64
00:03:15.630 --> 00:03:20.705
Now I know that your Prince2 2017 book,
you won't need necessarily for

65
00:03:20.705 --> 00:03:25.800
your foundation tests, you will need
it for your practitioner test though.

66
00:03:25.800 --> 00:03:29.425
So I would definitely
recommend that you go out and

67
00:03:29.425 --> 00:03:33.060
you obtain a copy of
that Prince2 2017 book.

68
00:03:33.060 --> 00:03:38.546
You'll see here, that what we have
is a change control technique,

69
00:03:38.546 --> 00:03:41.250
and what I want to start off with.

70
00:03:42.460 --> 00:03:44.590
Take a look in the purple
boxes that go along the top.

71
00:03:44.590 --> 00:03:49.465
Where we capture, where we assess,
where we propose, where we decide, and

72
00:03:49.465 --> 00:03:51.498
where we implement the change.

73
00:03:51.498 --> 00:03:56.070
Along the bottom with every single change.

74
00:03:56.070 --> 00:04:01.410
Once we capture the issue as we call it.

75
00:04:01.410 --> 00:04:05.220
Once we capture it, you will see that
we determine the priority of it.

76
00:04:05.220 --> 00:04:10.250
In other words, well, based on impact and
urgency, is it needed?

77
00:04:10.250 --> 00:04:15.770
What is the impact to the project and
what about the urgency?

78
00:04:15.770 --> 00:04:21.490
And then we log the issue in our
daily log or in our issue register,

79
00:04:21.490 --> 00:04:26.590
whatever you want to call it and
then we assess this issue.

80
00:04:26.590 --> 00:04:31.526
And we assess it on impact on the project
itself, from the project objectives,

81
00:04:31.526 --> 00:04:34.340
we assess it for
impact on the business case.

82
00:04:34.340 --> 00:04:40.300
Because of course the business cases are
continual justification for the project.

83
00:04:40.300 --> 00:04:45.029
So we need to make sure that if we
are accommodating any issues and

84
00:04:45.029 --> 00:04:50.470
if we're making changes to the project
itself, into the deliverables.

85
00:04:50.470 --> 00:04:55.415
Then we have got to ensure that the
business case therefore justifies those

86
00:04:55.415 --> 00:04:57.700
amendments to the deliverables.

87
00:04:57.700 --> 00:04:59.828
And again, we wanna check and

88
00:04:59.828 --> 00:05:04.720
we wanna validate that
priority that we've assigned.

89
00:05:04.720 --> 00:05:07.465
If we make any changes to the issue,

90
00:05:07.465 --> 00:05:12.510
then we update the issue register,
and that's when we propose.

91
00:05:12.510 --> 00:05:15.431
So now we've done the preliminary work,

92
00:05:15.431 --> 00:05:18.940
we've done almost
the evaluation of the change.

93
00:05:18.940 --> 00:05:23.470
We've got all of the issue rather, we've
got all of the information that we need.

94
00:05:23.470 --> 00:05:27.640
Now we're gonna identify what
we can do about that issue.

95
00:05:27.640 --> 00:05:30.749
So this is why we talk
about identifying options,

96
00:05:30.749 --> 00:05:33.050
it's what we can do about the issue.

97
00:05:34.050 --> 00:05:40.210
And then we make recommendations to
implement a solution to that issue.

98
00:05:40.210 --> 00:05:43.520
And that's when we make the decision.

99
00:05:43.520 --> 00:05:48.210
The decision is yes, we're going to do it,
so we approve it or we reject it or

100
00:05:48.210 --> 00:05:50.220
maybe even we defer it.

101
00:05:50.220 --> 00:05:56.000
And we leave it to a later management
stage in the project perhaps,

102
00:05:56.000 --> 00:06:01.180
something that is an option and
we escalate it if we need to.

103
00:06:01.180 --> 00:06:04.392
You'll notice that there
are a couple of arrows that

104
00:06:04.392 --> 00:06:08.470
go back up to the project board or
to the change authority.

105
00:06:08.470 --> 00:06:14.010
The project board are the, well they're
our governments board for our project.

106
00:06:14.010 --> 00:06:19.143
And so the project board are going
to help us to identify the severity,

107
00:06:19.143 --> 00:06:21.840
to identify the impact of any issue.

108
00:06:21.840 --> 00:06:26.148
They may have even requested
a particular issue, and

109
00:06:26.148 --> 00:06:33.710
the change authority is the person that is
going to approve that particular issue.

110
00:06:33.710 --> 00:06:38.150
And then once we've got a decision from
them, then we implement that issue.

111
00:06:38.150 --> 00:06:41.690
So we take the corrective action,
as it says.

112
00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:46.588
Now, the term corrective
action is not one that sort of

113
00:06:46.588 --> 00:06:49.580
fills me with joy, should I say.

114
00:06:49.580 --> 00:06:53.206
Because sometimes things are in RFC and
that's a request, and

115
00:06:53.206 --> 00:06:54.790
it's not to fix a problem.

116
00:06:54.790 --> 00:06:57.940
And therefore,
that issue is not necessarily negative.

117
00:06:57.940 --> 00:07:01.173
And I know that we had a discussion
in our previous episode about

118
00:07:01.173 --> 00:07:03.920
sort of the negative
connotations of the word issue.

119
00:07:03.920 --> 00:07:08.138
And I said to you, well, think of an issue
of something that's gotta be action,

120
00:07:08.138 --> 00:07:09.950
something that's got to be done.

121
00:07:09.950 --> 00:07:11.980
It's not necessarily negative,

122
00:07:11.980 --> 00:07:15.480
whereas then start talking
about corrective action.

123
00:07:15.480 --> 00:07:19.750
Well we take corrective if
it's saying negative issue.

124
00:07:19.750 --> 00:07:21.633
But we might also take corrective action,

125
00:07:21.633 --> 00:07:24.420
if we've chosen to defer that
particular issue for instance.

126
00:07:24.420 --> 00:07:29.353
So if we've chosen to defer it,
the corrective action would be

127
00:07:29.353 --> 00:07:34.390
to update the issue register with
a deferral date for instance.

128
00:07:36.880 --> 00:07:41.681
In terms of sort of continuance
about change control technique,

129
00:07:41.681 --> 00:07:46.670
here again, we've got another
diagram from our Prince2 manual.

130
00:07:46.670 --> 00:07:49.420
And you'll see here that
we've got a balance.

131
00:07:50.810 --> 00:07:53.226
Changes are not automatically approved,

132
00:07:53.226 --> 00:07:56.049
issues are not automatically
given the go ahead.

133
00:07:56.049 --> 00:07:59.784
We do not automatically say, yes,
we're gonna change the product delivery.

134
00:07:59.784 --> 00:08:06.908
I mentioned terms like scope And changes
to requirements in our last episode.

135
00:08:06.908 --> 00:08:10.640
And we don't know what's great to that.

136
00:08:10.640 --> 00:08:15.920
And, as I've just mentioned, we have to
have the relevant business justification.

137
00:08:15.920 --> 00:08:20.820
So we don't always agree,
we don't always approve

138
00:08:20.820 --> 00:08:24.640
an update to the project baseline or
an update to the project plan.

139
00:08:24.640 --> 00:08:26.980
We have to weigh things off.

140
00:08:26.980 --> 00:08:29.149
That sounds better than balance,
really, doesn't it,

141
00:08:29.149 --> 00:08:31.200
because that's the term
[LAUGH] that we generally use.

142
00:08:31.200 --> 00:08:33.980
We gotta weigh it up.

143
00:08:33.980 --> 00:08:40.626
Is the improved quality, or
is that changing scope worth the risk?

144
00:08:40.626 --> 00:08:43.100
Is it worth the cost?

145
00:08:43.100 --> 00:08:48.070
Are the increased benefits worth
the risk or are they worth the cost?

146
00:08:48.070 --> 00:08:49.390
So we've gotta weigh it out.

147
00:08:49.390 --> 00:08:53.380
We've gotta make sure that it's
something that we want to do

148
00:08:53.380 --> 00:08:58.310
before we then implement that particular,
well, issue.

149
00:08:58.310 --> 00:09:00.500
Implement the change itself.

150
00:09:02.020 --> 00:09:04.670
>> So when assessing an issue with RFC,
whatever it may be,

151
00:09:04.670 --> 00:09:08.647
about whether we're going to implement
a change deferred, or what, effectively,

152
00:09:08.647 --> 00:09:11.487
every time we go through
a cost-benefit analysis, right?

153
00:09:11.487 --> 00:09:12.110
>> Yes.

154
00:09:12.110 --> 00:09:14.070
>> So how much is it gonna cost us?

155
00:09:14.070 --> 00:09:15.030
What are the benefits?

156
00:09:15.030 --> 00:09:17.205
How do those compare to, is it good?

157
00:09:17.205 --> 00:09:18.340
Is it bad?

158
00:09:18.340 --> 00:09:20.040
Is it minimal increase?

159
00:09:20.040 --> 00:09:23.597
These are all the questions that
we will do for every issue-

160
00:09:23.597 --> 00:09:24.968
>> Yep.

161
00:09:24.968 --> 00:09:27.590
>> That would crop up during the project.

162
00:09:27.590 --> 00:09:31.590
>> Right, and that's why we have
the issue register because, yes,

163
00:09:31.590 --> 00:09:35.710
we are going to do that, that's why we
have that particular process that we just

164
00:09:35.710 --> 00:09:38.520
looked up because we wanna
make sure that happens.

165
00:09:38.520 --> 00:09:42.720
And we also want to make sure that not
only is the issue register updated but

166
00:09:42.720 --> 00:09:44.790
the business case is updated as well.

167
00:09:44.790 --> 00:09:49.600
If you remember from our previous
episodes, the business case is updated and

168
00:09:49.600 --> 00:09:54.460
is reviewed within every
single management stage.

169
00:09:54.460 --> 00:10:00.300
And so therefore, you have to ensure that

170
00:10:00.300 --> 00:10:05.340
whatever change you're making,
whatever issue you're addressing,

171
00:10:05.340 --> 00:10:08.810
well, that it actually meets
the needs of the organization.

172
00:10:08.810 --> 00:10:11.930
And that we do have the relevant
justification for it.

173
00:10:11.930 --> 00:10:15.740
So yeah, we've gotta do that
sorta cost benefit analysis,

174
00:10:15.740 --> 00:10:18.420
if you will, with every single issue.

175
00:10:19.630 --> 00:10:24.490
I have seen some horrendous
issue registers in projects.

176
00:10:24.490 --> 00:10:29.260
And when I say horrendous, I mean where
we've got 500 issues that are outlined.

177
00:10:29.260 --> 00:10:32.610
That tells me if we've got 500
issues in an issue register,

178
00:10:32.610 --> 00:10:35.111
then somebody's got the project
wrong in the first place.

179
00:10:37.280 --> 00:10:40.110
>> I thought you were gonna say I've
seen some horrendous ones like ones that

180
00:10:40.110 --> 00:10:40.905
don't exist.

181
00:10:40.905 --> 00:10:41.490
[LAUGH]
>> Well, yeah.

182
00:10:41.490 --> 00:10:44.020
I mean I've seen the opposite as well,
yeah.

183
00:10:44.020 --> 00:10:46.918
And I don't know which is worst,
[LAUGH] to be perfectly honest.

184
00:10:46.918 --> 00:10:52.070
>> Like do I just act
like nothing's there or

185
00:10:52.070 --> 00:10:54.770
do I have it packed full of things?

186
00:10:56.090 --> 00:10:58.951
I'm not even sure we're talking
about the same project when you see

187
00:10:58.951 --> 00:11:00.920
an issues list that is 300, 400 lines.

188
00:11:00.920 --> 00:11:03.589
>> You might.

189
00:11:03.589 --> 00:11:07.188
When you have that many issues and
you just think to yourself, well,

190
00:11:07.188 --> 00:11:11.630
somebody clearly didn't scope out this
project correctly in the first place.

191
00:11:11.630 --> 00:11:13.920
What do you reckon we do in
that instance by the way?

192
00:11:15.150 --> 00:11:17.200
>> That's one of the things where
at the end of the stage you go,

193
00:11:17.200 --> 00:11:22.020
this is this many issues we scoped out,
I'm gonna make green crayons but

194
00:11:22.020 --> 00:11:25.533
really what we need is a fork.

195
00:11:25.533 --> 00:11:26.992
>> Yeah.

196
00:11:26.992 --> 00:11:31.000
>> I would suspect you would go,
we're not gonna continue on this to

197
00:11:31.000 --> 00:11:34.290
implement all of these issues,
like corrective action or whatever.

198
00:11:34.290 --> 00:11:36.270
If it was me, I would say, stop.

199
00:11:36.270 --> 00:11:37.630
This project's done.

200
00:11:37.630 --> 00:11:41.060
Let's scope out the appropriate
project and reevaluate.

201
00:11:41.060 --> 00:11:42.360
>> Well, it's funny you should say that,

202
00:11:42.360 --> 00:11:47.835
because we actually have a process in
our stages for closing out a project,

203
00:11:47.835 --> 00:11:52.720
and it's an unexpected project closeout,
basically.

204
00:11:52.720 --> 00:11:57.960
And in that instance,
if I see an issue register where we've

205
00:11:57.960 --> 00:12:04.780
got 500 items in there, I will look
at them and I will actually say,

206
00:12:04.780 --> 00:12:09.750
this project has being, if there's
that many, then the chances are that

207
00:12:09.750 --> 00:12:12.490
the project has been scoped out
incorrectly in the first place.

208
00:12:12.490 --> 00:12:16.750
And then in that instance, you know what,
I want you to close out the project.

209
00:12:16.750 --> 00:12:20.390
And I want you then to start up a new
project where we have scoped everything

210
00:12:20.390 --> 00:12:21.400
out correctly.

211
00:12:21.400 --> 00:12:27.600
Now that doesn't necessarily
mean that we start everything

212
00:12:27.600 --> 00:12:32.030
from scratch because we've still got
roles and responsibilities, etc., that

213
00:12:32.030 --> 00:12:36.640
we can bring into the new project, but
nevertheless it needs to be a new project.

214
00:12:36.640 --> 00:12:37.960
It needs to be scoped out.

215
00:12:37.960 --> 00:12:43.750
It needs to be planned, because you
can't carry on making changes like that.

216
00:12:43.750 --> 00:12:46.680
You can't carry on updating
the risk register.

217
00:12:46.680 --> 00:12:50.810
That's actually going to be more effort
than going back to the drawing board and

218
00:12:50.810 --> 00:12:52.990
starting the process again.

219
00:12:52.990 --> 00:12:55.280
>> And to some extent,
you're more informed at this point.

220
00:12:55.280 --> 00:12:56.260
>> Right.
>> You're like,

221
00:12:56.260 --> 00:12:59.720
I had all these issues,
we didn't think about this correctly.

222
00:12:59.720 --> 00:13:02.940
We start a new project, we're now more
informed, we have more knowledge,

223
00:13:02.940 --> 00:13:06.770
and maybe we can get to a better
plan of action, so to speak.

224
00:13:06.770 --> 00:13:09.391
>> Yeah, exactly.

225
00:13:09.391 --> 00:13:12.410
And I do expect to see issue
registers in every single project.

226
00:13:12.410 --> 00:13:15.040
If a project doesn't
have an issue register,

227
00:13:15.040 --> 00:13:17.310
then that again tells me that, well,

228
00:13:17.310 --> 00:13:20.600
it doesn't tell me that you haven't scoped
it out correctly in the first place.

229
00:13:20.600 --> 00:13:23.810
It tells me that you're making assumptions
that you've scoped it out correctly

230
00:13:23.810 --> 00:13:25.530
right at the very, very beginning and

231
00:13:25.530 --> 00:13:29.050
it tells me that you're not necessarily
aligned with the organization either.

232
00:13:29.050 --> 00:13:33.050
Because if there isn't an issue
registered, then I would be asking

233
00:13:33.050 --> 00:13:35.400
the question, well, when was the last
time you went back to the users?

234
00:13:35.400 --> 00:13:39.480
When was the last time you verified with
them that you were on the right track?

235
00:13:39.480 --> 00:13:46.430
Because I have never seen a successful
project that there hasn't had

236
00:13:46.430 --> 00:13:50.690
an issue registrar where changes haven't
been requested throughout the project.

237
00:13:50.690 --> 00:13:54.410
I have never seen a successful
project where that's happened.

238
00:13:54.410 --> 00:13:58.150
I've seen plenty of projects that haven't
had an issue register that have gone

239
00:13:58.150 --> 00:14:02.130
through to fruition where the users
have said, well, that's great but

240
00:14:02.130 --> 00:14:07.440
I wanted this or but things have
changed now and I need it this way now.

241
00:14:07.440 --> 00:14:09.550
I've seen plenty of that happened.

242
00:14:09.550 --> 00:14:14.540
And sometimes projects can be in their
planning and in project management,

243
00:14:14.540 --> 00:14:16.410
we can be too rigid.

244
00:14:16.410 --> 00:14:20.410
And I teach you right at the very
beginning when we started off on this

245
00:14:20.410 --> 00:14:25.240
series I said, no, don't talk about things
being rigid please because it's not.

246
00:14:25.240 --> 00:14:29.930
We've got to be flexible, we have to have
a flexible approach to project management.

247
00:14:29.930 --> 00:14:33.070
And we have to accept that things change.

248
00:14:33.070 --> 00:14:37.500
We're in the 21st century now and
IT doesn't stay the same for 6 months.

249
00:14:38.500 --> 00:14:41.930
So there's absolutely,
[LAUGH] two months yeah,

250
00:14:41.930 --> 00:14:46.800
there's absolutely no way that
our project can stay the same.

251
00:14:46.800 --> 00:14:48.020
No way at all.

252
00:14:48.020 --> 00:14:51.650
So if I see a project that doesn't
have an issue register, then I'm

253
00:14:51.650 --> 00:14:57.590
equally as worried about that project as
if I see one that has 500 items in it.

254
00:14:57.590 --> 00:15:01.906
>> Now Jo, this issue register,
this very large one that we talked about,

255
00:15:01.906 --> 00:15:07.166
could that also

256
00:15:07.166 --> 00:15:12.050
kinda the result of a customer that

257
00:15:12.050 --> 00:15:15.790
does not have a clear understanding
of what they want, in particular?

258
00:15:15.790 --> 00:15:19.644
Like, maybe your scope report was correct
based on the information that you were

259
00:15:19.644 --> 00:15:20.780
given at the time.

260
00:15:20.780 --> 00:15:23.860
Then every time you show them, they're,
like, no actually, we want this now.

261
00:15:24.890 --> 00:15:27.019
Is that also a possibility
in this capacity?

262
00:15:27.019 --> 00:15:31.040
>> It is, but then that's down to
ineffective business analysis.

263
00:15:31.040 --> 00:15:34.600
And it's down to ineffective sorta
business relationship managements,

264
00:15:34.600 --> 00:15:39.720
as well, because I expect, if we've got
effective business relationship manages,

265
00:15:39.720 --> 00:15:43.570
if we've got effective business analysts,
then I expect them to know

266
00:15:43.570 --> 00:15:46.670
the organization well enough to
actually know what they want.

267
00:15:46.670 --> 00:15:50.765
And, in fact, again, and I know that in a
previous episode I said to you go back to

268
00:15:50.765 --> 00:15:54.343
ITIL and go back to looking at your
service transition series in ITIL.

269
00:15:54.343 --> 00:15:57.338
Go back to looking at your service
strategies series in ITIL and

270
00:15:57.338 --> 00:16:00.002
you'll see what happens
before a project's started.

271
00:16:00.002 --> 00:16:02.401
You'll see where the ideas come from.

272
00:16:02.401 --> 00:16:07.032
And the best projects are those
proactive ideas where the business

273
00:16:07.032 --> 00:16:12.087
relationship manager has a really
good understanding of the business.

274
00:16:12.087 --> 00:16:15.604
And has actually taken time and
has sat with the business and

275
00:16:15.604 --> 00:16:17.934
understands what the business needs.

276
00:16:17.934 --> 00:16:22.499
And actually recommends solutions for
the business, rather than waiting for

277
00:16:22.499 --> 00:16:26.620
the business to come to us and
ask for something specific.

278
00:16:26.620 --> 00:16:29.020
Invariably when
the organization comes to us,

279
00:16:29.020 --> 00:16:30.960
they'll tell us that they want an iPad.

280
00:16:30.960 --> 00:16:32.100
They'll give us the solution, and

281
00:16:32.100 --> 00:16:36.430
that's what they want, without really
understanding what their needs are.

282
00:16:36.430 --> 00:16:40.156
So the best projects,
the most successful projects,

283
00:16:40.156 --> 00:16:45.179
are the ones where business relationship
management has played a part and

284
00:16:45.179 --> 00:16:49.243
has been proactive in recommending for
the organization.

285
00:16:49.243 --> 00:16:51.779
Rather than those where we've waited for

286
00:16:51.779 --> 00:16:54.470
the organization to come
to us with a I want.

287
00:16:56.240 --> 00:16:59.130
So let's take a look then at
what we actually really need in

288
00:16:59.130 --> 00:17:02.370
order to have effective change
control within our project.

289
00:17:02.370 --> 00:17:07.850
Understanding that there are going
to be changes to requirements.

290
00:17:07.850 --> 00:17:14.870
We need to have an approach to change
control, to managing our issues,

291
00:17:14.870 --> 00:17:19.590
that show us how we identify those issues,
and assessing those issues.

292
00:17:19.590 --> 00:17:25.470
So everything that you have seen
in this particular diagram here,

293
00:17:25.470 --> 00:17:29.530
we need to have a structured,
consistent approach for

294
00:17:29.530 --> 00:17:34.530
how we perform every single
one of those activities.

295
00:17:34.530 --> 00:17:39.500
All of them,
including how we capture our product

296
00:17:39.500 --> 00:17:43.010
baselines and
how we control our product baselines.

297
00:17:43.010 --> 00:17:49.237
Including how we're going to manage
issues throughout the project itself.

298
00:17:49.237 --> 00:17:51.553
And what we do with
lessons learned as well,

299
00:17:51.553 --> 00:17:53.690
because they have to be identified too.

300
00:17:55.550 --> 00:17:59.340
Ultimately, as I've already said to
you just now when we were talking,

301
00:17:59.340 --> 00:18:02.010
we've got to align ourselves
with the organization.

302
00:18:02.010 --> 00:18:06.590
So this is reliant on good
business relationship management.

303
00:18:06.590 --> 00:18:10.130
But it's also reliant on good
project management as well.

304
00:18:11.140 --> 00:18:13.000
And the project manager,

305
00:18:13.000 --> 00:18:17.870
well, should be able to manage
the change control approach.

306
00:18:17.870 --> 00:18:21.180
They should be able to manage
all of those activities.

307
00:18:21.180 --> 00:18:23.563
You saw the interaction
with the project board and

308
00:18:23.563 --> 00:18:25.329
with change authorization as well.

309
00:18:25.329 --> 00:18:29.501
Because the change authority
has to authorize any issues,

310
00:18:29.501 --> 00:18:31.260
authorize any changes.

311
00:18:32.540 --> 00:18:36.588
And as we've already said as well,
we're doing that cost benefit analysis, so

312
00:18:36.588 --> 00:18:37.875
we have to have a budget.

313
00:18:37.875 --> 00:18:43.300
And any good effective project manager

314
00:18:43.300 --> 00:18:48.480
will ensure that we,
as part of the project budget,

315
00:18:48.480 --> 00:18:52.600
we have an allocated budget
to accommodate changes.

316
00:18:53.610 --> 00:18:57.250
Because as I've said right at the
beginning, we're in the 21st century now.

317
00:18:57.250 --> 00:19:00.310
Things change every, well I was
going to say every couple of months,

318
00:19:00.310 --> 00:19:02.340
Justin thinks every two months.

319
00:19:02.340 --> 00:19:05.160
So you have to accommodate for
that in your project,

320
00:19:05.160 --> 00:19:08.770
which means that you have to have
the budget to accommodate for that.

321
00:19:08.770 --> 00:19:12.080
Because when we're bringing in a new
change, it's probably going to cost us

322
00:19:12.080 --> 00:19:17.940
money, because we're going to need to
bring in additional skills to be on it.

323
00:19:17.940 --> 00:19:23.260
So we need to have a defined
approach to change control,

324
00:19:23.260 --> 00:19:27.910
and we need to have
a documented issue register.

325
00:19:27.910 --> 00:19:32.107
As well as a daily log,
as well as a report, and of course,

326
00:19:32.107 --> 00:19:37.797
we've already mentioned our CI record,
that's gonna be important as well.

327
00:19:37.797 --> 00:19:43.044
Don't forget, if we're making
any changes to any products,

328
00:19:43.044 --> 00:19:49.390
then they need to be updated in our
configuration management database too.

329
00:19:51.070 --> 00:19:52.930
Justin's thinking now.

330
00:19:52.930 --> 00:19:56.420
>> So this is one of those
things you may kinda gloss over.

331
00:19:56.420 --> 00:19:59.663
But having this approach,
it seems like this is a good way

332
00:19:59.663 --> 00:20:04.002
to stymie possible what I call shiny
object syndrome or anything like that.

333
00:20:04.002 --> 00:20:07.421
Where you have all this expense and
all this, well,

334
00:20:07.421 --> 00:20:10.764
all this change that occurs
because someone goes,

335
00:20:10.764 --> 00:20:15.260
I found this new tool that will
actually help us do this better.

336
00:20:15.260 --> 00:20:19.314
Except, no one in-house has the skills,
we don't have this infrastructure,

337
00:20:19.314 --> 00:20:21.827
we don't have, so
there's this over reaching.

338
00:20:21.827 --> 00:20:26.155
So I'm guessing having this approach
where it says this what we're gonna do,

339
00:20:26.155 --> 00:20:27.872
it helps stymie that, right?

340
00:20:27.872 --> 00:20:32.816
>> Right, and I also don't want you
to forget the fact that even though

341
00:20:32.816 --> 00:20:38.650
we're in project management,
we want to have a DevOps approach as well.

342
00:20:38.650 --> 00:20:41.695
And so
you don't need to reinvent the wheel,

343
00:20:41.695 --> 00:20:47.149
if our operations environment has got
a really good change management process,

344
00:20:47.149 --> 00:20:50.616
and it's a change management
process that works.

345
00:20:50.616 --> 00:20:54.743
And we've got the relevant change
authorities in place as well, and

346
00:20:54.743 --> 00:20:58.657
we've got the relevant places for
storing documentation and for

347
00:20:58.657 --> 00:21:02.120
recording change,
then why aren't we using that?

348
00:21:02.120 --> 00:21:06.800
The project environment is
not a separate organization,

349
00:21:06.800 --> 00:21:09.560
the project environment
is still part of IT.

350
00:21:10.600 --> 00:21:15.718
And therefore, as part of IT,
we should be working

351
00:21:15.718 --> 00:21:20.725
in the same way,
we should be using consistency.

352
00:21:20.725 --> 00:21:24.210
For the sake of efficiency,
we want consistent methods.

353
00:21:24.210 --> 00:21:29.875
Sure, we should have a separate,
I was gonna say, we should have

354
00:21:29.875 --> 00:21:36.789
a partitioned part of the database where
we record changes and record our RFCs.

355
00:21:36.789 --> 00:21:38.880
Should it be part of the live environment?

356
00:21:38.880 --> 00:21:44.830
Not necessarily, however, we should
still be looking at the same processes.

357
00:21:44.830 --> 00:21:48.920
We should still be as efficient
as we possibly can be.

358
00:21:48.920 --> 00:21:51.840
We have just as much of
a responsibility for

359
00:21:51.840 --> 00:21:56.460
efficiency as the operational
environment does.

360
00:21:56.460 --> 00:22:01.560
So learn from the operational environment,
don't act in silos,

361
00:22:01.560 --> 00:22:07.350
because acting in silos is just never
efficient, learn where you can.

362
00:22:07.350 --> 00:22:12.765
So as far as change is concerned,
we've looked at what change means.

363
00:22:12.765 --> 00:22:18.965
We've looked at issues, we've looked
at how we implement a change control

364
00:22:18.965 --> 00:22:24.895
approach, and the sorts of activities
that we have to ensure that we manage.

365
00:22:24.895 --> 00:22:27.215
So for this particular theme,

366
00:22:27.215 --> 00:22:31.509
then this is our final episode
on that particular theme.

367
00:22:31.509 --> 00:22:34.777
And when we come back,
we're going to be looking,

368
00:22:34.777 --> 00:22:38.350
in our next episode,
at the project theme of progress.

369
00:22:39.630 --> 00:22:43.488
>> Well, Jo, I'm kind of interested
to see how progress, I don't know,

370
00:22:43.488 --> 00:22:46.166
my mind is going a bunch
of different directions.

371
00:22:46.166 --> 00:22:47.920
And, well,
yours may be doing the same thing.

372
00:22:47.920 --> 00:22:50.410
And the only way you're gonna find
out is if you join us back and

373
00:22:50.410 --> 00:22:52.520
see what progress theme is all about.

374
00:22:52.520 --> 00:22:54.690
But for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

375
00:22:54.690 --> 00:22:57.490
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

376
00:22:57.490 --> 00:22:58.340
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

377
00:22:58.340 --> 00:22:59.827
>> And we'll see you next time.

378
00:22:59.827 --> 00:23:05.976
[MUSIC]

379
00:23:05.976 --> 00:23:08.751
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: This episode covers the Prince2® Progress theme, looking at the purpose, objectives, and main components of the theme.
episodes.title: Prince2 Themes: Progress
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.349
Welcome to ITPRO TV.

2
00:00:01.349 --> 00:00:03.576
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.576 --> 00:00:08.242
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.242 --> 00:00:11.776
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.

5
00:00:11.776 --> 00:00:15.647
>> Greetings everyone, and welcome back
to another exciting episode of IT PRO TV.

6
00:00:15.647 --> 00:00:19.870
I'm your host Justin Dennison and
well, welcome back to PRINCE2 2017

7
00:00:19.870 --> 00:00:23.709
Foundation Series and
we're continuing our discussion on themes.

8
00:00:23.709 --> 00:00:28.237
And in this episode we're actually gonna
be talking about the progress themes, and

9
00:00:28.237 --> 00:00:30.979
to help us progress through
this a little bit more,

10
00:00:30.979 --> 00:00:32.784
is none other than Ms Jo Peacock.

11
00:00:32.784 --> 00:00:33.744
How are you doing Jo?

12
00:00:33.744 --> 00:00:35.066
>> Absolutely good, thank you Justin.

13
00:00:35.066 --> 00:00:35.902
How are you?

14
00:00:35.902 --> 00:00:40.149
>> I"m doing fantastic, you know it's
been a little longer of a week but

15
00:00:40.149 --> 00:00:45.344
we finally progressed through the week and
I think we're getting ready to finish up.

16
00:00:45.344 --> 00:00:48.372
But I'm pretty sure that's not what
we're talking about here right?

17
00:00:48.372 --> 00:00:50.329
>> You think you're getting
ready to finish up well no.

18
00:00:50.329 --> 00:00:51.942
>> For the week, for the week.

19
00:00:51.942 --> 00:00:56.394
>> No, no, no we're finishing up we're
on the last of our themes now for

20
00:00:56.394 --> 00:01:01.616
PRINCE2 project management but that's
as much as we're gonna finish up today.

21
00:01:01.616 --> 00:01:03.795
We've got lots today.

22
00:01:03.795 --> 00:01:08.340
We've got quite a few episodes and
right now what we're gonna be doing

23
00:01:08.340 --> 00:01:13.289
is monitoring progress, just a little
correction there Justin by the way.

24
00:01:13.289 --> 00:01:14.639
>> That's what I said, progress.

25
00:01:14.639 --> 00:01:16.798
>> No, yeah exactly.

26
00:01:16.798 --> 00:01:19.939
Yeah, well I'm gonna be
looking at progress.

27
00:01:19.939 --> 00:01:23.688
>> This reminds me, tomato,

28
00:01:23.688 --> 00:01:27.767
tomato, pants, trousers.

29
00:01:27.767 --> 00:01:29.323
They all sound the same to me.

30
00:01:29.323 --> 00:01:31.148
[LAUGH]
>> They all sound the same to you,

31
00:01:31.148 --> 00:01:31.665
all right.

32
00:01:31.665 --> 00:01:35.919
Okay, well I just wanna reassure everybody
that Justin does actually have his

33
00:01:35.919 --> 00:01:37.667
trousers on not just his pants.

34
00:01:37.667 --> 00:01:42.263
Because otherwise I would be very scared,
I wouldn't be here.

35
00:01:42.263 --> 00:01:43.602
Let's be honest about this.

36
00:01:43.602 --> 00:01:49.261
[LAUGH] Let's start taking a look then
at our final theme within PRINCE2

37
00:01:49.261 --> 00:01:54.262
project management and
our final theme is the progress theme,

38
00:01:54.262 --> 00:01:58.048
and there's a very simple
explanation there.

39
00:01:58.048 --> 00:02:02.622
In every single one of these episodes
that we've looked at with our themes,

40
00:02:02.622 --> 00:02:06.199
we have had the purpose of each
particular theme outlined.

41
00:02:06.199 --> 00:02:11.299
And just as a little tip for your test,
because I know that you want to do

42
00:02:11.299 --> 00:02:16.588
your foundation test, well you probably
need to be aware of the themes.

43
00:02:16.588 --> 00:02:20.531
You certainly need to be able to recognize
them when it comes to your test.

44
00:02:20.531 --> 00:02:25.964
If they ask any questions such as,
what is the purpose of the progress theme?

45
00:02:25.964 --> 00:02:30.412
Then I expect you to be
able to recognize this.

46
00:02:30.412 --> 00:02:36.401
Now, don't forget,
we are in PRINCE2 project management,

47
00:02:36.401 --> 00:02:40.361
and we're in our very, very last theme.

48
00:02:40.361 --> 00:02:46.818
And a theme is something that goes
through all of the project itself,

49
00:02:46.818 --> 00:02:50.730
and the project is completely scalable.

50
00:02:50.730 --> 00:02:56.455
So whether we've got two stages or whether
we've got 15 stages to that project.

51
00:02:56.455 --> 00:02:59.213
Whether it's a waterfall approach project,
or

52
00:02:59.213 --> 00:03:02.051
whether we're managing
it is an Agile approach.

53
00:03:02.051 --> 00:03:08.688
The fact is that these things need
to run through all of our projects.

54
00:03:08.688 --> 00:03:15.432
So a progress theme is about
monitoring progress of the project.

55
00:03:15.432 --> 00:03:17.649
Now I've just mentioned
a waterfall approach and

56
00:03:17.649 --> 00:03:19.512
I've just mentioned an Agile approach.

57
00:03:19.512 --> 00:03:23.734
So ultimately when you think about it,
this is flexible.

58
00:03:23.734 --> 00:03:29.057
And when I said don't forget,
don't forget that PRINCE2

59
00:03:29.057 --> 00:03:34.172
is not a plug and play option for
managing your projects.

60
00:03:34.172 --> 00:03:39.515
it's a methodology that we use to
manage projects but it is flexible.

61
00:03:39.515 --> 00:03:45.693
And we've already talked about tailoring
and of course PRICE2 needs to be tailored.

62
00:03:45.693 --> 00:03:49.414
So does the progress theme definitely.

63
00:03:49.414 --> 00:03:53.761
We've got to be able to monitor
progress bearing in mind that for

64
00:03:53.761 --> 00:03:57.398
every single project,
progress will be different.

65
00:03:57.398 --> 00:04:01.815
And progress will probably need to be
measured in different ways as well.

66
00:04:01.815 --> 00:04:05.451
So what we want to do,
the objective of the progress theme,

67
00:04:05.451 --> 00:04:09.841
is at says there, it's about
establishing the relevant mechanisms.

68
00:04:09.841 --> 00:04:14.962
I always add the word relevant in there,
and it's not out of the PRINCE2 book,

69
00:04:14.962 --> 00:04:19.396
the PRINCE2 book simply says to
establish mechanisms to monitor and

70
00:04:19.396 --> 00:04:21.627
compare actual against planned.

71
00:04:21.627 --> 00:04:25.460
But I look at the word,
I use the word relevance in there and

72
00:04:25.460 --> 00:04:29.608
I use that quite, I was just
gonna say quite liberally really,

73
00:04:29.608 --> 00:04:32.915
because we've gotta have
relevant mechanisms.

74
00:04:32.915 --> 00:04:36.375
This is not just about taking out some
mechanisms out of the PRINCE2 book and

75
00:04:36.375 --> 00:04:38.881
applying them and saying,
hey, look that will work.

76
00:04:38.881 --> 00:04:41.086
That's not always going to work.

77
00:04:41.086 --> 00:04:45.967
We want to have smart ways
of managing progress.

78
00:04:45.967 --> 00:04:48.662
So we need to be able to
measure our progress.

79
00:04:48.662 --> 00:04:50.919
It says there look, monitor and compare.

80
00:04:50.919 --> 00:04:53.705
Well if you're comparing,
you need to be able to measure.

81
00:04:53.705 --> 00:04:57.541
But sometimes measurement
can be quite a challenge.

82
00:04:57.541 --> 00:04:58.873
How do you measure quality?

83
00:04:58.873 --> 00:05:02.287
>> [SOUND] Subjectively.

84
00:05:02.287 --> 00:05:03.788
I don't know if that's
what you were [LAUGH]

85
00:05:03.788 --> 00:05:04.598
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

86
00:05:04.598 --> 00:05:07.620
>> So you're doing so,
>> That's quite an ambiguous,

87
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:10.643
>> You were somehow trying to quantify

88
00:05:10.643 --> 00:05:16.801
this through either surveys or
something of that nature to gather data.

89
00:05:16.801 --> 00:05:19.294
>> Right.
>> That you can make in assertion about.

90
00:05:19.294 --> 00:05:22.985
>> When you think about it, we talked to
one on one of our previous episodes when

91
00:05:22.985 --> 00:05:24.555
we looked at the quality thing.

92
00:05:24.555 --> 00:05:26.846
And we talked about the fact that,

93
00:05:26.846 --> 00:05:31.901
you've got to be able to measure quality
and that it's really difficult for

94
00:05:31.901 --> 00:05:37.198
our customers sometimes to quantify
quality, because quality is perceived.

95
00:05:37.198 --> 00:05:42.341
And so, our customer surveys user surveys,
are one of the ways that we would actually

96
00:05:42.341 --> 00:05:47.128
measure quality, and in fact it's really
important, those customer surveys

97
00:05:47.128 --> 00:05:51.571
are going to tell us whether we have
delivered what was set out to deliver.

98
00:05:51.571 --> 00:05:56.219
Sometimes the customers will tell
you I want something to do this,

99
00:05:56.219 --> 00:05:58.792
I want to have something to write on.

100
00:05:58.792 --> 00:06:01.398
Let's talk about something that Justin and

101
00:06:01.398 --> 00:06:05.842
I were discussing with our directors
just before we started this episode.

102
00:06:05.842 --> 00:06:10.751
About the fact that we have a requirement
or I have a requirement anyway, and

103
00:06:10.751 --> 00:06:14.588
my requirement was right well
I want something to write on,

104
00:06:14.588 --> 00:06:18.444
actually what I want is a 75
inch iPad that's what I want.

105
00:06:18.444 --> 00:06:23.997
Now, just imagine that for a moment,
that as a customer this is my requirement.

106
00:06:23.997 --> 00:06:28.666
And then I have been able to give
that to the project manager, and

107
00:06:28.666 --> 00:06:32.558
now the project manager is
going to have to sit down and

108
00:06:32.558 --> 00:06:36.993
work out how he's going to
deliver that to us as edutainers.

109
00:06:36.993 --> 00:06:40.536
How am I going to deliver
a set of 75 inch iPad?

110
00:06:40.536 --> 00:06:43.335
It's not going to be that
easy because somehow I

111
00:06:43.335 --> 00:06:45.647
don't think Apple make them just yet.

112
00:06:45.647 --> 00:06:47.927
>> No, no.

113
00:06:47.927 --> 00:06:48.681
>> [LAUGH]
>> For

114
00:06:48.681 --> 00:06:53.380
some reason my mind went to zip tie as in
a bunch of iPad pros like zip tied, yeah.

115
00:06:53.380 --> 00:06:56.268
>> [LAUGH]
>> But I don't think that necessarily,

116
00:06:56.268 --> 00:06:59.869
it doesn't fulfill the request
necessarily [CROSSTALK].

117
00:06:59.869 --> 00:07:00.787
>> Yeah, not quite, no.

118
00:07:00.787 --> 00:07:04.040
So we've gotta measure whether we're

119
00:07:04.040 --> 00:07:08.091
delivering quality as
the project progresses.

120
00:07:08.091 --> 00:07:12.178
So we've gotta measure whether we're
actually progressing in that project.

121
00:07:12.178 --> 00:07:16.447
So quality's a difficult one,
and surveys will help us.

122
00:07:16.447 --> 00:07:20.451
But really what we want to try and
do is we want to try and

123
00:07:20.451 --> 00:07:26.253
take anything that is subjective and
turn it into an objective measurement.

124
00:07:26.253 --> 00:07:29.119
And that of course it mentions
that the end there for

125
00:07:29.119 --> 00:07:33.598
that particular purpose it mentions
controlling any acceptable deviations.

126
00:07:33.598 --> 00:07:38.304
Now, in previous episodes
we've used the word tolerance.

127
00:07:38.304 --> 00:07:40.584
And we've talked about tolerances, and

128
00:07:40.584 --> 00:07:43.726
this is why we talk about
acceptable deviations as well.

129
00:07:43.726 --> 00:07:47.062
Remember we've got tolerances
that we can work within.

130
00:07:47.062 --> 00:07:49.824
And so when I give my requirements or

131
00:07:49.824 --> 00:07:55.256
our requirements to our directing team,
and I say this is what I want,

132
00:07:55.256 --> 00:07:59.789
this is the technology I want,
I got certain tolerances.

133
00:07:59.789 --> 00:08:04.283
My certain tolerances would be
something like, it doesn't necessarily

134
00:08:04.283 --> 00:08:09.070
have to be 75 inch, it could be 85 inch
but I don't want it any less than 70.

135
00:08:09.070 --> 00:08:11.190
So I've got tolerances there, and

136
00:08:11.190 --> 00:08:15.800
in that one that's quite tangible
tolerance, you know, that specific size.

137
00:08:15.800 --> 00:08:18.995
I might also have a tolerance
over operating system as well.

138
00:08:18.995 --> 00:08:21.791
This isn't necessarily have to be in iPad,

139
00:08:21.791 --> 00:08:24.900
it could have a Windows
based operating system.

140
00:08:24.900 --> 00:08:28.266
What I actually want to is
to this particular ability,

141
00:08:28.266 --> 00:08:29.808
do you remember MoSCoW?

142
00:08:29.808 --> 00:08:36.488
>> Must have, should have, could have,
will not have the current time or wants.

143
00:08:36.488 --> 00:08:39.168
>> Yeah, I'd like in the future,
would like, yeah.

144
00:08:39.168 --> 00:08:43.879
So in that particular instance what
I've done is I've already got a MoSCoW

145
00:08:43.879 --> 00:08:47.410
list in my head,
it must have the ability to write on it.

146
00:08:47.410 --> 00:08:52.260
I must be able to write and it must be big
enough that I don't need to keep zooming

147
00:08:52.260 --> 00:08:54.187
in and zooming back out again.

148
00:08:54.187 --> 00:08:58.979
And it must be big enough to contain
a lot of information that I need to

149
00:08:58.979 --> 00:09:02.523
build up mind maps or,
they're my must-haves.

150
00:09:02.523 --> 00:09:07.540
And then we can go into the could-haves
on that one, well, it could

151
00:09:07.540 --> 00:09:13.537
be a 75 inch iPad or it could be another
operating system, these are my coulds.

152
00:09:13.537 --> 00:09:18.851
So, I'm quite happy to accept any
of those within those tolerances

153
00:09:18.851 --> 00:09:23.620
that I just outlined, and
then we've got our should haves.

154
00:09:23.620 --> 00:09:27.330
Or well, sorry you should haves
which is an operating systems,

155
00:09:27.330 --> 00:09:31.660
then your could haves, which are the
optionals, and then you would like or

156
00:09:31.660 --> 00:09:34.904
won't have right now, well,
that could be anything.

157
00:09:34.904 --> 00:09:39.940
My would like would be well, I'd like it
in white, but you know what, I don't care.

158
00:09:39.940 --> 00:09:44.036
>> Or it should have blinky
lights on the edges, right?

159
00:09:44.036 --> 00:09:46.990
No, I'm joking, they shouldn't do that,
that would be distracting.

160
00:09:46.990 --> 00:09:48.591
>> That would be, yeah, yeah.

161
00:09:48.591 --> 00:09:53.474
[LAUGH]
>> And not necessarily high tech either.

162
00:09:53.474 --> 00:09:56.933
>> I guess we all have
a difference in opinions.

163
00:09:56.933 --> 00:10:02.073
>> Moving on, [LAUGH] so let's take a look
at the progress theme in more detail.

164
00:10:02.073 --> 00:10:05.370
Now, look at this, we've got a purple

a previous episode about consistency, and

387
00:25:08.770 --> 00:25:14.660
about having appropriate controls in
place that allow us to be flexible,

388
00:25:14.660 --> 00:25:19.970
that allow each project to run smoothly
but still allow for that consistency.

389
00:25:19.970 --> 00:25:24.930
That as an outsider, I can come
into an organization and I can say,

390
00:25:24.930 --> 00:25:29.332
let me see how the progress of
any particular project is doing.

391
00:25:29.332 --> 00:25:33.700
Let me see if this project is
being managed efficiently.

392
00:25:33.700 --> 00:25:35.316
Remember the word efficient.

393
00:25:35.316 --> 00:25:38.070
I like that word,
it's what we're striving for.

394
00:25:38.070 --> 00:25:41.520
If we have consistency in place,

395
00:25:41.520 --> 00:25:45.360
I was gonna say I'm trying to avoid
using the word template because

396
00:25:45.360 --> 00:25:50.260
a template is just a from that you
fill out and that's not what I want.

397
00:25:50.260 --> 00:25:52.270
What I want and
what we should be aiming for

398
00:25:52.270 --> 00:25:56.360
is a consistent approach
to managing our project.

399
00:25:56.360 --> 00:26:00.500
So a consistent approach when it comes
to things like our milestone charts and

400
00:26:00.500 --> 00:26:03.700
our Kanban boards and
our burn down charts.

401
00:26:03.700 --> 00:26:05.133
That's what we're looking for.

402
00:26:05.133 --> 00:26:07.411
We're looking for a consistent approach.

403
00:26:07.411 --> 00:26:09.214
And in fact, as we carry on,

404
00:26:09.214 --> 00:26:13.818
you'll see that we've got lots of
documentation here that you may use.

405
00:26:13.818 --> 00:26:16.315
But then this is what I expect,

406
00:26:16.315 --> 00:26:20.937
why I expect to have progress
to be reported using these.

407
00:26:20.937 --> 00:26:25.343
And I also expect you to have templates,
and I am using that word here,

408
00:26:25.343 --> 00:26:28.630
expect templates for each of these.

409
00:26:28.630 --> 00:26:35.100
So if I look at an issue register from
one project, whilst it might have

410
00:26:35.100 --> 00:26:40.410
different things on, the issue register
itself, the look and feel of it,

411
00:26:40.410 --> 00:26:44.410
should look exactly the same as
the issue register from another project,

412
00:26:44.410 --> 00:26:48.580
which should look exactly the same as the
issue register from another project too.

413
00:26:49.990 --> 00:26:54.770
Having that consistency means that
we're not reinventing the wheel.

414
00:26:54.770 --> 00:26:58.020
We're not having to start off
with a blank piece of paper.

415
00:26:58.020 --> 00:27:03.910
And more importantly, we do have
that documentation that demonstrates

416
00:27:03.910 --> 00:27:10.568
the progress of the project that anybody
can look at, and that anybody can view and

417
00:27:10.568 --> 00:27:15.320
see where the project has got
to in terms of deliverables.

418
00:27:15.320 --> 00:27:21.010
And it's understood by everybody
because they're used to seeing.

419
00:27:21.010 --> 00:27:24.871
So what we've looked at right now,
then, is our last thing,

420
00:27:24.871 --> 00:27:27.267
we've looked at our progress theme.

421
00:27:27.267 --> 00:27:31.661
And when we come back, what we're
going to do in our next episode is

422
00:27:31.661 --> 00:27:35.830
we're going to start off by
looking at our project processes.

423
00:27:36.860 --> 00:27:38.080
>> Project processes.

424
00:27:38.080 --> 00:27:41.668
Those are things where I've
been part of companies where,

425
00:27:41.668 --> 00:27:43.740
we don't need any processes.

426
00:27:43.740 --> 00:27:44.840
It'll be all right.

427
00:27:44.840 --> 00:27:45.740
We'll just do it ad hoc.

428
00:27:46.840 --> 00:27:48.490
I strongly recommend you don't do that.

429
00:27:48.490 --> 00:27:51.294
So definitely join us on back as
we start looking at processes.

430
00:27:51.294 --> 00:27:54.822
And well, as Jo said,
we've kind of finished up themes.

431
00:27:54.822 --> 00:27:56.796
I'm sure they'll, well,
because they're a theme,

432
00:27:56.796 --> 00:27:59.160
they'll continue to come back up
here in the rest of this course.

433
00:27:59.160 --> 00:28:01.170
But for now, we're gonna ahead and
get out here.

434
00:28:01.170 --> 00:28:04.050
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

435
00:28:04.050 --> 00:28:04.763
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

436
00:28:04.763 --> 00:28:05.808
>> And we'll see you next time.

437
00:28:05.808 --> 00:28:12.473
[MUSIC]

438
00:28:12.473 --> 00:28:15.651
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: On our introduction to Prince2® processes in this episode Jo & Justin discuss the definition and purpose of a process and the use of processes within the Prince2® project environment
episodes.title: Prince2 Processes: Introduction to Processes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.180 --> 00:00:01.150
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.150 --> 00:00:04.321
I'm your host,

3
00:00:04.321 --> 00:00:08.847
Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]
>> You're

4
00:00:08.847 --> 00:00:12.998
watching ITProTV.
>> Greetings, everyone and

5
00:00:12.998 --> 00:00:15.117
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.117 --> 00:00:20.660
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and we're
back with more PRINCE2 2017 foundation.

7
00:00:20.660 --> 00:00:25.290
And well, in this episode, we're gonna be
looking at our introduction to processes

8
00:00:25.290 --> 00:00:28.334
and here to help us along on that
very endeavor is the one and only Ms.

9
00:00:28.334 --> 00:00:29.000
Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:30.670
How do you do today, Jo?
>> Absolutely great.

11
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:33.082
Thank you Justin, how are you?
>> I am doing fantastic and

12
00:00:33.082 --> 00:00:37.698
you know we kind of alluded to of
the previous episode, I am firm believer,

13
00:00:37.698 --> 00:00:40.630
that there should be no
processes in anything,

14
00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:44.935
everybody should do everything
in their own way, is that right?

15
00:00:44.935 --> 00:00:49.218
[LAUGH] I'm gonna go out on a limb and
say no.

16
00:00:49.218 --> 00:00:51.200
And I wanna be explicit here.

17
00:00:51.200 --> 00:00:51.934
I say that.

18
00:00:53.904 --> 00:00:57.427
With strong, dripping sarcasm.
>> Sometimes,

19
00:00:57.427 --> 00:01:01.019
I just wonder why I'm here.
>> Yeah [LAUGH] well,

20
00:01:01.019 --> 00:01:02.810
I know why you're here.

21
00:01:02.810 --> 00:01:06.364
You're here to help us be better and well,

22
00:01:06.364 --> 00:01:09.765
project management, right?
>> [LAUGH] Well,

23
00:01:09.765 --> 00:01:12.070
that was the intention, yeah.

24
00:01:12.070 --> 00:01:13.791
But, you know,
there's such a thing as a lost cause.

25
00:01:13.791 --> 00:01:17.815
Just gonna lay that one out there.

26
00:01:17.815 --> 00:01:21.084
No, no Justin,
we're never lost course honest.

27
00:01:21.084 --> 00:01:25.612
But, yeah, what we're gonna be looking
at in this particular episode is we

28
00:01:25.612 --> 00:01:28.815
literally going to do
an introduction to processes.

29
00:01:28.815 --> 00:01:31.145
We're gonna look at what a process is.

30
00:01:31.145 --> 00:01:36.845
And before we get into all of our episodes
where we look at specific processes

31
00:01:36.845 --> 00:01:41.310
within particular project management,
we wanna look at the concept of a process.

32
00:01:41.310 --> 00:01:46.120
So really, what we're going to be doing,
is we are going to be discussing quiet

33
00:01:46.120 --> 00:01:51.590
a lot and you're gonna see me try to
convince just in the little process,

34
00:01:51.590 --> 00:01:56.780
it's really a good idea, I'm in,
you know, we wanna be efficient, right.

35
00:01:56.780 --> 00:02:00.250
So what we're gonna do is and
I've got something here.

36
00:02:00.250 --> 00:02:03.439
Is that you all need and it's this.

37
00:02:03.439 --> 00:02:06.938
I know,
it's quite a ton really it's quite big.

38
00:02:06.938 --> 00:02:11.912
But in chapter 13, which is what we'll
be looking at, and you can see that when

39
00:02:11.912 --> 00:02:16.595
you look at your book, we'll be looking
at an introduction to processes and

40
00:02:16.595 --> 00:02:21.528
there is going to be quite a few diagrams,
and as I always say if it's in purple.

41
00:02:21.528 --> 00:02:23.358
>> It's from the PRINCE2 books.

42
00:02:23.358 --> 00:02:27.835
I wasn't aware,
I was like what a, it's my turn.

43
00:02:27.835 --> 00:02:32.620
[LAUGH]
>> If you see something in purple in any

44
00:02:32.620 --> 00:02:36.090
of the downloadable material that you've
got there then it means that it's

45
00:02:36.090 --> 00:02:40.600
directly from the PRINCE2 book and
it's a diagram directly from that book.

46
00:02:42.140 --> 00:02:45.689
What do you think process is?
>> A process is a structured set of

47
00:02:45.689 --> 00:02:52.115
activities to accomplish a common goal.
>> He's been reading.

48
00:02:52.115 --> 00:02:55.158
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, I couldn't help it,

49
00:02:55.158 --> 00:02:59.794
I've been trying to follow along with and
I admit, I kinda let the cat out of

50
00:02:59.794 --> 00:03:02.427
the bag [CROSSTALK]
>> Okay so, right, so

51
00:03:02.427 --> 00:03:06.330
I just wanna mention
a couple of things in here.

52
00:03:06.330 --> 00:03:11.290
Obviously, PRINCE2 is originally
from the UK government and well,

53
00:03:11.290 --> 00:03:16.250
it's actually managed and
controlled now by XLS.

54
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:18.880
Which means that it's the same people.

55
00:03:18.880 --> 00:03:23.385
The same organization that
control management of risk MOR,

56
00:03:23.385 --> 00:03:30.409
management of successful programs, PRINCE2
project management and of course IT.

57
00:03:30.409 --> 00:03:32.180
Few others too.

58
00:03:32.180 --> 00:03:36.825
So that means that what we want to do and
it's exactly the same as with the other

59
00:03:36.825 --> 00:03:40.825
methodologies that there are out there,
and we've got quite a few

60
00:03:40.825 --> 00:03:44.492
governance methodologies in our
library for you to look at.

61
00:03:44.492 --> 00:03:49.020
What we're trying to do is we're
trying to maintain some consistency.

62
00:03:49.020 --> 00:03:55.140
And I talk about consistency a lot
throughout all of our governance shows and

63
00:03:55.140 --> 00:03:58.180
again we've got exactly the same
definition of a process

64
00:03:58.180 --> 00:04:02.560
here as the definition of a process that
you'd find in ITEL as a definition of

65
00:04:02.560 --> 00:04:07.750
a process that you would find in MOR or
in MSP.

66
00:04:07.750 --> 00:04:12.113
We've got the same definition,
a process is a structure set of

67
00:04:12.113 --> 00:04:16.247
activities designed to
accomplish a specific objective.

68
00:04:16.247 --> 00:04:20.530
And all the words a process
is something that you do.

69
00:04:22.060 --> 00:04:27.470
So just before we start to this particular
episode, Justin was saying to me.

70
00:04:27.470 --> 00:04:29.029
Quite tongue in cheek.

71
00:04:29.029 --> 00:04:33.963
But Justin was saying to me about
the sort of, as a developer he's been

72
00:04:33.963 --> 00:04:38.830
in various environments where people
just wanna do their own thing.

73
00:04:40.160 --> 00:04:41.140
That's great, isn't it?

74
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:41.690
I mean, what's wrong?

75
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:45.089
If you've got a developer and
you've got a group of developers and

76
00:04:45.089 --> 00:04:48.793
they've all got their own specialists
skills, what's wrong with just

77
00:04:48.793 --> 00:04:51.210
letting them do what they wanna do?
>> So

78
00:04:51.210 --> 00:04:54.515
one of the most frustrating things for
me was lack of efficiency.

79
00:04:54.515 --> 00:04:58.939
Like if I was meant to help with
something, something went something

80
00:04:58.939 --> 00:05:03.379
went awry there was an exception or,
hey, I need you to help on this.

81
00:05:03.379 --> 00:05:06.290
What is all of that action?

82
00:05:06.290 --> 00:05:08.314
Like I couldn't tell,

83
00:05:08.314 --> 00:05:12.610
it took way more time to get up to speed.
>> Yeah.

84
00:05:12.610 --> 00:05:16.510
>> Or what I figured was a very simple

85
00:05:16.510 --> 00:05:19.025
task or like a set of things to do.

86
00:05:19.025 --> 00:05:21.520
It just took me a lot of time to dig in,
but

87
00:05:21.520 --> 00:05:26.250
also, it leads to disjointedness,
lack of maintainability.

88
00:05:28.180 --> 00:05:30.370
And to some extent, sometimes,

89
00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:35.600
a breakdown in personal relationships.
>> Right.

90
00:05:35.600 --> 00:05:36.296
>> Why'd you do it this way?

91
00:05:36.296 --> 00:05:40.005
You're wrong and part of it has
to do with personality type.

92
00:05:40.005 --> 00:05:42.618
>> Well, the reason why I ask Justin and

93
00:05:42.618 --> 00:05:47.421
the reason why I don't quite
understand here in breach is because of

94
00:05:47.421 --> 00:05:49.029
the simple fact that.

95
00:05:49.029 --> 00:05:52.508
I can tell you til I'm blue in the face,

96
00:05:52.508 --> 00:05:56.980
what benefits there are in
following processes.

97
00:05:56.980 --> 00:06:00.612
What benefits there are, and
I'll use words like consistency,

98
00:06:00.612 --> 00:06:04.391
I'll use words like structure,
I'll use words like efficiency.

99
00:06:04.391 --> 00:06:09.594
But the amount of time people say to me,
but that's just too much red tape,

100
00:06:09.594 --> 00:06:14.228
it's too bureaucratic.
>> But the fact of the matter is that when

101
00:06:14.228 --> 00:06:19.025
we talk about in a project,
first project processes, not so

102
00:06:19.025 --> 00:06:23.822
easy for me to say [LAUGH] project
processes are processes that

103
00:06:23.822 --> 00:06:28.262
are invariably undertaken
by people like developers.

104
00:06:28.262 --> 00:06:33.574
And so, it makes some more sense for
me to let Justin tell you about

105
00:06:33.574 --> 00:06:40.880
the effects of not having processes in
place, because it's him that it affects.

106
00:06:40.880 --> 00:06:45.920
He's the developer and he's the one
that is in an environment where well,

107
00:06:45.920 --> 00:06:47.820
chaos reigns.
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

108
00:06:47.820 --> 00:06:51.780
I think there's actually
a management used at a few places,

109
00:06:51.780 --> 00:06:56.690
they call it developer anarchy where
developers do whatever they want to.

110
00:06:56.690 --> 00:06:59.640
You come in during the day and
you go I'm gonna do that.

111
00:06:59.640 --> 00:07:04.510
It sounds good in principle,
because it allows creative processes, but

112
00:07:04.510 --> 00:07:10.290
with that said, I hear the kickback
on it's too bureaucratic.

113
00:07:10.290 --> 00:07:13.326
It's too much red tape,
it takes too much time,

114
00:07:13.326 --> 00:07:18.143
I'm like I don't think you're accounting
for how much time is spent going,

115
00:07:18.143 --> 00:07:20.680
I have no idea what's going on, right.

116
00:07:20.680 --> 00:07:26.180
So it's funny, I used to be one of
those people like, let me do my thing.

117
00:07:26.180 --> 00:07:30.640
But now, I've slowly come to,
if we just had, I don't know,

118
00:07:30.640 --> 00:07:34.400
a three-step, here's what you do,
here's what you do, here's what,

119
00:07:34.400 --> 00:07:37.410
when you're trying to accomplish
this particular task.

120
00:07:37.410 --> 00:07:41.271
Then everybody gets, I know what we've
got to do, and there's no ambiguity.

121
00:07:41.271 --> 00:07:43.317
>> Right, and this is why,

122
00:07:43.317 --> 00:07:47.799
like I said this is why I let
Justin tell you exactly what

123
00:07:47.799 --> 00:07:52.790
the advantages are to you
of following a process.

124
00:07:52.790 --> 00:07:54.589
It's not about bureaucracy.

125
00:07:54.589 --> 00:07:59.136
Trust me, we do not put a process
in place to create bureaucracy.

126
00:07:59.136 --> 00:08:02.471
It's not in my best interest
to create bureaucracy,

127
00:08:02.471 --> 00:08:04.778
because it's more for me to manage.

128
00:08:04.778 --> 00:08:07.298
So it's not in my best
interest to do that.

129
00:08:07.298 --> 00:08:12.548
It's not in my best interest to create
a cumbersome way of working for

130
00:08:12.548 --> 00:08:19.260
you because trust me, I've got to listen
to it in my ear when you are not happy.

131
00:08:19.260 --> 00:08:23.820
It's not in my best interest to do that,
the reason why we create processes.

132
00:08:23.820 --> 00:08:26.890
Just because of exactly what
Justin's just been saying.

133
00:08:26.890 --> 00:08:31.620
In that you end up with chaos
if we don't have process.

134
00:08:31.620 --> 00:08:36.300
Now, process brings inconsistency.

135
00:08:36.300 --> 00:08:42.370
Not just to Justin, but also brings
inconsistency to me, as a project manager.

136
00:08:42.370 --> 00:08:45.540
So I have a certain set of report.

137
00:08:45.540 --> 00:08:48.380
I have a certain set of templates.

138
00:08:48.380 --> 00:08:52.390
And we've looked at some of those to do
with the themes in our previous episodes.

139
00:08:52.390 --> 00:08:58.375
And so
I have a consistency to the reporting and

140
00:08:58.375 --> 00:09:01.395
to the progress of a project.

141
00:09:01.395 --> 00:09:04.565
So I'm able to look at any
say issue register and

142
00:09:04.565 --> 00:09:08.915
I'm able to identify what
an issue register looks like.

143
00:09:08.915 --> 00:09:12.445
I don't need to go to Justin and
say show me your issue register.

144
00:09:12.445 --> 00:09:15.675
I can look at what's on his desk and
say that's an issue register.

145
00:09:15.675 --> 00:09:18.065
That must be from this particular project.

146
00:09:18.065 --> 00:09:19.865
Let's see what issues we've got.

147
00:09:20.900 --> 00:09:25.030
So it actually makes it easier for
me to manage as well.

148
00:09:25.030 --> 00:09:27.820
It's not just about it being easier for
the developers.

149
00:09:27.820 --> 00:09:31.820
It's also about it being easier for
the project managers too.

150
00:09:32.820 --> 00:09:36.995
So a process,
structured set of activities.

151
00:09:36.995 --> 00:09:40.285
It brings inconsistency and
it brings inefficiency, but

152
00:09:40.285 --> 00:09:43.415
the one thing that we shouldn't
do is bring in bureaucracy.

153
00:09:43.415 --> 00:09:47.715
And I will tell you now that a process
should efficient as it possibly can be.

154
00:09:47.715 --> 00:09:53.775
And if somebody's telling you or
somebody's telling me, that the process

155
00:09:53.775 --> 00:09:58.630
is too bureaucratic and then quite simply,
you've defined the process wrong.

156
00:09:58.630 --> 00:10:01.150
Because if you brought
in too much red tape,

157
00:10:01.150 --> 00:10:04.740
then that's not an efficient process.
>> So Jo,

158
00:10:04.740 --> 00:10:06.330
I was kind of thinking about this.

159
00:10:06.330 --> 00:10:08.900
And I think sometimes this
is a matter of perspective.

160
00:10:08.900 --> 00:10:14.430
So a process should lead
to a standardized autonomy.

161
00:10:14.430 --> 00:10:18.200
For individuals would you say
that on accurate statement right,

162
00:10:18.200 --> 00:10:24.090
what I mean is I don't have come to you
and go, now how do we do this again?

163
00:10:24.090 --> 00:10:27.260
But I don't want too much work.

164
00:10:27.260 --> 00:10:30.663
I didn't step one I have to submet
this to you for approval and

165
00:10:30.663 --> 00:10:34.420
then I what I should be able
to do I say this is how we do.

166
00:10:34.420 --> 00:10:37.020
Plus thing X.
>> Yep.

167
00:10:37.020 --> 00:10:40.870
>> I can go do it without asking you

168
00:10:42.850 --> 00:10:47.110
or to some extent,
figuring out what to do on my own, right?

169
00:10:47.110 --> 00:10:49.900
I should have some amount
of standardization.

170
00:10:49.900 --> 00:10:51.930
But allow me to undertake

171
00:10:51.930 --> 00:10:54.247
the task at hand.
>> Right.

172
00:10:54.247 --> 00:10:56.402

you.

when we're doing consultancy, I will

288
00:17:09.051 --> 00:17:13.542
quite often walk into an environment and
I will simply ask one question.

289
00:17:13.542 --> 00:17:15.882
And that question is why.

290
00:17:15.882 --> 00:17:17.200
Why are you doing this?

291
00:17:17.200 --> 00:17:19.656
Why did you make that decision?

292
00:17:19.656 --> 00:17:25.380
And if I cannot find evidence, yeah,
and I wanna see things documented.

293
00:17:25.380 --> 00:17:28.860
Sure, keep it simple but
I wanna see things documented.

294
00:17:28.860 --> 00:17:33.730
If I cannot find evidence as to why
a particular decision has been made,

295
00:17:33.730 --> 00:17:38.530
then I have to ask myself,
what is the purpose of that decision?

296
00:17:38.530 --> 00:17:40.030
What was it achieving and

297
00:17:40.030 --> 00:17:43.720
how much time then has been wasted
because you made that decision?

298
00:17:44.840 --> 00:17:47.190
We have to ask the question why.

299
00:17:47.190 --> 00:17:52.930
Because it's not efficient if we don't
understand why we're undertaking

300
00:17:52.930 --> 00:17:57.786
certain tasks, and why we
are conducting a project in that way.

301
00:17:57.786 --> 00:17:59.881
>> So Jo, if you're ask why, all right?

302
00:17:59.881 --> 00:18:03.966
I've asked why, I go,
why are we doing this?

303
00:18:03.966 --> 00:18:06.286
I've heard this a lot,
it's more performing

304
00:18:08.118 --> 00:18:13.041
It's more performant, it's faster,
it does this thing better.

305
00:18:13.041 --> 00:18:20.083
Is your follow-up question, do you ask,
well, how do you know that?

306
00:18:20.083 --> 00:18:21.415
Do you ever ask that a question?

307
00:18:21.415 --> 00:18:26.072
>> No, I don't,
I have a saying that I use all the time.

308
00:18:26.072 --> 00:18:28.200
And it comes when I'm doing assessments,

309
00:18:28.200 --> 00:18:31.045
it comes when I'm doing any
sort of project management.

310
00:18:31.045 --> 00:18:35.508
And my saying is simply this,
two words, show me.

311
00:18:35.508 --> 00:18:37.119
So, it's pretty much the same thing,
right?

312
00:18:37.119 --> 00:18:38.349
>> I think it's pretty
much the same thing.

313
00:18:38.349 --> 00:18:39.008
>> Yeah.

314
00:18:39.008 --> 00:18:42.928
>> But what you're saying is our
assumptions should be based on either

315
00:18:42.928 --> 00:18:46.035
substantial, anecdotal,
or empirical evidence-

316
00:18:46.035 --> 00:18:46.672
>> Yes

317
00:18:46.672 --> 00:18:47.581
>> To support set assumptions.

318
00:18:47.581 --> 00:18:49.886
>> Yes
>> Not just, I feel,

319
00:18:49.886 --> 00:18:52.287
that it's more performant.

320
00:18:52.287 --> 00:18:56.588
If I hear the words, I feel,
when someone's providing me a, I go,

321
00:18:56.588 --> 00:18:57.426
this is bad.

322
00:18:57.426 --> 00:18:58.344
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

323
00:18:58.344 --> 00:18:59.389
>> This is real bad.

324
00:18:59.389 --> 00:19:06.760
>> No, gut feelings, which I know I've
heard people say things like that.

325
00:19:06.760 --> 00:19:09.480
Well, I feel that, based on what?

326
00:19:09.480 --> 00:19:11.380
Show me, show me the evidence,

327
00:19:11.380 --> 00:19:16.370
show me that this is how this
organization traditionally performs.

328
00:19:16.370 --> 00:19:20.650
Show me that this is
what happens in the past.

329
00:19:20.650 --> 00:19:23.980
Show me that this is how other
suppliers have conducted this.

330
00:19:23.980 --> 00:19:27.730
Show me that this is how
other customers have reacted.

331
00:19:27.730 --> 00:19:32.882
I want to see some form of evidence.

332
00:19:32.882 --> 00:19:37.071
I want to see that an assumption
is not just based on, so

333
00:19:37.071 --> 00:19:40.088
which way the winds blowing right now.

334
00:19:40.088 --> 00:19:43.771
>> They're outside throwing grass up
in the air going, that's to the left.

335
00:19:43.771 --> 00:19:44.850
We're going over there.

336
00:19:44.850 --> 00:19:45.419
>> Right.

337
00:19:45.419 --> 00:19:49.125
>> Yeah I use more performer but
I I've heard,

338
00:19:49.125 --> 00:19:53.139
it's easier this way or
it's, I don't know.

339
00:19:53.139 --> 00:19:56.097
This always tend to be very nebulous
when people when people tell me.

340
00:19:56.097 --> 00:20:00.337
They're like, it's just this thing and
they had an adjective.

341
00:20:00.337 --> 00:20:06.885
And I go, how do you know that and
then it's usually, I feel.

342
00:20:06.885 --> 00:20:08.521
>> No.

343
00:20:08.521 --> 00:20:13.471
>> I feel like you're wrong, is what I

344
00:20:13.471 --> 00:20:18.820
feel like [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] No, I want to see evidence.

345
00:20:18.820 --> 00:20:24.940
I don't want to see you sitting around
scratching your head in a meeting or

346
00:20:24.940 --> 00:20:30.080
whatever without any evidence to
support the decisions that you've made.

347
00:20:30.080 --> 00:20:33.520
If there's been a decision made,
you've got to have a reason for

348
00:20:33.520 --> 00:20:35.710
making that decision.

349
00:20:35.710 --> 00:20:40.550
Even if the reason is,
well I was in another organization and

350
00:20:40.550 --> 00:20:43.220
it happened like this and
this is what happened.

351
00:20:43.220 --> 00:20:48.250
Okay, but still show me,
show me exactly what happened.

352
00:20:48.250 --> 00:20:52.990
You cannot make decisions at this
critical point in the project,

353
00:20:52.990 --> 00:20:56.090
you cannot make decisions based on I feel.

354
00:20:57.180 --> 00:21:00.562
The objectives of
the starting up a project,

355
00:21:00.562 --> 00:21:04.180
this is a foundation to
starting up a project.

356
00:21:04.180 --> 00:21:10.230
If we get this wrong, then the whole
project is gonna go horribly wrong.

357
00:21:10.230 --> 00:21:14.270
So, it's really important
that everything that we do in

358
00:21:14.270 --> 00:21:17.564
this particular point
is documented as well.

359
00:21:17.564 --> 00:21:21.764
And so we document any evidence
that we base in our assumptions on,

360
00:21:21.764 --> 00:21:25.510
that we document who our
authorities are for instance.

361
00:21:25.510 --> 00:21:29.831
That we document the business
justification in that business case.

362
00:21:29.831 --> 00:21:35.584
That we document the scope and we document
the reasons why we have the scope.

363
00:21:35.584 --> 00:21:40.392
We document the reasons why we have the
timeline, we document the reasons why we

364
00:21:40.392 --> 00:21:46.030
have this budget, and obviously we plan
for how we're going to spend the budget.

365
00:21:46.030 --> 00:21:50.037
We document our roles and
responsibilities,

366
00:21:50.037 --> 00:21:53.538
we have stakeholder and RACI matrices.

367
00:21:53.538 --> 00:21:58.579
We evaluate the way that
the project is going to work.

368
00:21:58.579 --> 00:22:02.093
I talked to you about,
we're bringing in an iPad, well,

369
00:22:02.093 --> 00:22:05.780
the 75 inch iPad,
that's what we're looking for.

370
00:22:05.780 --> 00:22:10.210
And I said to you right,
what sort of project would you use,

371
00:22:10.210 --> 00:22:11.800
what sort of approach would you use?

372
00:22:11.800 --> 00:22:15.420
Would you use an Agile based approach, or
would you use a Waterfall based approach?

373
00:22:16.510 --> 00:22:22.284
And you said to me that, well, actually
Waterfall approaches are lengthier.

374
00:22:22.284 --> 00:22:24.699
And so my question is, what makes you say?

375
00:22:24.699 --> 00:22:26.164
Why do you think that?

376
00:22:26.164 --> 00:22:28.100
What makes you say that?

377
00:22:28.100 --> 00:22:30.120
And then you answered me
with the question, well,

378
00:22:30.120 --> 00:22:34.170
because in previous experienced
I've failed and it has always been.

379
00:22:34.170 --> 00:22:38.310
Well, that's because maybe it
wasn't particularly efficient.

380
00:22:38.310 --> 00:22:39.790
But what I'm gonna say to you is,

381
00:22:39.790 --> 00:22:45.460
show me the evidence of where the Agile
approach is better because it's shorter.

382
00:22:45.460 --> 00:22:47.030
It shouldn't be shorter.

383
00:22:48.360 --> 00:22:52.948
So, we have to be careful of making
assumptions just because something

384
00:22:52.948 --> 00:22:57.613
worked well in one particular environment,
or at one particular time,

385
00:22:57.613 --> 00:23:02.288
doesn't mean that that's the approach
that you should take this time.

386
00:23:02.288 --> 00:23:09.621
You have to have the evidence
not as you say just I feel.

387
00:23:09.621 --> 00:23:13.873
So, what we are gonna do now that
we've looked at what we need to

388
00:23:13.873 --> 00:23:18.152
have in place for starting up a project,
what objectives are?

389
00:23:18.152 --> 00:23:20.428
What our end goal is?

390
00:23:20.428 --> 00:23:25.000
When we come back in our next episode,
we're gonna take a look at the actual

391
00:23:25.000 --> 00:23:29.600
activities that we are going to undertake
as part of starting up a project.

392
00:23:29.600 --> 00:23:35.649
So, I'm gonna invite you to come back for
a part two of this particular process.

393
00:23:35.649 --> 00:23:38.629
>> I'll tell you what Jo,
who knew that there was so many in's and

394
00:23:38.629 --> 00:23:41.570
out's considerations and
just getting something started?

395
00:23:41.570 --> 00:23:43.119
But looks like we're
gonna have a part two, so

396
00:23:43.119 --> 00:23:44.522
you'll definitely want to come on back.

397
00:23:44.522 --> 00:23:46.622
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

398
00:23:46.622 --> 00:23:49.485
So signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Justin Dennison.

399
00:23:49.485 --> 00:23:50.301
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

400
00:23:50.301 --> 00:23:51.892
>> And we'll see you next time.

401
00:23:51.892 --> 00:23:58.002
[MUSIC]

402
00:23:58.002 --> 00:24:01.380
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Our 2nd Prince2® process; in this episode we cover the Prince2® process of Directing a Project. These episodes explore the purpose and objectives of the process as well as common activities.
episodes.title: Prince2 Processes: Directing a Project
