[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.658 --> 00:00:11.816
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.816 --> 00:00:15.788
>> Greetings everyone and welcome back
to another exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:15.788 --> 00:00:16.885
I'm your host, Justin Dennison.

7
00:00:16.885 --> 00:00:19.746
And boy, you better buckle up
because we have a treat for you.

8
00:00:19.746 --> 00:00:22.610
That's right,
more Prince2 2017 Foundation.

9
00:00:22.610 --> 00:00:23.645
And in this episode,

10
00:00:23.645 --> 00:00:26.758
we're gonna be talking about
the directing a project process.

11
00:00:26.758 --> 00:00:30.534
And well, here to help us along is,
well, none other than Ms. Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:30.534 --> 00:00:31.296
How are you doing, Jo?

13
00:00:31.296 --> 00:00:32.225
>> Absolutely, great.

14
00:00:32.225 --> 00:00:32.844
Thank you, Justin.

15
00:00:32.844 --> 00:00:33.449
How are you?

16
00:00:33.449 --> 00:00:37.857
>> I am doing fantastic and
at the previous episode, I admitted,

17
00:00:37.857 --> 00:00:42.531
there's a lot more to these
processes than I originally thought.

18
00:00:42.531 --> 00:00:45.179
So I'm kind of interested to see how well,
directing a project.

19
00:00:45.179 --> 00:00:49.121
It seems simple in my mind, but I don't
if it's necessarily as simple as far as

20
00:00:49.121 --> 00:00:51.538
considerations are all
we actually have to do.

21
00:00:51.538 --> 00:00:56.054
>> Well, I think to be honest though
there's a lot more to just manging

22
00:00:56.054 --> 00:00:59.077
the project than most
people are exposed to.

23
00:00:59.077 --> 00:01:03.463
Well, for most poeple, certainly I mean
your experience has been as a developer,

24
00:01:03.463 --> 00:01:07.099
and so for most developers,
you get involved with your activities,

25
00:01:07.099 --> 00:01:09.372
you get involved with your pieces of work.

26
00:01:09.372 --> 00:01:14.225
But there's a lot of work, there's
a lot of organization that has to go on

27
00:01:14.225 --> 00:01:17.372
in the background in order
to make that happen.

28
00:01:17.372 --> 00:01:20.396
We've got to make sure, and we've
talked about it in previous episodes,

29
00:01:20.396 --> 00:01:22.508
we've talked about
the importance of processes and

30
00:01:22.508 --> 00:01:24.580
we've talked about
the importance of structure.

31
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:27.235
And the importance of
having some consistency,

32
00:01:27.235 --> 00:01:29.642
otherwise, we've simple just got chaos.

33
00:01:29.642 --> 00:01:33.136
We've got people doing
what they want to do and

34
00:01:33.136 --> 00:01:39.049
just imagine how that is in terms of
delivering quality to the organization and

35
00:01:39.049 --> 00:01:42.378
delivering output to the customer as well.

36
00:01:42.378 --> 00:01:47.335
So right now, what we're doing is we're
gonna take a look at the process of

37
00:01:47.335 --> 00:01:48.842
directing a project.

38
00:01:48.842 --> 00:01:54.306
And this is not managing a project,
this is directing a project.

39
00:01:54.306 --> 00:01:58.704
Cuz if you take a look at the purpose
that we have on the slides, so

40
00:01:58.704 --> 00:02:02.368
the idea the purpose of
directing a project process,

41
00:02:02.368 --> 00:02:04.986
there's a lot of ps in there, right?

42
00:02:04.986 --> 00:02:08.075
The purpose of that is to well,
it's at executive level.

43
00:02:08.075 --> 00:02:14.081
Remember that executive branch, the
branch, the level that make the decisions.

44
00:02:14.081 --> 00:02:18.227
And this process is above
all of the other processes,

45
00:02:18.227 --> 00:02:21.186
because this sits above the project.

46
00:02:21.186 --> 00:02:26.300
So this is well direct in the project,
not managing it, but direct in it.

47
00:02:26.300 --> 00:02:29.393
And the purposes to
enable then these people,

48
00:02:29.393 --> 00:02:35.203
the executives to be accountable for the
project's success by making key decisions.

49
00:02:35.203 --> 00:02:37.572
So they have overall control, but

50
00:02:37.572 --> 00:02:41.832
they don't actually manage
the project on a day to day basis.

51
00:02:41.832 --> 00:02:46.542
And I want to draw your attention to that
simply because when you initially look at

52
00:02:46.542 --> 00:02:49.865
these processes, you look at them and
you think, well,

53
00:02:49.865 --> 00:02:52.120
why is the direct in a process?

54
00:02:52.120 --> 00:02:53.530
Why is that happening?

55
00:02:53.530 --> 00:02:57.420
Why are we talking about this after we
started talking about this starting up

56
00:02:57.420 --> 00:02:58.037
a process?

57
00:02:58.037 --> 00:02:59.588
Well, because this is
at a different level.

58
00:02:59.588 --> 00:03:04.810
So this encompasses the entire project
because this is at that executive level.

59
00:03:04.810 --> 00:03:08.323
It's at the project board level, and so

60
00:03:08.323 --> 00:03:13.915
the project board take accountability for
the entire project.

61
00:03:13.915 --> 00:03:17.629
Okay, and they take accountability for
ensuring that it happened.

62
00:03:17.629 --> 00:03:20.934
The project manager, on the other hand.

63
00:03:20.934 --> 00:03:27.029
Well, his accountabilities for
the day to day management of the project.

64
00:03:27.029 --> 00:03:29.119
And the project board is not,

65
00:03:29.119 --> 00:03:33.388
well I wouldn't normally expect
this to be a full time role.

66
00:03:33.388 --> 00:03:38.417
I would expect the project board
to be involved in other things,

67
00:03:38.417 --> 00:03:42.895
I'd expect them to be performing
their day to day tasks.

68
00:03:42.895 --> 00:03:47.212
But never the less they still
have tasks associated with and

69
00:03:47.212 --> 00:03:50.318
decisions to make and meetings to attend,

70
00:03:50.318 --> 00:03:55.770
associated with directing the project
that they're managing right now.

71
00:03:55.770 --> 00:04:00.623
So I wouldn't be surprised if
the project board or the executives on

72
00:04:00.623 --> 00:04:05.659
the project board were also on
the project boards for other projects.

73
00:04:05.659 --> 00:04:10.517
However, you've gotta be incredibly
careful when it comes to

74
00:04:10.517 --> 00:04:12.452
conflict of interests.

75
00:04:12.452 --> 00:04:15.666
Because if we do have any
conflict of interest, and

76
00:04:15.666 --> 00:04:18.069
they sit on multiple project boards.

77
00:04:18.069 --> 00:04:22.695
And perhaps, we want the same
resources and the same people for

78
00:04:22.695 --> 00:04:26.716
two projects,
then who's gonna make that decision?

79
00:04:26.716 --> 00:04:29.514
Well that's going to
occur at a higher level,

80
00:04:29.514 --> 00:04:32.545
it's going to occur at
portfolio program level.

81
00:04:32.545 --> 00:04:36.517
It's not necessarily going to occur
at individual project level, but

82
00:04:36.517 --> 00:04:40.886
we've got to be incredibly careful when
we're selecting our project board to

83
00:04:40.886 --> 00:04:43.884
ensure that there are no
conflict of interest there.

84
00:04:43.884 --> 00:04:48.757
And the priorities are already set
before we've started out on this

85
00:04:48.757 --> 00:04:50.394
particular project.

86
00:04:50.394 --> 00:04:53.886
So what they actually do,
if we take a look at the objectives,

87
00:04:53.886 --> 00:04:58.801
you'll see that they cover they activities
that's required at the executive level.

88
00:04:58.801 --> 00:05:04.300
Including giving authority to
initiate the projects and giving

89
00:05:04.300 --> 00:05:11.232
authority to deliver the products that
are going to be developed by the project.

90
00:05:11.232 --> 00:05:15.575
They take the responsibility
of the management decision

91
00:05:15.575 --> 00:05:19.562
making in that controls in
that sort of delegation.

92
00:05:19.562 --> 00:05:24.025
And they ensure, well,
the word ensure would suggest that

93
00:05:24.025 --> 00:05:28.943
they're going to do something
about making the project viable.

94
00:05:28.943 --> 00:05:33.703
But I mean, the reality of the situation
is that they ensure they are responsible

95
00:05:33.703 --> 00:05:35.250
for the decision making.

96
00:05:35.250 --> 00:05:38.883
So they're the ones that will come
to the project manager to say,

97
00:05:38.883 --> 00:05:41.674
we're going a little bit
off track on the budget.

98
00:05:41.674 --> 00:05:45.024
And we need to make sure that
this project is still viable and

99
00:05:45.024 --> 00:05:49.900
we need to make sure that it's still going
to deliver a return on the investment.

100
00:05:49.900 --> 00:05:55.031
And so therefore, our project manager
will be the person that's actually

101
00:05:55.031 --> 00:05:59.592
performing all of the activities
to get any project back on track,

102
00:05:59.592 --> 00:06:03.599
if we've gone under budget or
maybe we go in another time.

103
00:06:03.599 --> 00:06:07.936
I really like the fact that it
refers to the project board for

104
00:06:07.936 --> 00:06:12.719
this directing of project,
this process as being an interface.

105
00:06:12.719 --> 00:06:15.817
It's kind of a translation
to the corporate,

106
00:06:15.817 --> 00:06:19.081
the program management
with the organization.

107
00:06:19.081 --> 00:06:23.216
So you've got an additional buffer
in there for the project manager,

108
00:06:23.216 --> 00:06:26.030
so he's not talking
directly to the customer.

109
00:06:27.130 --> 00:06:33.404
Why wouldn't you want the project manager
liaising directly with the customer?

110
00:06:33.404 --> 00:06:35.434
Justin is just greening
[INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]

111
00:06:35.434 --> 00:06:36.824
>> [LAUGH] So some reason,

112
00:06:36.824 --> 00:06:41.810
I feel like this, I have seen this only
possible conflict to kind of opposition.

113
00:06:41.810 --> 00:06:46.719
But also I've seen where customers
sway the direction of a project

114
00:06:46.719 --> 00:06:51.016
without any further kind of
thought process involved, or

115
00:06:51.016 --> 00:06:55.990
considerations about well this
is what the customer wants.

116
00:06:55.990 --> 00:06:59.339
Is it really what the customer wants or
are they just spouting off, or

117
00:06:59.339 --> 00:07:01.084
do they really know what they want?

118
00:07:01.084 --> 00:07:04.728
It just seems that they may have undo
influence that's the kind of thing

119
00:07:04.728 --> 00:07:05.404
I've seen.

120
00:07:05.404 --> 00:07:09.839
>> Well bare in mind that the customer is
not necessarily in control of the purse

121
00:07:09.839 --> 00:07:10.474
strings.

122
00:07:10.474 --> 00:07:14.583
The customer was we talk about corperate
being in control of the purse strings.

123
00:07:14.583 --> 00:07:19.050
It depends on what level of the customer,
the project manager is talking to.

124
00:07:19.050 --> 00:07:24.051
And is it really the role of the project
manager to make the decisions

125
00:07:24.051 --> 00:07:30.121
on what functionality and what features
should be included and what shouldn't.

126
00:07:30.121 --> 00:07:34.278
The customer will be coming to the project
manager potentially with a big

127
00:07:34.278 --> 00:07:37.493
long list of requirements and
this is what I want to see.

128
00:07:37.493 --> 00:07:39.966
And if it's left out to
the project manager,

129
00:07:39.966 --> 00:07:44.669
we could have a long list of functionality
included that's not necessarily needed.

130
00:07:44.669 --> 00:07:47.933
Or maybe we don't have the right
functionality because the project manager

131
00:07:47.933 --> 00:07:51.250
simply says, well you know what,
I don't think that that's necessary.

132
00:07:51.250 --> 00:07:56.806
So there has to be somebody that's sitting
in between, that's making the decision.

133
00:07:56.806 --> 00:08:01.027
It's looking right across the board and
saying, okay Well I understand, Mr.

134
00:08:01.027 --> 00:08:05.520
Customer, that this is what you want,
but we've got another five projects.

135
00:08:05.520 --> 00:08:09.480
And we're putting funding into these
particular projects as well and

136
00:08:09.480 --> 00:08:11.210
these are our priorities.

137
00:08:11.210 --> 00:08:15.566
So this is why we're not gonna discourage
this relationship between a project

138
00:08:15.566 --> 00:08:18.074
manager and customer, don't get me wrong.

139
00:08:18.074 --> 00:08:24.202
Because for certain things, we need to
be able to go back to the customer and

140
00:08:24.202 --> 00:08:29.555
ask him to get involved and
beta testing and ask him to get involved

141
00:08:29.555 --> 00:08:36.108
in ensuring that the product is exactly
what they want and defining our output.

142
00:08:36.108 --> 00:08:40.521
But, at the same time, we don't want the
customer necessarily making the decisions

143
00:08:40.521 --> 00:08:41.940
with the project manager.

144
00:08:41.940 --> 00:08:43.720
This is how we end up with scope creep and

145
00:08:43.720 --> 00:08:47.040
this is how we end up with
projects that go over budget.

146
00:08:48.070 --> 00:08:53.260
So the direction then this project
board also gives us the authority to

147
00:08:53.260 --> 00:08:57.940

they also are accountable for

148
00:08:57.940 --> 00:09:03.140

we realized the post project benefits.

149
00:09:03.140 --> 00:09:05.590
So that we are able to

150
00:09:05.590 --> 00:09:09.910
articulate that benefits have been
achieved at the end of the project.

authorize the procedure

Until eventually, we'll get into our final

stage, then they authorize

And that's when, you've got two options

Was I supposed to just kinda sit there and

290
00:17:35.378 --> 00:17:38.236
But of course I have

00:17:38.236 --> 00:17:42.235

00:17:42.235 --> 00:17:46.940
Because I assumed that the project

00:17:46.940 --> 00:17:51.187

00:17:51.187 --> 00:17:53.826

295
00:17:53.826 --> 00:17:59.161
And, I have noticed that in a lot

00:18:06.306 --> 00:18:11.665

00:18:11.665 --> 00:18:15.805
And therefore, they're not really

299
00:18:15.805 --> 00:18:18.634
when they are brought into
a project to undertake

300
00:18:18.634 --> 00:18:22.490
certain activities including
that of the project board.

301
00:18:22.490 --> 00:18:28.134
So, one thing that I really wanted to add
in there was when you are in the real

302
00:18:28.134 --> 00:18:33.886
world and this is kind of an addition to
any exam advice that I wanna give you.

303
00:18:33.886 --> 00:18:37.600
But when you are in the real
world assign an executive for

304
00:18:37.600 --> 00:18:43.040
the project board you really need to
outline what it is you expect of them.

305
00:18:43.040 --> 00:18:46.940
Especially if they've never been involved
in any project management before,

306
00:18:46.940 --> 00:18:50.480
it's not something that would
necessarily be intuitive.

307
00:18:51.590 --> 00:18:57.454
Sometimes we just assume that the project
manager is going to perform all of this.

308
00:18:57.454 --> 00:18:59.689
You see, what the project board does and

309
00:18:59.689 --> 00:19:04.140
what happens at the executive
level is all of the authorization.

310
00:19:04.140 --> 00:19:08.842
So that includes authorizing
the initiation of the project

311
00:19:08.842 --> 00:19:13.355
that's authorizing when
the project is going to start,

312
00:19:13.355 --> 00:19:19.185
that's authorizing that we can move
as well onto our subsequent stages,

313
00:19:19.185 --> 00:19:24.843
it's verifying that our business
case well is a viable business case.

314
00:19:24.843 --> 00:19:29.125
If you've got somebody that doesn't really
understand what they're doing on a project

315
00:19:29.125 --> 00:19:32.733
board, then they're wondering why
they're reviewing a business case.

316
00:19:32.733 --> 00:19:36.964
We need to explain that to them,
they also take accountability for

317
00:19:36.964 --> 00:19:38.900
communication as well.

318
00:19:38.900 --> 00:19:42.660
Now as they may not necessarily take
the responsibility of performing

319
00:19:42.660 --> 00:19:46.140
the communication they
authorize the communication, so

320
00:19:46.140 --> 00:19:48.040
they take accountability.

321
00:19:48.040 --> 00:19:53.064
And again, we wanna ensure that
every project has got a well-defined

322
00:19:53.064 --> 00:19:56.909
stakeholder management chart and
a racy matrix too.

323
00:19:56.909 --> 00:20:01.145
And then of course they authorize
the project as a whole,

324
00:20:01.145 --> 00:20:03.270
and so the executive board.

325
00:20:03.270 --> 00:20:08.680
The project board takes an accountability
for authorizing the entire project,

326
00:20:08.680 --> 00:20:12.260
including all of the project
initiation documentation.

327
00:20:12.260 --> 00:20:17.543
They review all of that, and
they approve that prior to release,

328
00:20:17.543 --> 00:20:21.783
they also review and
approve all of the approaches.

329
00:20:21.783 --> 00:20:26.823
Remember in the previous episodes
we defined all of our approaches

330
00:20:26.823 --> 00:20:31.600
including the approach to risk management,
that was a theme.

331
00:20:31.600 --> 00:20:34.043
Including the approach to planning,

332
00:20:34.043 --> 00:20:39.020
including the approach to benefits
management and the approach to quality.

333
00:20:39.020 --> 00:20:44.341
Well the project board take
accountability for approving all of that,

334
00:20:44.341 --> 00:20:49.671
and they also authorize the Project
Manager to then start the project.

335
00:20:49.671 --> 00:20:55.681
And then again, as I have already
mentioned, during each stage boundary.

336
00:20:55.681 --> 00:21:01.638
In other words, when we complete one
stage, after we move onto the next,

337
00:21:01.638 --> 00:21:05.866
then the project board will
take responsibility for

338
00:21:05.866 --> 00:21:09.053
moving from that one stage to the next.

339
00:21:09.053 --> 00:21:12.846
Cuz they are the people, the group of
people that will sit there and say yes,

340
00:21:12.846 --> 00:21:16.225
okay, everything's been completed for
this particular stage and

341
00:21:16.225 --> 00:21:17.959
we're good to move on to the next.

342
00:21:19.150 --> 00:21:23.434
And then lastly, cuz we mention in
there as part of their activities,

343
00:21:23.434 --> 00:21:26.713
which is ad hoc direction and
ad hoc decision making.

344
00:21:26.713 --> 00:21:32.366
Whenever there's a decision that
needs to made a management decision

345
00:21:32.366 --> 00:21:37.442
within the project itself,
then of course I expect the project

346
00:21:37.442 --> 00:21:43.212
board to be able to give direction and
be able to make decisions, okay.

347
00:21:44.861 --> 00:21:49.140
So before we allow them to
authorize the project closure,

348
00:21:49.140 --> 00:21:52.998
which is our last slide in
this particular episode.

349
00:21:52.998 --> 00:21:56.541
And in fact our last slide in this
portion of the downloadable material,

350
00:21:56.541 --> 00:21:57.887
I o have a question for you.

351
00:22:00.577 --> 00:22:03.114
How many people do you think
should be on a project board?

352
00:22:05.693 --> 00:22:08.944
>> All right, you said think,
so nothing I say is wrong.

353
00:22:08.944 --> 00:22:12.458
[LAUGH] So I'm gonna go.

354
00:22:14.641 --> 00:22:17.464
>> Trust me,
Justin everything you say is wrong.

355
00:22:17.464 --> 00:22:21.883
>> All right, it sounds like a weird
al song, but I'm gonna go with five.

356
00:22:21.883 --> 00:22:26.985
>> Okay, there was no right or wrong,
you were right, yeah, you were right.

357
00:22:26.985 --> 00:22:27.630
>> See, I wasn't wrong.

358
00:22:27.630 --> 00:22:29.463
>> I know, but
it was kind of a trick question.

359
00:22:29.463 --> 00:22:31.570
>> You love those though.

360
00:22:31.570 --> 00:22:32.651
>> Yeah, but I do, yeah.

361
00:22:32.651 --> 00:22:33.584
>> Yeah.

362
00:22:33.584 --> 00:22:36.194
>> I'll admit this, certainly when
it comes to your practitioner test,

363
00:22:36.194 --> 00:22:38.118
this is something that you
wanna be thinking about.

364
00:22:38.118 --> 00:22:40.828
Is how many people do I
need on a project board?

365
00:22:40.828 --> 00:22:44.745
We've got a saying,
too many cooks spoil the broth,

366
00:22:44.745 --> 00:22:47.104
have you got a saying like that?

367
00:22:47.104 --> 00:22:51.239
>> We just say too many cooks in
the kitchen, it's one of the those things

368
00:22:51.239 --> 00:22:55.950
where you just kinda like, you kinda end
up with immobility and things go awry.

369
00:22:55.950 --> 00:22:58.418
>> Right,
you don't want too many decision makers.

370
00:22:58.418 --> 00:23:02.759
Because, everybody's gonna have
an opinion, and like you say,

371
00:23:02.759 --> 00:23:07.268
you've got too many decision makers and
everything just goes awry.

372
00:23:07.268 --> 00:23:13.372
But you do need to have a sufficient
number of people on your project

373
00:23:13.372 --> 00:23:19.377
board to enable an objective opinion and
an objective decision.

374
00:23:19.377 --> 00:23:23.885
Rather than just an subjective decision,
which is the opinion of one person.

375
00:23:23.885 --> 00:23:29.125
So there has to be a balance, and it has
to be scaled to the size of the project,

376
00:23:29.125 --> 00:23:32.430
so it has to be scaled appropriately.

377
00:23:32.430 --> 00:23:36.070
I don't want, if it is a large project and
it's gonna take two years to implement,

378
00:23:36.070 --> 00:23:38.160
I don't expect two people
on the project board,

379
00:23:39.160 --> 00:23:41.730
I'd expect quite a few more than that.

380
00:23:41.730 --> 00:23:45.737
But if it's a very small project,
like the project we were talking about in

381
00:23:45.737 --> 00:23:49.869
a previous episode, then Jo wants a 75
inch iPad, then I expect the project

382
00:23:49.869 --> 00:23:53.456
board's gonna consist of about
three people, no more than that.

383
00:23:53.456 --> 00:23:58.753
For something that's going to be
implemented across every single studio.

384
00:23:58.753 --> 00:24:02.741
So, think about the scale
of the project board.

385
00:24:02.741 --> 00:24:06.717
And then, of course, the last thing that
I mentioned was before we get to project

386
00:24:06.717 --> 00:24:08.950
closure, then think
about how many we need.

387
00:24:08.950 --> 00:24:12.100
Well, that's something that we should
think about before we even start

388
00:24:12.100 --> 00:24:13.140
the project.

389
00:24:13.140 --> 00:24:16.250
Is how many people we should
have on our project board.

390
00:24:17.630 --> 00:24:24.240
Project closure is an activity that
your project board will undertake,

391
00:24:24.240 --> 00:24:28.520
and it simply is decided that
the project has been closed.

392
00:24:30.210 --> 00:24:34.890
Now as somebody who sort of specializes
in governance and in methodologies,

393
00:24:34.890 --> 00:24:39.570
the one thing that I will tell you, and
I'm very very passionate about this,

394
00:24:39.570 --> 00:24:41.307
is that early life support.

395
00:24:41.307 --> 00:24:46.706
If you wanna call it sort of a DevOps
mindset, but early life support,

396
00:24:46.706 --> 00:24:53.640
a proper period of transition has to be
completed before we close the project.

397
00:24:53.640 --> 00:24:59.203
In other words, I don't want to hear the
words or the project team threw it over

398
00:24:59.203 --> 00:25:04.786
the fence to me, and I hear it constantly,
I hear it every single week almost.

399
00:25:04.786 --> 00:25:08.447
Now I'm told that project teams just
thrown something over the fence to

400
00:25:08.447 --> 00:25:12.351
the support teams and the support teams
are now trying to pick up the pieces,

401
00:25:12.351 --> 00:25:14.320
and they're the words that they use.

402
00:25:15.840 --> 00:25:19.890
We have to have an appropriate
length of early life support.

403
00:25:19.890 --> 00:25:23.160
Transition doesn't just mean,
here you go, Justin,

404
00:25:23.160 --> 00:25:26.780
this is yours, that's not a transition.

405
00:25:26.780 --> 00:25:30.290
A transition is where I give something
to Justin and I say, hey look,

406
00:25:30.290 --> 00:25:34.810
let's work with this together for
the next month.

407
00:25:34.810 --> 00:25:39.820
And then once I'm confident that you
understand it and you feel completely

408
00:25:39.820 --> 00:25:44.580
comfortable with that new service,
then I'm going to walk away.

409
00:25:45.690 --> 00:25:50.535
But I'm not going to just give you
something and walk away, it's not a new

410
00:25:50.535 --> 00:25:55.317
cellphone and that's something that
we really need to embrace better.

411
00:25:55.317 --> 00:26:00.289
And need to get as a,
I wasn't gonna say as an organization, but

412
00:26:00.289 --> 00:26:03.710
as an industry we need
to get better at this.

413
00:26:04.730 --> 00:26:09.828
Because the relationship that we have,
and this is why I mentioned DevOps.

414
00:26:09.828 --> 00:26:14.312
Because the DevOps mindset is about
expanding the relationship that exists

415
00:26:14.312 --> 00:26:18.237
between or doesn't exist sometimes
between the project teams and

416
00:26:18.237 --> 00:26:21.090
development teams and support teams.

417
00:26:21.090 --> 00:26:24.177
Then we have to get
better at our transition,

418
00:26:24.177 --> 00:26:29.390
we have to get better at handing the
project over into the live environment.

419
00:26:29.390 --> 00:26:32.856
And this is why the project
board needs to be sure

420
00:26:32.856 --> 00:26:35.717
that the project is truly completed and

421
00:26:35.717 --> 00:26:41.540
not just been thrown over the fence before
they actually sign off that project.

422
00:26:42.730 --> 00:26:47.080
But that is the directing
a project process and

423
00:26:47.080 --> 00:26:52.766
as we've already said, directing a project
is high level, it's high level direction.

424
00:26:52.766 --> 00:26:58.109
In our next episode,
we're going to get into the actual

425
00:26:58.109 --> 00:27:02.439
work that we do as part
of the project itself.

426
00:27:02.439 --> 00:27:08.150
And so we're gonna be looking at that
start up initiation of the actual project.

427
00:27:08.150 --> 00:27:12.760
So now, we did a start up, we got our
executive board in place and we've got out

428
00:27:12.760 --> 00:27:17.990
project manager assigned, and we did that
in our starting up a project process.

429
00:27:17.990 --> 00:27:23.200
And now we have ensured that in
this directing a project process,

430
00:27:23.200 --> 00:27:27.520
we have ensured that the project board
knows what they're going to be doing.

431
00:27:27.520 --> 00:27:30.990
So now,
we're gonna go to the project manager, and

432
00:27:30.990 --> 00:27:35.280
we're gonna get the project manager
to start and kick things off.

433
00:27:35.280 --> 00:27:39.598
And that's gonna be in our next episode,
so we're gonna invite you to come back and

434
00:27:39.598 --> 00:27:40.348
join us then.

435
00:27:40.348 --> 00:27:44.224
>> Well, I tell you what Jo,
I would definitely mess up starting up and

436
00:27:44.224 --> 00:27:47.360
initiating, and
I think I have in previous episodes.

437
00:27:47.360 --> 00:27:50.660
So, be very careful those
are distinct processes.

438
00:27:50.660 --> 00:27:53.688
And, for some reason, while you were
talking about handing over the fence,

439
00:27:53.688 --> 00:27:56.030
I'll leave you with that
an interesting thought.

440
00:27:56.030 --> 00:27:59.150
Individual teams having
these catapults for

441
00:27:59.150 --> 00:28:01.310
projects that they just
throw over the fence.

442
00:28:01.310 --> 00:28:04.950
That's not what we wanna do, but
that's how it ended up in my mind.

443
00:28:04.950 --> 00:28:07.460
Definitely work together and well,
speaking of work together it

444
00:28:07.460 --> 00:28:11.300
would be wonderful if you would come on
back and join us for our next episode.

445
00:28:11.300 --> 00:28:13.030
But for now we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

446
00:28:13.030 --> 00:28:15.950
So signing off for ITPro.TV I've
been your host Justin Dennison.

447
00:28:15.950 --> 00:28:16.860
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

448
00:28:16.860 --> 00:28:19.116
>> And we'll see you next time.

449
00:28:19.116 --> 00:28:25.538
[MUSIC]

450
00:28:25.538 --> 00:28:29.473
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Our 4th Prince2® process; in this episode we cover the Prince2® process of Controlling a Stage. These episodes explore the purpose and objectives of the process as well as common activities.
episodes.title: Prince2 Processes: Controlling a Stage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Welcome to IT ProTV,
I'm your host, Don- [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:02.917 --> 00:00:03.677
[MUSIC]

[MUSIC]

4

>> Greetings everyone, and welcome back to

5
00:00:09.607 --> 00:00:14.640
another exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.640 --> 00:00:19.687
I'm your host, Justin Dennison, and we're
back with more Prince 2-2017 foundation,

7
00:00:19.687 --> 00:00:23.700
and in this episode, we're going to
be talking about controlling a stage.

8
00:00:23.700 --> 00:00:28.099
The process that is and well here to
help us along is none other than Ms.

9
00:00:28.099 --> 00:00:28.940
Jo Peacock.

10
00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:29.980
How you doing today Jo?

11
00:00:29.980 --> 00:00:31.530
>> Absolutely great, thank you Justin.

12
00:00:31.530 --> 00:00:32.270
How are you?

13
00:00:32.270 --> 00:00:36.520
>> I am doing fantastic, trying to
get things up and going today, and

14
00:00:36.520 --> 00:00:40.270
well sometimes I feel
a little out of control, but

15
00:00:40.270 --> 00:00:43.750
hopefully thats not what we're
gonna talk about today, right?

16
00:00:43.750 --> 00:00:44.520
Only sometimes.

17
00:00:45.560 --> 00:00:46.668
>> Ahh
>> Yeah.

18
00:00:46.668 --> 00:00:50.960
Yeah I suggest that you have control
issues a little bit more than sometimes.

19
00:00:50.960 --> 00:00:52.020
But anyway.

20
00:00:52.020 --> 00:00:56.210
Yeah what we're doing is we're in our
prints two project management of course,

21
00:00:56.210 --> 00:01:00.078
and here what we're gonna
be talking about even.

22
00:01:00.078 --> 00:01:02.830
I was gonna say discussing, or
I was gonna say controlling, but

23
00:01:02.830 --> 00:01:04.110
we don't really want to go there.

24
00:01:04.110 --> 00:01:08.075
We're going to be discussing
controlling a stage.

25
00:01:08.075 --> 00:01:11.072
All of these processes that
we've talked about so far,

26
00:01:11.072 --> 00:01:13.890
they all seem to be a bit of a mouthful,
don't they?

27
00:01:13.890 --> 00:01:18.085
I know that, well Justin struggles,
but [INAUDIBLE].

28
00:01:18.085 --> 00:01:19.762
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

29
00:01:19.762 --> 00:01:22.445
>> Well yeah, I have maintained

30
00:01:22.445 --> 00:01:24.940
a fairly good flow for most of them.

31
00:01:24.940 --> 00:01:28.130
Every once and a while I'm like I don't
know if I'm gonna be able to get this out.

32
00:01:28.130 --> 00:01:32.050
But I have been under
control in that capacity.

33
00:01:32.050 --> 00:01:32.600
>> Okay.

34
00:01:32.600 --> 00:01:34.580
Yeah, I'll give you that much.

35
00:01:34.580 --> 00:01:36.620
So, let me ask you a question, then.

36
00:01:36.620 --> 00:01:37.670
>> All right.

37
00:01:37.670 --> 00:01:39.430
>> What do you think a stage is?

38
00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:42.158
When it comes to a project,
what do you think a stage is?

39
00:01:42.158 --> 00:01:44.770
>> A stage is.

40
00:01:44.770 --> 00:01:45.556
Man, that's.

41
00:01:45.556 --> 00:01:47.043
>> I know.
>> So it's one of those things where

42
00:01:47.043 --> 00:01:50.016
you're like, okay, in your mind,
okay conceputally I have an idea

43
00:01:50.016 --> 00:01:53.070
of what I wanna say, but I'm having
a hard time putting it into words.

44
00:01:53.070 --> 00:01:58.283
It's a predefined set of, man you-

45
00:01:58.283 --> 00:02:00.970
>> You're talking about a process, right?

46
00:02:00.970 --> 00:02:04.341
You're talking about
a predefined set of activities,

47
00:02:04.341 --> 00:02:08.290
that's a process,
we're imprints to processes, sure.

48
00:02:08.290 --> 00:02:10.240
And we're looking at the process
of controlling a stage.

49
00:02:10.240 --> 00:02:13.515
But a stage is not actually a process.

50
00:02:13.515 --> 00:02:18.830
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I'll you what, I'm at a loss, Jo.

51
00:02:18.830 --> 00:02:24.630
>> Right, so depending on whether
you're in a waterfall approach or

52
00:02:24.630 --> 00:02:30.440
whether you're in an agile approach
Our project will be split into stages.

53
00:02:30.440 --> 00:02:33.080
And stages are, and
I know where Justin was going with this,

54
00:02:33.080 --> 00:02:35.230
cuz Justin was talking
about sets of activities.

55
00:02:35.230 --> 00:02:37.890
What he actually means is,
groups of activities.

56
00:02:37.890 --> 00:02:39.200
Yeah, does that sound a bit better?

57
00:02:39.200 --> 00:02:40.225
Just say yes.

58
00:02:40.225 --> 00:02:41.153
>> [CROSSTALK] Yeah that'll do.

59
00:02:41.153 --> 00:02:45.889
>> That's one of those things where
we're cutting a line on terminology, but

60
00:02:45.889 --> 00:02:48.560
what do you mean by groups as they're set.

61
00:02:48.560 --> 00:02:51.864
>> Right, okay, so
I'm gonna just whiz back for

62
00:02:51.864 --> 00:02:56.200
a moment in my slides if I can
remember how to get back to them.

63
00:02:56.200 --> 00:03:01.420
And I'm gonna whiz back to
something that looked like a, wow,

64
00:03:01.420 --> 00:03:04.650
that was a long time ago,
where we talked about a Gantt chart.

65
00:03:04.650 --> 00:03:06.359
Do you Remember when we talked about that?

66
00:03:06.359 --> 00:03:08.100
>> I do remember talking
about a Gantt Chart.

67
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:12.324
They don't seem that difficult, but
apparently, there's some subtleties.

68
00:03:12.324 --> 00:03:14.930
>> Okay, so
here is a picture of a Gantt chart.

69
00:03:14.930 --> 00:03:17.100
If we can put this up
on the full screen so

70
00:03:17.100 --> 00:03:22.880
you can see it, what I want to look at is,
so if you take a look at the stages here.

71
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:26.890
And in stage one we've got
two lots of activities, and

72
00:03:26.890 --> 00:03:30.180
we're grouping them together.

73
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:34.081
And remember a Gantt chart is a timeline,
and then in stage two,

74
00:03:34.081 --> 00:03:38.650
again there's two lots of activities
that are happening at the same time.

75
00:03:38.650 --> 00:03:43.275
In stage three we've got three lots of
activities, so this is what we call,

76
00:03:43.275 --> 00:03:45.240
you'll see, the stages.

77
00:03:45.240 --> 00:03:49.370
And this stage is all, well,
what we might call groups of activities.

78
00:03:49.370 --> 00:03:54.170
And so the purpose then of,
if I can just find the right slide.

79
00:03:54.170 --> 00:04:00.780
And the purpose of the control
in a stage is this.

80
00:04:00.780 --> 00:04:03.080
To assign the work to be done.

81
00:04:03.080 --> 00:04:08.316
I monitor it and deal with issues and then
report progress to the project board and

82
00:04:08.316 --> 00:04:13.322
take corrective actions to ensure that
the stage remains within tolerance.

83
00:04:13.322 --> 00:04:16.310
There are so
many things that we can pick apart there.

84
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:19.970
So we've looked at the stage and
the stage contains groups of activities.

85
00:04:19.970 --> 00:04:22.420
So it's what is happening
at that point in time.

86
00:04:23.920 --> 00:04:29.310
What you saw there was a Gantt chart
that was looking at a specific waterfall

87
00:04:29.310 --> 00:04:34.730
approach, but
it could still apply to an agile approach.

88
00:04:34.730 --> 00:04:39.120
And an agile approach is of
course where we are releasing

89
00:04:39.120 --> 00:04:42.900
in a continual basis,
in an iterative basis.

90
00:04:42.900 --> 00:04:47.310
So as we develop one
particular functionality, and

91
00:04:47.310 --> 00:04:50.720
maybe we develop two or
three little pieces of functionality.

92
00:04:50.720 --> 00:04:53.030
And then we release those together.

93
00:04:53.030 --> 00:04:57.170
And we develop them in what we call
iterations in an agile environment.

94
00:04:57.170 --> 00:05:00.250
But in a PRINCE2 environment
we're gonna call them stages.

95
00:05:01.710 --> 00:05:02.862
Remember what I said to you.

96
00:05:02.862 --> 00:05:05.830
Okay, whatever's in the PRINCE2 book,
that's what you're gonna be tested on.

97
00:05:06.920 --> 00:05:10.850
But you are going to tailor
this to your environment.

98
00:05:10.850 --> 00:05:14.130
And in tailoring this to your
environment it's up to you to decide

99
00:05:14.130 --> 00:05:15.840
what approach you want to use,

100
00:05:15.840 --> 00:05:19.780
whether you wanna use a traditional
waterfall approach or an agile approach.

101
00:05:19.780 --> 00:05:23.220
And it's up to you to decide
on what terminology you use.

102
00:05:23.220 --> 00:05:26.610
Whether you call it an iteration,
whether you call it a stage,

103
00:05:26.610 --> 00:05:28.390
that is completely up to you.

104
00:05:28.390 --> 00:05:30.970
However, you're gonna be tested on

105
00:05:33.210 --> 00:05:37.680
the contents of this wonderful purple
book that I've been showing you.

106
00:05:37.680 --> 00:05:40.672
And I say wonderful, and
I'm not being sarcastic, just for once.

107
00:05:40.672 --> 00:05:45.717
You'll find that the PRINCE2 2017 book is,
and I know I've said it in previous

108
00:05:45.717 --> 00:05:50.761
episodes, it's really well written, it's
written in a way that it's in plain and

109
00:05:50.761 --> 00:05:54.975
simple English, so people like me
can understand, and even Justin.

110
00:05:54.975 --> 00:05:58.470
[LAUGH] He's nodding.

111
00:05:58.470 --> 00:06:00.010
See he's read some of it actually.

112
00:06:00.010 --> 00:06:02.300
He's been really good,

this is one of the questions that we could

337
00:19:34.550 --> 00:19:38.820
get asked is you tailor
your processes first,

338
00:19:38.820 --> 00:19:42.530
to meet the needs of the organization,
to meet the needs of the project.

339
00:19:42.530 --> 00:19:45.680
And then you will source a tool, and

340
00:19:45.680 --> 00:19:50.420
then tailor that tool to meet
the needs of your processes.

341
00:19:50.420 --> 00:19:53.490
You never just go and buy something
off the shelf and say, that'll do.

342
00:19:53.490 --> 00:19:57.530
Hang on a minute, I need to tweak the way
I work in order to accommodate the tool.

343
00:19:57.530 --> 00:20:00.020
Okay?
That's not something that we do.

344
00:20:00.020 --> 00:20:04.680
So we might have to tailor our product,
as it says up there, or our tools.

345
00:20:04.680 --> 00:20:07.860
But we should never tailor our
processes to suit our tools.

346
00:20:09.010 --> 00:20:12.700
We definitely will definitely have to
tailor the roles and responsibilities,

347
00:20:12.700 --> 00:20:16.110
because it really depends on
what team of developers I need

348
00:20:16.110 --> 00:20:18.700
as to who's going to be doing what.

349
00:20:18.700 --> 00:20:22.130
And think about the scale,
as I've already said, of the project,

350
00:20:22.130 --> 00:20:24.930
because that will determine how we tailor.

351
00:20:24.930 --> 00:20:25.620
And then, of course,

352
00:20:25.620 --> 00:20:29.370
we've also talked about the Agile
environment versus the Waterfall approach.

353
00:20:30.400 --> 00:20:33.720
Now, we mentioned supplier
perspective here.

354
00:20:33.720 --> 00:20:37.310
And in suppliers we talk about
internal and external suppliers.

355
00:20:37.310 --> 00:20:41.410
And so this is not just the people
that we're going to bring in

356
00:20:41.410 --> 00:20:44.360
from the outside to do
some of the work for us.

357
00:20:44.360 --> 00:20:47.840
Our suppliers could also be internal.

358
00:20:47.840 --> 00:20:49.070
They will have advice.

359
00:20:50.130 --> 00:20:51.640
They will have guidance.

360
00:20:51.640 --> 00:20:55.420
And remember,
we talk about lessons learnt quite a lot.

361
00:20:55.420 --> 00:20:56.880
Well, yeah.

362
00:20:56.880 --> 00:21:00.640
They will have, hopefully,
a list of lessons learnt.

363
00:21:00.640 --> 00:21:02.750
They will have experience.

364
00:21:02.750 --> 00:21:06.480
And so we expect them to bring their
experience into the project and

365
00:21:06.480 --> 00:21:09.350
that's what we are going to, and

366
00:21:09.350 --> 00:21:14.700
that's what we're going to use to
help us to tailor our project.

367
00:21:14.700 --> 00:21:19.920
And then of course think about what our
program and what our portfolio is and

368
00:21:19.920 --> 00:21:23.300
how many projects we've
actually got outstanding, and

369
00:21:23.300 --> 00:21:24.940
think about those resources too.

370
00:21:24.940 --> 00:21:27.170
Some of the resources are shared.

371
00:21:27.170 --> 00:21:29.890
And so we have to consider that when we

372
00:21:29.890 --> 00:21:33.880
are deciding whose going to
do what with any given stage.

373
00:21:35.430 --> 00:21:40.060
I know that it probably seems as
though in this controlling stage

374
00:21:40.060 --> 00:21:43.460
process that I basically turn around and
say, well, it's completely up to you.

375
00:21:43.460 --> 00:21:45.160
You'll do what you want.

376
00:21:45.160 --> 00:21:47.480
That's not strictly true.

377
00:21:47.480 --> 00:21:52.510
And certainly in a practitioner guidance,
we look in a lot more depth at

378
00:21:52.510 --> 00:21:56.510
the sort of activities that
we may be undertaking here.

379
00:21:56.510 --> 00:22:00.520
However it is true to say
that it is going to be very,

380
00:22:00.520 --> 00:22:03.120
very specific to your environment.

381
00:22:03.120 --> 00:22:05.560
So whilst we can give you guidelines,

382
00:22:05.560 --> 00:22:10.880
it's entirely up to you as how
you choose to manage your stage.

383
00:22:10.880 --> 00:22:13.150
How you choose to control the stage.

384
00:22:14.240 --> 00:22:19.520
So that is really our episode on
controlling the stages of process.

385
00:22:19.520 --> 00:22:22.600
When we come back in our next episode,

386
00:22:22.600 --> 00:22:25.970
we're going to be looking at
managing product delivery.

387
00:22:25.970 --> 00:22:28.880
>> Well Jo, that's something that,
I can't wait to see what you

388
00:22:28.880 --> 00:22:32.450
have to say about that because
I've seen a few go horribly awry.

389
00:22:32.450 --> 00:22:35.580
But you'll definitely have to come
on back to see how that plays out

390
00:22:35.580 --> 00:22:37.890
because right now we're going
to go ahead and get out of here.

391
00:22:37.890 --> 00:22:40.810
So signing off for ITPro TV,
I've been your host Justin Anderson.

392
00:22:40.810 --> 00:22:41.600
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

393
00:22:41.600 --> 00:22:42.455
>> And we'll see you next time.

394
00:22:42.455 --> 00:22:48.869
[MUSIC]

395
00:22:48.869 --> 00:22:52.040
>> Thank you for watching ITPro TV.

episodes.description: Our 5th Prince2® process; in this episode we cover the Prince2® process of Managing Product Delivery. These episodes explore the purpose and objectives of the process as well as common activities.
episodes.title: Prince2 Processes: Managing Product Delivery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:03.037
Welcome to ITPRO.TV, I'm your host Don
>> [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.037 --> 00:00:06.771
>> Coming at you live from San Francisco,

3
00:00:06.771 --> 00:00:10.480
California
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV

4
00:00:12.040 --> 00:00:13.154
>> Greetings, everyone and

5
00:00:13.154 --> 00:00:15.591
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:15.591 --> 00:00:20.660
I'm your host Justin Dennison and we're
back with more prints to 2017 foundation,

7
00:00:20.660 --> 00:00:24.188
and well, we're talking about
managing product delivery.

8
00:00:24.188 --> 00:00:27.473
That was one of those where I was
concerned that I wasn't going to get

9
00:00:27.473 --> 00:00:28.625
all of those words out,

10
00:00:28.625 --> 00:00:32.330
but luckily, we have someone who is
a little more adept at that than I am.

11
00:00:32.330 --> 00:00:33.430
The one and only Ms. Jo Peacock.

12
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:34.430
How are you doing today, Jo?

13
00:00:34.430 --> 00:00:36.500
>> I'm well,
I was absolutely great, Justin, but

14
00:00:36.500 --> 00:00:40.770
now you're making claims about something
that you know I can't live up to.

15
00:00:40.770 --> 00:00:41.800
>> I believe you can.

16
00:00:41.800 --> 00:00:46.130
I have trust In you, Jo,
I have faith in you.

17
00:00:46.130 --> 00:00:49.400
That you're gonna tell us all
about managing product delivery,

18
00:00:49.400 --> 00:00:50.900
and-
>> Well I could do that, yeah.

19
00:00:50.900 --> 00:00:52.330
>> And you're gonna do it so well,

20
00:00:52.330 --> 00:00:56.295
so eloquently,
that it's just gonna blow my mind.

21
00:00:56.295 --> 00:00:59.320
[LAUGH]
>> No,

22
00:01:01.190 --> 00:01:04.560
I'm leaving the sarcastic
comments until later.

23
00:01:04.560 --> 00:01:06.410
I refuse to be lured into that one.

24
00:01:06.410 --> 00:01:09.460
>> Well, ladies and gentlemen you
should probably stayed tuned because

25
00:01:09.460 --> 00:01:12.380
I suspect there will be
some questioning of Justin.

26
00:01:13.760 --> 00:01:17.020
>> There will be certainly
in this episode.

27
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:20.760
One of the first things that
i'm going to ask you, actually,

28
00:01:20.760 --> 00:01:22.920
before we even get going.

29
00:01:22.920 --> 00:01:26.900
Can you remember what
our last episode was?

30
00:01:26.900 --> 00:01:28.098
>> Controlling a stage.

31
00:01:28.098 --> 00:01:32.734
>> It was, okay, now when managing product
delivery do you know what the different

32
00:01:32.734 --> 00:01:33.903
between the two is?

33
00:01:33.903 --> 00:01:35.910
>> I would say.

34
00:01:35.910 --> 00:01:39.550
No.
>> No, see, I told you, here it comes.

35
00:01:39.550 --> 00:01:40.910
This is going to be it.

36
00:01:40.910 --> 00:01:42.950
Do you know this, Justin?

37
00:01:42.950 --> 00:01:43.450
Nope.

38
00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:49.646
>> Well one of the good things that I
really like about sort of having Justin

39
00:01:49.646 --> 00:01:51.490
around is that I can ridicule him.

40
00:01:51.490 --> 00:01:54.780
No, no that's not the reason why
I like having Justin around.

41
00:01:54.780 --> 00:02:00.090
It's because what Justin does is
hopefully he's probably feeling or it's

42
00:02:00.090 --> 00:02:04.420
probably just what you're feeling right
now is what Justin does is quite often.

43
00:02:04.420 --> 00:02:05.670
Justin will get involved and

44
00:02:05.670 --> 00:02:09.310
ask the same sort of questions
that you're thinking right now.

45
00:02:09.310 --> 00:02:14.160
The sort of questions that come into the
forefront of your mind as well is what's

46
00:02:14.160 --> 00:02:16.320
the difference between the two?

47
00:02:16.320 --> 00:02:18.300
Why do we have the two?

48
00:02:18.300 --> 00:02:19.960
But it's quite simple really.

49
00:02:19.960 --> 00:02:25.600
And the difference between the two
processes is responsibilities,

50
00:02:25.600 --> 00:02:28.010
in that controlling the stage,

51
00:02:28.010 --> 00:02:32.690
the focuses on the word control and
controlling that stage.

52
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:36.330
Whereas here,
we're managing product delivery.

53
00:02:36.330 --> 00:02:39.770
So what we're doing is we're
managing delivery of the product

54
00:02:41.060 --> 00:02:43.710
across the life of the project.

55
00:02:43.710 --> 00:02:46.740
So in the last particular episode,

56
00:02:46.740 --> 00:02:51.330
we looked at controlling the state, and
that was the job of the project manager,

57
00:02:51.330 --> 00:02:56.920
to control and coordinate all of
the activities across the state.

58
00:02:56.920 --> 00:03:02.960
This, well, managing product delivery
is the job of the team manager,

59
00:03:02.960 --> 00:03:10.680
and this is about managing the product in
its entirety across the project itself.

60
00:03:10.680 --> 00:03:13.990
So if we take a look at the purpose
then of managing product delivery,

61
00:03:13.990 --> 00:03:19.150
it's about controlling that link between
the project manager and the team manager.

62
00:03:19.150 --> 00:03:22.240
So having a definition

63
00:03:22.240 --> 00:03:26.960
right up front of this is what
we're going to deliver and when.

64
00:03:26.960 --> 00:03:32.180
And the team manager's job is to
coordinate, well, each individual team.

65
00:03:32.180 --> 00:03:36.270
A project goes across functions,
therefore across teams, so

66
00:03:36.270 --> 00:03:41.370
there will be probably, and
I use the word probably, not

67
00:03:41.370 --> 00:03:46.770
even just potentially, for most projects
we've got more than one team manager.

68
00:03:46.770 --> 00:03:50.630
And so where as the project
managers role is actually

69
00:03:50.630 --> 00:03:55.320
to coordinate across for
each individual stage.

70
00:03:55.320 --> 00:03:59.150
And for the length of the project
is to coordinate at a higher level.

71
00:03:59.150 --> 00:04:03.790
The team manager is coordinating
the work of their own team.

72
00:04:03.790 --> 00:04:08.970
So the role of the process, the managing
product delivery It's actually

73
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:14.130
to manage the delivery of
the product within the team.

74
00:04:14.130 --> 00:04:19.420
So it ensures that the work on product
is authorized and it is agreed.

75
00:04:19.420 --> 00:04:22.790
And that everyone is clear on
what we're going to deliver.

76
00:04:24.090 --> 00:04:26.830
And what the thresholds are or

77
00:04:26.830 --> 00:04:31.850
what we call the tolerances for
things like effort, cost and time scales.

78
00:04:31.850 --> 00:04:37.510
And we are delivering within that
tolerance, or those tolerances.

79
00:04:37.510 --> 00:04:42.200
And that progress information is
posted on information radiators,

80
00:04:42.200 --> 00:04:45.560
on any updates, any highlight reports.

81
00:04:45.560 --> 00:04:51.660
And the communication happens
at agreed and regular intervals.

82
00:04:51.660 --> 00:04:57.340
Regular iterative, I don't just wanna see
progress at the start of a project and

83
00:04:57.340 --> 00:04:58.700
then at the end of a project.

84
00:04:58.700 --> 00:05:05.600
I want to see well progress is happening
throughout the course of the project.

85
00:05:05.600 --> 00:05:12.410
So here we have then a small diagram and
of course it's in purple so

86
00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:18.060
That means that it's on page
237 of our prints to manual.

87
00:05:18.060 --> 00:05:19.710
And it's really simple.

88
00:05:19.710 --> 00:05:23.790
And what it is,
is simply accepting a work package,

89
00:05:23.790 --> 00:05:27.330
executing the work package, and
delivering the work package.

90
00:05:27.330 --> 00:05:28.700
That almost sounds agile to me.

91
00:05:28.700 --> 00:05:30.540
I don't know about to you.

92
00:05:30.540 --> 00:05:35.780
>> It does and it's not something that
I typically use the word package.

93
00:05:35.780 --> 00:05:36.440
>> Right.

94
00:05:36.440 --> 00:05:40.970
>> To discern, is that just like a,
here's a scope of,

95
00:05:40.970 --> 00:05:44.680
this little sliced up piece
that I need you to do.

96
00:05:44.680 --> 00:05:46.230
Is that what is meant by a work package?

97
00:05:46.230 --> 00:05:49.070
>> Right, so
if we think about this in an agile term.

98
00:05:49.070 --> 00:05:53.040
A work package would be what
we'd call an iteration.

99
00:05:53.040 --> 00:05:54.930
So it's what is or

100
00:05:54.930 --> 00:05:59.760
what stories are included in an agile
perspective within that iteration.

101
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:04.230
So in other words, this is the, these
are the chunks of work that we're going to

102
00:06:04.230 --> 00:06:06.990
undertake at this
particular point in time.

103
00:06:06.990 --> 00:06:11.920
So within this time span of maybe one,
two, three, or four weeks.

104
00:06:11.920 --> 00:06:13.790
That's in an agile project.

105
00:06:13.790 --> 00:06:18.330
Where in a PRINCE2 project,
which may be operating in an agile way or

106
00:06:18.330 --> 00:06:22.720
it may be operating in more
of a waterfall approach.

107
00:06:22.720 --> 00:06:25.290
Then we're looking at each
individual stage and we're saying,

108
00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:30.660
these are the activities that we expect
to be completed within each stage.

109
00:06:30.660 --> 00:06:35.410
So if I go back to, and I'm going to go
right the way back if I can take a look

110
00:06:35.410 --> 00:06:39.200
at my slides, and we're going to go right
the way back to this particular diagram

111
00:06:39.200 --> 00:06:42.480
here and what I'm interested
in is that Gantt chart there.

112
00:06:42.480 --> 00:06:45.790
If I go back to here you'll
see that in each stage

113
00:06:45.790 --> 00:06:50.090
we have got sets of activities
that we want to undertake.

114
00:06:50.090 --> 00:06:53.830
So a work package for stage two would
include the detailed design and

115
00:06:53.830 --> 00:06:55.180
the training syllabus.

116
00:06:55.180 --> 00:06:59.290
The work package for stage three
would include the peripheral design,

117
00:06:59.290 --> 00:07:05.600
the built facility, and having trained
staff that would be part of stage three.

118
00:07:05.600 --> 00:07:11.740
So that's what we're trying to release
the end of each individual stage.

119
00:07:11.740 --> 00:07:14.609
We don't want to say release so
don't be released to the live or

120
00:07:14.609 --> 00:07:15.757
create an environment.

121
00:07:15.757 --> 00:07:19.669
i don't mean released to our customers
because obviously that would be in

122
00:07:19.669 --> 00:07:20.941
an agile environment.

123
00:07:20.941 --> 00:07:25.546
But that really depends on whether
we're doing this in an agile way, or

124
00:07:25.546 --> 00:07:31.135
whether we're looking at basically
a waterfall approach as to when we relate.

125
00:07:31.135 --> 00:07:34.317
There's no right or
wrong with that at all, so

126
00:07:34.317 --> 00:07:37.117
what I will tell you is
then if we can go back.

127
00:07:37.117 --> 00:07:40.467
So, here we are at our last diagram.

128
00:07:40.467 --> 00:07:44.347
Whatever is in that work
package is what you want for

129
00:07:44.347 --> 00:07:47.387
that particular stage of development work.

130
00:07:48.477 --> 00:07:52.697
So it's the activities you expect to
undertake at that particular stage.

131
00:07:52.697 --> 00:07:54.840
Does that answer your question?

132
00:07:54.840 --> 00:07:57.300
>> It does it's just an odd
terminology for me, and

133
00:07:57.300 --> 00:08:01.240
it would take a little bit to find out,
what does that mean?

134
00:08:01.240 --> 00:08:03.520
>> Yeah, but
don't forget about the terminology.

135
00:08:03.520 --> 00:08:07.580
Everything is subject to tailoring
in a PRINCE2 environment.

136
00:08:07.580 --> 00:08:13.460
Now, sure when it comes to your test
then you're not gonna be tested on,

137
00:08:13.460 --> 00:08:16.700
certainly not for foundation year,
not gonna be tested on tailoring.

138
00:08:16.700 --> 00:08:19.810
And you're gonna be tested on
the terminology that we use, but

139
00:08:19.810 --> 00:08:24.010
what terminology you choose to use when
you get back into your own environment.

140
00:08:24.010 --> 00:08:26.140
Well, that's completely up to you.

141
00:08:26.140 --> 00:08:28.360
I mean we're certainly
not going to come in and

142
00:08:28.360 --> 00:08:31.375
judge you an audit you based on
the fact that you changed a word.

143
00:08:31.375 --> 00:08:34.370
[LAUGH] So don't worry about that.

144
00:08:34.370 --> 00:08:36.520
It's just that you
understand the principles.

145
00:08:36.520 --> 00:08:42.210
And the PRINCE2 project works to
the PRINCE2 principles and theme.

146
00:08:42.210 --> 00:08:47.060
It's not necessarily about being
pedantic over the words that we use.

147
00:08:47.060 --> 00:08:51.260
So we've got three particular activities
that we've got here, accepting the work

148
00:08:51.260 --> 00:08:55.060
package, executing the work package,
and delivering the work package.

149
00:08:55.060 --> 00:08:58.800
And very much like control in
a stage these work packages,

150
00:08:58.800 --> 00:09:02.740
well they're gonna be completely
tailored to your environment.

151
00:09:02.740 --> 00:09:07.400
So again, we're not going to
spend a lot of time talking about

152
00:09:07.400 --> 00:09:11.440
these particular activities because
I expect them to be to be tailored.

153
00:09:11.440 --> 00:09:14.410
So when it comes to
accepting the work package,

154
00:09:14.410 --> 00:09:18.010
that means that what we're doing
is we're reviewing the plan.

155
00:09:18.010 --> 00:09:21.230
We're going to produce at this level,
this is the team manager,

156
00:09:21.230 --> 00:09:24.610
we're going to produce a work plan for
the actual team.

157
00:09:24.610 --> 00:09:28.340
Make sure that we can
actually deliver this and

158
00:09:28.340 --> 00:09:31.280
that it meets the needs
of the organization.

159
00:09:31.280 --> 00:09:34.060
And then,
agree when we're gonna deliver it.

160
00:09:34.060 --> 00:09:36.410
And then, well, we build.

161
00:09:37.410 --> 00:09:42.290
Which means that we actually develop the
product and we keep everybody informed.

162
00:09:42.290 --> 00:09:46.700
Whether it's the by use of information
radiative kanban boards etcetera or

163
00:09:46.700 --> 00:09:48.540
maybe ScanDocs.

164
00:09:48.540 --> 00:09:52.570
And we obtain any approvals for
any issues that we may have.

165
00:09:52.570 --> 00:09:54.710
And we then deliver the work package.

166
00:09:54.710 --> 00:09:57.490
And when we deliver the work package,

167
00:09:57.490 --> 00:10:03.410
well we have to ensure that everything
is complete as per the quality register.

168
00:10:03.410 --> 00:10:09.500
And that all of the approvals that we have
such as your customer acceptance etcetera.

169
00:10:09.500 --> 00:10:12.160
Well did they,
all those boxes have been tainted.

170
00:10:12.160 --> 00:10:15.400
Everybody's happy with
what we have delivered.

171
00:10:15.400 --> 00:10:19.560
And then we notify the project manager
that work has been complete and

172
00:10:19.560 --> 00:10:24.860
then as you see then that is delivered
back into the control inner stage.

173
00:10:24.860 --> 00:10:29.170
In other words its reported back to,
its delivered back to the project manager.

174
00:10:30.360 --> 00:10:33.150
So as we've said with
the controlling of stage,

175
00:10:33.150 --> 00:10:38.700
well tailoring a managing a product,
has to be done.

176
00:10:38.700 --> 00:10:42.800
It's completely up to you,
within your organization,

177
00:10:42.800 --> 00:10:48.280
as to how you are going to
tailor this particular process.

178
00:10:49.880 --> 00:10:54.140
Because product delivery is going
to be very, very unique to you.

179
00:10:54.140 --> 00:10:57.500
So think about the tools
that we're going to use.

180
00:10:57.500 --> 00:11:02.150
Remember what we said in our last episode,
when it comes to tools.

181
00:11:02.150 --> 00:11:06.610
You define your process first, you work
out what you want from a tool, and

182
00:11:06.610 --> 00:11:09.620
then you go and
find a tool to facilitate that.

183
00:11:11.120 --> 00:11:13.160
You don't bring in a tool and then try and

184
00:11:13.160 --> 00:11:17.710
tailor a product to meet the needs of any
tool that you're using to deliver it.

185
00:11:17.710 --> 00:11:21.680
Think about who the roles and
responsibilities should be.

186
00:11:21.680 --> 00:11:25.680
And obviously it really depends on
the scale of the project itself.

187
00:11:25.680 --> 00:11:31.000
And whether we're in an agile environment
or a waterfall approach, environment.

188
00:11:31.000 --> 00:11:35.530
Think about the perspective of your
supplier both internal and external.

189
00:11:35.530 --> 00:11:39.990
They're gonna use their lessons learnt
as I've said in a previous episode.

190
00:11:39.990 --> 00:11:42.970
I want them to bring their
experience into this.

191
00:11:43.980 --> 00:11:48.270
If we're using somebody, we're using
suppliers without any experience,

192
00:11:48.270 --> 00:11:51.700
then they need to be very,
very highly skilled at what they do.

193
00:11:51.700 --> 00:11:56.490
But then that means that we have to use
our experience of our organization in

194
00:11:56.490 --> 00:12:01.480
order then to ensure that our suppliers
are able to tailor to meet our needs.

195
00:12:01.480 --> 00:12:05.360
I don't expect any external suppliers to

196
00:12:05.360 --> 00:12:09.560
necessarily understand our
environment right from the word go.

197
00:12:09.560 --> 00:12:15.170
But I expect throughout every single
stage that they are developing their

198
00:12:15.170 --> 00:12:19.200
tailoring and that they are enhancing
their knowledge of the environment.

199
00:12:19.200 --> 00:12:24.660
And therefore I expect the lessons
learned to be getting greater and

200
00:12:24.660 --> 00:12:28.830
the adjustments to the way
that we're working to also

201
00:12:28.830 --> 00:12:33.660
be made that we're working more
efficiently as the project goes along.

202
00:12:35.570 --> 00:12:38.920
So in terms of managing product delivery,

203
00:12:38.920 --> 00:12:41.840
then really it's to say
everything has to be tailored.

204
00:12:41.840 --> 00:12:46.370
So that's pretty much all we're
going to cover right now.

205
00:12:46.370 --> 00:12:52.410
You will need to understand the purpose
of this particular process for your exam.

206
00:12:53.620 --> 00:12:56.590
But everything else is going
to be tailored to suit

207
00:12:56.590 --> 00:12:58.700
the needs of your organization.

208
00:12:58.700 --> 00:13:01.310
So when we come back in
at our next episode what

209
00:13:01.310 --> 00:13:05.280
we're going to take a look at managing
the boundaries between stages.

210
00:13:05.280 --> 00:13:09.270
So we're going to be looking
at managing stage boundaries.

211
00:13:09.270 --> 00:13:13.330
>> Well Jo I will tell you I'm kind
intrigued because I I'm not entirely

212
00:13:13.330 --> 00:13:16.580
sure what is meant by state boundary but
you know what,

213
00:13:16.580 --> 00:13:19.720
we're going to have to come on
back to see how that plays out.

214
00:13:19.720 --> 00:13:20.890
But right now we're going to go ahead and

215
00:13:20.890 --> 00:13:21.771
get out of here
>> So

216
00:13:21.771 --> 00:13:24.508
signing up for
ITPRO.TV I'm your host Justin Dennison.

217
00:13:24.508 --> 00:13:25.220
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

218
00:13:25.220 --> 00:13:27.010
>> And we'll see you next time.

219
00:13:27.010 --> 00:13:32.892
[MUSIC]

220
00:13:32.892 --> 00:13:35.227
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Our 6th Prince2® process; in this episode we cover the Prince2® process of Managing a Stage Boundary. These episodes explore the purpose and objectives of the process as well as common activities.
episodes.title: Prince2 Processes: Managing a Stage

7
00:00:15.240 --> 00:00:17.310
I'm your host Justin Dennison.

8
00:00:17.310 --> 00:00:21.254
And we're back on PRINCE2 2017 Foundation.

9
00:00:21.254 --> 00:00:22.253
Whoo.
>> Are you struggling?

10
00:00:22.253 --> 00:00:23.737
>> I don't know what is wrong with me.

11
00:00:23.737 --> 00:00:27.485
But in this episode, we're gonna be
talking about managing a stage boundary

12
00:00:27.485 --> 00:00:31.405
and here to help us along and hopefully be

13
00:00:31.405 --> 00:00:33.670
currently is none other

14
00:00:33.670 --> 00:00:35.090
How are you doing today, Jo?

15
00:00:35.090 --> 00:00:38.580
>> Well, clearly I'm a lot more
articulate than you are today.

16
00:00:38.580 --> 00:00:39.700
>> I'll tell you what.

17
00:00:39.700 --> 00:00:44.424
I have no idea what is I have been
overcome by the lack of ability to

18
00:00:44.424 --> 00:00:47.718
speak in any [CROSSTALK]
>> At the end of the episode I'll get you

19
00:00:47.718 --> 00:00:49.190

20
00:00:49.190 --> 00:00:52.085
>> Okay,
well I don't know if that's gonna help.

21
00:00:52.085 --> 00:00:55.020
Maybe I need to drink of less caffeine.

22
00:00:55.020 --> 00:00:56.700
>> Let me take this one, how about that?

23
00:00:56.700 --> 00:01:00.000
You let me take this and then you
can stand there and look pretty and

00:01:00.000 --> 00:01:01.690
that will work for everyone.

25
00:01:01.690 --> 00:01:02.880
>> I will try my best.

26
00:01:02.880 --> 00:01:04.480
I will try real, real hard.

27
00:01:04.480 --> 00:01:08.750
>> But yeah what we're gonna be looking
at in this particular episode is managing

28
00:01:08.750 --> 00:01:10.590
a Stage Boundary.

29
00:01:10.590 --> 00:01:11.629
Now unfortunately,

30
00:01:11.629 --> 00:01:15.380
Justin has kind of scuppered all of my
plans because I was gonna involve him and

31
00:01:15.380 --> 00:01:18.496
the first thing that I was gonna do
was gonna ask him a question but

32
00:01:18.496 --> 00:01:22.099
I'm not too sure whether that's a really
sensible thing to do right now.

33
00:01:22.099 --> 00:01:25.218
>> Well I like to live on the edge,
you like to live on the edge?

34
00:01:25.218 --> 00:01:26.415
I mean we can try it.

35
00:01:26.415 --> 00:01:27.411
>> Well we could try it.

36
00:01:27.411 --> 00:01:29.271
[LAUGH] And see what happens.

37
00:01:29.271 --> 00:01:31.418
>> What's the worst that could happen?

38
00:01:31.418 --> 00:01:32.710
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

39
00:01:32.710 --> 00:01:34.450
>> I don't even wanna go there,

40
00:01:34.450 --> 00:01:35.200
I really don't.

41
00:01:36.570 --> 00:01:40.100
You asked me earlier on during one of

42
00:01:40.100 --> 00:01:44.240
our breaks in between episodes you
asked what a stage boundary was.

43
00:01:44.240 --> 00:01:46.920
And I explained what a stage boundary was.

44
00:01:46.920 --> 00:01:48.420
I gave him a bit of a heads-up.

45
00:01:48.420 --> 00:01:51.080
So I'm gonna ask you
what can you remember?

46
00:01:51.080 --> 00:01:56.230
>> A stage boundary is the little
dotted line on the Gantt chart.

47
00:01:56.230 --> 00:01:57.330
Right.
>> Where we,

48
00:01:57.330 --> 00:02:00.550
it's like the interface
between two respective stages.

49
00:02:00.550 --> 00:02:01.995
>> And that's not what I told him, but.

50
00:02:01.995 --> 00:02:04.200
[LAUGH]
>> It is not what she told me.

51
00:02:04.200 --> 00:02:06.805
But, that's all I could remember.

52
00:02:06.805 --> 00:02:10.325
[LAUGH] Because that's what I asked you.

53
00:02:10.325 --> 00:02:11.817
[LAUGH]
>> I'm just not too sure how you

54
00:02:11.817 --> 00:02:14.070
remembered something
that I didn't tell you.

55
00:02:14.070 --> 00:02:15.730
>> No you didn't tell me,
that's what I was.

56
00:02:15.730 --> 00:02:17.770
I ask you about that.

57
00:02:17.770 --> 00:02:19.810
I remembered my question.

58
00:02:19.810 --> 00:02:22.910
We lived on the edge there and
I think we came to the precipice.

59
00:02:22.910 --> 00:02:24.790
>> I think we kind of came
to the edge really, really.

60
00:02:24.790 --> 00:02:26.620
>> Watch out there's
a crevasse right over there.

61
00:02:26.620 --> 00:02:31.480
>> Yeah yeah and
I'm tempted to push right now [LAUGH].

62
00:02:31.480 --> 00:02:34.550
No, it's that actually he wasn't too bad.

63
00:02:34.550 --> 00:02:37.580
A stage boundary is we
know that we have stages.

64
00:02:37.580 --> 00:02:42.160
We had them in our Gantt charts, and if
you look back at the material that we gave

65
00:02:42.160 --> 00:02:46.000
you, the downloadable material where you
saw the project Gantt chart, and you will

66
00:02:46.000 --> 00:02:53.520
see that a stage is a set of activities
that are happening at that point in time.

67
00:02:53.520 --> 00:03:00.690
Managing a stage boundary is really simply
managing the end of one's stage and

68
00:03:00.690 --> 00:03:05.030
then the authorization to
proceed to the next stage.

69
00:03:06.335 --> 00:03:07.945
Yeah I remember I used that word?

70
00:03:07.945 --> 00:03:09.385
>> It's all coming back to me now Jo.

71
00:03:09.385 --> 00:03:11.195
>> Yeah it's all coming back right.

72
00:03:11.195 --> 00:03:11.915
Okay.
>> [LAUGH]

73
00:03:11.915 --> 00:03:13.895
>> So if we take a look at the purpose

74
00:03:13.895 --> 00:03:16.255
then of this particular process.

75
00:03:16.255 --> 00:03:20.075
It's about enabling the project
manager to provide the project.

76
00:03:20.075 --> 00:03:24.745
Not the project team but the project
with sufficient information to be able

77
00:03:24.745 --> 00:03:29.765
to review what went right and
then approve the next stage plan.

78
00:03:30.810 --> 00:03:35.570
And then you'd review that plan and
then say okay, yes that's great,

79
00:03:35.570 --> 00:03:38.010
we've got continued
business justification.

80
00:03:38.010 --> 00:03:40.910
We understand the risks and
everything's looking great.

81
00:03:42.230 --> 00:03:45.450
Let's move onto the next stage.

82
00:03:45.450 --> 00:03:47.811
So this is what our stage boundary is.

83
00:03:49.285 --> 00:03:53.906
As it says reviewing whether
we did well in our current

84
00:03:53.906 --> 00:03:59.810
management stage and
then approving the next stage plan.

85
00:03:59.810 --> 00:04:04.270
Hm, actually this is quite a chunk
of work when you think about this.

86
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:07.440
So what we've got to do is
we've got to look back.

87
00:04:08.510 --> 00:04:12.500
On the current stage and
we've got to say okay what went well and

88
00:04:12.500 --> 00:04:14.370
what didn't go well?

89
00:04:14.370 --> 00:04:17.230
And then we've got to work out
our plan for the next stage.

90
00:04:17.230 --> 00:04:21.320
I am gonna ask him another question.

91
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:23.260
Why don't we do this right
at the start of the project?

92
00:04:24.340 --> 00:04:29.213
>> Well we can't possibly plan out all
of our stages because that would be way

93
00:04:29.213 --> 00:04:30.791
too much work up front.

94
00:04:30.791 --> 00:04:34.167
We would plan all these things
that could possibly change, right?

95
00:04:34.167 --> 00:04:38.854
Shouldn't we do this at,
essentially we plan for the next step.

96
00:04:38.854 --> 00:04:40.449
Shouldn't we do that at
that at that point in time?

97
00:04:40.449 --> 00:04:43.388
>> You kind of got things a little bit
mixed up on there because you said

98
00:04:43.388 --> 00:04:46.300
something about we've got
way too much work up front.

99
00:04:46.300 --> 00:04:49.130
I don't care how much work you got
up front, to be perfectly honest.

100
00:04:49.130 --> 00:04:52.841
>> What I mean is,
too much work that is subject to change.

101
00:04:55.347 --> 00:04:56.154
>> Okay.

102
00:04:56.154 --> 00:05:00.548
>> So I remember a previous episode Jo
you said we shouldn't try to plan out all

103
00:05:00.548 --> 00:05:02.522
these stages over the long term.

104
00:05:02.522 --> 00:05:05.427
We should look at just what's in
front of us like the next step.

105
00:05:05.427 --> 00:05:06.937
>> Right.

106
00:05:06.937 --> 00:05:08.797
>> And I remember, and

107
00:05:08.797 --> 00:05:13.457
maybe I'm remembering wrong
because I have been known,

108
00:05:13.457 --> 00:05:17.817
then the impetus for that was because we
needed to reevaluate at the end of each

109
00:05:17.817 --> 00:05:22.710
stage to determine Whether we're still
progressing in the manner that we hope to.

110
00:05:22.710 --> 00:05:25.520
>> Okay, I'm gonna change some of your
words because I'm gonna take them and

111
00:05:25.520 --> 00:05:27.360
change some of them because I think, and

112
00:05:27.360 --> 00:05:31.630
this is, and I've said this in previous
episodes but this is the reason why,

113
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:35.120
this is why we love this
particular sort of format.

114
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:37.050
This is why I got Justin here actually,

115
00:05:37.050 --> 00:05:42.150
because Justin's asking the questions
that you would normally ask me and also

116
00:05:42.150 --> 00:05:46.260
Justin's sort of giving me the directions
to say, hm okay then well maybe if you've

117
00:05:46.260 --> 00:05:49.610
misunderstood something then somebody else
has probably misunderstood something too.

118
00:05:49.610 --> 00:05:51.660
And it's really easy to do.

119
00:05:51.660 --> 00:05:54.770
So what I'm going to do is I'm
going to re-explain this again.

120
00:05:54.770 --> 00:05:59.750
So the reason why we don't plan for
everything right up front

121
00:05:59.750 --> 00:06:05.470
is not because of the amount of work but
just because it's inefficient to do that.

122
00:06:05.470 --> 00:06:11.110
Because, exactly what Justin said,
that things could change.

123
00:06:11.110 --> 00:06:17.406
But also, we simply don't know where we're
going to be at the end of each stage.

124
00:06:17.406 --> 00:06:21.679
Think of it like walking to a destination
because that's what we are doing.

125
00:06:21.679 --> 00:06:26.820
As we're walking to our destination,
we take one step after the other.

126
00:06:26.820 --> 00:06:32.030
If we plan every single step
in great detail we are putting

127
00:06:32.030 --> 00:06:36.310
a lot of work in but it's not efficient
for us to do that because what will happen

128
00:06:36.310 --> 00:06:41.320
is that we will end up with a duplication
of work we will end up with a lot of.

129
00:06:41.320 --> 00:06:44.420
I'm gonna use the word redundancy but
I'm gonna use that in the English sense of

130
00:06:44.420 --> 00:06:49.540
the word redundancy which is superfluous
to requirements because quite

131
00:06:49.540 --> 00:06:55.040
simply if we've planned this first stage,

132
00:06:55.040 --> 00:06:58.850
well we might actually take a bigger
step than we thought we were going to.

133
00:06:58.850 --> 00:07:04.220
Or we might take a smaller step
because of unforeseen circumstances.

134
00:07:04.220 --> 00:07:06.420
Which means that if we've
planned the whole thing out,

135
00:07:06.420 --> 00:07:10.680
then everything from here onwards,
is now redundant?

136
00:07:10.680 --> 00:07:12.170
It's now obsolete.

137
00:07:12.170 --> 00:07:13.550
It's useless.

138
00:07:13.550 --> 00:07:19.330
So it wouldn't be efficient to do that
because it would be just a waste of time.

139
00:07:19.330 --> 00:07:24.430
So it's not about spending too much time,
it's about wasting too much time.

140
00:07:24.430 --> 00:07:26.760
It would be inefficient to do so.

141
00:07:26.760 --> 00:07:30.840
So what we're gonna do is we're gonna
still have a high level goal, but

142
00:07:30.840 --> 00:07:35.750
we're just going to plan each
individual stage in great detail.

143
00:07:35.750 --> 00:07:39.300
So this is why we've still got this
overarching project planned, but

144
00:07:39.300 --> 00:07:45.460
that's the reason why at the end of every
stage we now go on to plan the next stage.

145
00:07:45.460 --> 00:07:49.899
Because we've got to look back to see what
we achieved, and our next stage then is

146
00:07:49.899 --> 00:07:53.426
generally dependent on how far we
got with our previous stage and

147
00:07:53.426 --> 00:07:57.605
if there's any remedial work that needs
doing, or if there are any issues or

148
00:07:57.605 --> 00:07:59.006
any changes to our work.

149
00:07:59.006 --> 00:08:00.182
So does that make sense?

150
00:08:00.182 --> 00:08:03.750
>> It does, and
I think ultimately I was trying to say.

151
00:08:03.750 --> 00:08:05.094
Effectively that.

152
00:08:05.094 --> 00:08:09.180
>> Right.
>> Just I couldn't quite find the words to

153
00:08:09.180 --> 00:08:11.580
be able to articulate it.

154
00:08:11.580 --> 00:08:15.530
So when I say that there's a lot of work
upfront, I'm not saying about the relative

155
00:08:15.530 --> 00:08:19.720
magnitude, I'm talking about, I'm gonna
do a lot of work knowing that if I do

156
00:08:19.720 --> 00:08:23.360
all of that, I'm only going to keep
the benefits from a small portion.

157
00:08:23.360 --> 00:08:24.430
>> Right, yeah.

158
00:08:24.430 --> 00:08:28.180
A lot of the work's gonna be done upfront
and then a lot of it's going to be wasted,

159
00:08:28.180 --> 00:08:30.730
and it's important that you're
able to articulate that.

160
00:08:30.730 --> 00:08:34.400
Certainly when it comes to, well,
both your foundation test and

161
00:08:34.400 --> 00:08:35.850
your practitioner test.

162
00:08:35.850 --> 00:08:40.450
In your practitioner test, you will need
to articulate this, you will need to be

163
00:08:40.450 --> 00:08:45.770
able to understand why we do
certain things in certain ways.

164
00:08:45.770 --> 00:08:50.630
And so it's very important to get your
understanding on the right track.

165
00:08:50.630 --> 00:08:54.690
So managing the stage boundary then is to
just look back at what we've achieved and

166
00:08:54.690 --> 00:08:57.045
then work out what we need
to do in the next stage.

167
00:08:57.045 --> 00:09:00.880
Bearing in mind that we're only planning
our next stage in great detail,

168
00:09:00.880 --> 00:09:04.820
we're not planning subsequent
stages in any detail.

169
00:09:04.820 --> 00:09:07.890
So here we have then our
managing a stage boundary,

170
00:09:07.890 --> 00:09:11.900
it's our purple diagram,
which means, Justin?

171
00:09:11.900 --> 00:09:13.070
>> It's from my PRINCE2 book.

172
00:09:13.070 --> 00:09:14.840
>> Hey, look at that, see?

173
00:09:14.840 --> 00:09:15.890
It's from our PRINCE2 book.

174
00:09:15.890 --> 00:09:22.750
It's more importanly from page 247 on
our PRINCE2 book, that's 2-4-7, 247.

175
00:09:22.750 --> 00:09:28.850
And you'll see that the dotted-line,
that sort of pale purple dotted-line,

176
00:09:28.850 --> 00:09:32.250
these are the activities that
are managing the stage boundary.

177
00:09:32.250 --> 00:09:34.380
Now, when it comes to your practitioner,
and

178
00:09:34.380 --> 00:09:36.760
we'll be looking at that
in a different series,

179
00:09:36.760 --> 00:09:41.790
you'll notice that we talk about inputs
