180
00:09:41.790 --> 00:09:44.760
What we're focusing on
here is what activities

181
00:09:44.760 --> 00:09:47.800
take place in the managing
the stage boundary.

182
00:09:47.800 --> 00:09:52.300
So we're going to review
our previous stage and

183
00:09:52.300 --> 00:09:56.190
we are going to then authorize
movement to the next stage.

184
00:09:56.190 --> 00:09:59.140
In other words,
did we finish everything in that stage?

185
00:09:59.140 --> 00:10:00.850
Can we move to the next stage?

186
00:10:00.850 --> 00:10:03.065
And then how do we plan for
the next stage?

187
00:10:03.065 --> 00:10:07.410
So then it simply says,
plan the next stage,

188
00:10:07.410 --> 00:10:11.120
we update the project plan,
we update the business case and

189
00:10:11.120 --> 00:10:15.440
we report that particular stage end for
the previous stage.

190
00:10:15.440 --> 00:10:18.750
And any exception plan as
well that needs to come in.

191
00:10:18.750 --> 00:10:21.605
So if something has not quite gone right,

192
00:10:21.605 --> 00:10:27.250
then we probably need to factor that in
and we need to then develop and plan for

193
00:10:27.250 --> 00:10:32.950
developing a change,
developing an update, developing

194
00:10:32.950 --> 00:10:38.800
a remedial action from any mistake that's
happened or any error that's come about.

195
00:10:38.800 --> 00:10:43.038
Because let's face it,
we're in IT and these things happen.

196
00:10:43.038 --> 00:10:48.830
And we also have to factor in too into
our plan, any requests for change.

197
00:10:48.830 --> 00:10:53.110
So any issues,
any requests to move the tolerances or

198
00:10:53.110 --> 00:10:56.570
any request for a change in functionality.

199
00:10:56.570 --> 00:11:03.880
So this particular process then, the role
is to assure the project board that all

200
00:11:03.880 --> 00:11:08.160
of our previous steps have been completed,
unless there have been issues and

201
00:11:08.160 --> 00:11:13.100
exceptions, in which case we've got to
assure them that they've been reviewed and

202
00:11:13.100 --> 00:11:17.130
that we have made the necessary
updates to the plan, and

203
00:11:17.130 --> 00:11:20.210
perhaps the necessary updates to
the business justification as well.

204
00:11:21.330 --> 00:11:27.710
And then we prepare the next plan for
the next stage and update that PID.

205
00:11:27.710 --> 00:11:30.170
So the project initiation documentation,

206
00:11:30.170 --> 00:11:33.480
we will need to make sure that
that's updated if we need to.

207
00:11:33.480 --> 00:11:36.960
We also need to update the business case

208
00:11:36.960 --> 00:11:41.440
if there is any change to
the business justification.

209
00:11:42.500 --> 00:11:49.390
As the project progresses and
the project moves through development and

210
00:11:49.390 --> 00:11:54.650
various stages,
I expect that there will be changes

211
00:11:54.650 --> 00:11:59.960
throughout the project to the business
case, and to the business justification,

212
00:11:59.960 --> 00:12:03.630
because I expect there to be
changes to the requirements.

213
00:12:03.630 --> 00:12:09.120
We live in an environment now
unlike when PRINCE2 came out in

214
00:12:09.120 --> 00:12:14.850
the 1980s where a PRINCE2 project was
something that maybe took a year,

215
00:12:14.850 --> 00:12:18.050
18 months from beginning to end.

216
00:12:18.050 --> 00:12:22.170
Now we live in an agile environment
where projects are delivering

217
00:12:22.170 --> 00:12:25.470
on a continual basis,
and where a project is,

218
00:12:25.470 --> 00:12:29.120
well, we're expected to be able
to deliver very, very quickly.

219
00:12:30.250 --> 00:12:32.320
And requirements change
incredibly quickly.

220
00:12:32.320 --> 00:12:35.530
Because technology now,
in the 21st century,

221
00:12:35.530 --> 00:12:39.200
technology changes
incredibly quickly as well.

222
00:12:39.200 --> 00:12:44.750
I mean, here we are, and

223
00:12:44.750 --> 00:12:49.750
And here we are looking at PRINCE2
saying okay, then we know that

00:12:49.750 --> 00:12:54.830
the project management environment is
changed since the last version came out.

225
00:12:54.830 --> 00:12:59.830
But we also understand that,
that will change as well in the future

226
00:12:59.830 --> 00:13:01.870
because the way that we
deliver projects and

227
00:13:01.870 --> 00:13:07.350
the way that we develop also has
changed in the last few years.

228
00:13:07.350 --> 00:13:12.718
That means that we know that our
projects have got to be flexible.

229
00:13:12.718 --> 00:13:15.890
We know they've got to meet
the needs of the organization, but

230
00:13:15.890 --> 00:13:18.390
we still have to have
that structure in place.

231
00:13:18.390 --> 00:13:20.580
It can't be done in an ad hoc way.

232
00:13:20.580 --> 00:13:24.000
And if you look at our previous episodes,
one of our very first episodes in this

233
00:13:24.000 --> 00:13:29.850
particular series in fact, we looked
at the danger to the organization and

234
00:13:29.850 --> 00:13:36.000
the chaos that just ensuues from not

235
00:13:36.000 --> 00:13:39.383
But we also know that that's got
to be balance because we've got

236
00:13:39.383 --> 00:13:43.570
to get project management flexible
enough to meet those changing needs.

237
00:13:45.370 --> 00:13:50.350
We also need to submit any information.

On the viability of the project back

00:14:05.872 --> 00:14:09.900
In other words, whether the project

And sometimes we do prematurely

00:14:13.030 --> 00:14:17.340

00:14:17.340 --> 00:14:19.020
we collate all of the information

00:14:20.060 --> 00:14:25.120
to give to the project board to

00:14:25.120 --> 00:14:27.160
And we also record lessons learnt.

00:14:27.160 --> 00:14:29.590
And then of course as I've already said,

00:14:29.590 --> 00:14:33.980
we request the authorization to

249
00:14:35.660 --> 00:14:41.384
So what we're doing is, we're planning,
we're updating, we're reporting and

00:14:41.384 --> 00:14:46.070

anything that has gone wrong.

00:14:46.070 --> 00:14:50.920
Anything that has stepped outside

The tolerances that we agreed

00:14:54.962 --> 00:14:57.563
bearing in mind that they could change.

00:14:57.563 --> 00:15:00.121
So when we're planning the next stage,

00:15:00.121 --> 00:15:04.937
then we need to make sure that we review
that project initiation document for

00:15:04.937 --> 00:15:08.413

That's the detailed plan by the way.

And so we're planning for a stage.

Who do you think does this, Justin?

Would that, that one's tricky.

A CI is An asset,

cuz that's not gonna

And then we update our current stage plan,

So that's at high-level,

Or this specific stage plan,

And then revise the entire project plan,

And then don't forget,

And the business case

Even if our product hasn't changed,

Because you know what,

New technology is released,

But going back to the business case,

00:19:07.951 --> 00:19:10.574
because things change
in the outside world.

00:19:10.574 --> 00:19:13.820
And the business might decide

And that comes from bad communication

Where things have changed in

00:19:51.610 --> 00:19:54.419

00:19:54.419 --> 00:19:59.510
So at the end of every stage, we need

00:19:59.510 --> 00:20:03.590
Including a summary of,
well, where we've got to,

00:20:03.590 --> 00:20:08.954

00:20:27.394 --> 00:20:29.709

How many tasks we're finishing

00:20:37.483 --> 00:20:41.369
Right, so it's burn down, how much of

That's a burn down chart, and we can apply

But this is what we are, this is what

00:21:25.712 --> 00:21:29.280

And we also want to make note of how

Because it's when we, it's funny, but it's

Or this is when we've had any requests for

00:22:28.898 --> 00:22:33.370
You don't just accept them into

Because ultimately,

And that could potentially mean more cost,

00:22:42.008 --> 00:22:43.619

So it's just not as simple as saying,

But of course, ultimately, and these

Ultimately, we have to tailor this
particular process to our needs and

00:23:25.840 --> 00:23:27.270

00:23:27.270 --> 00:23:31.385
This is not something that we
can just take out of a book and

402
00:23:31.385 --> 00:23:35.220
plug-and-play, it has to
be tailored to our project.

403
00:23:36.950 --> 00:23:41.280
So what we've done here is that we've
taken a look at this sort of management of

404
00:23:41.280 --> 00:23:43.480
the boundary in between our stages.

405
00:23:43.480 --> 00:23:47.534
And of course, we know we can
have as many stages as we want.

406
00:23:47.534 --> 00:23:50.152
What we're gonna look at now, though,

407
00:23:50.152 --> 00:23:53.319
is actually what we do at
the end of our projects.

408
00:23:53.319 --> 00:23:55.336
So now, in our next episode,

409
00:23:55.336 --> 00:23:59.720
we're gonna be taking a look
at how we close a project.

410
00:23:59.720 --> 00:24:02.582
>> Well, Jo, I'm kind of interested
to see your take on that as well,

411
00:24:02.582 --> 00:24:05.116
because I've seen this kind
of just been a, I don't know.

412
00:24:05.116 --> 00:24:08.292
It's almost like someone
ordered a package delivery,

413
00:24:08.292 --> 00:24:10.926
they came up,
threw it at the door, ran away,

414
00:24:10.926 --> 00:24:12.880
didn't even ring the door bell-
>> [LAUGH]

415
00:24:12.880 --> 00:24:13.878
>> It was all kinds of bad.

416
00:24:13.878 --> 00:24:17.231
So I'm interested to see how you
do this in a more appropriate

417
00:24:17.231 --> 00:24:17.819
manner-
>> [LAUGH]

418
00:24:17.819 --> 00:24:19.282
>> And hopefully you do as well, but

419
00:24:19.282 --> 00:24:21.870
for now, we're gonna go ahead and
get out of here.

420
00:24:21.870 --> 00:24:24.481
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Justin Dennison.

421
00:24:24.481 --> 00:24:25.139
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

422
00:24:25.139 --> 00:24:26.530
>> And we'll see you next time.

423
00:24:26.530 --> 00:24:32.957
[MUSIC]

424
00:24:32.957 --> 00:24:36.041
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Our 7th Prince2® process; in this episode we cover the Prince2® process of Closing a Project. These episodes explore the purpose and objectives of the process as well as common activities.
episodes.title: Prince2 Processes: Closing a Project
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.438
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.438 --> 00:00:04.943
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.943 --> 00:00:06.323
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.323 --> 00:00:07.645
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.645 --> 00:00:12.938
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> Greeting everyone,

6
00:00:12.938 --> 00:00:15.780
and welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:15.780 --> 00:00:17.045
I'm your host, Justin Dennison.

8
00:00:17.045 --> 00:00:20.771
And boy, you better buckle up because
we got more PRINCE2 2017 Foundation,

9
00:00:20.771 --> 00:00:21.805
coming at you.

10
00:00:21.805 --> 00:00:24.905
And this episode, we're gonna be
talking about, closing a project.

11
00:00:24.905 --> 00:00:29.087
And here to make sure that we do it with
all the appropriateness that it entails.

12
00:00:29.087 --> 00:00:30.455
Is none other, than Ms Jo Peacock.

13
00:00:30.455 --> 00:00:33.650
How are you doing there, Jo?
>> Absolutely great Justin,

14
00:00:33.650 --> 00:00:35.660
how are you?
>> I am doing fantastic,

15
00:00:35.660 --> 00:00:40.286
I'm actually interested in how i'm suppose
to do this because I'm pretty sure I've

16
00:00:40.286 --> 00:00:44.137
done it wrong in the past, and seen it
done wrong in the past as I look in to

17
00:00:44.137 --> 00:00:46.257
the previous episode right at the end,

18
00:00:46.257 --> 00:00:50.018
it's mostly been here you go you just
throw it and you run away right?

19
00:00:50.018 --> 00:00:53.114
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah.

20
00:00:53.114 --> 00:00:58.501
No, no this is where I'm gonna get so
foaming and so tough.

21
00:00:58.501 --> 00:01:00.960
And I'm gonna turn into my mother, almost.

22
00:01:02.020 --> 00:01:02.800
No, heaven help me.

23
00:01:04.070 --> 00:01:05.760
No, absolutely not!

24
00:01:05.760 --> 00:01:06.355
No!

25
00:01:06.355 --> 00:01:09.200
[LAUGH] This is the bit, and

26
00:01:09.200 --> 00:01:13.660
it doesn't matter what side of
an imaginary fence you think you're on.

27
00:01:14.920 --> 00:01:18.470
Whether you're a project manager or
whether you're a service manager,

28
00:01:18.470 --> 00:01:22.990
I can tell you now this is
the one process, that causes so

29
00:01:22.990 --> 00:01:26.880
many arguments and
the well it's not just arguments.

30
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:29.020
It's almost all out war.

31
00:01:29.020 --> 00:01:33.210
And this is the process
that causes tension.

32
00:01:33.210 --> 00:01:40.040
And this is the process that really can
split an IT service provider in half.

33
00:01:40.040 --> 00:01:42.290
It can really divide teams.

34
00:01:42.290 --> 00:01:43.080
And you know what?

35
00:01:44.340 --> 00:01:46.130
I don't care about personalities.

36
00:01:46.130 --> 00:01:47.550
I'm not interested in that.

37
00:01:47.550 --> 00:01:51.560
What I am interesting in though, is
delivering quality to our businesses and

38
00:01:51.560 --> 00:01:52.660
to our customers.

39
00:01:52.660 --> 00:01:55.120
And when we've got
a project management team,

40
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:57.940
that is separate from
the service management team.

41
00:01:57.940 --> 00:01:59.840
And we haven't got any
synergy between them.

42
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:04.580
And then unfortunately,
the customer does not receive quality.

43
00:02:04.580 --> 00:02:06.100
And if they don't receive quality,

44
00:02:06.100 --> 00:02:08.980
do you know what,
they're gonna go somewhere else.

45
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:10.870
Because quite frankly,

46
00:02:10.870 --> 00:02:15.600
they do not wanna get involved in whatever
internal issues are going on within IT.

47
00:02:16.840 --> 00:02:20.600
And that's kind of my stern
talking-to you now, right?

48
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:27.480
If I see anybody trying to throw a product
over the fence to the service guys,

49
00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:32.410
to the operational guys, I will be
the first one to shout and scream.

50
00:02:32.410 --> 00:02:34.470
Because that's not what
we should be doing.

51
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:37.250
We don't want to encourage division.

52
00:02:37.250 --> 00:02:39.142
We don't wanna build a brick wall.

53
00:02:39.142 --> 00:02:43.570
We wanna encourage unity, and
now I sound like I'm preaching.

54
00:02:43.570 --> 00:02:47.190
But sometimes I feel like
we gotta preach this one,

55
00:02:47.190 --> 00:02:50.100
because it doesn't happen often enough.

56
00:02:50.100 --> 00:02:54.161
See, look at him.
>> So, I will tell you Jo, even though I

57
00:02:54.161 --> 00:02:59.910
speak in a fun manner to bring light,
some levity to a subject.

58
00:02:59.910 --> 00:03:03.819
I will say I have been both on a team
where there has been this kind of nice

59
00:03:03.819 --> 00:03:09.072
integrated feel, where you, okay I'm
making sure that we know what's going on.

60
00:03:09.072 --> 00:03:13.180
And everybody's kinda working together, to
make sure there's a seamless transition.

61
00:03:13.180 --> 00:03:19.680
I have also been in a project or two,
where it's just been like, here you go.

62
00:03:19.680 --> 00:03:22.817
I go well what, I don't,
what happened, what?

63
00:03:22.817 --> 00:03:29.380
You just kinda, it's like somebody
blindfolded you, put you in a car.

64
00:03:29.380 --> 00:03:30.980
And then drove me out to
the middle of nowhere and

65
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:33.020
said cool, we'll see you later.

66
00:03:33.020 --> 00:03:34.180
And it's not a good feeling.

67
00:03:34.180 --> 00:03:37.800
I don't think it's appropriate for
anybody, it doesn't help the project.

68
00:03:37.800 --> 00:03:41.810
If this is your business and your goal is
to deliver outside products to someone,

69
00:03:41.810 --> 00:03:46.150
this is a horrible way to do it because
it's going to cause, as you said,

70
00:03:46.150 --> 00:03:47.360
a bunch of tension.

71
00:03:47.360 --> 00:03:50.320
And it's funny, I feel like I'm
now getting a little [SOUND].

72
00:03:50.320 --> 00:03:53.801
[LAUGH]
>> Cuz I noticed you were like,

73
00:03:53.801 --> 00:03:55.390
let's do this.

74
00:03:55.390 --> 00:03:59.540
But it infuriates me,
because it doesn't help anybody.

75
00:03:59.540 --> 00:04:01.360
It actually frustrates me a great deal.
>> And

76
00:04:01.360 --> 00:04:03.140
it doesn't matter what team
it's sitting on, right?

77
00:04:03.140 --> 00:04:06.892
It doesn't matter whether I am
advising project managers, or

78
00:04:06.892 --> 00:04:09.449
whether I'm advising service managers.

79
00:04:09.449 --> 00:04:14.295
This is the area where I see the most
tension, this is the area where I

80
00:04:14.295 --> 00:04:19.327
see the most conflict as well, and
it's in this particular process.

81
00:04:19.327 --> 00:04:22.775
And so, I mean, you've heard of DevOps.

82
00:04:22.775 --> 00:04:24.940
Right?
>> I have, and admittedly so

83
00:04:24.940 --> 00:04:29.378
being a develop rat, I heard the term
thrown around without fully-

84
00:04:29.378 --> 00:04:31.151
>> This is like project products, right?

85
00:04:31.151 --> 00:04:35.900
It's just thrown.
>> Without fully recognizing or

86
00:04:35.900 --> 00:04:38.410
thinking about what that entails.
>> Right.

87
00:04:38.410 --> 00:04:40.950
>> We say DevOps, a lot of people use that

88
00:04:40.950 --> 00:04:45.270
term to justify saying we're
developers who are now ops people.

89
00:04:45.270 --> 00:04:49.650
And that's not what it means,
I know that what it means but

90
00:04:49.650 --> 00:04:53.243
I would say early on my career that's
when people would tell me that, I go,

91
00:04:53.243 --> 00:04:57.990
I guess I now have to deploy all this and
manage all this, not only develop it.

92
00:04:59.380 --> 00:05:03.570
But I know that's not what it is, but
to make sure that I don't botch it up.

93
00:05:03.570 --> 00:05:05.443
Well, you should tell us DevOps is.

94
00:05:05.443 --> 00:05:06.270
[LAUGH]
>> Well, I'm

95
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:08.570
gonna talk about something
called early life support.

96
00:05:08.570 --> 00:05:11.320
And I'm also gonna talk
about DevOps as well.

97
00:05:11.320 --> 00:05:16.020
So early life support is something
where we've been working at this.

98
00:05:16.020 --> 00:05:20.940
Now remember the PRINCE2 came out of
the UK government many years ago,

99
00:05:20.940 --> 00:05:25.520
and so did itill and so
did many other frameworks as well.

100
00:05:25.520 --> 00:05:30.310
Such as MSP and
portfolios of change and MOR.

101
00:05:30.310 --> 00:05:34.620
And we've always had this concept
of what we call early life support.

102
00:05:34.620 --> 00:05:39.970
And early life support is simply the,
when we deploy a project,

103
00:05:39.970 --> 00:05:44.490
then we transition it into
the live environment and

104
00:05:44.490 --> 00:05:49.470
the project team,
yes do carry on with the support.

105
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:54.017
For a determined period of time with,
the support of that

106
00:05:54.017 --> 00:05:58.770
particular product until it's
accepted by the customer.

107
00:05:58.770 --> 00:06:02.883
And it's at that point in time, when
the service level agreements are signed.

108
00:06:02.883 --> 00:06:04.820
They're not signed before that.

109
00:06:04.820 --> 00:06:07.120
It's at that point in
time when they're signed.

110
00:06:07.120 --> 00:06:11.340
And that's when the operations
team will take over completely and

111
00:06:11.340 --> 00:06:12.910
fully, the support for

112
00:06:12.910 --> 00:06:17.390
that particular service as they would
call it, or product, as we might call it.

113
00:06:18.740 --> 00:06:21.490
That's been around for years, and
nobody's really taken any notice of it.

114
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:24.050
And what's happened is, we've now got the,

115
00:06:24.050 --> 00:06:28.510
we had a team of project
managers not all that long ago.

116
00:06:28.510 --> 00:06:31.220
But within the last 10 years,
he sat there and said, you know what,

117
00:06:31.220 --> 00:06:34.550
this transition thing
just doesn't help at all.

118
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:36.780
And what we're finding
is it's not working, and

119
00:06:36.780 --> 00:06:42.190
we're finding is that we have got projects
that are being thrown over the fence.

120
00:06:43.800 --> 00:06:47.470
I like it to, you mentioned
something a little while ago.

121
00:06:47.470 --> 00:06:50.270
It's a bit like that package
being left on your doorstep and

122
00:06:50.270 --> 00:06:53.180
the delivery guy is just running
off as quickly as possible, and

123
00:06:53.180 --> 00:06:55.330
then your left with something and
you need to return it, or

124
00:06:55.330 --> 00:06:58.570
you've got an issue with it and
you don't know how to contact anyone.

125
00:06:58.570 --> 00:07:02.090
It's exactly the same as that, and a group
of project managers got together and

126
00:07:02.090 --> 00:07:03.310
said this has got to stop.

127
00:07:04.520 --> 00:07:09.220
So, what we've got to do is build better
synergy between our operations guys and

128
00:07:09.220 --> 00:07:10.690
the development guys.

129
00:07:10.690 --> 00:07:12.068
And so what they.

130
00:07:13.654 --> 00:07:16.592
I was gonna say what they created and
it's not what they created,

131
00:07:16.592 --> 00:07:18.850
cuz it's an evolution of
the early life support.

132
00:07:18.850 --> 00:07:24.876
But it's taking that concept of early life
support and saying, we're one big team.

133
00:07:24.876 --> 00:07:30.510
We're all working together, and
if we get our operations guys involved in

134
00:07:30.510 --> 00:07:36.280
the development of a project,
they may not necessarily be developers.

135
00:07:36.280 --> 00:07:39.990
And we don't want them to be developers,
but they need to be,

136
00:07:39.990 --> 00:07:42.040
they're the one that
are supporting the product.

137
00:07:42.040 --> 00:07:46.340
So they're the ones that need to say,
okay but it's got to be supportable.

138
00:07:46.340 --> 00:07:48.430
It's got to sit on this platform.

139
00:07:48.430 --> 00:07:49.993
These are the types of questions.

140
00:07:49.993 --> 00:07:52.442
Our users never remember their passwords.

141
00:07:52.442 --> 00:07:55.288
So can we come up with some
alternative to passwords,

142
00:07:55.288 --> 00:07:57.197
because they never remember them.

143
00:07:57.197 --> 00:08:02.170
So it means that our operations guys
are involved in the development.

144
00:08:02.170 --> 00:08:07.210
They're specifically involved
in the part of development

145
00:08:07.210 --> 00:08:12.790
where we are defining and articulating
what the end product should look like.

146
00:08:12.790 --> 00:08:15.350
And then they're also involved,
then, in the testing.

147
00:08:15.350 --> 00:08:19.030
Because they're gonna be testing
it from a user perspective,

148
00:08:19.030 --> 00:08:22.290
as well as then involved in
the actual deployment itself.

149
00:08:23.610 --> 00:08:27.710
But then on the flip side, our development
guys are involved in the support.

150
00:08:27.710 --> 00:08:30.240
They're performing that
early life support.

151
00:08:30.240 --> 00:08:35.340
They're involved in the picking up the
telephone when something goes wrong for

152
00:08:35.340 --> 00:08:37.710
a set period of time.

153
00:08:37.710 --> 00:08:41.660
And so with our operations guys
in that development arena,

154
00:08:41.660 --> 00:08:45.760
they're giving requirements,
they're giving service-level targets.

155
00:08:45.760 --> 00:08:49.140
And they're saying to the developers,
hey, this is what we need.

156
00:08:49.140 --> 00:08:53.600
We need you to develop something
that's going to deliver this.

157
00:08:53.600 --> 00:08:56.577
And then from the other
side of things as we move.

158
00:08:56.577 --> 00:09:00.652
And this is the idea, is that it should
be a transition, it should be a move,

159
00:09:00.652 --> 00:09:02.310
it should be seamless.

160
00:09:02.310 --> 00:09:08.680
As we move into the operating environment,
then the development guys are still there.

161
00:09:08.680 --> 00:09:13.340
So the customers have still got
exactly the same contact details.

162
00:09:13.340 --> 00:09:17.720
And the developers are working
with operations to sit there,

163
00:09:17.720 --> 00:09:21.930
literally on the service desk, and
look at whatever queries are coming in.

164
00:09:21.930 --> 00:09:23.300
And, well, you never know.

165
00:09:23.300 --> 00:09:27.250
Well, we didn't actually anticipate that
the users would be working in this way.

166
00:09:27.250 --> 00:09:31.150
So maybe we need to add
an additional stage to this project.

167
00:09:31.150 --> 00:09:35.220
Maybe we need to change something,
because it's not quite working.

168
00:09:35.220 --> 00:09:38.080
The simple fact is, though,
if this doesn't happen and

169
00:09:38.080 --> 00:09:42.790
you just leave the package on the doorstep
and then run away really quickly,

170
00:09:42.790 --> 00:09:46.390
you could be left with something
that simply doesn't work.

171
00:09:46.390 --> 00:09:51.470
And like I said just a little while ago,
you're gonna get, then, the customer,

172
00:09:51.470 --> 00:09:56.610
the business, your organization that's
not happy with what you've delivered.

173
00:09:56.610 --> 00:09:57.530
Guess what?

174
00:09:57.530 --> 00:10:00.241
Next time,
they're gonna go somewhere else.

175
00:10:00.241 --> 00:10:03.490
And they might even go somewhere
else external for a product.

176
00:10:03.490 --> 00:10:07.090
Or they might go somewhere else
external for support, as well.

177
00:10:07.090 --> 00:10:10.900
They might go to somebody who's doing
software as a service and say, well,

178
00:10:10.900 --> 00:10:14.410
we're gonna use these guys because
you're not gonna talk to each other.

179
00:10:15.440 --> 00:10:21.780
And so it does make me mad
when I see that we still have

180
00:10:21.780 --> 00:10:25.420
that mentality of just
throwing it over the fence and

181
00:10:25.420 --> 00:10:29.400
just hoping that it's not gonna
come back and bite you in the bum.

182
00:10:29.400 --> 00:10:30.590
Because it probably will.

183
00:10:31.840 --> 00:10:37.310
And as a developer,
you must also see that it

184
00:10:37.310 --> 00:10:42.405
doesn't look too good on you when you've
just thrown something over the fence and

185
00:10:42.405 --> 00:10:46.510
ran away.
>> So I tried my best not to do that.

186
00:10:46.510 --> 00:10:50.980
And I think something that you
spoke to that illustartes the need.

187
00:10:50.980 --> 00:10:53.290
Because this is to some extent a mindset,
also.

188
00:10:53.290 --> 00:10:54.891
Correct me if I'm wrong.
>> It is, it is,

189
00:10:54.891 --> 00:10:56.042
that's exactly what DevOps is.

190
00:10:56.042 --> 00:10:58.747
It's a mindset, yeah.
>> So it's a mindset.

191
00:10:58.747 --> 00:11:01.552
There were so many times that I wished,

192
00:11:01.552 --> 00:11:05.632
because we were interfacing
with other people, right?

193
00:11:05.632 --> 00:11:08.832
I was like, I wish I could sit
down with their ops people,

194
00:11:08.832 --> 00:11:11.111
where we're delivering this product.

195
00:11:11.111 --> 00:11:15.908
Because they're gonna be able to inform
me early on in the product development.

196
00:11:15.908 --> 00:11:19.750
Hey, can I do this, is this possible?

197
00:11:19.750 --> 00:11:25.320
I think that's where it would be so much
help, this kind of co-mingling of ideas.

198
00:11:25.320 --> 00:11:28.070
Where I can inform an ops person,
this is what we wanna do,

199
00:11:28.070 --> 00:11:30.440
this is why we wanna do this.

200
00:11:30.440 --> 00:11:34.040
And they can also give me some perspective
on, our platform doesn't support that.

201
00:11:34.040 --> 00:11:36.255
Or you know what,
that's gonna be hard to maintain.

202
00:11:36.255 --> 00:11:41.053
So when I hear those, I'm like,
that would have been so nice.

203
00:11:41.053 --> 00:11:44.361
Likewise, though, sometimes it
just didn't play out that way, and

204
00:11:44.361 --> 00:11:47.720
it was not a good experience for anybody.
>> Right, well, and

205
00:11:47.720 --> 00:11:52.680
it's funny because working with
one client that we have right now.

206
00:11:52.680 --> 00:11:54.950
And they're going through something very,
very similar.

207
00:11:54.950 --> 00:11:58.690
And as you say, they're saying that it's
not a very good experience for anybody.

208
00:11:58.690 --> 00:12:02.330
And a lot of that is because they
haven't set out what they want.

209
00:12:02.330 --> 00:12:03.200
And they haven't set out,

210
00:12:03.200 --> 00:12:06.980
the project team haven't set out what
they want from our support people.

211
00:12:06.980 --> 00:12:10.280
And our support people don't really
understand anything about a project.

212
00:12:10.280 --> 00:12:12.830
And so there has to be some synergy, and

213
00:12:12.830 --> 00:12:15.370
there has to be some
sort of melding of minds.

214
00:12:15.370 --> 00:12:20.180
But also an understanding
between them of what each

215
00:12:20.180 --> 00:12:23.620
particular role should
do within the project.

216
00:12:23.620 --> 00:12:26.960
It's not a case of having somebody along
sitting next to you in the project.

217
00:12:26.960 --> 00:12:30.470
Sort of over your shoulder,
kind of doing the good cop,

218
00:12:30.470 --> 00:12:32.110
bad cop routine on your shoulder.

219
00:12:32.110 --> 00:12:33.625
That's not what they're there for.

220
00:12:33.625 --> 00:12:35.204
They're there to contribute.

221
00:12:35.204 --> 00:12:38.442
But if they don't know what
they should be contributing,

222
00:12:38.442 --> 00:12:42.740
then you as a developer should know
what sort of questions to ask them.

223
00:12:42.740 --> 00:12:43.955
And it can work really well.

224
00:12:43.955 --> 00:12:48.826
It also gives the operations guys a huge,
big morale boost as well,

225
00:12:48.826 --> 00:12:50.740
believe it or not.

226
00:12:50.740 --> 00:12:54.960
Because, I mean, can you imagine
sitting on a service desk for eight,

227
00:12:54.960 --> 00:13:01.370
nine hours a day,
five days a week for years on end?

228
00:13:01.370 --> 00:13:03.325
You're being shouted at constantly.

229
00:13:03.325 --> 00:13:05.550
It's sometimes good to get a break.

230
00:13:05.550 --> 00:13:08.310
And I will always say to you if
you're managing a service desk.

231
00:13:08.310 --> 00:13:09.150
You need to be looking for

232
00:13:09.150 --> 00:13:12.890
opportunities like this to actually
take your team members away.

233
00:13:12.890 --> 00:13:18.170
And it makes them feel valued, because
their opinions are being listened to.

234
00:13:18.170 --> 00:13:20.011
You look confused by that.
>> No, sorry,

235
00:13:20.011 --> 00:13:24.363
you had said eight hours a day for
many years at a service desk.

236
00:13:24.363 --> 00:13:25.097
And I was like,

237
00:13:25.097 --> 00:13:26.750
I about had a panic attack.
>> [LAUGH]

238
00:13:26.750 --> 00:13:28.230
>> But then I thought of something else.

239
00:13:28.230 --> 00:13:32.262
Wouldn't this also make your team as a
whole a lot more resilient to any kind of

240
00:13:32.262 --> 00:13:32.893
whoopsie?

241
00:13:32.893 --> 00:13:36.835
Like I got sick, right, or
something happened with my family,

242
00:13:36.835 --> 00:13:41.520
someone could step up and be able to
assist because we have worked together.

243
00:13:41.520 --> 00:13:45.390
Instead of going, well, Justin was the
only one that knew anything about this.

244
00:13:45.390 --> 00:13:50.100
He's gone, he's out for
now, what are we gonna do?

245
00:13:50.100 --> 00:13:55.115
Resentment, frustration,
or dissatisfaction on

246
00:13:55.115 --> 00:13:57.265
the level of the customer or the user.
>> Right, and

247
00:13:57.265 --> 00:13:59.795
it also means that what you've
got on the service desk or

248
00:13:59.795 --> 00:14:03.285
in the support teams, you've got people
that understand something, as well.

249
00:14:03.285 --> 00:14:06.627
So when a query comes through
concerning that particular product,

250
00:14:06.627 --> 00:14:10.862
then you've got somebody that's able to
turn around and say, hang on a minute.

251
00:14:10.862 --> 00:14:15.147
I remember this because I remember getting
involved in this particular discussion.

252
00:14:15.147 --> 00:14:18.167
And the reason this
happened was because of X.

253
00:14:18.167 --> 00:14:23.837
Rather than making up a particular,
making up an answer, potentially.

254
00:14:23.837 --> 00:14:30.150
Which is sometimes what could happen, is
that you want that person to be informed.

255
00:14:30.150 --> 00:14:32.805
You wanna have informed people
on the service desk and

256
00:14:32.805 --> 00:14:34.285
in the support environment.

257
00:14:34.285 --> 00:14:36.050
And you know what?

258
00:14:36.050 --> 00:14:37.930
This really promotes this.

259
00:14:37.930 --> 00:14:44.646
So in terms of closing a project,
which is where we are right now,

260
00:14:44.646 --> 00:14:50.141
this process has to happen
on condition that the early

261
00:14:50.141 --> 00:14:56.390
life support and
DevOps has happened before this.

262
00:14:56.390 --> 00:15:01.047
So we have to have a transition period,
not a handover.

263
00:15:01.047 --> 00:15:05.110
I don't want to hear that word,
not a throwing over the fence.

264
00:15:05.110 --> 00:15:08.234
We have to have a transition period.

265
00:15:08.234 --> 00:15:12.856
And after that transition period, that's
when, at the end of early life support,

266
00:15:12.856 --> 00:15:14.038
as I've mentioned.

267
00:15:14.038 --> 00:15:17.525
That's when we're sitting down
with the user and saying, okay,

268
00:15:17.525 --> 00:15:21.839
these acceptance criteria, are you okay
with all of these acceptance criteria?

269
00:15:21.839 --> 00:15:26.020
And that happens at the end
of the early life support.

270
00:15:26.020 --> 00:15:30.793
So the purpose of closing a project is,
at the end of that then,

271
00:15:30.793 --> 00:15:36.478
to provide that point at which the
acceptance of the product is confirmed.

272
00:15:36.478 --> 00:15:40.048
So as it says on the screen
in front of you right now,

273
00:15:40.048 --> 00:15:43.953
recognizing that the objectives
have been achieved and

274
00:15:43.953 --> 00:15:47.460
that the project has
nothing more to contribute.

275
00:15:47.460 --> 00:15:48.390
I think we've got an issue.

276
00:15:48.390 --> 00:15:50.506
I've got an issue with my teeth today,
I think.

277
00:15:50.506 --> 00:15:53.239
That's what it is.

278
00:15:53.239 --> 00:15:56.550
We also close a project when
things aren't going quite right or

279
00:15:56.550 --> 00:16:00.310
maybe then when there's no longer
a need for that particular project.

280
00:16:00.310 --> 00:16:04.607
So some projects are closed
prematurely as well.

281
00:16:04.607 --> 00:16:09.034
So yes we have the project closure which
is the typical project closure at the end

282
00:16:09.034 --> 00:16:13.540
of early life support but we also have
projects that are closed prematurely too.

283
00:16:15.300 --> 00:16:16.801
>> And that's encompassed by that or

284
00:16:16.801 --> 00:16:18.984
that the project has
nothing more to contribute.

285
00:16:18.984 --> 00:16:19.565
>> Right.

286
00:16:19.565 --> 00:16:21.469
>> Right, so that little phrase,

287
00:16:21.469 --> 00:16:24.289
implicitly that means you
may be able to cut that

288
00:16:24.289 --> 00:16:25.174
off.
>> Yeah.

289
00:16:25.174 --> 00:16:27.169
>> You're like hey, this doesn't work for

290
00:16:27.169 --> 00:16:30.762
us, this viability is no good anymore.
>> Yeah, yeah, exactly,

291
00:16:30.762 --> 00:16:34.927
exactly it really is about sort
of contributing to the, well,

292
00:16:34.927 --> 00:16:38.420
to the requirements of the organization.

293
00:16:38.420 --> 00:16:43.770
So here you'll see then we've got our
purple diagram from our prince two book.

294
00:16:43.770 --> 00:16:48.560
And in the closing of project activities,
well, we're preparing either planned or

295
00:16:48.560 --> 00:16:50.870
premature closures as we just mentioned.

296
00:16:50.870 --> 00:16:52.620
We're handing over the products.

297
00:16:52.620 --> 00:16:58.620
In other words, this is where we're
saying okay, you signed off on this.

298
00:16:58.620 --> 00:17:00.880
Is everything okay?

299
00:17:00.880 --> 00:17:05.320
So when we say hand over, that doesn't
mean we throw over the products.

300
00:17:05.320 --> 00:17:08.920
What it means is, we say,
right, am I good to go now?

301
00:17:08.920 --> 00:17:10.480
Am I good to leave?

302
00:17:10.480 --> 00:17:12.139
Is everything okay?

303
00:17:12.139 --> 00:17:16.685
Okay, and then, what we'll do is,
we'll have a lessons learned

304
00:17:16.685 --> 00:17:20.760
exercise where we evaluate
the efficiency of the project.

305
00:17:20.760 --> 00:17:24.400
And we recommend that
the executive close the project.

306
00:17:25.650 --> 00:17:28.640
So we have to make sure that
the user is happy as we say.

307
00:17:28.640 --> 00:17:32.650
We have to make sure that
everything is working smoothly.

308
00:17:32.650 --> 00:17:37.620
And so reviewing the performance
of the actual product

309
00:17:37.620 --> 00:17:41.830
is something that should be done
as part of early life support,

310
00:17:41.830 --> 00:17:45.110
including ensuring the host
site is able to support.

311
00:17:45.110 --> 00:17:49.500
All of these should be done
in the early life support.

312
00:17:49.500 --> 00:17:53.930
But now what we're going to do is
we're going to close the project.

313
00:17:53.930 --> 00:17:58.890
And we're going to review the project for
performance and for efficiency.

314
00:17:58.890 --> 00:18:02.550
And assess the benefits
have been realized.

315
00:18:03.970 --> 00:18:10.000
So we are going to prepare for the planned
closure by updating the project plan,

316
00:18:10.000 --> 00:18:15.139
by getting that signed off, and
releasing the project resources.

317
00:18:15.139 --> 00:18:18.837
In other words, all of these people that
we've got, that have been working for us,

318
00:18:18.837 --> 00:18:21.970
that have been doing development and
then doing that hand over.

319
00:18:21.970 --> 00:18:25.100
Then we're going to release those people.

320
00:18:26.170 --> 00:18:28.640
And this is exactly the same, by the way.

321
00:18:28.640 --> 00:18:31.970
If we have a premature closure,
we're going to release records.

322
00:18:31.970 --> 00:18:34.960
We're going to update the project plan.

323
00:18:34.960 --> 00:18:39.940
But the one thing that we're also going
to do is agree to recover anything that,

324
00:18:39.940 --> 00:18:42.010
well, we may have got rid of.

325
00:18:42.010 --> 00:18:44.329
So sometimes, we brought in a project,

326
00:18:44.329 --> 00:18:49.060
as part of bringing in that project
we're going to retire something else.

327
00:18:49.060 --> 00:18:52.600
Well, if we prematurely close the project,
in other words,

328
00:18:52.600 --> 00:18:54.930
we decide that the project
is no longer viable,

329
00:18:54.930 --> 00:18:59.420
then we might have to bring back
something that we thought about retiring.

330
00:18:59.420 --> 00:19:01.700
So that's part of the premature closure.

331
00:19:02.730 --> 00:19:08.980
And then, we want to have a formal
hand over of the product.

332
00:19:08.980 --> 00:19:10.360
That's that formal.

333
00:19:10.360 --> 00:19:12.110
Is everything okay?

334
00:19:12.110 --> 00:19:13.430
Are you happy?

335
00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:16.390
Have you got any questions at all?

336
00:19:16.390 --> 00:19:18.830
Is it okay if I hand this over to support?

337
00:19:18.830 --> 00:19:24.475
Okay, and then we also want to ensure,
and this bottom one's quite important.

338
00:19:24.475 --> 00:19:28.640
Cuz the other's fairly self-explanatory,
but consulting the change control

339
00:19:28.640 --> 00:19:33.060
approach, are change management
okay to sign this off as well?

340
00:19:33.060 --> 00:19:36.110
This is not just about whether
the customer is okay to sign it off, but

341
00:19:36.110 --> 00:19:37.960
what about change management?

342
00:19:37.960 --> 00:19:42.039
Are they okay that everything
has been delivered as stated?

343
00:19:43.460 --> 00:19:48.590
And then we go back, and
we evaluate the project itself.

344
00:19:48.590 --> 00:19:51.500
This is where we conduct
a lessons leaned exercise.

345
00:19:51.500 --> 00:19:53.777
So we review the project for

346
00:19:53.777 --> 00:19:59.522
what we have delivered against what
we said we were going to deliver.

347
00:19:59.522 --> 00:20:04.807
And we create a report where we will
review what's been delivered and

348
00:20:04.807 --> 00:20:07.550
also review how things went, too.

349
00:20:08.770 --> 00:20:09.920
Creating lessons learned,

350
00:20:09.920 --> 00:20:14.110
who's not gonna benefit?
>> I think that would benefit everybody.

351
00:20:14.110 --> 00:20:15.420
>> At this point in time,

352
00:20:15.420 --> 00:20:18.210
we're looking to do this for
future projects and for other

353
00:20:18.210 --> 00:20:23.080
projects that are ongoing right now that
could learn from any of those lessons.

354
00:20:23.080 --> 00:20:25.710
So it is still important that we do this.

355
00:20:25.710 --> 00:20:28.934
I've heard of a lot of people and
a lot of organizations who've said, no,

356
00:20:28.934 --> 00:20:30.632
we don't bother at the end of a project.

357
00:20:30.632 --> 00:20:35.210
Because we've got nothing else to
learn in that particular project.

358
00:20:35.210 --> 00:20:39.210
And I say, okay, maybe not in that
particular project, but you got plenty

359
00:20:39.210 --> 00:20:44.040
to learn for another project.
>> Man, that would make me really nervous.

360
00:20:44.040 --> 00:20:46.212
We have nothing further to learn.
>> [LAUGH]

361
00:20:46.212 --> 00:20:48.664
>> I got to find another job, no.

362
00:20:48.664 --> 00:20:50.901
That's what that would tell me.
>> Yeah, yeah,

363
00:20:50.901 --> 00:20:55.170
I've got plenty to learn but
from probably somewhere else, right?

364
00:20:55.170 --> 00:21:00.150
Yeah, the lessons learned is so
important, so important.

365
00:21:00.150 --> 00:21:01.500
And then what we'll do is,

366
00:21:01.500 --> 00:21:06.230
well, we want to communicate
that this project is all over.

367
00:21:06.230 --> 00:21:10.260
That's something else that I've
seen people shy away from as well.

368
00:21:10.260 --> 00:21:15.320
Communicate in the project
is being completed and

369
00:21:15.320 --> 00:21:19.730
now the project team is being
disbanded because everybody's happy.

370
00:21:19.730 --> 00:21:20.881
That's that email that you get.

371
00:21:20.881 --> 00:21:23.440
You know when a parcel's been
dumped on your doorstep and

372
00:21:23.440 --> 00:21:25.852
then you get this email
saying it's been delivered.

373
00:21:25.852 --> 00:21:28.558
And you're the one sitting there
going yeah, but it doesn't work.

374
00:21:28.558 --> 00:21:32.370
It's that, right?
>> Or it's not even mine.

375
00:21:32.370 --> 00:21:34.890
You gave me the wrong one,
or something like that.

376
00:21:34.890 --> 00:21:39.340
Now, that's physical parcels but-
>> No, but that's exactly why

377
00:21:39.340 --> 00:21:43.561
people don't like to do this
communication because it's that kind of,

378
00:21:43.561 --> 00:21:45.580
you're adding visibility to it.

379
00:21:45.580 --> 00:21:49.400
You're saying hey, look,
you've got it now, right?

380
00:21:49.400 --> 00:21:50.590
And you're okay.

381
00:21:50.590 --> 00:21:55.490
And you're opening the door up to
criticism, or you're opening the door up

382
00:21:55.490 --> 00:22:01.100
to any sort of feedback, and
that's what a lot of people don't want.

383
00:22:01.100 --> 00:22:04.870
But if you've gone through this early life
support, if you've gone through the whole

384
00:22:04.870 --> 00:22:10.890
sort of dev ops, then telling somebody
right, well I'm walking away right now.

385
00:22:10.890 --> 00:22:12.050
Well, that's okay though.

386
00:22:12.050 --> 00:22:13.460
Just turn around and say, yeah, okay then,

387
00:22:13.460 --> 00:22:17.480
yeah, bye.
>> On the flip side of that,

388
00:22:17.480 --> 00:22:22.150
it's funny because I know people who are,
I don't want them to come back,

389
00:22:22.150 --> 00:22:25.950
but really, again, that goes back
to what do you have to learn?

390
00:22:25.950 --> 00:22:28.670
Your feedback is where
you gain intelligence

391
00:22:28.670 --> 00:22:30.587
about how you've performed.
>> Yeah.

392
00:22:30.587 --> 00:22:31.925
>> So communicating that,

393
00:22:31.925 --> 00:22:33.560
I always welcome feedback.

394
00:22:33.560 --> 00:22:37.368
I've worked with some individuals who
are like, they just kinda sit there, and

395
00:22:37.368 --> 00:22:38.098
kinda tuck in.

396
00:22:38.098 --> 00:22:44.626
I'm like, but I can't get better, we
can't get better, unless we have actual,

397
00:22:44.626 --> 00:22:48.020
reliable, and honest feedback.
>> Yeah.

398
00:22:48.020 --> 00:22:49.350
>> And maybe that feedback is

399
00:22:49.350 --> 00:22:51.840
this transition was not a good one, right?
>> Right.

400
00:22:51.840 --> 00:22:53.270
>> So we need to reevaluate how

401
00:22:53.270 --> 00:22:56.970
we're doing this.
>> Yeah, yeah, exactly that, exactly.

402
00:22:56.970 --> 00:22:59.860
And so we have to elicit feedback.

403
00:22:59.860 --> 00:23:01.560
Communication is a two way process and

404
00:23:01.560 --> 00:23:03.860
we've got to make sure
that we elicit feedback.

405
00:23:03.860 --> 00:23:08.500
But people that run away from doing
the communication, invariably it's because

406
00:23:08.500 --> 00:23:13.670
they know that the lessons learned,
probably being quite extensive, right?

407
00:23:13.670 --> 00:23:16.082
There's a lot to learn,
we could have done a lot better.

408
00:23:16.082 --> 00:23:20.429
Part of this as well though is
also to close off any logs and

409
00:23:20.429 --> 00:23:23.290
any documentation too.

410
00:23:23.290 --> 00:23:25.060
We do not delete anything.

411
00:23:26.520 --> 00:23:28.370
Don't wanna hear about
you burning evidence.

412
00:23:30.390 --> 00:23:31.320
Don't look at me like that.

413
00:23:31.320 --> 00:23:34.714
I've heard this before.
>> This is not what we mean by a burn down

414
00:23:34.714 --> 00:23:36.432
chart, right?
>> Right, no, exactly no.

415
00:23:36.432 --> 00:23:38.162
>> Let me make a list of all of the things

416
00:23:38.162 --> 00:23:40.424
I need to destroy,
put through the shredder.

417
00:23:40.424 --> 00:23:41.754
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, yeah,

418
00:23:41.754 --> 00:23:43.560
no, this is not what we do.

419
00:23:43.560 --> 00:23:45.700
We archive the documentation.

420
00:23:45.700 --> 00:23:48.362
We may wanna go back to
this at some point in time.

421
00:23:48.362 --> 00:23:52.130
There's gonna be a huge amount of
documentation produced as part of

422
00:23:52.130 --> 00:23:53.430
every project, but you know what?

423
00:23:53.430 --> 00:23:55.769
This is what knowledge management is for.

424
00:23:55.769 --> 00:23:59.972
It's to ensure that that documentation
is saved somewhere, it's archived.

425
00:23:59.972 --> 00:24:04.614
We might actually want To use it at
some point in time in the future, and

426
00:24:04.614 --> 00:24:08.652
then we prepare a draft closure
notification for the board.

427
00:24:08.652 --> 00:24:12.761
Who do you think actually signs
off on a project, and says, yes,

428
00:24:12.761 --> 00:24:17.879
it's definitely closed?
>> Here you go with these questions

429
00:24:17.879 --> 00:24:22.477
that I don't know anything about.
>> [LAUGH] It's cuz I'm mean

430
00:24:22.477 --> 00:24:23.947
you know.
>> So,

431
00:24:23.947 --> 00:24:25.360
we're recommending a project closure.

432
00:24:25.360 --> 00:24:29.987
The actual closure would be you have to
sign off, would it be the project board?

433
00:24:29.987 --> 00:24:30.730
>> It is, yeah.

434
00:24:30.730 --> 00:24:34.227
It's the project board, but
they would never, or should never,

435
00:24:34.227 --> 00:24:36.927
sign off on a project for,
well, for two reasons.

436
00:24:36.927 --> 00:24:41.786
They shouldn't sign off a project unless
the customer has agreed that they're

437
00:24:41.786 --> 00:24:46.501
happy with everything, or where a project
has been prematurely closed, and

438
00:24:46.501 --> 00:24:49.112
if a project has been prematurely closed,

439
00:24:49.112 --> 00:24:52.590
then obviously that would be
down to the project board.

440
00:24:52.590 --> 00:24:55.030
But again, there's got to have
been a reason for it, and

441
00:24:55.030 --> 00:24:57.630
that reason should be documented, and

442
00:24:57.630 --> 00:25:01.940
therefore it should be kept in the sort
of the lessons learned review, and

443
00:25:01.940 --> 00:25:06.296
also should be archived appropriately,
along with the rest of the documentation.

444
00:25:06.296 --> 00:25:08.350
Even when a project's
been prematurely closed,

445
00:25:08.350 --> 00:25:12.500
you never, ever, want to get rid
of that documentation at all.

446
00:25:13.860 --> 00:25:17.330
Now, the last thing that I
want to talk about is, and

447
00:25:17.330 --> 00:25:22.702
this is the last thing as far as
our series is concerned as well,

448
00:25:22.702 --> 00:25:26.340
is that, just like everything else,

449
00:25:26.340 --> 00:25:31.790
we've got to tailor our project closure
to meet the needs of the organization.

450
00:25:31.790 --> 00:25:34.120
But one thing I've got to
tell you about tailoring, and

451
00:25:34.120 --> 00:25:39.730
you'll see exactly the same criteria here
as you have done in any other process,

452
00:25:39.730 --> 00:25:43.092
but the one thing I've got to tell you
about tailoring, tailoring does not mean

453
00:25:43.092 --> 00:25:46.333
removing early life support, or
removing that dev ops environment.

454
00:25:48.050 --> 00:25:51.547
Tailoring does not mean well in an
organization we just through the project

455
00:25:51.547 --> 00:25:54.010
over the fence, and
then run as quickly as we can.

456
00:25:54.010 --> 00:25:57.170
That's not tailoring,
that's called bad practice.

457
00:25:57.170 --> 00:25:59.487
It's certainly [LAUGH]
not called best practice.

458
00:25:59.487 --> 00:26:01.340
So, I don't ever want to see that.

459
00:26:01.340 --> 00:26:04.940
I never want to go into an organization
and for them to say, yes,

460
00:26:04.940 --> 00:26:06.970
well this is the way we do this.

461
00:26:06.970 --> 00:26:11.319
Because, I can tell you now, I've been to
so many organizations where I turn around

462
00:26:11.319 --> 00:26:14.809
and said, no, this is not the way
that you should be doing this, and

463
00:26:14.809 --> 00:26:18.572
this is the way that we recommend for
you to actually close off a project.

464
00:26:18.572 --> 00:26:20.560
You do not simply throw it over the fence.

465
00:26:20.560 --> 00:26:23.020
So tailoring should not involve that.

466
00:26:23.020 --> 00:26:26.999
Now, that's real life,
a real world practical example there, but

467
00:26:26.999 --> 00:26:31.060
that's also something that you have
got to plan for your test as well.

468
00:26:32.420 --> 00:26:34.490
So, talking about your test.

469
00:26:34.490 --> 00:26:40.780
It's at this point in time where we
have reached the conclusion of all of

470
00:26:40.780 --> 00:26:46.560
our sort of the instructional
episodes to do with PRINCE2,

471
00:26:46.560 --> 00:26:51.170
and so certainly with our
foundation series, and so

472
00:26:51.170 --> 00:26:55.170
what we're going to do now, we are going
to come back for some future episodes, but

473
00:26:55.170 --> 00:27:00.740
in our subsequent episodes we're going
to be looking at the sample paper.

474
00:27:00.740 --> 00:27:05.619
Now, available as part of your
downloadable material is a sample exam

475
00:27:05.619 --> 00:27:06.204
paper.

476
00:27:06.204 --> 00:27:10.455
This is the official sample exam paper.

477
00:27:10.455 --> 00:27:13.300
So what do you remember about the exam,
Justin?

478
00:27:13.300 --> 00:27:15.588
>> It is 60 question, you get 60 minutes.

479
00:27:15.588 --> 00:27:20.907
You gotta get, I wanna say,
wait a minute, wait a minute.

480
00:27:20.907 --> 00:27:22.791
You gotta get 33 of them right or

481
00:27:22.791 --> 00:27:24.121
something like that.
>> Yep.

482
00:27:24.121 --> 00:27:25.651
>> Yeah, you gotta get a 55%, I think,

483
00:27:25.651 --> 00:27:26.447
you said?
>> Yeah,

484
00:27:26.447 --> 00:27:30.654
you gotta get 33 right in order to be
able to pass your PRINCE2 Foundation.

485
00:27:30.654 --> 00:27:34.913
So now's your chance to
take the sample paper,

486
00:27:34.913 --> 00:27:40.130
download it,
it's in your downloadable materials, and

487
00:27:40.130 --> 00:27:46.950
when we come back in our next episode we
are going to go over the sample paper.

488
00:27:46.950 --> 00:27:51.040
Now it's gonna take more than one episode,
because we've got 60 questions, and

489
00:27:51.040 --> 00:27:52.740
that's quite a lot.

490
00:27:52.740 --> 00:27:57.680
So, come back, join us again, and we'll
take a look at that sample paper, and

491
00:27:57.680 --> 00:27:59.590
we'll make sure that you are prepared for

492
00:27:59.590 --> 00:28:02.210
your test.
>> Now Jo, I do have one question.

493
00:28:02.210 --> 00:28:05.509
Am I gonna be in those episodes,
or is that gonna be all you?

494
00:28:05.509 --> 00:28:07.295
>> Boy, I don't know, I don't know.

495
00:28:07.295 --> 00:28:09.253
Should we make Justin take the test,

496
00:28:09.253 --> 00:28:11.932
this is the question.
>> I don't know, I guess everybody will

497
00:28:11.932 --> 00:28:13.978
have to stay tuned to find out.
>> [LAUGH]

498
00:28:13.978 --> 00:28:14.945
>> But if I'm not,

499
00:28:14.945 --> 00:28:18.828
I wish you the best of luck, and
hopefully it all works out for you.

500
00:28:18.828 --> 00:28:20.717
Jo is gonna lead the way.

501
00:28:20.717 --> 00:28:23.087
I'll be a bystander even if I am here.

502
00:28:23.087 --> 00:28:25.547
But, for right now,
we're gonna go ahead and get out of here.

503
00:28:25.547 --> 00:28:28.351
So signing off for ITProTV,
I've been you host Justin Dennison.

504
00:28:28.351 --> 00:28:29.407
>> And I'm Jo Peacock.

505
00:28:29.407 --> 00:28:31.235
>> And we'll see you next time.

506
00:28:31.235 --> 00:28:37.408
[MUSIC]

507
00:28:37.408 --> 00:28:40.504
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: The PeopleCert Prince2® 2017 Foundation exam is a 1 hour test and in this episode Jo outlines the format of the exam and prerequisites for taking the exam as well as hints and tips on the exam taking.
episodes.title: Intro to Exam
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.142
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.142 --> 00:00:12.840
Hi, and welcome to your exam
review episodes on ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.840 --> 00:00:14.220
My name is Jo Peacock.

4
00:00:14.220 --> 00:00:21.580
I'm your host and also your guide for
this particular prints to foundation exam.

5
00:00:21.580 --> 00:00:23.400
And that's exactly what
we're going to be doing,

6
00:00:23.400 --> 00:00:26.820
is we're going to be looking at
the PRINCE2 foundation exam.

7
00:00:26.820 --> 00:00:31.750
Now by now,
I am hoping that you have completed all of

8
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:36.465
the episodes in our PRINCE2 series and
your ready to start your test.

9
00:00:36.465 --> 00:00:38.465
But before we do that,

10
00:00:38.465 --> 00:00:42.245
I wanna give you a little bit of an
overview of what the test is going to be

11
00:00:42.245 --> 00:00:47.745
like, give you a little bit of an overview
on the test conditions as well.

12
00:00:47.745 --> 00:00:50.580
And just prepare you for the test.

13
00:00:50.580 --> 00:00:53.470
So the first thing that I'm going to
tell you to do is to download all

14
00:00:53.470 --> 00:00:54.280
of the materials.

15
00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:55.740
And hopefully you've already done that.

16
00:00:55.740 --> 00:01:00.860
So you've downloaded the PDF that comes
along with this particular class.

17
00:01:00.860 --> 00:01:03.410
And there are 3 PDF's that
come along with the series,

18
00:01:03.410 --> 00:01:08.730
you have your course PDF which
is the Powerpoint slides.

19
00:01:08.730 --> 00:01:11.780
You also have your sample paper and

20
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:15.620
then you have the answers to
your sample paper as well.

21
00:01:15.620 --> 00:01:19.110
So these are the PDF's that
come along with the course.

22
00:01:19.110 --> 00:01:22.460
Now I know that you've downloaded your
sample paper because that's what we're

23
00:01:22.460 --> 00:01:27.690
going to start and go over in this
particular sort of mini series, so

24
00:01:27.690 --> 00:01:30.080
now you're ready to do your test.

25
00:01:30.080 --> 00:01:32.670
Well what is the test going to be like?

26
00:01:32.670 --> 00:01:35.630
Well the first thing that you have
to do is you have to request,

27
00:01:35.630 --> 00:01:39.640
you have to tell us that you're ready for
your test.

28
00:01:39.640 --> 00:01:42.500
And you'll request an exam voucher.

29
00:01:42.500 --> 00:01:48.890
Now, the exam voucher, you will be able to
request that on the peoplecert website.

30
00:01:48.890 --> 00:01:55.900
You simply log onto peoplecert.org and
you are able then to book an exam.

31
00:01:55.900 --> 00:02:00.780
And you can book your prints two
foundation exam by telling the,

32
00:02:00.780 --> 00:02:04.370
by completing the form with all
your details and by simply stating,

33
00:02:04.370 --> 00:02:06.710
I was going to say telling,
but it doesn't sound as good.

34
00:02:06.710 --> 00:02:12.490
By stating that you have
sat your course with us.

35
00:02:12.490 --> 00:02:15.430
And at that point in time,
they will reach out to us and

36
00:02:15.430 --> 00:02:18.670
confirm that you have actually
watched all of the episodes.

37
00:02:18.670 --> 00:02:23.400
So yes, that's something that It's part
of the exemplary requisites that you have

38
00:02:23.400 --> 00:02:27.430
actually spent some time with me and with
Justin as well, cuz we did have Justin

39
00:02:28.600 --> 00:02:32.510
here too, to review all of
the requirements for the exam.

40
00:02:32.510 --> 00:02:36.060
Now one of the things that I'm going
to recommend that you do as well

41
00:02:36.060 --> 00:02:40.330
prior to doing this is and I know that
I've done it throughout the actual

42
00:02:40.330 --> 00:02:43.960
throughout our episodes is I'm gonna
recommend that you get this, okay?

43
00:02:43.960 --> 00:02:47.830
You're going to need this for
your PRINCE2 practitioner anyway, but

44
00:02:47.830 --> 00:02:52.810
I would recommend this as well prior
to taking your PRINCE2 foundation.

45
00:02:52.810 --> 00:02:56.020
It's a really useful book,
really, really useful.

46
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:02.850
I mean in 2017 version of prints to has
been written away that actually very

47
00:03:02.850 --> 00:03:08.560
simple, very straight forward, with lots
of full of points, lots of hints and

48
00:03:08.560 --> 00:03:13.860
tips and lots of guidance to help you with
PRINCE2 in your natural environment and

49
00:03:13.860 --> 00:03:17.040
then also, help you to audio test tape.

50
00:03:17.040 --> 00:03:22.980
So, once you've completed all of this and
you have filled out their forms ready and

51
00:03:22.980 --> 00:03:28.170
you have paid the exam [INAUDIBLE],
what will happen is they will ask you for

52
00:03:28.170 --> 00:03:31.700
a convenient date and time for your exam.

53
00:03:31.700 --> 00:03:33.150
You can pick a date and

54
00:03:33.150 --> 00:03:37.070
time that is convenient for you,
completely convenient for you.

55
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:41.930
I can tell you now that people are sort of
really flexible, they're based in Europe.

56
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:45.140
But that doesn't include
the exam times at all.

57
00:03:45.140 --> 00:03:48.460
You can pick a time that really is,
I mean,

58
00:03:48.460 --> 00:03:54.420
I've seen exams on Saturday mornings,
I've seen exams, you know, during the day,

59
00:03:54.420 --> 00:03:59.470
on Sundays, but In the past I've also
seen exams in an evening, now of course,

60
00:03:59.470 --> 00:04:01.630
I mean that's completely
relative to where you are.

61
00:04:01.630 --> 00:04:04.270
So me saying, Saturdays and Sundays and

62
00:04:04.270 --> 00:04:06.370
whatever, that's relative to
where you are in the world.

63
00:04:06.370 --> 00:04:08.510
So obviously,
that's going to make a difference.

64
00:04:08.510 --> 00:04:10.190
But there is a widespread,

65
00:04:10.190 --> 00:04:14.000
there's a plethora of times that
are available for your test.

66
00:04:14.000 --> 00:04:16.330
There's a few prerequisites for the test.

67
00:04:16.330 --> 00:04:22.100
One is that you must have a PC
with a camera, because you have

68
00:04:22.100 --> 00:04:26.670
to be able to be proctor or invigilator,
whatever, you want to call them.

69
00:04:26.670 --> 00:04:28.900
The invigilator has to look at you and

70
00:04:28.900 --> 00:04:32.790
has to observe you during
the examining process.

71
00:04:32.790 --> 00:04:37.210
So you must have a camera and it either
must be attached to the laptop, you know.

72
00:04:37.210 --> 00:04:41.320
Most of them are nowadays they're a part
of the laptop or it must be an independent

73
00:04:41.320 --> 00:04:46.210
camera that again [INAUDIBLE] your
test has to sit on your screen.

74
00:04:47.980 --> 00:04:50.730
There are a few other
requirements as well.

75
00:04:50.730 --> 00:04:54.780
Bearing in mind these requirements
before you go into your test,

76
00:04:54.780 --> 00:04:57.570
because the last thing you want
to do is go into the test and

77
00:04:57.570 --> 00:05:00.110
find out you don't have
a suitable environment.

78
00:05:00.110 --> 00:05:03.040
You've got to be in a room by yourself.

79
00:05:03.040 --> 00:05:04.372
Unless requirement number one.

80
00:05:04.372 --> 00:05:06.950
That room come have any windows.

81
00:05:06.950 --> 00:05:10.910
Or if it has co-windows and
the curtains must be closed.

82
00:05:10.910 --> 00:05:12.240
There is a reason for this.

83
00:05:12.240 --> 00:05:15.530
We don't want anybody
seeing your test paper.

84
00:05:15.530 --> 00:05:20.095
We don't want anybody looking over
your shoulder because once they live

85
00:05:20.095 --> 00:05:23.605
questions in a live database,
get out in the big wild world and

86
00:05:23.605 --> 00:05:27.345
get into the Internet then we have
to remove it from our database.

87
00:05:27.345 --> 00:05:31.145
That means that we have to write
new question for the exam.

88
00:05:31.145 --> 00:05:36.020
So obviously we put protective
over our materials.

89
00:05:36.020 --> 00:05:38.190
So, you can't be overlooked for start.

90
00:05:38.190 --> 00:05:39.760
You can't have anybody else in the room.

91
00:05:39.760 --> 00:05:41.960
That means no animals, okay.

92
00:05:41.960 --> 00:05:47.370
Unless you have a dog that is there for
a specific

93
00:05:47.370 --> 00:05:52.360
reason, like a guide dog for
instance, although obviously,

94
00:05:52.360 --> 00:05:56.970
you know, I don't think that they're gonna
help by barking out the questions for you.

95
00:05:58.060 --> 00:06:02.530
But unless you have a service animal with
you and you can demonstrate that that

96
00:06:02.530 --> 00:06:07.030
is a service animal then you won't be
allowed any animals in the room either.

97
00:06:07.030 --> 00:06:08.680
Nothing that can disrupt you.

98
00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:12.940
Nothing that's going to interfere
with you taking the test.

99
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:16.330
So, that means no telephones on your desk.

100
00:06:17.500 --> 00:06:22.760
No other computers on your desk, nothing
that can access the internet in that room.

101
00:06:22.760 --> 00:06:28.110
And nothing, especially at foundation
because this is a closed book test,

102
00:06:28.110 --> 00:06:34.500
so nothing related to PRINCE2 or service
management at all anywhere in the room or

103
00:06:34.500 --> 00:06:39.780
on your desk, I quite often get people ask
me whether they can do the test at work.

104
00:06:39.780 --> 00:06:42.970
And yes, you can do the test at work but
you have to make sure that you're in

105
00:06:42.970 --> 00:06:46.750
an office with no windows or
that there's a blind at the window,

106
00:06:46.750 --> 00:06:50.620
that you cannot be disturbed and
that you're not going to be disturbed.

107
00:06:50.620 --> 00:06:56.390
And it has to be sort of an office that's
devoid of any IT stuff on the walls,

108
00:06:56.390 --> 00:06:58.090
that sort of thing as well.

109
00:06:58.090 --> 00:07:01.730
So you know, if you want to do it,
I have had one person say to me,

110
00:07:01.730 --> 00:07:02.890
can I do it in the bathroom?

111
00:07:02.890 --> 00:07:04.230
And I've said, sure.

112
00:07:04.230 --> 00:07:07.440
That's probably a really good place to do
it, as long as you've got good internet

113
00:07:07.440 --> 00:07:10.200
connection, cuz you know you're not
going to be disturbed there and

114
00:07:10.200 --> 00:07:13.770
you know that you've got nothing
on the walls around there or

115
00:07:13.770 --> 00:07:15.150
at least I should hope not, right?

116
00:07:16.710 --> 00:07:20.080
So, you wanna make sure that
the environment is just you, you alone.

117
00:07:20.080 --> 00:07:21.930
And that there's nothing on your desk.

118
00:07:21.930 --> 00:07:24.880
Now, what about this?

119
00:07:24.880 --> 00:07:26.740
Sure, you can have coffee.

120
00:07:26.740 --> 00:07:30.670
All right, nobody is gonna say you can't
have a coffee or a tea at your desk or

121
00:07:30.670 --> 00:07:31.500
anything to drink.

122
00:07:31.500 --> 00:07:33.360
You can have whatever you want.

123
00:07:33.360 --> 00:07:39.330
You can have sweets, candy whatever
you want to call it if you want to.

124
00:07:39.330 --> 00:07:42.050
But its only an hour, so you know,

125
00:07:42.050 --> 00:07:46.670
I wouldn't have thought that you might
need anything during that period and time.

126
00:07:47.850 --> 00:07:49.500
Pen and paper.

127
00:07:49.500 --> 00:07:50.830
No.

128
00:07:50.830 --> 00:07:54.000
Okay?
You cannot write anything down,

129
00:07:54.000 --> 00:07:58.230
again its down to that protecting
material in that we don't want

130
00:07:58.230 --> 00:08:02.650
anything written down that could
then be taken away from the room.

131
00:08:02.650 --> 00:08:06.510
Again, so, yeah, nothing to write with.

132
00:08:06.510 --> 00:08:08.550
You don't need to write anything.

133
00:08:08.550 --> 00:08:14.110
You will need to have your driving
license or some form of ID with you.

134
00:08:14.110 --> 00:08:16.930
And I'll tell you why a little bit later.

135
00:08:16.930 --> 00:08:21.250
But its the only thing you'll need for
your test is a PC and

136
00:08:21.250 --> 00:08:22.780
your driving license.

137
00:08:22.780 --> 00:08:27.810
Or a form of a ID, a government issued
form of ID, by the way, not just

138
00:08:27.810 --> 00:08:33.450
something that you knocked up five minutes
ago and then laminated it quickly, okay?

139
00:08:33.450 --> 00:08:35.190
It has to be government issued.

140
00:08:35.190 --> 00:08:39.370
And it has to have your name and
your address on there as well.

141
00:08:39.370 --> 00:08:40.790
And a photograph.

142
00:08:40.790 --> 00:08:45.650
It can't just be something that just
printed off without any photograph.

143
00:08:45.650 --> 00:08:47.470
We need to know that it's
you taking the test and

144
00:08:47.470 --> 00:08:50.210
that you haven't paid somebody
else to do it for you.

145
00:08:50.210 --> 00:08:53.280
Although why you'd want
to do that I don't know.

146
00:08:53.280 --> 00:08:55.910
If you go through this
particular series and

147
00:08:55.910 --> 00:08:57.710
you've actually go through
learning all of the material,

148
00:08:57.710 --> 00:09:00.420
why would you want somebody else
to take your test for you, right?

149
00:09:02.160 --> 00:09:04.480
So now you're ready to take your test.

150
00:09:04.480 --> 00:09:08.430
Well just before you do that,
they're going to send you a link.

151
00:09:08.430 --> 00:09:13.350
And that link is a link to
some downloadable software.

152
00:09:13.350 --> 00:09:14.990
It's called ExamShield.

153
00:09:14.990 --> 00:09:17.830
You're going to have to
download that onto your PC.

154
00:09:17.830 --> 00:09:21.520
Now I've already said that you
need to have a camera on your PC.

155
00:09:21.520 --> 00:09:26.290
You really need to have a PC or

156
00:09:26.290 --> 00:09:30.000
a laptop that you
are the administrator over.

157
00:09:30.000 --> 00:09:33.210
Because you have to download
this software and it has to run.

158
00:09:34.480 --> 00:09:40.960
So, you know, using your home personal
PC is probably your best bet, okay.

159
00:09:40.960 --> 00:09:42.060
It's gonna be really difficult,

160
00:09:42.060 --> 00:09:45.630
by the way, you cannot take
this test over a VPN either.

161
00:09:46.780 --> 00:09:52.140
The test has to be taken on sort
of a directly connected network.

162
00:09:52.140 --> 00:09:54.210
So, it is going to be easier for
you to take it at home.

163
00:09:54.210 --> 00:09:56.635
My personal recommendation
is take it at home.

164
00:09:56.635 --> 00:10:00.605
Don’t take it at the office
unless you absolutely have to,

165
00:10:00.605 --> 00:10:02.920
just try and find a suitable time.

166
00:10:02.920 --> 00:10:04.050
It’s an hour long.

167
00:10:04.050 --> 00:10:06.590
To take it at home somewhere quiet.

168
00:10:06.590 --> 00:10:07.770
But don't do it in your living room.

169
00:10:07.770 --> 00:10:09.180
Don't do it in a open room.

170
00:10:09.180 --> 00:10:12.440
It needs to be somewhere
where you can close the door

171
00:10:12.440 --> 00:10:14.550
cuz they will insist on
you closing the door.

172
00:10:16.050 --> 00:10:20.460
What I would do personally with this exam
shield software is a couple of days before

173
00:10:20.460 --> 00:10:23.980
your test download the software and
make sure that it works.

174
00:10:25.100 --> 00:10:28.830
you can delete it again if you want to
afterwards but download the software,

175
00:10:28.830 --> 00:10:29.650
make sure that it works.

176
00:10:31.190 --> 00:10:34.576
And then 15 minutes before your exam,

177
00:10:34.576 --> 00:10:39.857
you're going to log on and
when the proctor, the inviduator,

178
00:10:39.857 --> 00:10:45.450
comes online she will ask you or
he will ask you to show them your ID.

179
00:10:46.610 --> 00:10:50.180
They will need to see your photo ID and

180
00:10:50.180 --> 00:10:54.210
no you can't blank anything out and you
can't hold your finger over everything.

181
00:10:54.210 --> 00:10:58.230
They want to prove, this is a government
ID, this is a government test,

182
00:10:58.230 --> 00:11:02.980
yeah, this is a test that's
an officially recognized tests and

183
00:11:02.980 --> 00:11:06.690
therefore, [LAUGH] we need to prove
that it's you taking the test.

184
00:11:06.690 --> 00:11:10.600
So you will need to hold your
ID like this up to the camera,

185
00:11:10.600 --> 00:11:13.850
to demonstrate that it is actually
you that's taking the test.

186
00:11:15.830 --> 00:11:19.520
And then the individuator will
ask to look around the room and

187
00:11:19.520 --> 00:11:22.760
at that point in time you
need to use your laptop or

188
00:11:22.760 --> 00:11:27.900
your camera and literally turn it
around and scan around the room.

189
00:11:27.900 --> 00:11:31.570
That's so that they can see that there
isn't anything around that could help you

190
00:11:31.570 --> 00:11:33.665
with the test, that you haven't
got anything on your desk.

191
00:11:33.665 --> 00:11:36.415
Like a cellphone that you
haven't got another PC,

192
00:11:36.415 --> 00:11:39.875
that you don't have anything
that can access the internet.

193
00:11:39.875 --> 00:11:43.425
And to make sure that there's nobody
that could look over your shoulder and

194
00:11:43.425 --> 00:11:45.555
no one hiding underneath
your desk as well.

195
00:11:46.775 --> 00:11:50.965
And then once you put your
laptop back down then they will

196
00:11:50.965 --> 00:11:54.315
ask you if you have any questions and
they'll tell you what you need to do.

197
00:11:55.830 --> 00:12:00.570
Now if you're listening to
the invigilator through headphones

198
00:12:00.570 --> 00:12:04.740
it will ask you to take them out and
that's because somebody could

199
00:12:04.740 --> 00:12:08.530
be giving you instructions over
that headset or that headphones.

200
00:12:08.530 --> 00:12:11.320
So they will ask you to remove it.

201
00:12:11.320 --> 00:12:15.740
But they will ask you to keep your
microphone on at all during the test.

202
00:12:17.300 --> 00:12:20.690
One of the things that they
want to check [LAUGH] is that

203
00:12:20.690 --> 00:12:22.390
you're not reading questions out loud.

204
00:12:22.390 --> 00:12:25.730
And they're gonna watch to make sure that
you're not reading questions out loud.

205
00:12:25.730 --> 00:12:28.540
And this is why they ask you
to leave your microphone on.

206
00:12:29.945 --> 00:12:32.375
The other thing that this
ExamShield software will do,

207
00:12:32.375 --> 00:12:37.405
this ExamShield software gives them
access to see the controls on your PC.

208
00:12:37.405 --> 00:12:42.135
And so they will be able to tell if you've
got your microphone turned down to a low

209
00:12:42.135 --> 00:12:47.175
volume, then they're going to ask you
to turn it up to a higher volume so

210
00:12:47.175 --> 00:12:49.135
that they can hear you and so

211
00:12:49.135 --> 00:12:52.285
that they can hear what else is
going on in the background as well.

212
00:12:53.440 --> 00:12:57.210
So at this point time and
now you've downloaded the material.

213
00:12:57.210 --> 00:12:59.740
You've downloaded the ExamShield software.

214
00:12:59.740 --> 00:13:04.130
You have logged on at your allotted
time or fifteen minutes beforehand.

215
00:13:04.130 --> 00:13:07.680
And you've spoken to your invigilator and
they've looked around the room and

216
00:13:07.680 --> 00:13:09.440
they've asked you to
remove your headphones.

217
00:13:10.690 --> 00:13:12.800
Once you've done all of this.

218
00:13:12.800 --> 00:13:16.100
Then they will ask you if
you're ready to start the test.

219
00:13:16.100 --> 00:13:19.470
And they will display
the exam in front of you.

220
00:13:21.150 --> 00:13:25.280
It's at that point in time
when the clock will start.

221
00:13:25.280 --> 00:13:29.030
Now you know that you've got 60 questions.

222
00:13:29.030 --> 00:13:31.670
You've got an hour to
answer every question.

223
00:13:31.670 --> 00:13:34.220
And you have to get 33 right.

224
00:13:34.220 --> 00:13:36.000
In order to pass.

225
00:13:36.000 --> 00:13:40.240
It's closed book but to be perfectly
honest that is actually quite fortuitous.

226
00:13:40.240 --> 00:13:46.720
Because, let's face it,
60 questions in 60 minutes.

227
00:13:46.720 --> 00:13:48.870
That's a minute per question,

228
00:13:48.870 --> 00:13:51.805
you're not going to have time to be
thumbing through a book in that time.

229
00:13:51.805 --> 00:13:56.670
Answer with your gut instinct, remember
the acronym I gave you during one of

230
00:13:56.670 --> 00:14:06.139
the episodes, a couple of the episodes
RTFQ, right, read the full question.

231
00:14:06.139 --> 00:14:11.590
Don't answer what you think is being
asked, answer what is being asked of you.

232
00:14:13.010 --> 00:14:17.160
Don't try and interpret
a question read it word for word,

233
00:14:17.160 --> 00:14:19.830
read the full thing, read the full answer.

234
00:14:19.830 --> 00:14:24.090
And answer what is being asked not
what you think is being asked.

235
00:14:25.350 --> 00:14:27.850
You don't have to answer them
in chronological order, right?

236
00:14:27.850 --> 00:14:28.790
Or numerical order.

237
00:14:28.790 --> 00:14:31.660
You don't have to go one through to 60.

238
00:14:31.660 --> 00:14:35.290
You don't have to do that but
what you could do is you could say.

239
00:14:35.290 --> 00:14:39.030
Well you know what I don't know number
one offhand I'll skip that one.

240
00:14:39.030 --> 00:14:41.000
I don't know number two,
I'm gonna skip that one.

241
00:14:41.000 --> 00:14:42.610
I don't know number three.

242
00:14:42.610 --> 00:14:48.730
And go through until you find one that
you do know and then start from there.

243
00:14:48.730 --> 00:14:50.240
It's perfectly acceptable.

244
00:14:50.240 --> 00:14:52.210
It'll get you in the right frame of mind.

245
00:14:52.210 --> 00:14:56.130
Just remember that you do have to go
back and you won't have a pen and paper.

246
00:14:56.130 --> 00:14:59.180
To be able to make note of
the ones that you skipped.

247
00:14:59.180 --> 00:15:03.790
So it's really important to
ensure at the end of the test

248
00:15:03.790 --> 00:15:06.870
that you have answered
every single question.

249
00:15:06.870 --> 00:15:10.460
You don't get any negative marks for
getting one wrong, but

250
00:15:10.460 --> 00:15:15.930
obviously, if you don't answer one, then
you're not gonna get it right, are you?

251
00:15:15.930 --> 00:15:21.720
So, once you have finished, answering your
paper, once you finished with everything,

252
00:15:21.720 --> 00:15:26.300
then at that point in time, you click on
submit in the bottom right hand corner.

253
00:15:26.300 --> 00:15:30.100
That's when the invigilator
will come back on line.

254
00:15:30.100 --> 00:15:33.160
You won't believe it, but they have
been there, watching it the whole time.

255
00:15:33.160 --> 00:15:35.700
They will come back on line and
they would say, are you sure,

256
00:15:35.700 --> 00:15:38.180
that you definitely want
to submit your text?

257
00:15:39.320 --> 00:15:39.905
And you say.

258
00:15:39.905 --> 00:15:41.830
Yes.

259
00:15:41.830 --> 00:15:45.640
And at that point in time then there
will be a few minute delay, but

260
00:15:45.640 --> 00:15:48.320
at that point in time
the screen will disappear.

261
00:15:48.320 --> 00:15:53.310
And after a couple of minutes or so you
will get, the invigilator will lead you.

262
00:15:53.310 --> 00:15:54.920
And then you will get,

263
00:15:54.920 --> 00:15:58.500
on that particular screen it will tell
you whether you have passed or failed.

264
00:15:58.500 --> 00:16:03.950
That is a preliminary result,
it is not your definitive result.

265
00:16:03.950 --> 00:16:05.700
It is not your certificate.

266
00:16:05.700 --> 00:16:07.930
It's just the preliminary result.

267
00:16:07.930 --> 00:16:10.550
It's just going to tell you
whether you passed or failed.

268
00:16:10.550 --> 00:16:11.840
So you don't know how many you've got.

269
00:16:11.840 --> 00:16:14.200
But you know how well you got on.

270
00:16:15.480 --> 00:16:18.650
A couple of days later, it's usually
about three to four days later,

271
00:16:18.650 --> 00:16:20.360
you're gonna get an email.

272
00:16:20.360 --> 00:16:23.790
So make sure when you register that you
put the right email address in there.

273
00:16:23.790 --> 00:16:28.170
Because a few days later you're gonna get
an email telling you what your result was.

274
00:16:29.440 --> 00:16:35.780
That is your official confirmation that
you have either passed or failed, that.

275
00:16:35.780 --> 00:16:39.490
The preliminary result is not your
official confirmation because that

276
00:16:39.490 --> 00:16:45.680
preliminary result doesn't,
