well it hasn't been independently marked.

277
00:16:45.680 --> 00:16:49.600
It hasn't been looked at independently and

278
00:16:49.600 --> 00:16:55.990
that is just an automated response as
to the, what you've actually selected.

279
00:16:55.990 --> 00:16:58.260
So it has to be independently proctored.

280
00:16:58.260 --> 00:17:03.490
It has to be looked at again before
you actually are given your results

281
00:17:03.490 --> 00:17:05.910
I mentioned your email
address is really important.

282
00:17:05.910 --> 00:17:09.840
I would always recommend that you use
a personal email address and not your work

283
00:17:09.840 --> 00:17:13.200
email address because it's important
that it doesn't go to your junk file.

284
00:17:13.200 --> 00:17:17.810
You wouldn't believe how many people had
their exam results pass through to their

285
00:17:17.810 --> 00:17:21.410
junk file and then they've emailed me and
said I can't find my exam result.

286
00:17:21.410 --> 00:17:22.340
And I say well I've had it.

287
00:17:23.400 --> 00:17:27.590
And that reminds me, there are only two
people in the world that will actually

288
00:17:27.590 --> 00:17:33.690
know your test result, one is you and

289
00:17:33.690 --> 00:17:38.130
the other person is the person that
you listed as your instructor for

290
00:17:38.130 --> 00:17:41.920
your course,
which obviously happens to be me.

291
00:17:41.920 --> 00:17:44.340
So you will need to
make a note of my name.

292
00:17:44.340 --> 00:17:50.210
Because you have to have sat a class or
in this case a series.

293
00:17:50.210 --> 00:17:54.270
You have to have watched this
series with an accredited trainer.

294
00:17:54.270 --> 00:17:55.530
So you will need to use my name.

295
00:17:55.530 --> 00:17:59.170
And the only two people in the world who
get to find out what your results are you

296
00:17:59.170 --> 00:18:00.940
and me and that's it.

297
00:18:00.940 --> 00:18:01.840
Nobody else.

298
00:18:03.140 --> 00:18:06.520
And if your manager ever tries to contact
me to ask me what your results were?

299
00:18:06.520 --> 00:18:11.040
Trust me, with GDPR data protection,
no, we're not allowed to do that.

300
00:18:11.040 --> 00:18:14.850
And there's absolutely no way that
we would do that ethically, anyway.

301
00:18:14.850 --> 00:18:18.560
So really, you're the only
person that gets your result.

302
00:18:18.560 --> 00:18:21.980
You will get the certificate and
your certificate is downloadable,

303
00:18:21.980 --> 00:18:22.820
again, as PDF.

304
00:18:22.820 --> 00:18:26.370
And it will just simply
say that you have passed.

305
00:18:26.370 --> 00:18:32.850
They will not say what your result it's
just that you have been successful but

306
00:18:32.850 --> 00:18:36.820
then you have achieve this
particular qualification.

307
00:18:36.820 --> 00:18:43.800
So that's it really, that's your exam
that's what is going to be like.

308
00:18:44.830 --> 00:18:50.860
So, what we gonna do now, is I know
you've already sat your sample paper and

309
00:18:50.860 --> 00:18:53.270
in our next episode then
we gonna come back and

310
00:18:53.270 --> 00:18:58.420
we're gonna start to look over the sample
paper that you've already taken.

311
00:18:58.420 --> 00:19:03.330
And hopefully,
you will found it really, well.

312
00:19:03.330 --> 00:19:08.418
Reflective of what the subjects that
we've actually covered during our series.

313
00:19:08.418 --> 00:19:15.150
So come back into our part two and
we will see you for our exam review.

314
00:19:15.150 --> 00:19:19.882
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Jo reviews the Axelos PeopleCert sample exam and explores the justification of the exam answers.
episodes.title: Exam Review
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.646 --> 00:00:06.340
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.340 --> 00:00:11.565
Hi and welcome to our Part
1 of our exam review for

3
00:00:11.565 --> 00:00:16.928
our PRINCE2 2017 version Foundation Test.

4
00:00:16.928 --> 00:00:20.609
I'm Jo Peacock, I'm your host and
your guru I think,

5
00:00:20.609 --> 00:00:23.650
your guide through your sample paper,
and so

6
00:00:23.650 --> 00:00:28.820
hopefully by now you've had a change
to take a look at the sample paper.

7
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:33.140
And what we're going to do is we're going
to go through every single question,

8
00:00:33.140 --> 00:00:35.300
well one by one.

9
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:38.390
So let's get going then shall we,
and let's take a look and

10
00:00:38.390 --> 00:00:41.520
our first look at question number 1.

11
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:45.498
Which statement about controls is CORRECT?

12
00:00:45.498 --> 00:00:47.110
Well, let's take a look at them, shall we?

13
00:00:47.110 --> 00:00:51.840
A highlight report is
an event-driven report, is it?

14
00:00:51.840 --> 00:00:56.480
Actually no, a highlight report is,
well it's something

15
00:00:56.480 --> 00:01:01.140
that we produce on a regular basis, so
it's time-driven, not event-driven.

16
00:01:01.140 --> 00:01:03.550
Exception report is time driven?

17
00:01:03.550 --> 00:01:07.737
Well, no, we produce an exception
report when something has happened,

18
00:01:07.737 --> 00:01:10.651
an exception so, therefore,
it is event driven.

19
00:01:10.651 --> 00:01:11.990
And a daily log?

20
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:16.200
Well, if it's daily then that's suggests
to me that it is time driven, so,

21
00:01:16.200 --> 00:01:18.050
no, the answer here is D.

22
00:01:18.050 --> 00:01:21.745
A checkpoint report is
a time-driven control.

23
00:01:21.745 --> 00:01:26.416
Okay because checkpoints
happen at regular checkpoints

24
00:01:26.416 --> 00:01:30.119
at regular times throughout a stage, okay.

25
00:01:30.119 --> 00:01:34.904
So which document then,
moving on to number 2 is used to identify

26
00:01:34.904 --> 00:01:39.960
interested parties that need to be
informed of project disclosure?

27
00:01:42.460 --> 00:01:47.685
RTFQ, that's one of my favorite acronyms,
and it really applies in this one, okay.

28
00:01:47.685 --> 00:01:51.420
Which document is used to identify?

29
00:01:52.730 --> 00:01:57.690
This is not which document communicates,
it's asking you which document do

30
00:01:57.690 --> 00:02:03.500
we use to identify who we're
going to communicate to?

31
00:02:03.500 --> 00:02:08.551
Read the full question, and so which
document is gonna use to communicate?

32
00:02:08.551 --> 00:02:15.560
Well any project closure, well,
how do we identify those people?

33
00:02:15.560 --> 00:02:20.017
We identify those people in our
communication management approach.

34
00:02:20.017 --> 00:02:24.379
We certainly wouldn't identify who we're
going to talk to in a change control

35
00:02:24.379 --> 00:02:26.504
approach, not for project closure.

36
00:02:26.504 --> 00:02:31.128
And we certainly wouldn't identify who
we're going to communicate to in an end of

37
00:02:31.128 --> 00:02:33.120
project report.

38
00:02:33.120 --> 00:02:37.160
No, because there's an assumption
there that that report is going to be

39
00:02:37.160 --> 00:02:38.762
communicated to somebody.

40
00:02:38.762 --> 00:02:43.022
So that's not the right answer and D the
project brief yet again we should already

41
00:02:43.022 --> 00:02:47.469
know who we're gonna communicate to before
we've outlined the project brief, and

42
00:02:47.469 --> 00:02:50.860
that happens right at
the beginning of the project.

43
00:02:50.860 --> 00:02:56.058
So the answer there is C, so
what about number 3 then?

44
00:02:56.058 --> 00:03:00.200
Identify the missing words
in the following sentence.

45
00:03:01.790 --> 00:03:06.746
Any change to the products
agreed at the start of the stage

46
00:03:06.746 --> 00:03:11.711
is monitored as part of what
process on a day to day basis?

47
00:03:11.711 --> 00:03:16.870
So any change to products that
are agreed at the start of the stage,

48
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:20.330
is monitored as part of what process?

49
00:03:20.330 --> 00:03:24.215
Well, we know that controlling a stage,

50
00:03:24.215 --> 00:03:30.100
that process actually monitors
projects on a day to day basis.

51
00:03:30.100 --> 00:03:32.540
What about directing a project?

52
00:03:32.540 --> 00:03:36.322
Well, directing the project is very,
very high level.

53
00:03:36.322 --> 00:03:41.463
And that's the project board,
isn't it, that directed the project.

54
00:03:41.463 --> 00:03:46.320
So monitoring,
that's a little bit too detailed for them.

55
00:03:46.320 --> 00:03:51.100
Managing a state boundary, well that's
about looking at the end of one stage and

56
00:03:51.100 --> 00:03:53.405
then planning for the next stage.

57
00:03:53.405 --> 00:03:57.890
And that's not monitoring,
that's the authorization to proceed.

58
00:03:57.890 --> 00:04:02.601
And closing a project is when we say,
yes, the project is definitely closed and

59
00:04:02.601 --> 00:04:07.101
has met all the acceptance criteria and
the customer has signed off on it, so

60

of the management of the project?

522
00:32:20.670 --> 00:32:25.601
Yes, okay it is because again, it's about
project assurance, making sure that we

523
00:32:25.601 --> 00:32:30.120
can deliver what we are supposed
to deliver in terms of quality.

524
00:32:30.120 --> 00:32:32.460
Is it to control uncertainty?

525
00:32:32.460 --> 00:32:33.900
Definitely not.

526
00:32:33.900 --> 00:32:35.378
No, that's not quality.

527
00:32:35.378 --> 00:32:39.830
No, that would be down to risk
management controlling uncertainty.

528
00:32:40.840 --> 00:32:45.811
And is to establish mechanisms to
control any unacceptable deviation?

529
00:32:45.811 --> 00:32:50.090
No, the project manager will have to do
that as part of just managing the project,

530
00:32:50.090 --> 00:32:52.360
controlling the project itself.

531
00:32:52.360 --> 00:32:55.720
So the answer there is, B.

532
00:32:55.720 --> 00:33:00.690
Number 27 then, what is the purpose
of the business case theme?

533
00:33:00.690 --> 00:33:04.956
Well, the business case theme,
that purpose is to well,

534
00:33:04.956 --> 00:33:09.835
compile the business case which
means justification as to whether

535
00:33:09.835 --> 00:33:14.452
this project is going to deliver a return,
either financial or

536
00:33:14.452 --> 00:33:17.522
non-financial, to the organization.

537
00:33:17.522 --> 00:33:21.400
So, is it to establish mechanisms for
managing issues?

538
00:33:21.400 --> 00:33:22.680
Absolutely not.

539
00:33:22.680 --> 00:33:27.701
Is it to establish methods to judge
whether the ongoing project is justified?

540
00:33:27.701 --> 00:33:28.293
Yes.

541
00:33:28.293 --> 00:33:31.870
Does it assess and
control on certain events?

542
00:33:31.870 --> 00:33:33.040
No, definitely not.

543
00:33:33.040 --> 00:33:35.980
Does it describe how
products will be delivered?

544
00:33:37.150 --> 00:33:40.040
No, that sounds very much like a plan,
that doesn't sound like a business case.

545
00:33:40.040 --> 00:33:45.000
A business case is a justification for
a significant item of expenditure.

546
00:33:45.000 --> 00:33:48.237
So, of course, the answer to that is B.

547
00:33:48.237 --> 00:33:53.185
So which process then, number 28, provides
the project board with the information

548
00:33:53.185 --> 00:33:56.450
it requires in order to commit
resources to the project?

549
00:33:58.490 --> 00:33:59.166
Which process?

550
00:33:59.166 --> 00:34:01.450
Is it managing product delivery?

551
00:34:01.450 --> 00:34:03.718
If you're committing
resources to the project,

552
00:34:03.718 --> 00:34:05.503
it better be at the beginning, right?

553
00:34:05.503 --> 00:34:08.400
It's not gonna be halfway
through the project or

554
00:34:08.400 --> 00:34:10.812
once the project's been established.

555
00:34:10.812 --> 00:34:12.400
So it's not gonna be A.

556
00:34:13.460 --> 00:34:15.678
It's gonna be an initiating
a project surely.

557
00:34:15.678 --> 00:34:19.531
It's not gonna be in controlling
the stage because again,

558
00:34:19.531 --> 00:34:22.239
it should be done right to the beginning.

559
00:34:22.239 --> 00:34:25.992
And it's not going to be in
directing the project because,

560
00:34:25.992 --> 00:34:30.881
directing the project is that, well
that one's owned by the project board.

561
00:34:30.881 --> 00:34:34.908
And it's asking here, which process
provides the project board with

562
00:34:34.908 --> 00:34:38.680
the information it needs to
essentially direct a project?

563
00:34:38.680 --> 00:34:42.220
So it's going to be initiating
the project that's going to do that.

564
00:34:42.220 --> 00:34:44.908
Because basically you're asking for

565
00:34:44.908 --> 00:34:49.590
which process provides information
to directing a project.

566
00:34:49.590 --> 00:34:51.404
Well, so it's not gonna be D, is it?

567
00:34:51.404 --> 00:34:52.720
It's actually going to be B.

568
00:34:52.720 --> 00:35:00.520
And number 29, which two statements
describe a highlight report?

569
00:35:00.520 --> 00:35:05.340
A highlight report is, well,
where are we right now?

570
00:35:05.340 --> 00:35:06.160
How are we doing?

571
00:35:06.160 --> 00:35:09.790
So, does it provide a summary
of the stage status?

572
00:35:09.790 --> 00:35:11.141
Yes, it does.

573
00:35:11.141 --> 00:35:14.900
Is it used by the project board to
monitor the progress of the stage?

574
00:35:14.900 --> 00:35:17.030
Yes, it is.

575
00:35:17.030 --> 00:35:18.416
So that's number 1 and 2.

576
00:35:18.416 --> 00:35:23.380
So I'm erring towards A, but let me
just check the others just to make sure.

577
00:35:23.380 --> 00:35:26.320
Is it produced by the project manager
when a new risk is identified?

578
00:35:26.320 --> 00:35:28.336
No, that's a risk register.

579
00:35:28.336 --> 00:35:32.102
And is it used by the project manager
to escalate with the exception?

580
00:35:32.102 --> 00:35:33.900
No, of course not.

581
00:35:33.900 --> 00:35:38.080
The highlight report is a highlight of
the actual progress of the project.

582
00:35:38.080 --> 00:35:41.960
So the answer there is A, 1 and 2.

583
00:35:41.960 --> 00:35:43.594
And so now, question number 30.

584
00:35:43.594 --> 00:35:46.242
Which is gonna be the last question for

585
00:35:46.242 --> 00:35:52.030
this particular episode cuz we're
halfway through this particular test.

586
00:35:52.030 --> 00:35:54.459
And so,
we're gonna come back in episode two and

587
00:35:54.459 --> 00:35:58.440
we're gonna take a look at questions
31 through through the questions 60.

588
00:35:58.440 --> 00:36:00.803
So let's take a look at number 30 then.

589
00:36:00.803 --> 00:36:06.980
Which product provides the version number
of all products in a particular stage?

590
00:36:08.200 --> 00:36:10.008
Which product?
I don't like the wording of that,

591
00:36:10.008 --> 00:36:11.830
it does sound a little bit clumsy.

592
00:36:11.830 --> 00:36:17.010
You could say, well, which document or
which activity, for instance,

593
00:36:17.010 --> 00:36:22.620
but it's definitely a document,
which is why they're saying about product.

594
00:36:22.620 --> 00:36:26.330
Which provides the version
number of all products?

595
00:36:26.330 --> 00:36:27.928
Is it gonna be an issue register?

596
00:36:27.928 --> 00:36:31.040
No, because this is not
necessarily an issue.

597
00:36:31.040 --> 00:36:32.610
Is it a product status account?

598
00:36:32.610 --> 00:36:33.217
Yes.

599
00:36:33.217 --> 00:36:35.910
Is it the description?

600
00:36:37.080 --> 00:36:39.288
No, because that's not gonna
give a version number,

601
00:36:39.288 --> 00:36:41.498
that's just gonna give
a description of the product.

602
00:36:41.498 --> 00:36:45.730
What you're talking about in version
numbers, you're talking about attributes.

603
00:36:45.730 --> 00:36:48.720
And so the attribute is gonna
be listed in the status account.

604
00:36:48.720 --> 00:36:51.950
And is it the CI record?

605
00:36:54.010 --> 00:36:58.818
No, it's not necessarily the CI
record because the CI record

606
00:36:58.818 --> 00:37:01.971
will just list the attributes of one CI.

607
00:37:01.971 --> 00:37:09.110
That is an individual CI record,
be very careful on this one.

608
00:37:09.110 --> 00:37:11.641
And this is the last question for
this particular episode and

609
00:37:11.641 --> 00:37:13.040
we'll be back in a little while.

610
00:37:13.040 --> 00:37:14.940
Be really careful.

611
00:37:14.940 --> 00:37:18.271
Remember to RTFQ, read the full question.

612
00:37:18.271 --> 00:37:23.260
Which product provides the version
number of all products?

613
00:37:23.260 --> 00:37:25.630
The CI record would be right.

614
00:37:25.630 --> 00:37:30.333
If we were just talking about one product,
but we're not,

615
00:37:30.333 --> 00:37:33.260
we're talking about all products.

616
00:37:33.260 --> 00:37:37.112
And so that would be in
the product status account.

617
00:37:37.112 --> 00:37:40.463
Now, I know that in previous episodes,

618
00:37:40.463 --> 00:37:46.470
I have referred you through to
the ITIL series that we have done.

619
00:37:46.470 --> 00:37:51.285
I would recommend that if you
are confused about status accounting and

620
00:37:51.285 --> 00:37:55.447
if you are confused about the CI records,
for instance, and

621
00:37:55.447 --> 00:38:00.930
configuration management, I would
recommend that you go to your ITIL series.

622
00:38:00.930 --> 00:38:06.458
You have access to that, it's under the
ops and project management, operations and

623
00:38:06.458 --> 00:38:11.470
project management in the course library,
and go into service transition.

624
00:38:11.470 --> 00:38:16.236
And within service transition,
there is an episode on Service Asset and

625
00:38:16.236 --> 00:38:21.313
Configuration Management or SACM,
take a look at that episode and there will

626
00:38:21.313 --> 00:38:26.572
be much more of an in depth description
on asset and configuration management.

627
00:38:26.572 --> 00:38:31.039
So, CIs configuration items and
status accounting and

628
00:38:31.039 --> 00:38:35.120
also the configuration
management database.

629
00:38:35.120 --> 00:38:39.643
So if you are confused,
then go to that particular episode.

630
00:38:39.643 --> 00:38:42.610
So we've looked at questions
1 through questions 30.

631
00:38:42.610 --> 00:38:45.476
And as you've seen, we had a little
bit of talk at the beginning,

632
00:38:45.476 --> 00:38:47.210
so we've just gone over 30 minutes.

633
00:38:47.210 --> 00:38:52.220
So you'll see that you still can
analyze each question, but you're not

634
00:38:52.220 --> 00:38:58.180
going to have time to sit there and
put your feet up and twiddle your thumbs.

635
00:38:58.180 --> 00:39:02.092
So what I'm gonna do for now, we're
gonna take a little bit of a break and

636
00:39:02.092 --> 00:39:04.403
then when we come back
in our next episode,

637
00:39:04.403 --> 00:39:08.146
we're gonna take a look at questions
31 through to question 60.

638
00:39:08.146 --> 00:39:11.746
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Jo reviews the Axelos PeopleCert sample exam and explores the justification of the exam answers.
episodes.title: Exam Review Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.681
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.681 --> 00:00:08.614
Hi, and welcome to Episode 2.

3
00:00:08.614 --> 00:00:17.330
This is a part 2 of your Prince
2 2017 Foundation sample paper.

4
00:00:17.330 --> 00:00:23.790
So in part 1, we took a look at questions
1 through 30, and here we are in part 2,

5
00:00:23.790 --> 00:00:28.665
and we're gonna take a look at
questions 30 through to questions 60.

6
00:00:28.665 --> 00:00:32.995
And as ever, I am Jo Peacock,
I am here as your guru and

7
00:00:32.995 --> 00:00:35.495
your guide through these
last 30 questions.

8
00:00:35.495 --> 00:00:38.345
So lets jump straight in,
cuz you know what?

9
00:00:38.345 --> 00:00:40.730
We're under a time pressure here,
aren't we?

10
00:00:40.730 --> 00:00:43.960
We've only got an hour and
we've got 60 questions to do.

11
00:00:43.960 --> 00:00:46.411
So let's take a look then at number 31.

12
00:00:46.411 --> 00:00:50.327
And this is another one of these ones I,
I always like these multiple choice

13
00:00:50.327 --> 00:00:54.910
ones because you can simply just put that
tick and that cross next to each answer.

14
00:00:54.910 --> 00:00:59.820
So number 31, which two statements
about the risk theme are correct?

15
00:00:59.820 --> 00:01:05.050
So does risk identify how to manage
risk at corporate program management or

16
00:01:05.050 --> 00:01:06.990
customer level of an organization?

17
00:01:08.390 --> 00:01:09.130
Does it?

18
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:09.940
Yes, it does.

19
00:01:09.940 --> 00:01:15.320
It identifies how to manage risks
at program management, yeah.

20
00:01:15.320 --> 00:01:19.325
Does risk management aim to
support better decision making

21
00:01:19.325 --> 00:01:22.610
through good understanding of
the threats and opportunities?

22
00:01:22.610 --> 00:01:24.613
Yes, it does.

23
00:01:24.613 --> 00:01:27.334
But we're talking about
the risk theme here,

24
00:01:27.334 --> 00:01:29.854
not about risk management in particular.

25
00:01:29.854 --> 00:01:32.840
Does it explain risk management activity?

26
00:01:32.840 --> 00:01:36.530
No, no, no, of course not,
because the risk

27
00:01:36.530 --> 00:01:41.610
being is not about explaining explicit
activities for risk management.

28
00:01:41.610 --> 00:01:47.680
It's about cutting a method to
identify risk into managers.

29
00:01:47.680 --> 00:01:51.760
Specific activities, that's part
of the individual risk management.

30
00:01:51.760 --> 00:01:56.684
Does it identify, assess and
controls approved changes to that?

31
00:01:56.684 --> 00:01:58.920
No, that's change control.

32
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:01.810
No, risk management doesn't identify or
assess, or

33
00:02:01.810 --> 00:02:03.960
control changes to the baseline.

34
00:02:03.960 --> 00:02:06.540
So the answer here is
most definitely 1 and 2.

35
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:10.360
So what about number 32 then?

36
00:02:10.360 --> 00:02:14.340
What must be recorded in project
initiation documentation to meet

37
00:02:14.340 --> 00:02:18.160
the minimum requirements for
applying the progress theme?

38
00:02:18.160 --> 00:02:21.460
That is about identifying
how we’re going to progress.

39
00:02:21.460 --> 00:02:25.010
So do we need an overall approach
to managing by exception?

40
00:02:25.010 --> 00:02:25.580
Yes, we do.

41
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:30.890
And this is in that PID,
that Project Initiation Documentation.

42
00:02:30.890 --> 00:02:34.610
Do we need to have the tailoring
required for progress reports?

43
00:02:35.960 --> 00:02:40.870
Yes, we do, but not part of the progress
theme, cuz that's too specific.

44
00:02:40.870 --> 00:02:44.779
Remember, our themes
are our overall approaches.

45
00:02:44.779 --> 00:02:53.500
They have to be overarching thought
processes rather than detailed tailoring.

46
00:02:53.500 --> 00:02:57.330
Does it include the tolerance
areas that will not be controlled?

47
00:02:57.330 --> 00:03:02.160
No, we wanna control all tolerance,
so that doesn’t make any sense.

48
00:03:02.160 --> 00:03:05.600
Does it detail the levels of
management control that will be used?

49
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:07.290
What, in the progress thing?

50
00:03:07.290 --> 00:03:08.240
No, it doesn’t.

51
00:03:08.240 --> 00:03:11.650
Again, that’s part of
the individual project management.

52
00:03:11.650 --> 00:03:15.055
So the answer to that is,
an overall approach.

53
00:03:15.055 --> 00:03:18.280
That's the most, remember,
this is very high-level, and

54
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:21.950
that's the most high-level answer
that's actually appropriate.

55
00:03:23.030 --> 00:03:25.970
So which theme establishes
mechanisms to monitor and

56
00:03:25.970 --> 00:03:29.540
compare actual achievements
against those plans.

57
00:03:29.540 --> 00:03:31.900
Well again, that's progress.

58
00:03:31.900 --> 00:03:35.910
Now, one thing that I do want to tell you
here, though, and I wanna point this out.

59
00:03:35.910 --> 00:03:39.280
We've had a couple of instances in
our last episode and in this one,

60
00:03:39.280 --> 00:03:43.070
where we've had questions that
have been grouped together.

61
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:46.180
That is not usually the case, okay?

62
00:03:47.360 --> 00:03:50.628
I cannot guarantee that you're gonna have
questions that are grouped together, or

63
00:03:50.628 --> 00:03:53.170
you're not gonna have questions
that are not grouped together.

64
00:03:53.170 --> 00:03:55.164
I can't guarantee one way or

65
00:03:55.164 --> 00:04:01.110
the other cuz the questions are randomly
selected, so don't rely on that.

66
00:04:01.110 --> 00:04:05.097
Now, in this particular test,
we don't necessarily have the time to read

67
00:04:05.097 --> 00:04:08.536
through all of the questions first,
so be incredibly careful.

68
00:04:08.536 --> 00:04:12.918
If you don't know one, immediately, time
is of the essence, move on to the next one

69
00:04:12.918 --> 00:04:16.994
because there maybe a question a little
bit later on, this'll do with the same

70
00:04:16.994 --> 00:04:21.050
theme or the same topic, and that might
help you answer that other question.

71
00:04:22.540 --> 00:04:25.632
So number 34 then,
which role is responsible for

72
00:04:25.632 --> 00:04:28.580
management of risk assigned to it?

73
00:04:28.580 --> 00:04:30.320
Well, that's the owner.

74
00:04:31.420 --> 00:04:33.280
It's not the actionee.

75
00:04:34.470 --> 00:04:38.420
It's the owner, the owner is responsible.

76
00:04:38.420 --> 00:04:42.490
The actionee might actually help
with some of the actions, but

77
00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:46.050
who's responsible for
the management of the risk?

78
00:04:47.180 --> 00:04:49.168
That's the risk owner.

79
00:04:49.168 --> 00:04:53.640
Again, I'm gonna use my acronym,
read the full question, okay,

80
00:04:53.640 --> 00:04:56.380
because that's going
to help you with that.

81
00:04:56.380 --> 00:04:59.236
If you misread the question or
you answer the one,

82
00:04:59.236 --> 00:05:03.459
the question that you think is being
asked, then you're gonna go with C.

83
00:05:03.459 --> 00:05:04.550
Be careful.

84
00:05:05.930 --> 00:05:08.580
What's a responsibility
of the change authority?

85
00:05:08.580 --> 00:05:13.870
Well, we know that the change authority
approves change and that the larger

86
00:05:13.870 --> 00:05:19.090
the scale of the change or the higher the
impact of the change, we know that, well,

87
00:05:20.240 --> 00:05:26.290
we know that that will be a higher level
of authority of proving that change.

88
00:05:26.290 --> 00:05:28.430
So let me take a look there,

89
00:05:28.430 --> 00:05:31.630
is it to ensure that an acceptable
solution is being developed?

90
00:05:33.140 --> 00:05:35.190
No, because that's very technical, and

91
00:05:35.190 --> 00:05:38.460
I don't expect the change
authority to do that.

92
00:05:38.460 --> 00:05:39.970
To prepare a team plan?

93
00:05:39.970 --> 00:05:44.550
No, that's not part of the change
authority, they're to approve changes.

94
00:05:44.550 --> 00:05:49.490
To maintain project files according
to document control procedures?

95
00:05:49.490 --> 00:05:52.540
No, they're not maintaining project files.

96
00:05:52.540 --> 00:05:55.980
This is a change authority to
somebody who approves change, so

97
00:05:55.980 --> 00:06:00.120
their job is therefore to approve or
reject requests for change.

98
00:06:01.930 --> 00:06:04.020
So what about number 36 there?

99
00:06:04.020 --> 00:06:09.400
Number 36 says, what does applying
managements by stages principle,

100
00:06:09.400 --> 00:06:11.640
what does that ensure?

101
00:06:11.640 --> 00:06:16.140
Does it ensure that the customer's quality
expectations are captured and agreed?

102
00:06:17.200 --> 00:06:18.865
That's not part of managing by stages.

103
00:06:20.120 --> 00:06:25.030
Does it ensure that the project is
properly initiated before work begins?

104
00:06:25.030 --> 00:06:30.632
Well, yes, because that's one of the first
stages, is initiating the project, okay?

105
00:06:30.632 --> 00:06:33.084
So what about C then?

106
00:06:33.084 --> 00:06:37.230
Does it ensure that project management
understands what they're accountable for?

107
00:06:37.230 --> 00:06:41.715
No, that's the RACI matrix,
that's not part of managing the stage,

108
00:06:41.715 --> 00:06:44.277
that's part of directing the project.

109
00:06:44.277 --> 00:06:48.285
And does it ensure that
the project is only started and

110
00:06:48.285 --> 00:06:53.040
continued if it's desirable,
viable, and achievable?

111
00:06:53.040 --> 00:06:57.760
Well, that's actually part of ensuring
the business justification for

112
00:06:57.760 --> 00:07:01.910
the project, and
it's part of the project board.

113
00:07:01.910 --> 00:07:05.640
They will ensure that that is continued.

114
00:07:05.640 --> 00:07:11.030
So the answer there is B,
the project is properly initiated.

115
00:07:11.030 --> 00:07:15.030
So number 37 then, identify the missing
word in the following sentence.

116
00:07:15.030 --> 00:07:18.324
A management stage can
be longer when risk is?

117
00:07:18.324 --> 00:07:22.990

actions to resolve

00:20:59.050 --> 00:21:02.690
tolerance deviations from the stage plan?

353
00:21:02.690 --> 00:21:07.340
No, that sounds like something
the project manager would impress

354
00:21:07.340 --> 00:21:09.060
from the project board.

355
00:21:09.060 --> 00:21:12.315
It doesn't sound like something that
would happen as part of managing a stage

356
00:21:12.315 --> 00:21:14.780
boudary, that could happen at any time.

357
00:21:14.780 --> 00:21:16.200
So of course the answer is A.

358
00:21:16.200 --> 00:21:23.290
51 then, in which process is authorization
given to deliver the project's product?

359
00:21:24.410 --> 00:21:26.430
Is it starting up?

360
00:21:26.430 --> 00:21:27.630
Is it initiating?

361
00:21:27.630 --> 00:21:30.970
Is it managing a boundary or
is it directing a project?

362
00:21:30.970 --> 00:21:35.925
Well we know that directing a project
is performed by a project board and

363
00:21:35.925 --> 00:21:40.810
they will give the authorization
to actually deliver the products.

364
00:21:40.810 --> 00:21:43.010
Not the project manager.

365
00:21:43.010 --> 00:21:46.546
They don't give the authorization
to deliver the project or

366
00:21:46.546 --> 00:21:47.872
deliver the product.

367
00:21:47.872 --> 00:21:51.437
It's done by the project board,
so it is D.

368
00:21:51.437 --> 00:21:54.605
And number 52 then,
what's a minimum requirement for

369
00:21:54.605 --> 00:21:57.130
applying the business case theme?

370
00:21:57.130 --> 00:22:01.830
Should we be documenting the
responsibility for defining standards for

371
00:22:01.830 --> 00:22:03.450
the business case?

372
00:22:03.450 --> 00:22:04.930
Yes, we should.

373
00:22:04.930 --> 00:22:07.500
We need to know what's gonna
be in our business case.

374
00:22:07.500 --> 00:22:11.230
And I've already mentioned
that we should have templates.

375
00:22:11.230 --> 00:22:14.180
And I mentioned this in previous episodes,
we want efficiency,

376
00:22:14.180 --> 00:22:19.110
so we should have templates, so
that there should be minimum standards.

377
00:22:19.110 --> 00:22:22.800
Do we want to appoint a senior user
from an area of the business impacted

378
00:22:22.800 --> 00:22:23.610
by the project?

379
00:22:23.610 --> 00:22:25.680
Is that a minimum requirement?

380
00:22:25.680 --> 00:22:29.660
It's probably not a bad idea but
it's not a minimum requirement.

381
00:22:29.660 --> 00:22:34.470
Do we wanna have a benefits management
approach approved by participants of

382
00:22:34.470 --> 00:22:36.600
the benefits reviews?

383
00:22:38.130 --> 00:22:39.250
Let me repeat that again.

384
00:22:39.250 --> 00:22:42.510
Do we want to have a benefits
management approach

385
00:22:42.510 --> 00:22:45.570
approved by participants
of benefits reviews?

386
00:22:47.260 --> 00:22:50.010
Is that part of the business case?

387
00:22:50.010 --> 00:22:51.540
No, definitely not.

388
00:22:51.540 --> 00:22:55.700
That's part of benefits approach,
benefits management.

389
00:22:55.700 --> 00:22:56.400
What about D then,

390
00:22:56.400 --> 00:23:00.250
delegating the development of business
justification to the project manager?

391
00:23:00.250 --> 00:23:02.210
Is that a minimum requirement?

392
00:23:02.210 --> 00:23:03.930
No.
It's something that could be done but

393
00:23:03.930 --> 00:23:06.480
it's not a minimum requirement.

394
00:23:06.480 --> 00:23:08.900
What about the project
initiation documentation,

395
00:23:08.900 --> 00:23:12.560
how is it used during
the closing of a project?

396
00:23:12.560 --> 00:23:15.140
Well, I would say as a comparison,
isn't it,

397
00:23:15.140 --> 00:23:19.680
between this is what we wanted to do and
have we done it?

398
00:23:19.680 --> 00:23:22.520
So, A looks good,
it's used as the basis for

399
00:23:22.520 --> 00:23:25.610
comparing the original aim to
what was actually achieved.

400
00:23:26.930 --> 00:23:29.580
Providing controls for
the final stage of the project?

401
00:23:29.580 --> 00:23:30.640
No, definitely not.

402
00:23:30.640 --> 00:23:33.010
This is an initiation documentation.

403
00:23:33.010 --> 00:23:38.060
And what about, is it updated to include
relevant lessons from previous projects?

404
00:23:40.020 --> 00:23:41.532
Well, it might be
throughout the project but

405
00:23:41.532 --> 00:23:43.960
it's [LAUGH] certainly not during
the closing the project process.

406
00:23:44.960 --> 00:23:47.570
Does it provide the project
product description for

407
00:23:47.570 --> 00:23:51.230
approval by the project board that's
right at the beginning of the project?

408
00:23:51.230 --> 00:23:54.100
So no, it's definitely A.

409
00:23:54.100 --> 00:23:55.254
Common sense approach here.

410
00:23:55.254 --> 00:23:59.596
So number 54 then,
which process aims to ensure that during

411
00:23:59.596 --> 00:24:04.029
the project all parties understands
The project objectives.

412
00:24:04.029 --> 00:24:09.550
Right, during the project,
all project and all parties understand.

413
00:24:09.550 --> 00:24:13.620
Well that's part of then initiating
the project, cuz it's about

414
00:24:14.760 --> 00:24:20.540
going through the project and setting
up a stakeholder communication plan.

415
00:24:20.540 --> 00:24:22.660
That's what we should be doing here.

416
00:24:22.660 --> 00:24:28.140
During, and in fact, I was trying to get
that during C, initiating a project.

417
00:24:29.780 --> 00:24:32.745
Managing a stage boundary,
when do we undertake that?

418
00:24:32.745 --> 00:24:36.083
Well, close to the end of
every single management stage,

419
00:24:36.083 --> 00:24:39.020
cuz it gives us the authority
to move on to the next.

420
00:24:40.090 --> 00:24:44.810
So, the only answer to that
one that makes any sense is A.

421
00:24:44.810 --> 00:24:47.240
It's at the end of every management stage.

422
00:24:48.630 --> 00:24:49.753
So number 56 then.

423
00:24:49.753 --> 00:24:52.249
What is a project outcome?

424
00:24:52.249 --> 00:24:56.730
Well a project outcome is
what we are delivering.

425
00:24:56.730 --> 00:24:59.730
So it's the outcome that the user,

426
00:24:59.730 --> 00:25:05.360
the customer sees as a result
of using the project's outputs.

427
00:25:05.360 --> 00:25:06.876
So, is it A then?

428
00:25:06.876 --> 00:25:10.620
A measurable improvement that is
perceived as an advantage by one or

429
00:25:10.620 --> 00:25:12.070
more stakeholders.

430
00:25:12.070 --> 00:25:14.870
No, because it's not one or
more stakeholders,

431
00:25:14.870 --> 00:25:17.410
we're talking about our customs here.

432
00:25:17.410 --> 00:25:20.460
Is the outcome the reason for the project?

433
00:25:20.460 --> 00:25:21.900
No the outcome is what you achieve

434
00:25:23.070 --> 00:25:26.170

delivered by the project.

435
00:25:26.170 --> 00:25:30.220
So is it the results have changed
derived from using the project's output?

436
00:25:30.220 --> 00:25:31.860
Yes, it is.

437
00:25:31.860 --> 00:25:34.690
It's certainly not a specialist product.

438
00:25:34.690 --> 00:25:39.887
A product is different from an outcome,
so it is C.

439
00:25:39.887 --> 00:25:42.140
And what about number 57 then?

440
00:25:42.140 --> 00:25:45.870

00:25:45.870 --> 00:25:51.276
Six aspects of project

00:25:51.276 --> 00:25:55.043
[SOUND] cost and time scales and scope.

So what else do we want to manage then?

444
00:25:57.660 --> 00:26:02.367
Well we want to manage benefits,
we want to manage quality, and

445
00:26:02.367 --> 00:26:04.121

446
00:26:04.121 --> 00:26:08.074
These are something that you're going

447
00:26:08.074 --> 00:26:11.400

to identify these, okay?

448
00:26:11.400 --> 00:26:13.390
And the answer to this one is B.

449
00:26:13.390 --> 00:26:16.810
It is benefits and quality and risk.

450
00:26:16.810 --> 00:26:19.273
These are six aspects
of project performance.

451
00:26:19.273 --> 00:26:23.647
We covered that way back in one of
our very, very earlier episodes, so

452
00:26:23.647 --> 00:26:27.220

00:26:27.220 --> 00:26:32.430
Sometimes the easiest ones are the ones

00:26:32.430 --> 00:26:33.260

455
00:26:34.560 --> 00:26:36.356
So question number 58 then,

456
00:26:36.356 --> 00:26:40.789

project consist of, as a minimum?

457
00:26:40.789 --> 00:26:44.540
We know we need to have at

00:26:44.540 --> 00:26:47.100
So we need to have an initiation stage,
and

459
00:26:47.100 --> 00:26:51.800

stage that covers the rest of the project.

460
00:26:51.800 --> 00:26:53.740
So, we know we need at least two.

461
00:26:55.082 --> 00:27:00.540
So and number A says, starting up
initiation and at least one other.

462
00:27:00.540 --> 00:27:01.780
No, well that makes it three.

463
00:27:01.780 --> 00:27:02.825
So that's not right.

464
00:27:02.825 --> 00:27:07.320
B says, at least one stage for
developing and the closing stage.

465
00:27:07.320 --> 00:27:08.450
Well what about startup?

466
00:27:08.450 --> 00:27:10.650
We need an initiation.

467
00:27:10.650 --> 00:27:13.632
C says initiation in at
least one other stage.

468
00:27:13.632 --> 00:27:15.480
Okay, that's right.

469
00:27:15.480 --> 00:27:20.590
D says initiation and at least one stage
for developing and the closing stage.

470
00:27:20.590 --> 00:27:22.700
No you can combine developing stage and

471
00:27:22.700 --> 00:27:26.000

472
00:27:27.390 --> 00:27:30.750
Which statement about project

00:27:30.750 --> 00:27:35.950
A stakeholder is anybody who is

00:27:39.400 --> 00:27:41.075

Cuz quite often you can't

477
00:27:44.240 --> 00:27:47.940
Sometimes they just keep sort of

478
00:27:47.940 --> 00:27:49.150
So, it's not A.

479
00:27:49.150 --> 00:27:49.788
What about B?

00:27:49.788 --> 00:27:52.570
Are all stakeholders members

481
00:27:52.570 --> 00:27:55.070
Can you imagine the size

if that were the case.

483
00:27:57.860 --> 00:28:01.100
No, are all stakeholders external?

484
00:28:01.100 --> 00:28:02.981
No, definitely not.

485
00:28:02.981 --> 00:28:06.888
All three principal categories of
stakeholder have their interest

486
00:28:06.888 --> 00:28:09.080
represented by the project board.

487
00:28:09.080 --> 00:28:15.360
That's right, that's the users, the
suppliers, and the project team itself.

488
00:28:15.360 --> 00:28:19.759
So, three principle categories of
stakeholder, and that's right.

489
00:28:19.759 --> 00:28:22.474
So the answer there is D.

490
00:28:22.474 --> 00:28:26.004
And now our last question then,
on this sample paper,

00:28:26.004 --> 00:28:29.170

00:28:29.170 --> 00:28:32.650
Well, it's at the beginning
of the project, and

00:28:32.650 --> 00:28:36.420
the project mandate is our terms

494
00:28:36.420 --> 00:28:38.570
So the answer there is A.

495
00:28:38.570 --> 00:28:44.810
It's not a detailed business case, this
is just the mandate to start a project.

496
00:28:44.810 --> 00:28:49.080
It's not specific tolerances, and
it's not a plan for the initiation stage,

497
00:28:49.080 --> 00:28:52.490

a mandate.

498
00:28:52.490 --> 00:28:54.460
So the answer there is A.
